1-8-1: OFFICERS ENUMERATED:
The officers of the Village shall consist of the following:
   A.   Elective Officers:
Village President
Board of Trustees
Village Clerk
   B.   Appointive Officers:
Village Manager
Village Attorney
Village Treasurer
Director of Administrative Services
Director of Community Development
Director of Engineering (“Village Engineer”)
Director of Finance
Director of Fire and Emergency Medical Services
Director of Law Enforcement Services
Director of Municipal Services
Director of Recreation
Director of Technology
Coordinator, Emergency Management Agency (EMA)
and such other officers as the President and Board of Trustees may deem
expedient. Officers can fill one or more positions. (Ord. 82-1615, 2-16-1982;
amd. Ord. 94-1891, 3-28-1994; 1997 Code; Ord. 98-2064, 12-21-1998; Ord. 20-
3007, 6-22-2020)
1-8-2: ELECTIVE OFFICERS:
The President, the members of the Board of Trustees and the Village Clerk shall
be elected in the manner and for the respective terms provided by law. (Ord.
82-1615, 2-16-1982)
1-8-3: APPOINTIVE OFFICERS:
All appointive officers of the Village, except as otherwise provided by this
Code, shall be appointed by the Village Manager with the approval of the
President and Board of Trustees. Terms of such appointive office shall begin at
the date of approval by the Village Board, and the office shall be held until
the appointive officer dies, becomes disabled, resigns, is dismissed from the
position by the Village Manager, or until his or her successor is appointed by
the Village Manager. No employment contract is established or intended by any
such appointment and such officers serve at the pleasure of the appointing
authority (i.e. the Village Manager or the Board). (Ord. 94-1891, 3-28-1994;
amd. 1997 Code; Ord. 20-3007, 6-22-2020)
1-8-4: OATH OF OFFICE:
All officers, whether elected or appointed, shall, before entering upon the
duties of their respective offices, take and subscribe to the following oath or
affirmation:
I do solemnly swear (or affirm, as the case may be) that I will support the
Constitution of the United States, the Constitution of the State of Illinois,
and the Municipal Code of the Village of Western Springs and that I will
faithfully discharge the duties of the office of                       
according to the best of my ability.
which oath or affirmation so subscribed shall be filed in the office of the
Village Clerk. (Ord. 82-1615, 2-16-1982; amd. 1997 Code)
1-8-5: BONDS:
   A.   Bonds Required; Filing: Except as otherwise provided by ordinance, all
Village officers, other than a Trustee, who shall be elected or appointed to
office shall, before entering upon the duties of their respective offices,
execute a bond with security, to be approved by the President and Board of
Trustees. This bond shall be payable to the Village in the amount elsewhere
provided in this Code and shall be conditioned upon the faithful performance of
the duties of the office and the paying over of all public monies received by
such officer, in accordance with law and the Village ordinances, and the orders
and resolutions of the President and Board of Trustees. All such bonds shall be
filed with the Village Clerk, except the bond of the Clerk, which shall be
filed with the Treasurer; provided, that a blanket coverage surety bond may be
executed, with approval by the President and Board of Trustees, for all
elective and appointive officers of the Village. (Ord. 82-1615, 2-16-1982; amd.
1997 Code)
   B.   Failure To Give Bond: No officer shall be commissioned until he gives
such bond if other than a blanket coverage surety bond is required; if he does
not take the oath and present such bond to the Clerk when such bond is required
(or, in the case of the Clerk, to the Treasurer) within ten (10) days after
notification by the Clerk of his election or appointment to office, his office
shall become vacant.
   C.   Payment Of Premiums: All premiums charged by the corporate surety on
such bonds shall be paid by the Village out of its general funds, and in no
case by the individual officer furnishing the bond. (Ord. 82-1615, 2-16-1982)
1-8-6: RECORDS:
   A.   Inspection: All books, papers, warrants, correspondence, entries,
accounts and memoranda of each and every officer having reference to Village
matters may be examined at any time by the President or any member of the Board
of Trustees; and the said Board by resolution may call upon any officer to make
a report in writing concerning any subject matter pertaining to his office and
within such time as the Board may designate in such resolution.
   B.   Records To Successor: Any person having been an officer of the Village
shall, within five (5) days after notification and request, deliver to his
successor in office all property, books and effects of every description in his
possession belonging to the Village and pertaining to his office. (Ord. 82-
1615, 2-16-1982)
1-8-7: POWERS AND DUTIES:
Every Village officer, beside the powers and duties assigned to him by this
Code, shall also have the further powers and perform the further duties which
usually pertain to his office, and shall be subject to such other rules and
regulations as the President and Board of Trustees may from time to time
prescribe or by ordinance establish. (Ord. 82-1615, 2-16-1982)
1-8-8: OFFICIAL COMMISSION:
All officers, elective or appointive, except the President, Clerk and Trustees,
shall be commissioned by warrant signed by the President and the Board of
Trustees and attested by the Clerk under the Corporate Seal. The commission
shall be substantially the following form:
OFFICIAL COMMISSION: The Village of Western Springs. To all to whom these
presents shall come:                  having been duly elected (or appointed)
to the office of                   in and for the Village of Western Springs,
in the County of Cook and State of Illinois, for the term from the       day of
                         19     to the       day of                        
19     and until his successor shall be duly elected (or appointed) and
qualified, is hereby fully authorized and empowered to assume and perform all
of the duties of his office according to the laws of the State of Illinois and
the provisions of the Village Code, and all persons are required to respect him
in the discharge of his said duties.
Given under my hand and the Corporate Seal of the Village of Western Springs
this       day of                   . 19    .
                             
   President of the Village
   of Western Springs
Attest:
                       
Village Clerk
(Ord. 82-1615, 2-16-1982)
1-8-9: PERMITS IN WRITING:
All permits issued by any officer, pursuant to ordinance of the Village, shall
be in writing and duplicates thereof shall be kept on permanent file. (Ord. 82-
1615, 2-16-1982; 1997 Code)
ARTICLE A. VILLAGE MANAGER 1
SECTION:
1-8A-1: Creation; Appointment; Term
1-8A-2: Qualifications
1-8A-3: Bond; Oath; Compensation
1-8A-4: Vacancy
1-8A-5: Deputy Village Manager
1-8A-6: Personnel; Audit Report
 
Notes
1 1. See also section
  1-9A-3 of this title.
1-8A-1: CREATION; APPOINTMENT; TERM:
There is hereby created the office of village manager, an administrative office
of the village. The village manager shall be appointed by a majority of votes
of the president and board of trustees, voting jointly, and may be removed at
any time for any reason by a similar vote. During his or her term of office,
the village manager need not be a resident of the village, but shall reside at
a permanent residence at a location agreeable to the president and board of
trustees. (Ord. 00-2137, 8-8-2000)
1-8A-2: QUALIFICATIONS:
The village manager shall be chosen solely on the basis of his executive and
administrative qualifications with special reference to his actual experience
in, and his knowledge of, accepted practices in respect to the duties of his
office. (Ord. 82-1615, 2-16-1982)
1-8A-3: BOND; OATH; COMPENSATION:
   A.   Bond: Before entering upon the duties of his office the village manager
shall furnish a bond as provided in section
1-8-5 of this chapter in the sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00). In the
event the village maintains in force a blanket coverage surety bond which
includes coverage for the village manager, the village manager shall not be
required to furnish a bond as provided herein.
   B.   Oath And Compensation: The village manager shall take the oath
prescribed by statute 1 . He shall receive such compensation as may be fixed
from time to time by the president and board of trustees. (Ord. 82-1615, 2-16-
1982)
 
Notes
1 2. See section
  1-8-4 of this chapter.
1-8A-4: VACANCY:
In the event of death, removal from the village, resignation, incapacity, or
disability of the village manager, the vacancy thus or otherwise created shall
be filled by the president and board of trustees voting jointly. (Ord. 82-1615,
2-16-1982)
1-8A-5: DEPUTY VILLAGE MANAGER:
During the temporary absence of the village manager, the duties of his office
shall be performed by an appointive officer of the village designated as the
deputy village manager. The deputy village manager shall be appointed by the
village manager with the approval of the board of trustees. (Ord. 82-1615, 2-
16-1982)
1-8A-6: PERSONNEL; AUDIT REPORT:
The village manager shall make an annual report, in writing, to the president
and board of trustees of the status of village personnel. (Ord. 82-1615, 2-16-
1982)
ARTICLE B. VILLAGE TREASURER
SECTION:
1-8B-1: Creation; Appointment
1-8B-2: Bond; Oath
1-8B-3: Accounts And Records
1-8B-4: Warrants
1-8B-5: Special Assessments
1-8B-6: Reports
1-8B-7: Monies Collected; Custody
1-8B-8: Depository Banks
1-8B-9: Records To Successor
1-8B-10: Compensation
1-8B-11: Fees For Nonsufficient Funds
1-8B-1: CREATION; APPOINTMENT:
There is hereby created the office of Village Treasurer, an administrative
office of the Village. The Treasurer shall be appointed by the President and
the Board of Trustees, voting jointly. (Ord. 78-1519, 9-18-1978; amd. Ord. 94-
1891, 3-28-1994)
1-8B-2: BOND; OATH:
Before entering upon the duties of his office, the Treasurer shall furnish a
bond, as provided in Section
1-8-5 of this Chapter, in such sum as shall be from time to time determined by
the Board of Trustees by ordinance. Said bond shall be for a sum not less than
ten percent (10%) of the highest amount of taxes and special assessments
received by him or his predecessors during any fiscal year in the last
preceding five (5) fiscal years, nor less than one and one-half (11/2) times
the largest amount which is estimated will be in his custody at any one time,
or less than three (3) times the latest Federal census population or any
subsequent census figure used for motor fuel tax purposes. The Treasurer shall
also take the oath of office prescribed by statute. (Ord. 79-1549)
1-8B-3: ACCOUNTS AND RECORDS:
   A.   Payments: The Treasurer, in addition to the duties prescribed by
statute, shall keep a true and accurate account showing all monies paid into
the Treasury and by whom and on what account received; he shall pay out such
sums of money as may be owed by the Village, but only after the presentation of
claims which shall be approved as provided in Section
1-13-5 of this Title. All checks shall be signed by the Treasurer. In all cases
checks shall state upon what particular funds they are drawn. Any bond or
interest coupon issued by the Village, and due and payable, shall be considered
as a warrant duly authorized for payment by the Treasurer. (Ord. 79-1547, 6-25-
1979)
   B.   Books And Accounts: The books kept by the Village Treasurer shall at
all times show the exact condition of the monies under his control, of each
account and appropriation, and of all receipts and disbursements, and such
books together with all others in his custody and belonging to the Village
shall be by him handed over to his successor. The Treasurer shall keep a
separate account for each fund or appropriation. The Treasurer shall keep all
books, papers, vouchers, warrants, documents and all other instruments in
writing pertaining to his office at the office of the Village, which books and
documents shall, at all times, be open to the inspection of the President, the
Trustees, the Village Attorney and the Village Manager. The Treasurer shall
keep such books of accounts as are herein provided and as the President and
Board of Trustees shall from time to time direct. (1978 Code § 1-9-6; 1997
Code)
   C.   Balance Of Accounts: The books of accounts provided for in this Article
shall be properly balanced at least once in each month, in such a manner that
the same, when so balanced, shall show the true status and condition of each
and every account therein shown. (1978 Code § 1-9-6)
1-8B-4: WARRANTS:
   A.   Payment: No monies shall be paid by the Treasurer upon any warrant,
bond or coupon except from the monies belonging to the particular fund or
appropriation upon which such warrant shall have been drawn; no money shall be
transferred by the Treasurer from one fund to another after it has been
received by him, nor be appropriated to any other purpose than that for which
it has been collected or paid, without the vote of a majority of the Board of
Trustees.
   B.   Register: The Treasurer shall keep a register of all warrants redeemed
and paid, which shall describe such warrants and show the date, amount, serial
numbers, the fund from which paid, the name of the person to whom paid and the
date of payment. (1978 Code § 1-9-4)
   C.   Cancellation: The Treasurer shall cancel all warrants paid or redeemed
by him. (1978 Code § 1-9-4; 1997 Code)
1-8B-5: SPECIAL ASSESSMENTS:
   A.   Accounts For Special Assessments: The Treasurer shall keep an account
of each special assessment under its general description and number, and said
account shall show at its head the amount assessed for public benefits and also
that for special benefits. All monies received on any special assessment shall
be held by the Treasurer as a special fund to be applied to payment for the
improvement for which the assessment was made, and said money shall be issued
for no other purpose, except as may be provided in the ordinance for the
improvement. (1978 Code § 1-9-5)
   B.   Collector Of Special Assessments: The Treasurer shall act as collector
of special assessments and shall execute all special assessment and other
warrants. (1997 Code)
1-8B-6: REPORTS:
   A.   Monthly: The Treasurer shall, each month, make a report in writing to
the Board of Trustees containing a full detailed account of all receipts and
expenditures of the Village, as shown by his books, for the preceding calendar
month. (1978 Code § 1-9-7; 1997 Code)
   B.   Annual: Within six (6) months after the end of each fiscal year, the
Treasurer shall annually prepare and file with the Village Clerk an account of
the monies received and expenditures incurred during the preceding fiscal year
as specified in 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-10-5.1. (1997 Code)
1-8B-7: MONIES COLLECTED; CUSTODY:
   A.   Monies Collected:
      1.   Collection Of Monies; Reports: The Village Treasurer shall collect
money belonging to the Village and shall each month make a written report to
the President and Board of Trustees to be presented at the regular meeting of
the Board in each month, covering collections and disbursements for the
preceding month. These reports shall be delivered to the Village Manager who
shall present them to the Board.
      2.   Monies To Treasurer: Each and every officer of the Village who shall
collect any monies belonging to the Village shall, by or before the end of the
day in which they are collected, turn over the same to the Village Treasurer
together with an itemized statement of the same, taking his receipt therefor.
(Ord. 82-1615, 2-16-1982; 1997 Code)
   B.   Custody Of Monies: The Treasurer shall keep all money belonging to the
Village separate and distinct from his own monies, and he is hereby expressly
prohibited from using, either directly or indirectly, any Village monies or
warrants in his custody and keeping, for his own use and benefit or that of any
other person. Violation of this provision shall subject him to immediate
removal from office by the President and Board of Trustees. In case of his
removal, the President and Board of Trustees, voting jointly, shall appoint a
successor, who shall hold office for the remainder of the unexpired term. (1978
Code § 1-9-8; 1997 Code)
1-8B-8: DEPOSITORY BANKS:
The Treasurer shall keep all monies, belonging to the Village, in such
regularly organized bank or banks as may, from time to time, be designated by
ordinance, as provided by law. (1978 Code § 1-9-9; 1997 Code)
1-8B-9: RECORDS TO SUCCESSOR:
Whenever his term of office shall expire, whether by resignation, relocation
out of the Village, removal from office by the President and Board of Trustees,
the appointment of a successor or other cause, the Treasurer shall at once
deliver to his successor in office, or such other person as may be specially
designated by resolution of the Board of Trustees, all monies, property, books
and effects of every description in his possession, belonging to the Village or
pertaining to his office. He shall also at once account for and pay over to
such successor or other person designated all monies that belong to the
Village. (1978 Code § 1-9-10; 1997 Code)
1-8B-10: COMPENSATION:
The Village Treasurer shall not receive compensation for his or her services as
such officer during his or her respective term of office and until his or her
respective successor shall have been appointed or until the term of office of
such officer shall terminate by removal or otherwise an amount as the President
and Board of Trustees shall from time to time determine. (Ord. 81-1595, 4-20-
1981; amd. Ord. 21-3039, 4-26-2021)
1-8B-11: FEES FOR NONSUFFICIENT FUNDS:
The Treasurer is hereby authorized to assess a ten dollar ($10.00) fee for each
check that is submitted as payment to the Village and which is returned to the
Village because the payer's bank account does not have sufficient funds to pay
the check and shall add to said ten dollar ($10.00) service fee all related
bank charges assessed against the Village. (Ord. 85-1683, 5-20-1985; 1997 Code)
ARTICLE C. VILLAGE ATTORNEY
SECTION:
1-8C-1: Creation; Appointment
1-8C-2: Bond; Oath
1-8C-3: Duties
1-8C-4: Compensation
1-8C-5: Special Counsel
1-8C-1: CREATION; APPOINTMENT:
There is hereby created the office of Village Attorney, an executive office of
the Village. The Village Attorney shall be appointed by the President and the
Board of Trustees, voting jointly. (1978 Code §
1-11-1; amd. Ord. 94-1891, 3-28-1994)
1-8C-2: BOND; OATH:
   A.   Bond: The Village Attorney, before entering upon the duties of his
office, shall execute a bond, as provided in Section
1-8-5 of this Chapter, unless the Village maintains in force a blanket coverage
surety bond which includes coverage for the Village Attorney. If such a blanket
coverage bond is maintained in force by the Village, the Village Attorney shall
not be required to furnish a bond as provided herein.
   B.   Oath: The Village Attorney shall also take the oath prescribed by
statute 1 . (1978 Code § 1-11-2)
 
Notes
1 1. See Section
  1-8-4 of this Chapter.
1-8C-3: DUTIES:
The Village Attorney shall:
   A.   Duties Generally: Prepare certain contracts, leases, deeds and other
legal documents which may be required of him by the Board of Trustees or any
committee thereof and shall draw up certain ordinances and resolutions of the
Board. He shall give the necessary attention to certain suits and proceedings
in every court of record and before certain administrative bodies in which the
Village may be a party or be directly interested. He shall appear as the
Attorney in behalf of any officer of the Village in any suit, prosecution or
other judicial proceeding brought by or against such officer in his official
capacity and, as the case may require, shall prosecute or defend to the
termination thereof. He shall, when required by the President or the Board of
Trustees or, in emergency, by the Village Manager or Director of Law
Enforcement Services, prosecute all cases brought before the proper officer for
violation of any provision of this Code. He shall also perform all other
services legal in character customarily performed by a municipal attorney.
(1978 Code § 1-11-3; 1997 Code)
   B.   Legal Opinions: Give his legal opinions in writing, when requested, to
the Board of Trustees, or any committee thereof, the Village Manager, the
President, the Zoning Board of Appeals or the Village Plan Commission, on legal
questions arising under or concerning any provisions of this Code and on legal
questions and subjects in which the Village shall be legally interested. (1978
Code § 1-11-4; 1997 Code)
   C.   Docket: Keep, in proper books provided for the purpose, a docket of all
suits or proceedings prosecuted or defended by him in which the Village is an
interested party, in which shall be briefly entered all steps taken in each
such proceeding. All such books, and all files, papers and memoranda relating
to all suits or proceedings shall be the property of the Village. (1978 Code §
1-11-5)
   D.   Attendance At Meetings; Reports: Attend the meetings of the Board of
Trustees and each year make a report to said Board of all suits, proceedings or
actions prosecuted or defended by him or outside counsel during the preceding
year, with the names of the parties thereto, the titles of the courts or other
bodies where the same are pending, their progress and final disposition, and
such other information concerning the legal interests of the Village as may be
required by the President or Board of Trustees. He shall make such other
reports on pending matters as the President or Board may from time to time
require. (1978 Code § 1-11-6; 1997 Code)
1-8C-4: COMPENSATION:
The Village Attorney shall be compensated as shall from time to time be fixed
by the President and Board of Trustees and, in addition thereto, such
compensation as may be agreed upon from time to time for prosecution of cases
brought before the proper officer for violation of any Village ordinance, and
for time spent in preparation and trial proceedings in courts of record and
before commissions and other regulatory bodies. (1978 Code § 1-11-7; 1997 Code)
1-8C-5: SPECIAL COUNSEL:
Nothing in this Code contained shall be construed as prohibiting the Board of
Trustees from employing special counsel to represent the Village from time to
time, or from paying such compensation to such special counsel as the said
Board of Trustees may from time to time determine. (1978 Code § 1-11-8)
CHAPTER 9
ADMINISTRATIVE CODE
ARTICLE A. GENERAL PROVISIONS
SECTION:
1-9A-1: Short Title
1-9A-2: Definitions
1-9A-3: Village Manager
1-9A-4: Administrative Organization
1-9A-5: Administrative Policies And Procedures
1-9A-1: SHORT TITLE:
This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the ADMINISTRATIVE CODE OF THE
VILLAGE OF WESTERN SPRINGS. (1997 Code)
1-9A-2: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this code, unless the context otherwise requires, the following
words and terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section:
BOARD OF TRUSTEES OR BOARD OR CORPORATE AUTHORITIES: The president and board of
trustees of the village of Western Springs.
VILLAGE: The village of Western Springs.
VILLAGE MANAGER, MANAGER, CHIEF ADMINISTRATOR OR ADMINISTRATOR: The village
manager of the village of Western Springs. (1997 Code)
1-9A-3: VILLAGE MANAGER 1 :
The village manager shall be the chief administrative officer of the village
government, shall enforce laws of the village and require the faithful
performance of all administrative duties. His powers shall include, but not be
limited to, the following:
   A.   Duties:
      1.   Appointment, Supervision And Dismissal Of Officers And Employees:
Appoint competent, qualified officers and employees to the administrative
service and have the power to supervise, dismiss, suspend and discipline, in
accordance with the personnel rules and regulations in effect, all officers and
employees in the administrative service under his control. He shall also have
the power to authorize a group director, department head or officer responsible
to him to appoint and remove subordinates serving under that group director,
department head or officer.
      2.   Appointment To Acting Capacity: Designate himself or some other
officer or employee to perform the duties of any office or position in the
administrative service under his control which is vacant or which lacks
supervision due to absence or disability of the incumbent.
      3.   Reports: Prepare and present to the board various reports as
appropriate of the village's affairs, including a summary of reports compiled
by directors and department heads and such other reports as the board shall
require. (1997 Code)
      4.   Annual Budget And Corporate Plan: Act as the budget officer and
assemble estimates of the financial needs, resources and programs of the
village for each of three (3) ensuing years, and incorporate those factors into
a three (3) year budget or corporate plan and a single year fiscal operating
budget with proper supporting schedules and analyses which shall be submitted
to the village board for approval at the appropriate time during each fiscal
year. (Ord. 01-2190, 12-17-2001)
      5.   Purchasing Agent: Act as or designate a purchasing agent for the
village, as more fully provided in chapter 13 of this title.
      6.   Attend Board Meetings: Attend all official meetings of the president
and board of trustees.
      7.   Additional Duties: Perform such other duties as may from time to
time be required of him.
   B.   Powers:
      1.   Assign According To Classification: Assign any employee of the
village to any department or branch thereof requiring services appropriate to
the personnel system classification of the employee so assigned.
      2.   Prescribe Rules: In conformity with this code, prescribe,
promulgate, amend or repeal such rules and regulations in effect as he shall
deem necessary or expedient to efficiently carry out the duties of
administration of the affairs of the village; provided, that there shall be no
conflict with said code or the group personnel rules and regulations of the
village.
      3.   Investigate: Either by himself or by any officer or person
designated for the purpose by him, investigate and examine or inquire into the
affairs or operation of any department, division, bureau or office, and when so
authorized by the board, employ consultants and professional counsel to aid in
such investigations, examinations or inquiries.
      4.   Overrule Officials: Set aside any action or decision made by a group
director or department head and may supersede him in the functions of his
office.
      5.   Delegate Duties: Direct any group, department or division to perform
the work for any other group, department or division or assign any work or
project to any group, department or division.
      6.   Appoint Administrative Committees: Establish from time to time such
administrative committees as he shall find necessary. Such committees shall
meet at the request of the village manager and shall make such recommendation
on matters referred to them as they shall find necessary for the best interests
of the village. (1997 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. See also chapter 8, article A of this title.
1-9A-4: ADMINISTRATIVE ORGANIZATION:
The administrative organization of the village shall be divided under the
village manager into the following groups and departments thereof. Each group
shall be managed by a director, and the director of each group shall report to
the village manager:
   A.   General government group: Village manager:
Village manager's office
Village clerk's office
Legal services
Management services/data processing
   B.   Financial services group: Director of finance:
Finance administration
Burlington Northern accounting/collections
Water utility meter reading
Debt service management
Pension fund management
   C.   Municipal services group: Director of municipal services:
Public works administration
Street right of way and Burlington Northern maintenance
Vehicle maintenance
Municipal property management
Forestry
Water and sewer utility administration
Water production and distribution
Sewer maintenance and rehabilitation
Recreation services and property management
   D.   Law enforcement group: Director of law enforcement services:
Law enforcement administration
Patrol services and criminal investigation
Crime prevention and youth services
Communication and information management
Parking enforcement
Emergency telephone (911) (1997 Code)
   E.   Fire and inspectional services group: Director of fire and inspectional
services:
Fire administration
Fire suppression and emergency medical services
Training and public education
Inspectional services
Emergency management agency (1997 Code; amd. Ord. 13-2711, 2-25-2013)
1-9A-5: ADMINISTRATIVE POLICIES AND PROCEDURES:
   A.   Perform Duties: Every employee shall perform all duties required of his
office by state law, this code and ordinances of the village, and such other
duties not in conflict therewith as may be required by the village manager.
   B.   Group Directors: The directors of groups shall:
      1.   Responsibility To Village Manager: Be immediately responsible to the
village manager for the effective administration of their respective groups and
all activities assigned thereto.
      2.   Initiate Sound Practices: Keep informed as to the latest practices
in their particular field and shall initiate, with the approval of the village
manager, such new practices as appear to be of benefit to the service of the
public.
      3.   Report To Village Manager: Submit quarterly and annual reports of
the activities of the group to the village manager and such other reports as
may be requested from time to time.
      4.   Maintain Records: Establish and maintain a system of filing and
indexing records and reports in sufficient detail to furnish all information
necessary for proper control of group activities which will form a basis for
the periodic reports to the village manager.
      5.   Authority Over Employees: Have power, when authorized by the village
manager, to appoint and remove, subject to personnel rules and regulations in
effect, all subordinates under them.
      6.   Maintain Equipment: Be responsible for the proper maintenance of all
village property and equipment used in their respective group.
   C.   Department Heads: The heads of departments shall:
      1.   Responsible To Group Director: Be immediately responsible to their
respective group director for the effective administration of their respective
divisions and all activities assigned thereto.
      2.   Authority Over Employees: Have power, when authorized by the village
manager, to appoint and remove, subject to personnel rules and regulations in
effect, all subordinates under them.
      3.   Maintain Equipment: Be responsible for the proper maintenance of all
village property and equipment used in their respective department.
   D.   Cooperation Among Groups: Each group and department thereof shall
furnish, upon the direction of the village manager, any other group and
division thereof such service, labor and materials as may be formally requested
by the head of such group and as its own facilities permit on a cooperative
basis for the betterment of service to the public. (1997 Code)
ARTICLE B. GENERAL GOVERNMENT GROUP
SECTION:
1-9B-1: General Government Group
1-9B-2: Village Manager's Office
1-9B-3: Duties Of Village Manager As A Department Head
1-9B-4: Functions Of General Government Group
1-9B-1: GENERAL GOVERNMENT GROUP:
The General Government Group shall consist of the Village Manager and the
direct reports to the Village Manager which include but are not limited to the
Assistant to the Village Manager, Technical Systems Coordinator, Executive
Secretary, Administrative Intern and other clerical employees as authorized at
any time. (1997 Code)
1-9B-2: VILLAGE MANAGER'S OFFICE:
The General Government Group shall also be known as the Village Manager's
office. (1997 Code)
1-9B-3: DUTIES OF VILLAGE MANAGER AS A DEPARTMENT HEAD:
The Village Manager shall have management responsibility and control over all
matters pertaining to the General Government Group in addition to the general
duties of the office of Village Manager specified in Section
1-9A-3 of this Chapter. (1997 Code)
1-9B-4: FUNCTIONS OF GENERAL GOVERNMENT GROUP:
The General Government Group shall be responsible for the administration of:
   A.   Village Manager's Office: The following general duties and programs:
liaison and service to the President and Board of Trustees and the volunteer
boards and commissions, personnel rules and regulations in effect, risk
management programs and public relations and communications programs.
   B.   Legal Services: The following legal services: corporate legal work,
prosecutions, litigation and labor relations.
   C.   Management Services/Data Processing: The central and management
services functions of the Village and the coordination of data processing
services and equipment. (1997 Code)
ARTICLE C. FINANCIAL SERVICES GROUP
SECTION:
1-9C-1: Financial Services Group
1-9C-2: Duties Of Director Of Finance
1-9C-3: Functions Of Financial Services Group
1-9C-1: FINANCIAL SERVICES GROUP:
The Financial Services Group shall consist of a Director of Finance and such
other department heads, officers and employees as the Village Manager shall
authorize. (1997 Code)
1-9C-2: DUTIES OF DIRECTOR OF FINANCE:
The Director of Finance shall:
   A.   Management Responsibility And Control: Have management responsibility
and control over all matters pertaining to the Financial Services Group.
   B.   Chief Financial Officer/Treasurer: Act as the Chief Financial Officer/
Treasurer of the Village and as such shall be responsible for the collection of
Village funds from any source and the prompt payment of expenses after such
expenses have been properly approved.
   C.   Secure Financial Interests: In all cases where the duty is not
expressly charged to any other group or department thereof, act to promote,
secure and preserve the financial and property interests of the Village.
   D.   Fiscal Supervision Over Officers: Exercise general supervision over all
officers of the Village regarding the property management and the fiscal
concerns of their respective offices. (1997 Code)
1-9C-3: FUNCTIONS OF FINANCIAL SERVICES GROUP:
The Financial Services Group shall:
   A.   Administration: Maintain accurate and timely records and safeguard the
assets of the Village. The Financial Services Group shall also provide outside
agencies with accurate, effective and timely accounting and reporting systems
as well as any needed support services.
   B.   Burlington Northern Accounting/Collections: Account and maintain
accurate records of the parking permits issued.
   C.   Water Meter Utility Reading: Monitor and supervise the reading of all
residential and commercial meters on a predetermined schedule.
   D.   Debt Service Management: Administer and account for the accumulation of
resources for, and the payment of, principal and interest on general long-term
debt.
   E.   Pension Fund Management: Administer and account for the accumulation of
resources to be used for retirement annuity payments of appropriate amounts at
times in the future. (1997 Code)
ARTICLE D. MUNICIPAL SERVICES GROUP
SECTION:
1-9D-1: Municipal Services Group
1-9D-2: Duties Of Director Of Municipal Services
1-9D-3: Departments And Divisions Of Municipal Services Group
1-9D-1: MUNICIPAL SERVICES GROUP:
The municipal services group shall consist of a director of municipal services
and such department heads, superintendents and employees as the village manager
shall authorize. (1997 Code)
1-9D-2: DUTIES OF DIRECTOR OF MUNICIPAL SERVICES:
The director of municipal services shall:
   A.   Management Responsibility And Control: Have management responsibility
and control over all matters pertaining to the municipal services group,
including the supervision of all personnel, the provision of all services and
the management of all budgetary programs, subject to direction from the village
manager.
   B.   Office Operations: Have responsibility for the supervision of the
municipal services office operations including the implementation and
monitoring of the municipal services management information system and, in
particular, the geographic information system.
   C.   Capital Planning: Coordinate assembly of the municipal services portion
of the five (5) year corporate plan and the twenty (20) year infrastructure
management plan.
   D.   Cooperation With Other Directors: Work cooperatively with other village
directors, staff members and consultants on all municipal services matters,
code or policy enforcement matters, and other village related matters referred
to him/her by the village manager or as required by applicable laws, ordinances
and regulations, including this code.
   E.   Technical Consultants: Supervise the work of technical consultants on
matters related to municipal services projects. (1997 Code; amd. Ord. 20-3007,
6-22-2020)
1-9D-3: DEPARTMENTS AND DIVISIONS OF MUNICIPAL SERVICES GROUP:
   A.   Functions Of The Department Of Public Works:
      1.   Public right of way maintenance, including streets, sidewalks,
streetlights and traffic signals.
      2.   Vehicle maintenance and repair.
      3.   Forestry, including public tree replacement, trimming, removal and
public consultation and education regarding forestry matters.
      4.   Water distribution, including the maintenance of water mains and
hydrants.
      5.   Sewer maintenance/rehabilitation, including the maintenance and
repair of the village's sanitary, storm and combined sewer systems. (1997 Code)
      6.   Liaison with the Western Springs infrastructure commission 1 . (1997
Code; amd. Ord. 01-2187, 12-17-2001)
   B.   Functions Of The Water Department:
      1.   Water production, including the operation and maintenance of the
village's wells, water plant and storage facilities.
      2.   Water distribution, including the maintenance of residential water
services.
   C.   Functions Of The Department Of Recreation:
      1.   Recreation services, including the operation of the village's fall,
winter/spring and summer programs.
      2.   Building services, including the operation and maintenance of the
village's recreation center.
      3.   Grand Avenue community center, including the operation and
maintenance of the Grand Avenue community center and liaison with the Western
Springs community center association.
      4.   Liaison with the Western Springs recreation commission 2 . (1997
Code)
      5.   Cooperation with school districts, park districts or other
governmental authorities and bodies for the purpose of utilizing lands,
buildings and equipment made available to the department by such other
governmental bodies and authorities. (Ord. 00-2111, 1-24-2000)
   D.   Functions Of The Properties Division:
      1.   Municipal properties, including the maintenance and repair of the
village hall, firehouse, public works garage, village tower/historical museum
and other general properties of the village.
      2.   Burlington Northern commuter facilities, including the repair and
maintenance of the train station, railroad right of way and parking facilities.
      3.   Liaison with the west suburban mass transit district. (1997 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. See title 2, chapter 11 of this code.
2 2. See title 2, chapter 7 of this code.
ARTICLE E. LAW ENFORCEMENT GROUP
SECTION:
1-9E-1: Law Enforcement Administration
1-9E-2: Patrol Services And Criminal Investigation
1-9E-3: Crime Prevention And Youth Services
1-9E-4: Communication And Information Management
1-9E-5: Ordinance Control And Parking Enforcement
1-9E-6: Emergency Telephone (9-1-1)
1-9E-1: LAW ENFORCEMENT ADMINISTRATION:
   A.   Department Of Law Enforcement Services: The department of law
enforcement services shall consist of a director, a deputy police chief (deputy
director of law enforcement services), and such police lieutenants, sergeants
and police officers as the operating budget and the personnel classification
system shall authorize.
   B.   Appointment, Removal And Suspension Of Personnel: Notwithstanding any
other provisions of this code, all police lieutenants, sergeants and full time
officers shall be appointed by the board of fire and police commissioners 1 .
The board of fire and police commissioners may, at any time, for cause, remove
from office or suspend any member of the department of law enforcement services
except the director of law enforcement services, the deputy police chief
(deputy director of law enforcement services), and nonsworn personnel. (Ord.
06-2411, 10-23-2006)
   C.   Duties Of Director Of Law Enforcement Services: The director of law
enforcement services shall direct the police work of the village and be
responsible for the enforcement and maintenance of law and order and shall:
      1.   Generally: Have the custody, care and control of the public property
of the department and of all firearms and other equipment; devote his whole
time to village affairs, to preserve the peace, order, safety and cleanliness
thereof, and to this end execute and enforce all village code provisions and
all orders of the president and board of trustees; be charged with the duty of
protecting the rights of persons and the protection of property in the village;
make rules and regulations governing the conduct of members of the department
of law enforcement services subject to conflict with the rules and regulations
of the board of fire and police commissioners and review and approval of the
village manager.
      2.   Division Assignments: Assign officers to each division of the
department. Reassignment from one division to another shall only be made by the
director of law enforcement services.
      3.   Juvenile Officer: Designate a juvenile officer to supervise all
cases under the juvenile court act.
      4.   Execution Of Process: Have power and authority, and it shall be his
duty, within the village, to serve and execute warrants and other processes for
the apprehension and commitment of persons charged with violation of any code
provision or any crime or misdemeanor or offense against the peace of the state
or the village or held for examination or trial or taken on execution for the
commission of any crime or misdemeanor or violation of any law or ordinance,
and he shall also have power and authority and it shall be his duty to serve
and execute any civil process issued by any court or proper officer, in any
case in which the village is a party, and while serving or executing or
assisting in the service or execution of any such warrant or process, he shall
be vested with and have all the powers and authority conferred on constables at
common law and by the laws of the state.
      5.   Reports: On or before April 1 of each year, make an annual report,
in writing, to the village manager and president and board of trustees
concerning the state of the department, with a detailed statement of the
transactions of the department of law enforcement services for the preceding
year, together with such statistics and suggestions in regard to the
requirements of the department of law enforcement services as he may deem
advisable. He shall also make reports of any matter concerning the department
whenever requested by the president and board of trustees. (1997 Code)
   D.   Deputy Police Chief (Deputy Director Of Law Enforcement Services):
      1.   Generally: There is established the position of deputy police chief
(also referred to as the deputy director of law enforcement services). The
deputy police chief shall be appointed by the director of law enforcement
services with the approval of the village manager. The rank of deputy police
chief shall be an exempt rank immediately below that of director. The
appointment shall be from any rank of sworn, full time officers of the
village's police department, provided such officer has at least five (5) years
of full time service as a police officer with the village's police department.
The deputy police chief shall serve at the discretion of and may be removed
from the position by the director of law enforcement services with or without
cause. If removed from the position of deputy police chief, the officer shall
revert to the rank held immediately prior to appointment to the deputy police
chief rank, regardless of whether a vacancy exists in that rank. A deputy
police chief, having been appointed from any rank of sworn full time officers
of the village's police department, shall be permitted, regardless of rank, to
take promotional exams and be promoted to a higher classified rank than he or
she currently holds, without having to resign as deputy police chief.
      2.   Duties: The deputy police chief shall perform those duties as
required by the director of law enforcement services. Should there be a vacancy
in the office of director of law enforcement services, the deputy police chief
shall have the powers and shall perform the duties of the director of law
enforcement services until such time as a new director is appointed and sworn
into office. Should the director of law enforcement services be incapacitated
or otherwise unable to perform the duties of director, the deputy police chief
shall have the powers and shall perform the duties of director of law
enforcement services until such time as the director is able to resume the
performance of the duties of director of law enforcement services.
      3.   Compensation: The compensation of the deputy police chief shall be
set by the village manager in conjunction with the annual budget approved by
the corporate authorities of the village. (Ord. 06-2411, 10-23-2006)
   E.   Auxiliary Police:
      1.   Appointment: The village manager or his designee may, with the
advice and consent of the president and board of trustees, appoint auxiliary
police officers in such number as the village manager or his designee shall
from time to time deem necessary.
      2.   Duties And Restrictions: Such auxiliary police shall not be members
of the regular department of law enforcement services. Such auxiliary police
shall not supplement members of the regular department of law enforcement
services in the performance of their assigned and normal duties, except as
otherwise provided herein. Such auxiliary police members shall only be assigned
to perform the following duties in the village:
         a.   To aid or direct traffic within the village.
         b.   To aid in control of natural or manmade disasters.
         c.   To aid in case of civil disorder as directed by the director of
law enforcement services; provided, that in cases which render it impractical
for members of the regular department of law enforcement services to perform
the normal and regular police duties, the director of law enforcement services
is hereby authorized to assign auxiliary police officers to assist sworn police
officers in the performance of those sworn police officers' normal and regular
police duties.
      3.   Identification Symbols: Identification symbols, including a badge
and uniform worn by such auxiliary police officers, shall be different and
distinct from those used by members of the regular department of law
enforcement services. Such auxiliary police shall, at all times during the
performance of their duties, be subject to the direction and control of the
director of law enforcement services.
      4.   Firearms: The auxiliary police officers shall not carry firearms,
except with the permission of the director of law enforcement services and
while in uniform and in the performance of their duties, and only after
completing the same course of training as required of peace officers under
section 2 of the peace officer firearm training act 2 .
      5.   Conservators Of The Peace: The auxiliary police, when on duty, shall
not be conservators of peace, shall not have the powers (including arrest
powers) as specified in 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3.1-15-25, and shall
not have the powers set forth in subsection F1 of this section, except with the
permission of the director of law enforcement services and while in uniform and
in the performance of their duties, and only after successful completion of the
same course of training as required of peace officers under section 2 of the
peace officer firearm training act 3 , as amended, and compliance with the
provisions of section 7 of the Illinois police training act 4 , as amended,
including successful completion of the mandatory basic law enforcement officer
training course or such other training requirements required by state law.
      6.   Training; Fingerprinting: Auxiliary police, prior to entering upon
any of their duties, shall receive a course of training in the use of weapons
and other police procedures as shall be appropriate in the exercise of the
powers conferred upon them under this subsection, which training and course of
study shall be determined and provided by the village. Prior to the appointment
of any auxiliary police officer, his fingerprints shall be taken, and no person
shall be appointed as such auxiliary police officer if he has been convicted of
a felony or other crime involving moral turpitude.
   F.   Powers And Duties Of Department And Police Officers:
      1.   Arrests: All police officers shall have power to: a) arrest, with or
without process, all persons who break the peace or are found violating any
ordinance of the village or any criminal law of the state; b) commit arrested
persons for examination; c) if necessary, detain arrested persons in the
village jail or any other safe place until they can be brought before the
proper county officer for trial. They shall have all the powers of constables
as established by common law or by statutes. (Ord. 07-2452, 7-23-2007)
      2.   Police As Witnesses: All officers making arrests shall attend as
witnesses before the court where the trial may be held and shall procure all
necessary evidence in their power, and furnish a list of witnesses to the
court. No village officer or police officer shall be entitled to any witness
fees to be paid by the village in any action for a violation of any code
provision where the village is plaintiff.
      3.   Aid To Department Of Fire And Inspectional Services: It shall be the
duty of the department of law enforcement services to aid the department of
fire and inspectional services by giving alarm in case of fire and by clearing
the streets or grounds in the immediate vicinity of the fire so that members of
the fire and inspectional services department shall not be hindered or
obstructed in the performance of their duties.
      4.   Accident Reports: Each and every police officer of the village,
whenever any accident shall occur within the village limits of which he has or
should have notice or knowledge, shall record forthwith in writing the place,
day and nature of the accident, the hour of the day or night when occurred, the
condition of the weather (and, if at night, whether cloudy, clear or moonlit
and whether the streetlamps nearby were not lighted), the name of each person
injured, the extent and nature of the injury suffered, the names and residences
of the principal witnesses and the name and work location of the examining
physician, if any. Said records shall be kept on file at the police station,
and where village personnel, equipment or liability may be involved, a copy of
said record shall be sent forthwith to the village manager.
   G.   Furnishing Bail: No members of the police force shall become or furnish
bail for any person arrested for violation of any ordinance or of the criminal
laws of the state.
   H.   Badge: Every member of the department of law enforcement services,
including auxiliary police officers, shall wear a suitable badge, to be
furnished by the village, and any member who shall lose or destroy the same
shall be required to pay the cost of replacing it. Whenever any member shall
leave the department, he shall immediately deliver his badge and all other
articles in his possession belonging to the village to the director of law
enforcement services.
   I.   Custody Of Lost Or Stolen Property: The director of law enforcement
services shall be, under the general directions of the village manager, the
custodian of all property seized or taken by the police and of all lost or
stolen property within the village. As such custodian, he shall keep or cause
to be kept a record of all property which has been seized or otherwise taken
possession of by the police force. If such property shall not be claimed by the
rightful owner thereof and possession surrendered to such owner within sixty
(60) days from the day of the final disposition of the court proceedings in
connection with which such property was seized or taken possession of, or, in
case there are no such court proceedings, then if such property shall not be
claimed by the rightful owner within six (6) months from the date of such
seizure or taking by the police, the director of law enforcement services shall
publish or cause to be published, in a newspaper of general circulation in the
village, a notice containing a description of such property together with the
date of seizure or the taking possession thereof; copies of said notice shall
also be posted in at least one public place where public notices are commonly
posted, and shall state in said notice that if such property be not claimed by
the rightful owner or owners thereof within ten (10) days from the date of such
publication, said property will be sold at public auction at such place as the
director of law enforcement services may direct and in such manner as to expose
to the inspection of bidders all property so offered for sale; provided, that
such unclaimed property, if deemed by the director of law enforcement services
to be of use to the department of law enforcement services, may be retained for
the use of said department, and provided further, that no member of said
department, directly or indirectly, shall purchase or participate in the
bidding for or purchase of such unclaimed property.
   J.   Emergency Sale Of Property: If any property seized by or coming into
the possession of the police force shall be of a perishable nature or of such a
nature as to make it dangerous or inadvisable to retain possession thereof for
sixty (60) days, the director of law enforcement services, upon certifying such
fact to the board of trustees and setting forth his reasons why such property
should not be retained for the period hereinabove fixed before selling the
same, shall, with the approval of the board of trustees, cause to be posted a
notice as prescribed in subsection I of this section but providing for sale at
any time after three (3) days from the date of such posting and, at the time
fixed in such notice, shall sell such property as provided in subsection I of
this section.
   K.   Resisting Officer; Aid In Escape: It shall be unlawful for any person
in the village to resist any member of the police force in the discharge of his
duties or in any way interfere with or prevent or hinder him in the discharge
of his duty as such member or use any abusive or profane language toward said
police officer or offer or endeavor to do so or in any manner to assist any
person in the custody of any member of the police force to escape or attempt to
escape from custody or attempt to rescue any person in such custody.
   L.   Aid To Police Required: It shall be the duty of any person in the
village, when called upon by the director of law enforcement services or any
member of the department of law enforcement services, to promptly aid and
assist in the execution of police duties. (1997 Code; amd. Ord. 06-2411, 10-23-
2006)
 
Notes
1 1. See title 2, chapter 3 of this code.
2 1. 50 ILCS 710/2.
3 2. 50 ILCS 710/2.
4 3. 50 ILCS 705/7.
1-9E-2: PATROL SERVICES AND CRIMINAL INVESTIGATION:
   A.   Composition Of Patrol Services: Patrol consists of uniformed police
officers providing the most visible and critical police services.
   B.   Duties Of Patrol Officers:
      1.   Uniformed officers will patrol the village in cars, on foot and on
bicycles to effectively provide those services.
      2.   Patrol officers respond to calls for service, both criminal and
civil. They will investigate crimes and file reports documenting their
findings.
      3.   Patrol officers will respond to and investigate traffic accidents.
They will attend to the needs of the injured, provide for the safe flow of
traffic and document their findings regarding the accident.
      4.   Patrol officers will enforce both state and village traffic
regulations in order to enhance the safe and efficient flow of traffic within
the village.
      5.   Patrol officers will perform preventative patrols within the village
to discourage crime and promote a sense of security for citizens.
      6.   Patrol officers will provide services as needed on a twenty four
(24) hour a day, seven (7) day a week basis when other service agencies are not
available. (1997 Code)
1-9E-3: CRIME PREVENTION AND YOUTH SERVICES:
   A.   Follow Up Investigation: Officers assigned to the investigation
division will provide follow up investigation of criminal cases.
   B.   Identify Perpetrators, Collect Evidence, Assist In Prosecutions:
Investigators will strive to identify the perpetrators of those crimes, collect
evidence and assist in the prosecution of those persons.
   C.   DARE/Crime Prevention: An officer will:
      1.   Provide drug awareness (DARE) instruction in all fifth grade
classes.
      2.   Provide gang awareness (VEGA) instruction at the fifth or sixth
grade level.
      3.   Provide DARE refresher training at the junior high level.
      4.   Provide drug and gang awareness instruction at the high school
level.
      5.   Coordinate the department's gang interdiction efforts with those of
neighboring departments. (1997 Code)
1-9E-4: COMMUNICATION AND INFORMATION MANAGEMENT:
Telecommunicators will:
   A.   Answer telephones, radio calls, data link messages and personally deal
with the public.
   B.   Answer the emergency telephone lines and dispatch police, fire and EMS
personnel in a professional and timely manner.
   C.   Provide effective records management and storage for departmental
activities. (1997 Code)
1-9E-5: ORDINANCE CONTROL AND PARKING ENFORCEMENT:
The ordinance control officer is a civilian position that provides for
compliance with village ordinances as they affect the general welfare of the
village and its citizens through fair and equal enforcement of those
ordinances. The ordinance control officer provides other services to the public
to assist sworn officers in the performance of their duties. Parking
regulations will also be enforced by the ordinance control officer. (1997 Code)
1-9E-6: EMERGENCY TELEPHONE (9-1-1):
Emergency telephone (9-1-1):
   A.   Provides three (3) digit dialing access for all telephone calls for
emergency services within the village.
   B.   Provides for the acquisition and maintenance of all equipment and/or
personnel necessary to support the 9-1-1 system. (1997 Code)
ARTICLE F. FIRE AND EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICES GROUP
SECTION:
1-9F-1: Fire And Emergency Medical Services Administration
1-9F-2: Fire Suppression And Emergency Medical Services
1-9F-3: Training And Public Education
1-9F-4: Duties Of Director Of Emergency Management Agency (EMA)
1-9F-1: FIRE AND EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICES ADMINISTRATION:
   A.   Fire And Emergency Medical Services Group: The fire and emergency
medical services group shall consist of a director of fire and emergency
medical services and such department heads, assistants, inspectors and
employees as the operating budget and the classification system shall
authorize.
   B.   Appointment, Removal And Suspension Of Firefighter/Paramedics:
Notwithstanding any other provisions of this code, all full time, sworn
firefighter/paramedics shall be appointed by the board of fire and police
commissioners 1 . The board of fire and police commissioners may, at any time,
remove from office or suspend any full time, sworn firefighter/paramedic.
      1.   Abolishment Of Position Of Full Time Firefighter/Paramedic: As of
December 31, 1998, notwithstanding any other provisions of this code, all
filled and unfilled positions of sworn, full time firefighter/paramedics are
hereby abolished. No new full time firefighter/paramedics shall be appointed by
the board of fire and police commissioners and no action in regard to the
process of applications, examinations or posting of eligibility lists for new
hires as sworn, full time firefighter/paramedics shall be performed by the
board of fire and police commissioners.
   C.   Powers And Duties Of Director: The director of fire and emergency
medical services shall have management control and responsibility of all
matters pertaining to the fire and emergency medical services group including
fire and emergency medical services, code enforcement and EMA, and shall:
      1.   Powers And Duties Generally: Be charged with the prevention of
fires, the protection of life and property against fire and the provision of
emergency medical services. He shall be responsible for the implementation,
administration and management of a proactive code enforcement program. He shall
recruit and maintain a viable paid on call firefighting force. He shall make
rules and regulations governing departmental operations and conduct of the
members of the department of fire and emergency medical services subject to the
review and approval by the village manager.
      2.   Command At Fires: If possible, attend all fires occurring in the
village, and in the case of his absence, the officer of the highest rank at the
fire scene shall take command of the department and direct the fire scene.
      3.   Investigation Of Fires: Investigate the causes of all fires as soon
as is practical following their occurrence, and shall make and keep a record of
their investigation and of the circumstances of each case.
      4.   Inspection Of Premises: Have the right to enter any building,
structure or premises, whether completed or in the course of construction, for
the purpose of determining whether such building, structure or premises has
been or is being constructed and maintained in accordance with the fire and
life safety regulations of the village.
      5.   Annual Report: On or before May 1 of each year, make an annual
report in writing to the corporate authorities through the village manager
concerning the state of the fire and emergency medical services group for the
preceding year, together with such statistics and suggestions in regard to the
requirements of the group as he may deem advisable.
   D.   Establishment Of Fire Prevention Bureau: The village shall staff and
maintain a fire prevention bureau consisting of a fire inspector or a fire
marshal, who shall work under the supervision of the director of fire and
emergency medical services and the village manager. Unless authorized by the
annual budget, the village shall not employ a fire marshal and a fire inspector
at the same time. The director, with the approval of the village manager, may
remove the designated fire inspector or fire marshal and designate a
replacement. The village personnel who work in the fire prevention bureau
perform almost exclusively administrative job duties and functions, and, as
part of their full time job description, the fire inspector does not perform
any fire protection duties typical of a firefighter and the fire marshal may at
times perform fire protection duties typical of a firefighter.
      1.   Establishment And Powers And Duties Of Fire Inspector: The fire
inspector shall perform such duties as required by the ordinances and codes of
the village and as directed by the director, or other department command
personnel. The fire inspector shall enforce the ordinances and codes of the
village and the national fire prevention and life safety codes, as adopted, and
may assist the director with the investigation of the causes of all fires. The
fire inspector shall have the power to inspect, issue citations, serve process
and arrest for violation, and shall have all other powers incidental to the
foregoing in order to enforce compliance with the provisions of this chapter,
and such other code provisions and ordinances dealing with fire prevention or
protection and the national fire prevention and life safety codes, as adopted.
      2.   Interdepartment Cooperation: The director of fire and emergency
medical services shall ensure prompt and efficient submission of reports
concerning building and related permits by the fire prevention bureau personnel
to the director of community development. In the instance of such permits, the
community development department shall be the responsible agency. The director
of community development shall ensure prompt and efficient submission of
reports concerning fire prevention, by duly appointed community development
department code inspectors, to the fire prevention bureau. In the instance of
such reports, the fire prevention bureau shall be the responsible agency.
   E.   Reinstatement And Powers And Duties Of Fire Marshal: The director of
fire and emergency medical services, with the approval of the village manager,
may employ a fire marshal, who shall work under the supervision of the director
and the village manager. The fire marshal shall:
      1.   Powers And Duties Generally: Perform such duties as required by the
ordinances and codes of the village and as directed by the director, or other
department command personnel. The fire marshal shall administer fire prevention
activities and all related recordkeeping for the department of fire and
emergency medical services. The fire marshal shall enforce the ordinances and
codes of the village and the national fire prevention and life safety codes, as
adopted, and may assist the director with the investigation of the causes of
all fires. The fire marshal shall have the power to inspect, issue citations,
serve process and arrest for violation, and shall have all other powers
incidental to the foregoing in order to enforce compliance with the provisions
of this chapter, and such other code provisions and ordinances dealing with
fire prevention or protection and the national fire prevention and life safety
codes, as adopted.
      2.   Fire And Emergency Medical Services: If available, respond with fire
and emergency medical services to emergency situations within the village and
in conjunction with mutual aid calls involving fire and emergency medical
services, and act as incident commander when ordered.
      3.   Training Activities: Assist the department of fire and emergency
medical services with training activities, records management systems
administration, and liaison with the office of the state fire marshal to
provide all mandated information.
      4.   Inspections: Coordinate and perform fire and life safety inspections
in all business, commercial, medical and education buildings, and prepare
inspection reports and enter information into databases for follow up and
statistics. (Ord. 16-2832, 3-28-2016)
 
Notes
1 1. See title 2, chapter 3 of this code.
1-9F-2: FIRE SUPPRESSION AND EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICES:
   A.   Fire Suppression Forces: Fire suppression forces shall provide for the
effective response, extinguishment and investigation of fire incidents so as to
reduce fire loss and fire related injury.
   B.   Emergency Medical Services Personnel: Emergency medical services
personnel shall provide an effective emergency medical service system with
informed citizens, trained first responders, trained advanced life support and
basic life support response and transport coordinated with the local hospitals.
   C.   Rules And Regulations At Fires:
      1.   Prescribing Limits At Fires: The director or other officers in
command at any fire may prescribe limits in the vicinity of the fire within
which no persons, excepting those who reside therein, firefighters, police
officers, officers of the village and those admitted by any officer of the
department shall be permitted to go.
      2.   Removal Of Property: The director, or in his absence the officer in
charge, shall have power to cause the removal of any property whenever it shall
become necessary for the preservation of said property from fire or to prevent
the spreading of fire or to protect adjoining properties.
      3.   Destruction Of Buildings: The director, or his designee, may direct
the members of the department to tear down and remove any building, structure
or fence for the purpose of checking the progress of any fire and in case of
need may blow up or cause to be blown up, with powder or otherwise, any
building or erection, during the process of a fire, for the purpose of
extinguishing or checking the same.
   D.   Uniform And Badge: The director, subject to the approval of the village
manager, shall issue regulations under which the officers and other
firefighters of the department shall be required to wear an appropriate uniform
or badge by which, in case of fire or other emergency, the authority of such
officers and other firefighters in the department may be known.
   E.   Police Power Of Firefighters: The director or the other officers in
command and any member of the department shall have the power and authority
during the time of a fire to arrest any person suspected of causing a fire or
any person hindering, resisting or conducting himself in a disorderly manner or
refusing to obey any such firefighter while acting in the discharge of his
duties and, as soon as his duties in relation to the extinguishment of the fire
will permit, to take such person before the proper village officer to be dealt
with according to law. All firefighters shall, during such time, be severally
vested with the usual power and authority of police officers to command all
persons to assist them in the performance of such duty.
   F.   Residency Requirement For Full Time Firefighter/Paramedics (Suspended
As Of December 31, 1998):
      1.   Residency Requirement: Effective February 1, 1992, all newly
appointed, sworn, full time firefighter/paramedics shall live within five (5)
miles of the corporate limits of the village.
      2.   Residency Compliance: Probationary firefighter/paramedics hired
after May 1, 1992, need not live within the five (5) mile limit during the term
of their probationary status. However, within one year after the date of their
appointment to the position of a sworn firefighter/paramedic, they shall
establish residency within the five (5) mile limit.
      3.   Purpose: Said residency requirement is established for the purpose
of helping to ensure that all full time, sworn firefighter/paramedics will be
available for callback for emergencies with a minimum of delay.
      4.   Promotion: Notwithstanding the foregoing, any existing sworn, full
time firefighter/paramedics who are promoted in rank shall comply with said
residency requirement within one year from the effective date of said
promotion.
      5.   Residency Requirement Suspended: The residency requirement has been
suspended as of December 31, 1998, when the Village abolished all filled and
unfilled positions of sworn, full time firefighter/paramedics.
      6.   Contract Fire And EMS Personnel: There is no residency requirement
for contractual firefighter/paramedics employed by the Village.
   G.   Ambulance Fee:
      1.   Fee; Due Date: Any “resident” and “nonresident”, as hereafter
defined, who is provided with ambulance services or any of the below listed
emergency medical services by the Western Springs Department of Fire and
Emergency Medical Services shall pay to the Village the fees for such ambulance
services and emergency medical services rendered within or outside of the
corporate limits by the Western Springs Department of Fire and Emergency
Medical Services. These fees shall be paid within thirty (30) days of the
mailing or the delivery of an invoice issued by the Village or its billing
agent. (Ord. 13-2718, 5-20-2013)
      2.   Fees Enumerated: The fees, payable for each person served with
ambulance services or emergency medical services are as follows:
FEES FOR AMBULANCE SERVICES AND EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICES
 
                                          Resident Fees      Nonresident Fees
Ambulance service (basic life support     $1,999.00         $1,999.00  
services)
Ambulance service (advanced life support  $1,999.00         $1,999.00  
services #1)
Ambulance service (advanced life support  1,999.00          1,999.00   
services #2)
Extrication                               250.00            250.00

transported, mileage will be calculated   20.00     per mile 20.00     per mile
