hearings supervisor's function is to expedite the prosecution and/or correction
of code violations subject to the jurisdiction of the administrative
adjudication system. The administrative hearings supervisor is authorized to
manage the administrative adjudication process in the manner provided for in
this chapter, which shall include determining the qualifications of
administrative hearing officers, appointing administrative hearing officers,
and establishing such rules and regulations as may be necessary for the
effective operation of the administrative adjudication system. The
administrative hearings supervisor may also appoint other persons to assist
with the administrative adjudication system provided for in this chapter. (Ord.
03-2258, 8-11-2003)
1-18-4: SCOPE OF AUTHORITY OF ADMINISTRATIVE HEARING OFFICERS:
Administrative hearing officers shall preside over administrative hearings. The
authority of an administrative hearing officer shall encompass all acts
necessary to conduct fair and impartial administrative hearings, including, but
not limited to:
   A.   Hearing testimony and accepting evidence relevant to the existence of a
code violation.
   B.   Administering oaths and affirmations to witnesses.
   C.   Asking questions of the parties and witnesses, if necessary, to ensure
the clarity and completeness of the testimony and the record.
   D.   At the request of any party or on the administrative hearing officer's
own motion, issuing subpoenas for the attendance of relevant witnesses and/or
the production of relevant books, records, or other information.
   E.   Preserving and authenticating the transcript and record of the hearing,
including all exhibits and evidence admitted into the record at the hearing.
   F.   Issuing a determination of whether a code violation exists in the form
of a written finding, decision and order, based upon a review of the notice of
violation, citation, other charging document, and on the evidence admitted, as
set forth in section
1-18-6 of this chapter. (Ord. 03-2258, 8-11-2003)
   G.   Upon finding a respondent liable for violating one or more charged code
provisions:
      1.   Imposing penalties as provided by the governing penalty provision of
this section, except, however, that in no event shall an administrative hearing
officer have authority to: a) impose a penalty of incarceration, or b) impose a
fine in excess of seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for an individual
violation, excluding allowable costs. When applicable, each day a code
provision is found to have been violated by the respondent shall constitute a
separate offense, and each separate offense subjects the respondent to the
penalty provided by the governing penalty provision.
      2.   Imposing administrative and/or enforcement costs in addition to
fines, and, when applicable, imposing costs incurred by the village for
effecting compliance with code provision(s) for which a respondent has been
found liable.
      3.   Ordering, notwithstanding fines imposed or costs assessed, the
respondent to correct the code violation or to otherwise comply with code
provision(s) found to have been violated.
      4.   Ordering, regardless of fines imposed or costs assessed, the
respondent to perform a term of community service.
      5.   Ordering forfeiture of all or part of bond money deposited by a
respondent in a case involving a violation of the overweight provisions of the
Illinois motor vehicle code, as incorporated by section
7-7-6 of this code, if respondent is found guilty of or pleads guilty to the
violation or fails to appear at the hearing. (Ord. 08-2486, 2-25-2008)
   H.   Adhering to the policies, procedures, and ordinances set forth in this
code, as amended, except where discretion is specifically vested in the
administrative hearing officer; provided, however, that an administrative
hearing officer is authorized to waive the fine and/or costs that otherwise
would be imposed upon finding a respondent liable for one or more code
violations when the administrative hearing officer specifically finds as a
matter of fact that the violation occurred under such circumstances that, as a
reasonable person, would constitute an excuse for the violation.
   I.   Regulating the course of the hearing in accordance with this chapter,
the rules adopted by the administrative hearings supervisor for the conduct of
administrative hearings, and other applicable law. (Ord. 03-2258, 8-11-2003)
1-18-5: PROCEDURE:
All matters to be adjudicated by the code hearing department shall be commenced
against the party alleged to have violated one or more code provisions by
issuing and serving upon that party a notice of violation, citation, or other
charging document (hereinafter, "charging document"), and shall be conducted in
accordance with the following procedures:
   A.   Issuance: The charging document shall be issued by a village officer or
employee authorized to issue a code violation and served as provided for in
subsection B of this section.
      1.   Notice: Any charging document issued pursuant to this section shall
be on a multiple copy violation notice and report form that contains the
following information:
         a.   The name; village department; position; and identification
number, if applicable, of the person issuing the charging document;
         b.   The name and address of the person or entity being charged with
one or more code violations ("respondent");
         c.   The section(s) of the code alleged to have been violated;
         d.   A legally sufficient description of the activity or conduct
alleged to constitute a violation of each code section set forth in the
charging document or a legally sufficient description of the facts giving rise
to the allegations set forth in the charging document;
         e.   The date, time, and place the alleged violation was observed;
         f.   The names of any witnesses to the alleged violation;
         g.   The complainant's name if the complainant is not the issuing
village officer or employee; and
         h.   The signature of the person issuing the charging document and the
date of issuance.
      2.   Certification: The village officer or employee shall certify the
correctness of the information required by this section by signing his or her
name to the charging document to be issued. Compliance with this section shall
establish a prima facie case.
   B.   Docketing; Hearing Date: The charging document shall be forwarded to
the code hearing department where a docket number shall be stamped on all
copies of the report and a hearing date shall be noted in the blank spaces
provided for that purpose on the form. The hearing date shall not be less than
thirty (30) nor more than forty (40) days after the violation is reported.
      1.   Notice: The respondent named in a charging document shall be given
notice of the alleged violation(s), date of the administrative hearing, the
legal authority and jurisdiction under which the hearing will be held, and the
potential penalties for failure to appear at the hearing. Notice is to be
provided by serving a copy of the charging document on the respondent by first
class mail in an envelope addressed to the respondent's current or last known
residence, along with a summons commanding the respondent to appear at the
hearing. One copy of the charging document shall be maintained in the files of
the code hearing department and shall be part of the record of the
administrative hearing and one copy of the charging document shall be returned
to the individual representing the village in the case so that he or she may
prepare evidence of the code violation for presentation at the hearing on the
date indicated. (Ord. 03-2258, 8-11-2003)
1-18-6: ADMINISTRATIVE HEARINGS:
All administrative hearings conducted by the code hearing department are open
to the public and shall be presided over by a duly appointed administrative
hearing officer who is charged with providing the parties a full and fair
opportunity to be heard. The procedures for conducting an administrative
hearing shall be as follows:
   A.   The case for the village may be presented by a village employee, or by
an attorney designated by the village attorney. The case for the village may
not be presented by an employee or other representative of the code hearing
department, provided, however, that documentary evidence, prepared by another
department of the village and submitted to the code hearing department, may be
presented at the hearing by the administrative hearing officer.
   B.   The case for the respondent may be presented by the respondent or by an
attorney or other representative of the respondent. An attorney or
representative appearing at an administrative hearing on behalf of a respondent
shall present the administrative hearing officer with a signed appearance form
stating, on oath or affirmation, that he or she has been authorized by the
respondent to represent the respondent at the hearing.
   C.   All administrative hearings shall be conducted on the date set for
hearing. No continuances shall be granted except where absolutely necessary to
protect the rights of the respondent. Lack of preparation shall not be grounds
for a continuance. Any continuances granted shall not exceed twenty five (25)
consecutive calendar days.
   D.   Both parties may present evidence relevant to the existence or
nonexistence of a code violation, present witnesses, and cross examine opposing
witnesses.
   E.   The formal and technical rules of evidence shall not apply in the
conduct of the hearing. Evidence, including hearsay, may be admitted only if it
is of a type commonly relied upon by reasonably prudent persons in the conduct
of their affairs.
   F.   No violation may be established except upon proof by a preponderance of
the evidence; provided, however, that the original or a legible copy of the
charging document, issued in accordance with the applicable provisions of this
code, shall be prima facie evidence of the correctness of the facts specified
therein.
   G.   At the conclusion of the hearing, the administrative hearing officer
shall make a determination on the basis of the evidence presented at the
hearing as to whether or not a code violation exists. The administrative
hearing officer may issue the following determinations: liable, not liable, or
liable upon a plea of no contest. The administrative hearing officer also may
dismiss the case with or without prejudice or grant a properly made motion by
the village voluntarily dismissing the case. If the administrative hearing
officer issues a final determination of liability, he may impose fines, assess
costs, and make orders, all as provided by subsection
1-18-4G of this chapter, and as are consistent with the specific code provision
(s) found to have been violated.
   H.   The administrative hearing officer shall inform the parties orally and
in writing of his determination. The written determination shall be designated
as "findings, decision, and order" and shall include the hearing officer's
findings of fact, a decision of whether or not a code violation exists based
upon the findings of fact, and an order that states the sanction or dismisses
the case if a violation is not proved. A copy of the findings, decision, and
order shall be served on the respondent within five (5) days after it is issued
by first class mail as provided in subsection
1-18-5B of this chapter.
   I.   The administrative hearing officer's findings, decision and order
constitutes a final determination for purposes of judicial review. Either party
may seek review under the Illinois administrative review law 1 .
   J.   The administrative hearings supervisor shall determine the manner in
which the record of the hearing shall be preserved. Such preservation may be
made by tape recording or other appropriate means. Recording by any means by
any member of the public is prohibited unless expressly authorized by the
administrative hearings supervisor. The record of all hearings before an
administrative hearing officer shall include a copy of the findings, decision,
and order of the administrative hearing officer's final determination. (Ord.
03-2258, 8-11-2003)
 
Notes
1 1. 735 ILCS 5/3-101 et seq.
1-18-7: DEFAULT:
If at the time set for hearing, the respondent, or his attorney or
representative of record, fails to appear, the administrative hearing officer
may find the respondent in default and proceed with the hearing and accept
evidence relevant to the existence of a code violation. Upon entering a default
judgment of liability against the respondent, the administrative hearing
officer may impose fines and assess costs. A copy of the order of default shall
be served on the respondent by first class mail as provided in subsection
1-18-5B of this chapter.
   A.   A copy of the default judgment, which constitutes a final determination
for purposes of judicial review and is subject to review under the Illinois
administrative review law 1 , shall apprise the respondent of the availability
of an appeal of the default judgment to the circuit court of Cook County. (Ord.
03-2258, 8-11-2003)
 
Notes
1 1. 735 ILCS 5/3-101 et seq.
1-18-8: ENFORCEMENT OF ADMINISTRATIVE HEARING OFFICER'S ORDER:
   A.   Any fine, other sanction, or administrative, enforcement, or compliance
costs, or part of any such fine, other sanction or costs, imposed by an
administrative hearing officer's order that remain unpaid after the exhaustion
of, or the failure to exhaust, judicial review procedures, shall be a debt due
and owing the village and may be collected in accordance with applicable law.
   B.   After the expiration of the period for which judicial review of a final
determination may be sought, the village may commence a proceeding in the
circuit court of Cook County for the purpose of obtaining a judgment on the
findings, decision, and order. The village may consolidate multiple findings,
decisions, and orders against the same respondent under a single petition in a
single proceeding. Upon commencement of the action, the village shall file a
certified copy of the findings, decision, and order, which shall be accompanied
by a certification that recites facts sufficient to show that the findings,
decision, and order was issued in accordance with this chapter and division 2.2
of the Illinois municipal code.
   C.   Service of the summons and a copy of the petition may be made by any
method provided for by section 2-203 of the Illinois code of civil procedure 1
or by certified mail, return receipt requested, provided that the total amount
of fines, other sanctions, and costs imposed by the findings, decision, and
order does not exceed two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00).
   D.   If the court is satisfied that the findings, decision, and order was
entered in accordance with the requirements of this chapter and division 2.2 of
the Illinois municipal code, and that the respondent had an opportunity for an
administrative hearing and judicial review:
      1.   The court shall render judgment in favor of the village and against
the respondent for the amount indicated in the findings, decision, and order,
plus costs. The judgment shall have the same effect and may be enforced in the
same manner as other judgments for the recovery of money.
      2.   The court may also issue any other orders and injunctions that are
requested by the village to enforce the order of the administrative hearing
officer to correct a code violation. (Ord. 03-2258, 8-11-2003)
 
Notes
1 2. 735 ILCS 5/2-203.
1-18-9: ELECTION OF REMEDIES:
In no case may the code hearing department conduct an administrative hearing
for an alleged code violation where the remedy provided for is a punishment of
imprisonment. Nothing in this chapter, however, shall preclude the village from
petitioning a court of competent jurisdiction to adjudicate any ordinance
violation, which provides the remedy of imprisonment, or from petitioning a
court of competent jurisdiction to impose the remedy of imprisonment for
failure to comply with an order of an administrative hearing officer. (Ord. 03-
2258, 8-11-2003)
CHAPTER 19
ADMINISTRATIVE ADJUDICATION OF BUILDING CODE VIOLATIONS
SECTION:
1-19-1: Creation Of Administrative Adjudication System
1-19-2: Jurisdiction
1-19-3: Code Hearing Department; Administrative Hearings Supervisor
1-19-4: Scope Of Authority Of Administrative Hearing Officers
1-19-5: Procedure
1-19-6: Administrative Hearings
1-19-7: Default
1-19-8: Enforcement Of Administrative Hearing Officer's Order
1-19-9: Election Of Remedies
1-19-10: Eviction; Rights Of Occupants
1-19-11: Defenses To Code Violations
1-19-12: Sanctions Applicable To Respondent-Owner; Real Property
1-19-1: CREATION OF ADMINISTRATIVE ADJUDICATION SYSTEM:
   A.   Pursuant to division 31.1 of title 11 of the Illinois municipal code 1
, which authorizes municipalities to implement a system of administrative
adjudication of violations of any municipal ordinance, law, housing or building
code or zoning ordinance that establishes construction, plumbing, heating,
electrical, fire prevention, sanitation or other health and safety standards
that are applicable to structures in a municipality or any municipal ordinance
that requires, after notice, the cutting of weeds, the removal of garbage and
debris, the removal of inoperable motor vehicles, or the abatement of nuisances
from private property, there is created within the department of fire and
inspectional services a code hearing department to implement an administrative
adjudication system for charges of violations of this code, as amended.
   B.   The village adopts division 31.1 of title 11 of the Illinois municipal
code 2 , as it may be amended from time to time. The adoption of division 31.1
of title 11 does not preclude the village from using other lawful methods to
enforce the provisions of this code. (Ord. 03-2259, 8-11-2003)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/11-31.1-1 et seq.
2 2. 65 ILCS 5/11-31.1-1 et seq.
1-19-2: JURISDICTION:
Those matters subject to the administrative adjudication system authorized by
this chapter are charges of violations of any village ordinance, housing or
building code or zoning ordinance establishing construction, plumbing, heating,
electrical, fire prevention, sanitation or other health and safety standards
that are applicable to structures located in the village, or any ordinance of
the village requiring, after notice, the cutting of weeds, the removal of
garbage and debris, the removal of inoperable motor vehicles, or the abatement
of nuisances from private property, so long as the relief sought is not a
penalty of incarceration. (Ord. 03-2259, 8-11-2003)
1-19-3: CODE HEARING DEPARTMENT; ADMINISTRATIVE HEARINGS SUPERVISOR:
The establishment of the position of administrative hearings supervisor, and
functions and authority of said supervisor under the administrative
adjudication system authorized by this chapter, shall be the same as and in
accordance with the provisions of section
1-18-3 of this title, as amended, which are incorporated herein by reference.
(Ord. 03-2259, 8-11-2003)
1-19-4: SCOPE OF AUTHORITY OF ADMINISTRATIVE HEARING OFFICERS:
The establishment of the position of administrative hearing officer, and the
functions and authority of said officer under the administrative adjudication
system authorized by this chapter, shall be the same as and in accordance with
the provisions of section
1-18-4 of this title, as amended, which are incorporated herein by reference.
(Ord. 03-2259, 8-11-2003)
1-19-5: PROCEDURE:
All matters to be adjudicated by the code hearing department under the
administrative adjudication system authorized in this chapter shall be
commenced by a building inspector who, upon finding a code violation while
inspecting a structure, shall note the violation on a multiple copy violation
notice and report form, indicating the name and address of the structure owner,
the address of the structure where the violation is observed, and the other
information required in subsection
1-18-5A1 of this title. In all other respects, the relevant procedures under
this chapter shall be in accordance with the provisions of section
1-18-5 of this title, as amended, which are incorporated herein by reference,
except that the respondent given notice as set forth in subsection
1-18-5B of this title shall be the owner of the structure. If the name of the
respondent-owner of the structure cannot be ascertained or if service cannot be
made by mail, service may be made on the respondent-owner by posting or nailing
a copy of the charging document on the front door of the structure where the
violation is found, not less than twenty (20) days before the hearing is
scheduled. (Ord. 03-2259, 8-11-2003)
1-19-6: ADMINISTRATIVE HEARINGS:
Administrative hearings conducted by the code hearing department under the
administrative adjudication system authorized in this chapter shall be
conducted in accordance with the provisions of section
1-18-6 of this title, as amended, which are incorporated herein by reference.
(Ord. 03-2259, 8-11-2003)
1-19-7: DEFAULT:
All defaults under the administrative adjudication system authorized by this
chapter shall be in accordance with the provisions of section
1-18-7 of this title, as amended, which are incorporated herein by reference.
(Ord. 03-2259, 8-11-2003)
1-19-8: ENFORCEMENT OF ADMINISTRATIVE HEARING OFFICER'S ORDER:
Enforcement of an administrative hearing officer's order under the
administrative adjudication system authorized by this chapter shall be in
accordance with the provisions of section
1-18-8 of this title, as amended, which are incorporated herein by reference,
except that any certification filed with the circuit court of Cook County under
this chapter shall recite facts sufficient to show that the findings, decision,
and order was issued in accordance with this chapter and division 31.1 of the
Illinois municipal code. (Ord. 03-2259, 8-11-2003)
1-19-9: ELECTION OF REMEDIES:
Election of remedies under the administrative adjudication system authorized by
this chapter shall be in accordance with the provisions of section
1-18-9 of this title, as amended, which are incorporated herein by reference.
(Ord. 03-2259, 8-11-2003)
1-19-10: EVICTION; RIGHTS OF OCCUPANTS:
No action for eviction, abatement of a nuisance, forcible entry and detainer,
or other similar proceedings shall be threatened or instituted against an
occupant of a dwelling solely because such occupant agrees to testify or
testifies at an administrative hearing relative to a code violation under the
administrative adjudication system authorized by this chapter. (Ord. 03-2259,
8-11-2003)
1-19-11: DEFENSES TO CODE VIOLATIONS:
In any administrative hearing conducted under the administrative adjudication
system authorized by this chapter, it shall be a defense to a code violation if
the respondent-owner, his attorney, or any other representative proves to the
satisfaction of the administrative hearing officer that:
   A.   The code violation alleged in the charging document does not in fact
exist, or at the time of the hearing the violation has been remedied or
removed.
   B.   The code violation has been caused by the current property occupants
and that in spite of reasonable attempts by the respondent-owner to maintain
the premises or dwelling free of such violations, the current occupants
continue to cause the violations.
   C.   An occupant or resident of the dwelling has refused entry to the
respondent-owner or his agent to all or a part of the premises or the dwelling
for the purpose of correcting the code violation. (Ord. 03-2259, 8-11-2003)
1-19-12: SANCTIONS APPLICABLE TO RESPONDENT-OWNER; REAL PROPERTY:
The order to correct a code violation and the sanctions imposed by the village
as the result of a finding of a code violation under this chapter shall attach
to the real property as well as to the respondent-owner of the real property,
so that a finding of a code violation against one owner cannot be avoided by
conveying or transferring the real property to another owner. The village has
the right to record with the Cook County recorder of deeds and against title to
the real property a notice of violation and/or the findings, decision and
order. The village shall file a release of said notice or order upon correction
of the code violation with the Cook County recorder of deeds. The property
owner shall be responsible for the payment of all legal fees and recording
costs associated with the preparation and filing of said notice or order and
said release. Any subsequent transferee or owner of real property takes subject
to the findings, decision and order of an administrative hearing officer under
this chapter. (Ord. 03-2259, 8-11-2003)
CHAPTER 20
RULES AND PROCEDURES FOR LAND USE PUBLIC HEARINGS
SECTION:
1-20-1: Findings
1-20-2: Definitions
1-20-3: Rules And Procedures
1-20-1: FINDINGS:
The president and board of trustees find and declare that it is in the best
interests of the village of Western Springs to amend the municipal code to
specifically provide a general set of rules and regulations to guide all
village boards, commissions and committees that conduct statutory public
hearings relative to land use approvals, including special uses, variations,
rezoning and planned unit developments, in accordance with the decision of the
Illinois supreme court in Klaeren v. Village of Lisle, 202 Ill.2d 164, 781
N.E.2d 223 (2002). (Ord. 03-2268, 11-24-2003)
1-20-2: DEFINITIONS:
For purposes of interpreting these rules and procedures, the following
definitions apply:
INTERESTED PERSON: Includes, but is not limited to: village residents, village
staff, members of the public and any attorney or consultant appearing on behalf
of the village, village residents or members of the public.
OBJECTOR: Any person who desires to object to a filed application for zoning
relief and his or her attorney or consultant.
PETITIONER: Any person who has filed an application for zoning relief and his
or her attorney or consultant.
PUBLIC BODY: The Western Springs village board, plan commission, zoning board
of appeals and any other board, committee and commission. (Ord. 03-2268, 11-24-
2003)
1-20-3: RULES AND PROCEDURES:
The following rules and procedures shall apply to all public hearing
proceedings:
   A.   Notice Requirements: Notice requirements for a public hearing are found
in the Illinois municipal code 1  and in the development control ordinance
(title 10, "Development Control Ordinance", of this code). It is the
responsibility of the petitioner to ensure that any required notice is given in
a timely manner, consistent with statutory and ordinance requirements.
      For example, section 11-13-1.1 of the Illinois municipal code, 65
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-13-1.1, provides that "a special use shall be
permitted only after a public hearing before some commission or committee
designated by the corporate authorities, with prior notice thereof given in the
manner as provided in sections 11-13-6 and 11-13-7". While the notice
provisions of sections 11-13-6 and 11-13-7 apply only to municipalities with
five hundred thousand (500,000) or more in population, the notice requirement
of section 11-13-1.1 applies to all municipalities, regardless of population.
Therefore, notice of the time and place of the public hearing for special uses
must be published, at least once, not more than thirty (30) nor less than
fifteen (15) days prior to the public hearing, in a newspaper of general
circulation in the municipality. In addition, written notice, either personally
delivered or sent by certified mail, must be provided to the owners, as
recorded in the office of the recorder of deeds and as appears from the tax
records of the county, for all property located within two hundred fifty feet
(250') in any direction from the location for which the special use is
requested. The notice must contain the address of the location for which the
special use is requested, a brief statement of the nature of the special use
requested, the name     and address of the legal and beneficial owner of the
property for which the special use is requested, and a statement that the
applicant intends to file an application for special use and the date upon
which the application will be filed.
These above notice requirements for all land use matters requiring a public
hearing are generally set forth in the development control ordinance, including
chapters 3, "Administrative Procedures", 8, "Planned Developments" and 10,
"Subdivisions".
   B.   Compliance With Illinois Open Meetings Act And Village Procedures,
Protocols And Regulations For Remote Meetings And Electronic Attendance At
Meetings: All public hearings of a public body are meetings as defined by the
Illinois open meetings act 1 . The Illinois open meetings act must be adhered
to in all instances, including the village rules and procedures set forth in
section 1-21-1 (Participation In Meetings By Telephone Conference Call Or Other
Electronic Means) and the village procedures, protocols and regulations for
remote meetings, which were adopted by the village pursuant to sections 2.01
and 7 of the open meetings act (120 ILCS 5/2.01 and 7). See, Village President
Declaration No. 2020-03 (Declaration Of A State Of Emergency In The Village Of
Western Springs, Cook County, Illinois (Covid 19 - November 9, 2020) (Disaster
Declaration and Remote Meeting Rules). The open meetings act requires that a
verbatim record of all closed meetings of public bodies be kept in the form of
an audio or video recording. Under these rules and procedures, the public body
shall make verbatim audiotape recordings of its closed session meetings. No
final action (or final vote) may be taken on any matter in a closed session 2
. Subject to compliance with applicable laws, the village reserves the right
when conducting any public hearing to allow the petitioner and its
representatives and consultants, the village officials, representatives and
consultants, and the public to attend and participate in the public hearing by
one (1) or more methods:
      1.   In-person attendance, subject to maximum room occupancy limitations
mandated by state, county or local occupancy and health/life safety laws and
regulations;
      2.   By an internet-based electronic audio and video meeting platform
(the Zoom App); and/or
      3.   By dial-in conference call line as an alternate means of public
participation.
   C.   Registration To Participate In Public Hearings: All individuals
desiring to participate in the public hearing process shall register with the
community development department during normal business hours or immediately
prior to the commencement of the public hearing with the village staff liaison,
or his/her designee, or during the public hearing, provided that they do not
disturb the proceedings. A registration form is available on the village’s
website or from the community development department. This form can be used for
a specific public hearing or for multiple public hearings to be heard at one
meeting of the public body. A link for information on how to attend and
participate in the public hearing, including the meeting ID number and access
code for the internet-based audio and video meeting platforms (e.g., Zoom app),
the dial-in conference call number, and the village rules and procedures for
land use public hearings, will be posted to https://wsprings.com/calendar at
least two (2) hours before each public hearing. In order to electronically
participate in a public hearing by providing verbal testimony or written
evidence or conducting cross- examination of any witnesses, you are required to
submit your records to and pre-register by email or over the phone with the
director of community development (708-246-1800 ext. 175) at least forty-eight
(48) hours before the public hearing. The contact information for the director
of community development is available on the village’s website
(www.wsprings.com) or by calling the village’s general information number of
708-246-1800. The pre-registration requirement provides the village with an
opportunity to ensure that any audio and visual technological needs can be
accommodated and that any referenced or submitted documents can be made
available in advance for review by members of the public body, the petitioner
and its representatives and consultants, the village staff and consultants, and
the general public. The intent of the pre-registration requirement is to
provide all interested persons with the opportunity to attend and participate
in public hearings scheduled by the village and to ensure that the public
hearing is conducted in an efficient, fair and transparent manner. The pre-
registration requirement and any other provision of these rules should not be
applied in an unreasonable manner to deny any person the opportunity to attend
and participate in a public hearing.
   D.   Representation: At a public hearing, a petitioner, objector or other
interested persons may appear on his or her own behalf or may be represented by
an attorney.
   E.   Introductory Matters: Prior to the commencement of the public hearing,
the chair will determine whether there are any objectors or other interested
persons and if an attorney represents any objector, group of objectors or
interested persons. The chair will also determine whether any parties have
evidence or testimony to be admitted. The chair may make prefatory comments
indicating the order of presentation, the ability to ask questions and to
present testimony. The chair will also explain that during the time for
questioning witnesses, testimony should not be given by the person asking
questions. All members of the public body participating in the meeting or
public hearing, wherever their physical location, shall be verified and must be
able to hear one another and must be able to hear all discussion and testimony
of all other attendees.
   F.   Order Of Presentation: Unless the chair decides to alter the order of
presentation, the general order of presentation will be as follows:
      1.   Opening of public hearing.
      2.   Acknowledgment of names of attendees participating remotely.
      3.   Swearing in petitioner, objectors and interested persons.
      4.   Confirmation of notices being published and mailed in accordance
with state law and municipal code requirements.
      5.   Petitioner presentation.
         a.   Cross examination.
         b.   Questions by public body.
      6.   Village staff presentation.
         a.   Cross examination.
         b.   Questions by public body.
         c.   Rebuttal.
      7.   Objectors presentation(s) * .
         a.   Cross examination.
         b.   Questions by public body.
      8.   Interested persons presentation(s).
         a.   Cross examination.
         b.   Questions by public body.
         c.   Rebuttal.
      9.   Petitioner rebuttal.
      10.   Final questions by public body.
      11.   Closing remarks by petitioner, objectors, interested persons and
village staff.
      12. Close or continuation of public hearing.
      *   For remote public hearing proceedings conducted pursuant to section 7
(e) of the open meetings act, after the presentations by the petitioner and
village staff, the chair will first allow objectors or interested persons who
are present in- person to ask questions or provide comment or testimony, and
then the chair will open the public hearing to objectors or interested persons
who attend remotely. All persons attending remotely must follow any
participation protocols explained by the chair during the public hearing.
   G.   Rules Of Evidence: The chair may impose reasonable limitations on
evidence or testimony presented by persons and parties, such as barring
repetitious, irrelevant or immaterial testimony. The public body shall not be
bound by strict rules of evidence; however, irrelevant, immaterial or unduly
repetitious evidence shall not be admissible. The chair shall rule on all
questions related to the admissibility of evidence, which ruling may be
overruled by a majority of at least a quorum of the public body.
   H.   Authority Of Chair: The chair may take such actions as are required to
maintain an orderly and civil hearing, and may take such further actions to
ensure that all public hearings are conducted in an efficient, fair and
transparent manner.
   I.   Record Of Proceedings: All public hearings must have a record of
proceedings. For major presentations, matters where objectors will be
participating and matters believed to be controversial, the public hearing will
be transcribed by a certified court reporter at the cost of the petitioner.
Other public hearings may be recorded by use of a tape recorder or as part of
the internet-based audio and video meeting platform. Care should be made to
ensure the tape recorder is functioning and will be audible to a person seeking
to understand the proceedings.
   J.   Burden Of Proof; Oath: Since the petitioner has the burden of proof,
the petitioner should present his or her evidence and witnesses first. All
persons offering testimony at a hearing shall testify under oath. An attorney
shall be sworn if he or she offers testimony but not if he or she is
questioning witnesses, summarizing testimony of witnesses, or addressing the
public body.
   K.   Exhibits: All exhibits shall be clearly and distinctly marked by the
person offering the exhibit into the record and the exhibit number or letter
shall be identified when the exhibit is used at or referred to during the
public hearing.
   L.   Cross-examination: After each witness has testified, objectors and
interested persons will have the right to ask questions or cross examine the
witness. There is no time limit placed upon cross examination, but if a
question has already been asked by some person, the chair may refuse to allow a
second person to ask the same question. Questions must be relevant and material
to the public hearing proceeding. The examination of a witness shall not be
used by the questioner to offer testimony or evidence of the questioner.
   M.   Questions By Public Body: After all objectors or interested persons
have asked questions, the members of the public body may ask questions of each
witness.
   N.   Objectors Or Interested Persons: After all petitioner witnesses have
testified and all evidence for the petitioner has been presented, members of
the objectors or interested persons may testify or present evidence. There is
no time limit on the presentation by members of the public. The petitioner and
other members of the general public may cross examine any witness of objectors
or interested persons who testifies.
   O.   Rebuttal: After the conclusion of the objector or interested persons
testimony, the petitioner may offer rebuttal witnesses or evidence.
   P.   Village Presentation: Then village staff may make a presentation or
report. Staff presenting a report will be subject to cross examination by the
petitioner or objector or other interested persons.
   Q.   Identification Of Participants: All individuals testifying or
participating shall identify themselves (and their current place of residence)
for the record, either orally or in writing, and indicate if an attorney
represents them, or if they are representing any person or appearing on behalf
of any other person, association, corporation or entity. Any person
participating, other than the petitioner, shall be referred to in these rules
as an objector or interested person.
   R.   Closing Remarks: The petitioner, objectors and interested persons may
be given the opportunity to make closing remarks.
   S.   Continuance: If a hearing needs to be continued to another date in
order for a full presentation by all parties, then it may be continued to a
date and time selected by the public body and approved by a motion of the
public body.
   T.   Deliberation By Public Body: At the conclusion of the public hearing,
the public body may move to deliberate its decision on the evidence presented,
recess to closed session to deliberate its decision on the evidence presented
(if the proper motion is approved by a majority under a roll call vote), or
continue the hearing to a specific date, time and location by a motion approved
by a roll call vote.
   U.   Decision; Ordinance: A written decision shall be prepared which shall
include findings of fact and the public body's recommendation or decision based
upon the record. An ordinance approving or denying the application may be a
sufficient written decision if it contains appropriate findings of fact
concerning the relevant standards to be applied by the public body.
   V.   Additional Rules For Remote Meetings And Public Hearings:
      1.   Pursuant to section 7(e) of the open meetings act, the following
additional rules shall apply:
         a.   Access: After the village president and/or the chair, in their
sole discretion, has determined that in-person meeting(s) or public hearing(s)
conducted under OMA is not practical or prudent because of a disaster, the
village manager, or his/her designee, may decide to allow such meeting(s) or
public hearing(s) to proceed remotely, whether fully or in-part. In determining
whether it is necessary to proceed remotely, the village shall consider the
type and nature of the meeting or hearing along with any emergency
proclamations, executive orders and public health guidelines in place at the
time of the meeting or hearing. The village, in its discretion, may allow the
meeting or hearing to proceed with:
            (1)   In-person attendance as allowed under any active public
health guidelines with live stream audio with or without video of the meeting
or hearing available at alternative locations to accommodate overflow capacity
and allow for social distancing; and/or
            (2)   An internet- based audio/video meeting platform such as Zoom;
and/or
            (3)   Conference call lines that allow members of the public to
call in to participate in the meeting or hearing.
         b.   Petitioner Consent: Prior to the commencement of a public
hearing, the petitioner must sign a written consent acknowledging their choice
to proceed with a virtual/remote public hearing and assuming any risk that the
hearing process may be held defective.
         c.   Mandatory Physical Presence: At least one (1) member of the
public body, chief legal counsel or chief administrative officer must be
physically present at the scheduled meeting or public hearing location (e.g.,
village hall) during the meeting or public hearing, unless unfeasible due to
the disaster.
         d.   Access Platform And Agenda Posting: The platform for remote,
electronic attendance at the meeting or public hearing will be arranged in
advance by the village manager, or his/her designee, and will be communicated
to the public body and the petitioner at least forty-eight (48) hours prior to
the commencement of the meeting or public hearing. An agenda and information
regarding how to attend the meeting or public hearing, including any remote
access instructions, shall be posted on the village’s website and at the
meeting or public hearing location and at village hall at least forty-eight
(48) hours prior to the commencement of the meeting or public hearing.
         e.   Agenda Content: Information will be printed on the agenda and
prominently on the village’s website about how to provide public comment or
participate in the meeting or public hearing. The agenda shall include at least
the following information in substantially the following form:
            (1)   Attendance at and participation in the meeting or public
hearing by the petitioner and its representatives and consultants, the village
officials, representatives and consultants, and the public may be restricted to
one (1) or more methods: (a) in-person attendance, subject to maximum room
occupancy limitations mandated by state, county or local occupancy and health/
life safety laws and regulations; (b) by an internet- based electronic audio
and video platform (the Zoom app); and/or (c) by dial-in conference call line
as an alternate means of public participation.
            (2)   Members of the public are encouraged to use the internet-
based audio/video platform to watch, listen and participate in the meeting or
public hearing. A link with the meeting ID number and access code to join the
meeting or public hearing will be posted to https://www.wsprings.com/551/
Public-Meeting-Notice at least two (2) hours before commencement of the meeting
or hearing. That page will have more information on use of the internet-based
audio/video platform. Public comments will be allowed using the “raise hand”
function in the internet-based audio/video platform or when recognized by the
chair.
            (3)   Public comments may also be submitted in advance of the
meeting or public hearing by leaving a hard copy in the village drop box or via
email to xxxxxx by three o’clock (3:00) P.M. on the day of the meeting or
public hearing. Your written comments will be read into the public record (if
concise) or included as part of the public record.
         f.   Alternate Access Methods: Any meeting or public hearing allowing
for remote or virtual attendance shall, at the minimum, allow for the use of a
conference call line as an alternate means of participation by the public. If
the meeting or public hearing is utilizing an internet-based audio/video
meeting platform, the village shall provide alternate methods of communication
such as use of a conference call line as a back-up means of communication if
the internet-based audio/video meeting platform has connectivity issues and to
provide members of the public who lack internet access a more traditional means
of communication.
         g.   Civility And Decorum: Anyone participating in the meeting or
public hearing remotely shall be held to the same decorum standards and shall
proceed in a manner as if the person was physically present. Conduct and
comments injurious or disruptive to the progress of the meeting or public
hearing or to the harmony of the public body or comments that engage in a
debate or make direct threats or personal attacks or are uncivil or abusive
will be called to order by the chair and the remote access may be disconnected
if said comments or behavior persist.
         h.   Muted Status: When not speaking, all persons participating
remotely, with the exception of members of the public body, should have their
microphones muted.
         i.   Roll Call Voting: All votes on all matters considered and acted
on at the meeting or public hearing shall be conducted by roll call, so each
member’s vote on each issue can be identified and recorded. Each member
participating remotely shall announce his/her name as part of stating his/her
vote.
         j.   Testimony: All persons who desire to testify will be asked to
raise their right hands and be sworn in at the outset of the meeting or public
hearing. Then, when each speaker begins their individual comments, the chair
shall have them verbally confirm that they have previously been sworn in.
Participants shall be sworn in regardless of their physical location, as if
they were being sworn in and providing testimony in the village. All applicable
rules and laws of the state apply to the meeting or public hearing, the
testimony and the participants, regardless of where any participant is actually
physically located during the meeting or public hearing.
         k.   Verbatim Minutes: In addition to the requirements for open
meetings under section 2.06 of the OMA, the public body must also keep a
verbatim record of all their remote access meetings and public hearings in the
form of an audio or video recording. Verbatim records made under these rules
shall be made available to the public under, and are otherwise subject to, the
provisions of section 2.06 of the OMA.

  protocols explained by the chair during the public hearing.
This policy is designed to provide a generally applicable framework for public
hearings so that full and fair hearings are conducted by the public body. The
public body should know all of the facts concerning a proposed land use and a
thorough and complete hearing process is the best way to learn about the facts
and the issues concerned. (Ord. 03-2268, 11-24-2003; amd. Ord. 21-3040, 4-26-
2021)
CHAPTER 21
MEETINGS
SECTION:
1-21-1: Participation In Meetings By Telephone Conference Call Or Other
Electronic Means
1-21-2: Approval Of Minutes
1-21-3: Public Comment Participation Guidelines At Public Meetings
1-21-1: PARTICIPATION IN MEETINGS BY TELEPHONE CONFERENCE CALL OR OTHER
ELECTRONIC MEANS:
   A.   Findings: Public Act 94-1058, effective January 1, 2007, amends the
open meetings act 1  to allow municipalities to adopt rules and procedures that
permit appointed and elected members of boards, commissions and committees to
attend, participate and vote at open and closed public meetings through the use
of telephone conference calls or other electronic means. The corporate
authorities of the village find that it is in the public interest to adopt a
set of rules and procedures that allow appointed and elected members of village
boards, commissions and committees to attend, participate in and vote at open
and closed public meetings through the use of telephone conference calls or
other electronic means (e.g., video or audio conference). Public Act 101-0640,
effective June 12, 2020, further amends the open meetings act to allow public
bodies to adopt remote meeting rules that allow public meetings and hearings to
be conducted through the use of internet-based audio and video meeting
platforms, telephone conference calls or other electronic means where a quorum
is not physically present, provided the head of the public body determines that
in- person meetings or public hearings are not practical or prudent because of
a disaster and other specific criteria are met.
   B.   Definitions: The definitions of the terms "meeting", "public body",
"other means", "quorum" or any other defined term used in this section, which
is also found in the open meetings act, shall have the same definitions as
contained in the open meetings act 2 , as amended.
   C.   Rules And Procedures:
      1.   Village boards, committees and commissions must comply with all of
the applicable requirements of the open meetings act 3 , as amended.
      2.   Village boards, committees and commissions are prohibited from
establishing a quorum to conduct business at an open or closed meeting through
the attendance of board members by the use of telephone conference calls or
other electronic means. A quorum of members of a village board, commission or
committee must be physically present at the location of an open or closed
meeting.
      3.   Village officials who wish to attend a meeting electronically must
give notice before the commencement of the meeting to the recording secretary
or the village clerk (or deputy clerk), unless advance notice is impractical.
      4.   Meeting minutes must reflect whether a member is present physically
or electronically, regardless of whether any members are attending through the
use of a telephone conference call or other electronic means.
      5.   Provided that the audio, telephone or video conference connection
allows the voice of an absent member to be clearly heard by the attendees of
the meeting (including the public) and the absent member can clearly hear the
voices of the attendees who participate in the meeting, a member of a village
board, committee and commission may attend, participate and vote at an open or
closed meeting through the use of a telephone conference call or other
electronic means if the member is prevented from physically attending because
of:
         a.   Personal illness or disability; or
         b.   Employment purposes or the business of the public body; or
         c.   A family or other emergency.
      6.   Where one or more members of a village board, committee and
commission is attending the meeting by use of a telephone conference call or
other electronic means, the presiding officer shall, immediately after
convening of the meeting, announce to the public which member is attending the
meeting by use of a telephone conference call or other electronic means,
identify the method of attendance and the reason why the absent member is
participating by such means.
      7.   If the presiding officer attends the meeting through the use of a
telephone conference call or other electronic means, he or she shall not be
required to vacate the chair and may act in his or her capacity as the
presiding officer for the purposes of the meeting despite not being physically
present.
      8.   The voice of the absent member participating by telephone conference
call or other electronic means, after being identified by the other village
board, committee and commission members as belonging to the absent member,
shall be simultaneously broadcast to the public present at the meeting so that
his or her voice can be heard, and the member shall also be able to hear any
discussions of the other members and the public comment regarding any issue
discussed at the meeting before a vote is taken. (Ord. 06-2414, 10-23-2006)
   9.   Procedures, Protocols And Regulations For Remote Meetings: Pursuant to
sections 2.01 and 7 of the open meetings act (120 ILCS 5/2.01 and 7) (“OMA”),
and for the duration of any Illinois governor issued disaster declaration (a
disaster as defined in section 4 of the Illinois emergency management agency
act), the village shall comply with the procedures, protocols and regulations
for remote meetings as approved by the village president under Declaration No.
2020-03 Declaration Of A State Of Emergency In The Village Of Western Springs,
Cook County, Illinois (Covid-19 - November 9, 2020) (Disaster Declaration And
Remote Meeting Rules) dated November 9, 2020. (Ord. 06-2414, 10-23-2006; amd.
Ord. 21-3040, 4-26-2021)
 
Notes
1 1. 5 ILCS 120/1 et seq.
2 2. 5 ILCS 120/1 et seq.
3 3. 5 ILCS 120/1 et seq.
1-21-2: APPROVAL OF MINUTES:
Each board, committee and commission shall approve minutes of their open
meetings within thirty (30) days after that meeting, or at the second
subsequent regular meeting thereafter, whichever is later. (Ord. 11-2613, 1-24-
2011)
1-21-3: PUBLIC COMMENT PARTICIPATION GUIDELINES AT PUBLIC MEETINGS:
In accordance with the requirements of section 2.06(g) of the Illinois open
meetings act 1 , any person attending a public meeting of any village board,
committee, subcommittee or commission shall be permitted to address the public
officials during the public comment period, which shall be reserved for each
meeting, subject to the following guidelines:
   A.   Public Comment Participation Guidelines:
      1.   A period of time not to exceed thirty (30) minutes will be devoted
to public comment at each meeting, unless the public officials, by a majority
vote at the meeting, agree to allow the public comment period to exceed thirty
(30) minutes for that particular meeting.
      2.   Public comment for each individual who desires to address the public
body shall be limited to three (3) minutes per person per meeting. The public
officials may, by a majority vote at the meeting, agree to allow the per person
public comment session to exceed three (3) minutes for a particular topic or a
particular meeting.
      3.   Each person who desires to address the public body shall contact the
village clerk or secretary of the public body prior to the start of the meeting
and provide their name and the topic on which they wish to speak.
      4.   Each person shall state their name to the public body at the start
of his or her public comment session.
      5.   Each person may provide preprepared copies of his or her public
comments to the public body prior to, during or after his or her public comment
session.
      6.   A group of three (3) or more individuals speaking on the same topic
are asked to designate a single spokesperson to present the group's public
comments.
      7.   Public comment at all public meetings of village boards, committees,
subcommittees and commissions shall be entertained on any subject matter.
      8.   Members of the public body will not respond to the public comments
at the public meeting, unless directed by the village president or chair of the
public body. The village president or chair, or his/her designee, will respond
to the public comments, as he or she deems appropriate, and may direct the
person to the appropriate village official or staff member for assistance.
      9.   Abusive, foul or other inappropriate language or conduct and/or
personal attacks are not permitted.
      10.   The village president or chair has the authority to terminate the
public comment session of any person who fails to adhere to these guidelines.
(Ord. 16-2838, 5-23-2016)
 
Notes
1 1. 5 ILCS 120/2.06(g).
CHAPTER 22
DOWNTOWN SOUTH TIF DISTRICT
SECTION:
1-22-1: Establishment Of The Downtown South TIF District
1-22-2: Designation Of TIF Administrator
1-22-1: ESTABLISHMENT OF THE DOWNTOWN SOUTH TIF DISTRICT:
On January 26, 2015, pursuant to the Illinois tax increment allocation
redevelopment act, 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-74.4-1 et seq., the
president and board of trustees of the village of Western Springs established
the downtown south tax increment financing district (referred to as the
"downtown south TIF district") for the village of Western Springs with the
adoption of the following ordinances:
   A.   Western Springs ordinance 15-2777 (designating the village of Western
Springs downtown south tax increment financing district redevelopment project
area).
   B.   Western Springs ordinance 15-2778 (approving the village of Western
Springs downtown south tax increment financing district redevelopment project
area redevelopment plan and project).
   C.   Western Springs ordinance 15-2779 (adopting tax increment financing for
the village of Western Springs downtown south tax increment financing
district).
Copies of the above referenced ordinances and the map of the redevelopment
project area and the redevelopment project area redevelopment plan for the
downtown south TIF district are available on the village's website and from the
village clerk's office. (Ord. 15-2800, 4-27-2015)
1-22-2: DESIGNATION OF TIF ADMINISTRATOR:
The president and board of trustees of the village of Western Springs designate
the village manager as the TIF administrator for the downtown south TIF
district, who shall be responsible for performing all administrative duties and
compliance actions in regard to the downtown south TIF district, including
compliance with all annual filing and reporting requirements required by state
law (Illinois tax increment allocation redevelopment act 1  and the industrial
jobs recovery law 2 , preparation and filing of the annual TIF report with the
office of the state of Illinois comptroller, scheduling and coordination of the
annual joint board of review meetings, and such other duties as are necessary
to maintain compliance with applicable laws. (Ord. 15-2800, 4-27-2015)
