CHAPTER 24
PSEBA BENEFIT ADMINISTRATION
SECTION:
1-24-1: Purpose
1-24-2: Policy And Procedure For Administering Applications For PSEBA Benefits
1-24-3: Policy And Procedure For Hearings For PSEBA Benefits
1-24-4: PSEBA Benefits Granted By The Village
1-24-1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this chapter is to provide a fair and efficient method of
determining the eligibility of a full-time Village employee for the benefits
enumerated under the Public Safety Employee Benefits Act, 820 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 320/1, et seq., as amended ("PSEBA"). All benefits provided by the
Village to employees pursuant to the PSEBA shall be consistent with the PSEBA.
(Ord. 18-2922, 5-21-2018)
1-24-2: POLICY AND PROCEDURE FOR ADMINISTERING APPLICATIONS FOR PSEBA BENEFITS:
   A.   Employees, or family member(s) of injured or deceased employees, who
may qualify for PSEBA benefits (hereinafter "applicant") must file a full and
complete application in writing with the Village Manager no later than sixty
(60) calendar days from the date of issuance of a written decision by the
Police Pension Fund Board or Firefighter Pension Fund Board, whichever is
applicable, granting a line of duty disability pension. Failure to timely file
a full and complete application shall result in a forfeiture of benefits under
PSEBA.
   B.   A complete application shall include the following:
      1.   The applicant's name and date of hire, detailed information
regarding the incident for which PSEBA benefits are sought, including
information relating to how the injury was sustained in the line of duty,
including the date, time, place, nature of injury, and other factual
circumstances surrounding the incident.
      2.   The applicant's firsthand knowledge explaining, to the Village's
satisfaction, how the injury directly resulted from:
         a.   Response to fresh pursuit;
         b.   Response to what is reasonably believed to be an emergency;
         c.   Response to an unlawful act perpetrated by another; or
         d.   The investigation of a criminal act.
      3.   A signed unconditional PSEBA medical authorization release which
authorizes the Village to collect information related to the incident
including, but not limited to, disability pension proceedings, worker's
compensation records, and medical records, and a complete list of the names and
addresses for all health care providers involved in the diagnosis, treatment,
review or handling of the injury for which PSEBA benefits are sought.
      4.   A signed unconditional PSEBA general information release specifying
the name and signature of the applicant or her/his authorized representative
along with legal proof of said representation and name and signature of witness
authorizing the collection of information necessary to review the application.
      5.   The names, addresses and telephone numbers of witnesses to the
incident resulting in the injury for which PSEBA benefits are sought, along
with any statements of the witnesses which the applicant either possesses, may
obtain or is aware of.
      6.   The names, addresses and telephone numbers of witnesses the
applicant intends to call at the PSEBA hearing, along with their anticipated
subjects of testimony and any opinions the witnesses are expected to give.
      7.   Information and documentation filed with the appropriate Pension
Board.
      8.   Information regarding other sources of health insurance benefits
currently enrolled in, received by, or available to the applicant and/or the
applicant's family members, including the source of the benefits and the
benefits provided or available.
      9.   Any other information supporting the PSEBA eligibility requirements.
   C.   The PSEBA application must be sworn to by the applicant and notarized
to certify the truthfulness of the application's contents. A review of the
application shall not occur until the application is complete.
   D.   On the date that the PSEBA application is deemed complete by the
Village, the completed application shall then be submitted to the Village
Manager as the preliminary record, and a copy of the same shall be date stamped
and provided to the applicant.
   E.   Upon receipt of a complete application for PSEBA benefits, the Village
Manager shall set the matter for an administrative hearing with the Village
Manager or his or her designee serving as the Hearing Officer to make a
determination on whether to grant the application and provide the applicant
with benefits under PSEBA.
   F.   The applicant shall be given written notice of the date for the
administrative hearing not less than ten (10) calendar days prior to the
commencement of the hearing. If the applicant, upon receiving written notice of
the administrative hearing, cannot attend said date, the applicant must contact
the Hearing Officer in writing within seven (7) calendar days after being
served. The Hearing Officer shall establish an alternative hearing date within
thirty (30) calendar days of the original hearing date. The applicant's failure
to appear at the administrative hearing shall result in denial of PSEBA
benefits.
   G.   The Village Manager may delegate any of his/her authority, duties and
obligations under this chapter, in whole or part, to a designee, or designees.
(Ord. 18-2922, 5-21-2018)
1-24-3: POLICY AND PROCEDURE FOR HEARINGS FOR PSEBA BENEFITS:
   A.   Hearing Officer: The Village Manager or his or her designee shall be
the Hearing Officer for hearings on applications for PSEBA benefits. The
Hearing Officer shall have all of the authorities granted under statute and
common law relative to the conduct of administrative hearings, including to:
      1.   Adopt, revise and enforce rules of procedure for hearings;
      2.   Preside over hearings;
      3.   Administer oaths;
      4.   Hear testimony and accept evidence that is relevant to the issue of
eligibility under PSEBA;
      5.   Issue subpoenas to secure attendance of witnesses and the production
of relevant papers or documents upon the request of the parties, their
representatives or the Hearing Officer;
      6.   Rule upon objections to the admissibility of evidence;
      7.   Preserve and authenticate the record of the hearing and all exhibits
in evidence introduced at the hearing; and
      8.   Issue a final written determination on each application for PSEBA
benefits based on the evidence presented at the hearing which shall include
findings of fact, decision and order.
   B.   Hearings: Hearings for the determination of eligibility for benefits
under PSEBA shall be initiated by the Village after the submission of a full
and complete PSEBA application, and a determination by the Hearing Officer that
it is appropriate to proceed with the hearing, which determination shall
include consideration of the status of any disability pension proceeding
related to the applicant and whether the disability pension proceeding has
resulted in a final and non-appealable decision. A hearing shall be held to
adjudicate and determine whether the applicant is eligible for benefits under
the PSEBA. If the applicant is found eligible, the PSEBA benefits provided to
the applicant shall be consistent with the PSEBA.
      1.   Record: Hearings shall be attended by a certified court reporter,
and a transcript of all proceedings shall be made by said certified court
reporter.
      2.   Procedures: The Village and the applicant shall be entitled to
representation by counsel at hearings and may present witnesses, testimony and
documents, may cross-examine opposing witnesses, and may request the issuance
by the Hearing Officer of subpoenas to compel the appearance of relevant
witnesses or the production of relevant documents. The Hearing Officer may
issue subpoenas to compel the appearance of relevant witnesses or the
production of relevant documents in his/her discretion.
      3.   Evidence: The Illinois Rules of Evidence shall apply to the extent
practicable unless, by such application, the Hearing Officer determines that
application of the rule would be an injustice or preclude the introduction of
evidence of the type commonly relied upon by a reasonably prudent person in the
conduct of her/his affairs. Such determination shall be in the sole discretion
of the Hearing Officer. The Hearing Officer must state on the record his or her
reason for that determination.
      4.   Final Determination: A written determination by the Hearing Officer
of whether the applicant is eligible for benefits under the PSEBA shall
constitute a final administrative determination for the purpose of judicial
review under the common law writ of certiorari. Motions to reconsider, set
aside or challenge the final determination of the Hearing Officer are not
permitted.
      5.   Burden Of Proof: At any administrative hearing, the applicant shall
have the obligation and burden of proof to establish that the applicant is
eligible and qualified to receive PSEBA benefits. The standard of proof in all
hearings shall be by the preponderance of the evidence. (Ord. 18-2922, 5-21-
2018)
1-24-4: PSEBA BENEFITS GRANTED BY THE VILLAGE:
   A.   Basic Group Insurance Plan: If an applicant is determined to be
eligible for PSEBA benefits, the applicant will be eligible to receive
continued health coverage consistent with the PSEBA under the Village's basic
group health insurance plan. The basic group health insurance plan shall be the
least expensive health plan offered to Village employees at the time PSEBA
benefits are awarded as determined solely by the Village from time to time.
PSEBA benefits do not include benefits not provided in the Village's basic
group health insurance plan, such as, but not limited to, dental, vision, life
insurance, etc.
   B.   Reduction Or Elimination Of PSEBA Benefits By Other Health Coverage: If
an applicant becomes eligible to receive health insurance benefits from any
other source, including, but not limited to, Medicare, the applicant's PSEBA
coverage may be reduced or eliminated as determined by the Village consistent
with PSEBA.
   C.   Affidavit Of Continued PSEBA Eligibility: All recipients of PSEBA
benefits from the Village shall complete and return to the Village Manager on
an annual basis an affidavit verifying the recipient's continued eligibility
for PSEBA benefits. The affidavit must be completed and returned to the Village
Manager within sixty (60) calendar days of written notice from the Village. If
the recipient does not complete and return the affidavit within the time
required, the Village Manager shall give the recipient an additional written
notice providing an additional thirty (30) calendar days for the recipient to
complete and return the affidavit. Failure to return the affidavit within the
time required shall result in the recipient incurring responsibility for
reimbursing the Village for premiums paid during the period the affidavit is
due and not filed. (Ord. 18-2922, 5-21-2018)
TITLE 2
BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS
CHAPTER 1
ADVISORY BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS
SECTION:
2-1-1: Creation
2-1-2: Appointment; Membership
2-1-3: Removal From Office
2-1-4: Duties
2-1-5: Chair; Organization; Records; Meeting Minutes
2-1-6: Compensation
2-1-7: Meetings
2-1-8: Public Comment Participation Guidelines At Meetings
2-1-1: CREATION:
The administrative service of the Village shall include under the President and
Board of Trustees the following advisory boards and commissions hereby created:
Board of Fire and Police Commissioners
Board of Local Improvements
Board of Zoning Appeals
Economic Development Commission
Firefighters' Pension Board (Fire Pension Board)
Infrastructure Commission
Joint Emergency Telephone System Board
Local Liquor Control Commission
Plan Commission
Police Pension Board
Recreation Commission
Technology Commission
Transportation and Safety Commission
(Ord. 00-2111, 1-24-2000; amd. Ord. 01-2187, 12-17-2001; Ord. 04-2291, 4-26-
2004; Ord. 15-2816, 11-23-2015)
2-1-2: APPOINTMENT; MEMBERSHIP:
Each advisory board or commission member shall be appointed by the Village
President with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees unless otherwise
prescribed by State Statute or this Code. The members shall be appointed from
the community at large, and serve for a term designated by State Statutes or
this Code. Any vacancy occurring shall be filled for the remainder of the
unexpired term in the same manner as in the case of the original appointment.
One of the members of the Board of Trustees shall be appointed by the Village
President to act as liaison between the Board of Trustees and each advisory
board and commission. The Village Manager or his designee shall serve as staff
liaison to each advisory board and commission. (Ord. 00-2111, 1-24-2000)
2-1-3: REMOVAL FROM OFFICE:
Any advisory board or commission member may be removed, unless otherwise
prescribed by State Statute or this Code, by the Village President for failure
to attend meetings or inattention to duties. The Village President must report
the reasons for the removal to the Board of Trustees at a meeting to be held
not less than five (5) days nor more than ten (10) days after the removal. If
the Village President fails or refuses to report to the Board of Trustees the
reasons for the removal, or if the Board of Trustees by a two-thirds (2/3) vote
of all the members of the Board of Trustees disapproves of the removal, the
member of the advisory board or commission shall be restored to membership on
the advisory board or commission in question. (Ord. 00-2111, 1-24-2000)
2-1-4: DUTIES:
Each board or commission shall act as an advisory body to the Board of Trustees
regarding specific problems referred to it by this Code, a stand alone
ordinance, a resolution, the Village President, Board of Trustees or the
Village Manager. (Ord. 00-2111, 1-24-2000)
2-1-5: CHAIR; ORGANIZATION; RECORDS; MEETING MINUTES:
A Chair for each advisory board or commission shall be appointed by the Village
President with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees unless otherwise
prescribed by statute or this Code. The Chair shall preside at the meetings of
the advisory board or commission and shall otherwise supervise the affairs of
the board or commission. It shall be the Chair's duty to maintain a written
record of the proceedings of the advisory board or commission, which shall at
all times be open to inspection by the Board of Trustees, staff, local media
and the general public. Each board, committee and commission shall approve
minutes of their open meetings within thirty (30) days after that meeting, or
at the second subsequent regular meeting thereafter, whichever is later. Any
Chair may be removed by the Village President for failure to attend meetings or
inattention to duties or by a two-thirds (2/3) vote of the members of the Board
of Trustees unless otherwise prescribed by statute or this Code. (Ord. 11-2613,
1-24-2011)
2-1-6: COMPENSATION:
No member of any advisory board or commission shall receive any compensation
for serving; except, that to assist in the maintenance of records, a Secretary
may be appointed by the Village Manager or his designee and paid such
compensation as the Village Manager or his designee shall authorize. (Ord. 00-
2111, 1-24-2000)
2-1-7: MEETINGS:
Meetings of the advisory boards and commissions shall be public meetings held
according to the schedule in this Code and notice of said meetings shall be
given in accordance with State Statutes. A quorum shall consist of a simple
majority of those members appointed to the advisory board or commission at any
time, and no official business shall be conducted without a quorum of members
present. The advisory board or commission may adopt its own rules of procedure
not inconsistent with the provisions of this Code. (Ord. 00-2111, 1-24-2000)
2-1-8: PUBLIC COMMENT PARTICIPATION GUIDELINES AT MEETINGS:
The guidelines set forth at section
1-21-3, "Public Comment Participation Guidelines At Public Meetings", of this
Code shall apply to every board, commission, committee and subcommittee of the
Village. (Ord. 11-2613, 1-24-2011)
CHAPTER 2
PLAN COMMISSION
SECTION:
2-2-1: Establishment; Membership; Terms Of Office
2-2-2: Meetings
2-2-3: Powers And Duties
2-2-1: ESTABLISHMENT; MEMBERSHIP; TERMS OF OFFICE:
There is hereby created a plan commission for the village. The plan commission
shall consist of seven (7) members. The members shall be appointed from the
community at large, and serve for a term of three (3) years. (Ord. 00-2111, 1-
24-2000)
2-2-2: MEETINGS:
The plan commission shall meet at the village hall once a month on a regular
date or more often if requested by the board, the village manager or the
manager's designee. (Ord. 00-2111, 1-24-2000)
2-2-3: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The plan commission shall have powers and duties as provided in title 10 of
this code. (Ord. 00-2111, 1-24-2000)
CHAPTER 3
BOARD OF FIRE AND POLICE COMMISSIONERS
SECTION:
2-3-1: Establishment; Membership; Terms Of Office
2-3-2: Qualifications; Oath, Bond And Removal
2-3-3: Officers
2-3-4: Meetings
2-3-5: Powers And Duties
2-3-6: Reimbursement Agreement For Recovery Of Training, Certification And
Equipment Costs
2-3-1: ESTABLISHMENT; MEMBERSHIP; TERMS OF OFFICE:
There is hereby created a board of fire and police commissioners (hereinafter
in this chapter to be known as the "BOFPC") consisting of three (3) members as
provided by state statute. The members shall be appointed from the community at
large, and serve for a term of three (3) years or until their respective
successors are appointed and have qualified; provided that no such appointments
shall be made by any president within thirty (30) days before the expiration of
the president's term of office. (Ord. 15-2825, 12-21-2015)
2-3-2: QUALIFICATIONS; OATH, BOND AND REMOVAL:
The BOFPC shall have such qualifications as are now, or may hereafter be
required of them by state statute. Each member of the BOFPC shall take an oath
or affirmation of office and shall execute and deliver such sureties as the
board of trustees shall approve, conditioned upon the faithful performance of
the duties of office. In the event the village maintains in force a blanket
coverage surety bond which includes coverage for each member of the BOFPC, the
members of the BOFPC shall not be required to furnish a bond as provided
herein. In either case, the cost of the surety bond will be borne by the
village.
No person shall be appointed as a member of the BOFPC who is related, either by
blood or marriage up to the degree of first cousin, to any village elected
official. No more than two (2) members of the BOFPC shall belong to the same
political party in the village. If no local political party exists at the time
of the appointment of BOFPC members to office, then state or national political
party affiliations shall be utilized.
BOFPC members can only be removed for cause and upon written charges being
filed. BOFPC members must be given an opportunity to be heard to present their
defense within thirty (30) days before a regular meeting of the board of
trustees. A simple majority vote of the board of trustees shall be required to
remove a BOFPC member from office after the proper hearing. (Ord. 15-2825, 12-
21-2015)
2-3-3: OFFICERS:
The BOFPC is to elect annually from their body a chair. (Ord. 15-2825, 12-21-
2015)
2-3-4: MEETINGS:
Meetings of the BOFPC shall be on call at the village hall. (Ord. 15-2825, 12-
21-2015)
2-3-5: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The BOFPC shall have such powers and duties as are now, or as may hereafter be
given to it, by state statute and this code. (Ord. 15-2825, 12-21-2015)
2-3-6: REIMBURSEMENT AGREEMENT FOR RECOVERY OF TRAINING, CERTIFICATION AND
EQUIPMENT COSTS:
All persons who apply for entry level police officer and full time firefighter
positions with the village shall, as a condition of application for employment
with the village, sign a reimbursement agreement prepared by the village that
requires the repayment, on a prorated basis, of the training, certification and
equipment costs that the village pays on behalf of the applicant after he or
she is hired by the village, in the event that the applicant's employment with
the village ends within thirty six (36) months of being hired by the village
due to any reason other than termination by the village or injury or illness
that prevents continued employment. The reimbursement agreement shall be in a
form that has been approved by the village and shall be attached to the village
employment application form that is used for entry level police officer and
full time firefighter positions. The following individuals are authorized to
sign the reimbursement agreement on behalf of the village during the employment
application process and no further village approval shall be necessary for the
reimbursement agreement to be valid and enforceable: the village manager, each
member of the board of fire and police commissioners, the fire chief and the
police chief. (Ord. 15-2825, 12-21-2015)

2-4-2: Meetings

2000)

CHAPTER 6
ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION
SECTION:
2-6-1: Establishment; Membership; Terms Of Office
2-6-2: Purpose
2-6-3: Meetings
2-6-1: ESTABLISHMENT; MEMBERSHIP; TERMS OF OFFICE:
There is hereby established an economic development commission which shall
consist of seven (7) regular members, and one (1) advisory member, selected
from the village business community and the community at large. All members
shall be appointed for a term of three (3) years, except for the first three
(3) appointments made after June 1, 2009, who shall serve for a term of two (2)
years. One (1) additional, non-voting advisory member who is a representative
of the Western Springs business association (WSBA) may be appointed at the
discretion of the village board. This advisory member may provide feedback to
the commission regarding matters relevant to the business community. All
members shall be appointed by the village president with the advice and consent
of the board of trustees. (Ord. 09-2540, 6-22-2009; amd. Ord. 21-3037, 3-29-
2021)
2-6-2: PURPOSE:
The economic development commission shall be advisory to the board of trustees
in all areas of economic development of the village including the maintaining
of communication between the business community and the village government, the
promotion of economic growth of its business districts, and other such matters
referred to the commission by the village president, board of trustees or
village manager. (Ord. 00-2111, 1-24-2000)
2-6-3: MEETINGS:
The economic development commission shall meet on call at the village hall.
(Ord. 02-2195, 1-28-2002)
CHAPTER 7
RECREATION COMMISSION
SECTION:
2-7-1: Establishment; Membership; Terms Of Office
2-7-2: Purpose
2-7-3: Meetings
2-7-4: Gifts And Bequests
2-7-1: ESTABLISHMENT; MEMBERSHIP; TERMS OF OFFICE:
There is hereby created a recreation commission of five (5) members. All
members shall be appointed for a term of three (3) years. (Ord. 00-2111, 1-24-
2000)
2-7-2: PURPOSE:
The purpose of the recreation commission shall be as follows:
   A.   To advise the board of trustees on matters relating to the
administration, operation and provision of recreation programs for the village;
   B.   To advise the board of trustees regarding the maintenance, equipping
and operation of the community and recreation center and any other recreational
facilities;
   C.   To advise the board of trustees regarding other matters relating to
recreational facilities and recreation programs which are referred to the
recreation commission;
   D.   To advise the director of recreation on a regular basis regarding the
development of a comprehensive recreation program for the village. (Ord. 00-
2111, 1-24-2000)
2-7-3: MEETINGS:
Regular meetings of the recreation commission shall be held on the first
Thursday of March, July, September and November, and special meetings shall be
held on an on-call basis at the recreation center or the village hall.
(Ord. 00-2111, 1-24-2000; amd. Ord. 22-3070, 3-21-2022)
2-7-4: GIFTS AND BEQUESTS:
The board of trustees or their designee(s) may accept any grant or devise of
real estate or any gift or bequest of money or other personal property or any
donation, the principal or income of which is to be applied for either
temporary or permanent use for recreation purposes. Money received by the
village for such purpose shall be deposited with the village treasurer. (Ord.
00-2111, 1-24-2000)
CHAPTER 8
TRANSPORTATION AND SAFETY COMMISSION
SECTION:
2-8-1: Establishment; Membership; Terms Of Office
2-8-2: Meetings
2-8-3: Purpose
2-8-1: ESTABLISHMENT; MEMBERSHIP; TERMS OF OFFICE:
There is hereby created a transportation and safety commission which shall
consist of seven (7) members. All members shall be appointed for a term of
three (3) years. (Ord. 00-2111, 1-24-2000)
2-8-2: MEETINGS:
Meetings of the commission shall be held not less than quarterly at the village
hall. (Ord. 00-2111, 1-24-2000)
2-8-3: PURPOSE:
The purpose of the transportation and safety commission shall be as follows:
   A.   To advise the board of trustees on matters relating to transportation
and transit systems of the village in general, including local streets and
roads; county, state and federal highways; and mass transportation, including,
but not limited to, rail and bus transit.
   B.   To consult, cooperate and coordinate with the plan commission,
operating departments of the village and other governmental bodies on matters
relating to transportation and transit systems of the village.
   C.   To advise the board of trustees regarding other matters relating to
transportation, transit, traffic and safety which are referred to the
transportation and safety commission.
   D.   To perform such other duties and be of such other assistance as may be
from time to time assigned by the board of trustees. (Ord. 00-2111, 1-24-20000)
CHAPTER 9
JOINT EMERGENCY TELEPHONE SYSTEM BOARD
SECTION:
2-9-1: Establishment; Membership; Authority And Duties
2-9-2: Dissolution Of Local ETSB; Re-Instatement
2-9-3: Use Of ETSB Funds; Surcharge Funds
2-9-1: ESTABLISHMENT; MEMBERSHIP; AUTHORITY AND DUTIES:
   A.   Establishment: Pursuant to resolution 15-2336 (adopted on November 23,
2015), the Village approved an Intergovernmental Agreement entitled
"Intergovernmental Agreement Entered Into by the Villages of La Grange, La
Grange Park and Western Springs to Establish an Intergovernmental Cooperative
Venture Known as the 'Lyons Township Area Communications Center' for the
Operation and Maintenance of a Combined Dispatch and Communication System" (the
"LTACC Intergovernmental Agreement") that provided for the establishment of an
intergovernmental cooperative venture known as the "Lyons Township Area
Communications Center" (also referred to as "LTACC") for the operation and
maintenance of a centralized, combined emergency services dispatch and
communication system that includes 9-1-1 services and wireless E-9-1-1 services
(the "system"). The LTACC Intergovernmental Agreement also provided for the
creation of the LTACC's Joint Emergency Telephone System Board.
   B.   Membership; Authority And Duties: The members of LTACC's Joint
Emergency Telephone System Board shall be comprised of the members of the
LTACC's Operating Board. The authority and duties of LTACC's Joint Emergency
Telephone System Board shall be governed by article V (Operating Board) of the
LTACC Intergovernmental Agreement and the Emergency Telephone System Act 1  and
any other applicable laws. (Ord. 15-2816, 11-23-2015)
 
Notes
1 1. 50 ILCS 750/1 et seq.
2-9-2: DISSOLUTION OF LOCAL ETSB; RE-INSTATEMENT:
   A.   Dissolution Of Local ETSB: Pursuant to the ordinance codified herein,
the Village's ETSB was dissolved effective upon the date of the regulatory
approval of the LTACC and LTACC's JETSB by the Illinois Commerce Commission
("ICC") or the 9-1-1 Administrator of the Illinois Department of State Police.
   B.   Re-Instatement Of Local ETSB: In the event the Village withdraws from
participation in LTACC, to the extent permitted by applicable laws and
regulations, the Village will either take the necessary corporate actions to
re-instate its local ETSB or join another Joint Emergency Telephone System
Board. (Ord. 15-2816, 11-23-2015)
2-9-3: USE OF ETSB FUNDS; SURCHARGE FUNDS:
   A.   Use Of ETSB Funds: Under the LTACC Intergovernmental Agreement, the
Village, in its own discretion, may use or expend any of its ETSB funds,
including any surcharge funds, to pay for budgeted items or obligations that
exist in its current 2015/2016 ETSB budget in accordance with the applicable
laws, including the Emergency Telephone System Act 1 , the Wireless Emergency
Telephone Safety Act 2  and the Prepaid Wireless 9-1-1 Surcharge Act 3 .
   B.   Surcharge Funds: Upon dissolution of the Village's ETSB and subject to
the terms of the intergovernmental agreement and the Village's continued
participation in LTACC, all monies received or collected by the Village that
are intended to be used to pay for the operation and maintenance of LTACC's
system from any surcharge or revenue source authorized by any Federal or State
law, including section 15.3 of the Emergency Telephone System Act 4 , the
Wireless Emergency Telephone Safety Act 5  and the Prepaid Wireless 9-1-
1 Surcharge Act 6 , shall be transferred to the LTACC for deposit and
expenditure by the LTACC JETSB in accordance with applicable Federal or State
law. (Ord. 15-2816, 11-23-2015)
 
Notes
1 1. 50 ILCS 750/1 et seq.
2 2. 50 ILCS 751/1 et seq.
3 3. 50 ILCS 753/1 et seq.
4 4. 50 ILCS 750/15.3.
5 5. 50 ILCS 751/1 et seq.
6 6. 50 ILCS 753/1 et seq.
CHAPTER 10
FIREFIGHTERS' PENSION BOARD (FIRE PENSION BOARD)
SECTION:
2-10-1: Establishment Of The Pension Fund
2-10-2: Composition Of The Pension Fund
2-10-3: Board Of Trustees Of The Fire Pension Fund
2-10-4: Elected Members Of The Board Of Trustees
2-10-5: Officers
2-10-6: Meetings
2-10-7: Compensation
2-10-8: Powers And Duties
2-10-1: ESTABLISHMENT OF THE PENSION FUND:
The village hereby adopts the provisions of act 5, article 4 of the Illinois
pension code, as amended and entitled "firefighters' pension fund –
municipalities 500,000 and under" (hereinafter to be referred to as the "fire
pension fund"). The fire pension fund shall be established and administered in
accordance with the provisions of said article 4, for the benefit of the
village's firefighters and their surviving spouses, children and certain other
dependents. Pensions shall be paid and said fund shall be held, invested and
disbursed as provided in said act. (Ord. 00-2111, 1-24-2000)
2-10-2: COMPOSITION OF THE PENSION FUND:
There shall be set apart by the village treasurer the following monies which
shall constitute the fire pension fund:
   A.   All monies derived from taxes levied pursuant to state statute for the
fire pension fund.
   B.   Eight and four hundred fifty five-hundredths percent (8.455%) per month
from July 1, 2004, which shall be paid or deducted from the salary of each full
time firefighter.
   C.   All rewards in monies, fees, gifts and emoluments that may be paid or
given for or on account of extraordinary services by the fire department or any
member of the department, except when allowed to be retained by competitive
awards, shall be paid into the fire pension fund.
   D.   Any other money, real property, or personal property received by the
board of trustees of the fire pension fund in accordance with state statutes.
(Ord. 05-2377, 12-19-2005)
2-10-3: BOARD OF TRUSTEES OF THE FIRE PENSION FUND:
There is hereby created a board of trustees (the "board") of the fire pension
fund to provide for the administration of said fund as provided by state
statutes. Prior to the third Monday in April, 2006, the board shall consist of
nine (9) members or such other number as provided by the same statutes. The
board shall consist of the village president, village clerk, village attorney,
village treasurer, director of fire and inspectional services, three (3) active
full time firefighters, if any, and a retired firefighter, if any.
Notwithstanding any provision of this section to the contrary, the term of
office of each member of a board established on or before the third Monday in
April, 2006, shall terminate on the third Monday in April, 2006, but all
incumbent members shall continue to exercise all of the powers and be subject
to all of the duties of a member of the board until all the new members of the
board take office.
Beginning on the third Monday in April, 2006, the board for each municipality
or fire protection district shall consist of five (5) members. Two (2) members
of the board shall be appointed by the mayor or president of the board of
trustees of the municipality or fire protection district involved. Two (2)
members of the board shall be active participants of the pension fund who are
elected from the active participants of the fund. One member of the board shall
be a person who is retired under the firemen's pension fund act of 1919 or this
chapter. (Ord. 05-2377, 12-19-2005)
2-10-4: ELECTED MEMBERS OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES:
   A.   Active Firefighters: Two (2) active firefighters shall serve on the
board and are to be elected only from and by the active firefighters on the
third Monday in April of the applicable year. They are to be elected by secret
ballot for a term of three (3) years. Elected representatives to the board
should merit the confidence of their fellow firefighters and should have an
interest in and be willing to serve the fire pension fund.
   B.   Retired Firefighter: The retired firefighter to be elected to the board
is to be elected only from and by the retired firefighters on the third Monday
in April of the applicable year. The retired firefighter is to be elected by
secret ballot for a term of three (3) years.
   C.   Voting; Terms Of Office; Unexpired Terms: In case of a tie vote, the
fire pension board shall determine by lot who has been elected. No person shall
be entitled to cast more than one ballot at such election. The term of elected
members shall be three (3) years and until a successor has been duly elected
and qualified. Upon the death, resignation or inability to act of any elected
board member, his or her successor shall be elected for the unexpired term at a
special election, to be called by the board and conducted in the same manner as
the regular election. (Ord. 05-2377, 12-19-2005)
2-10-5: OFFICERS:
The fire pension board is to elect annually from their body a president and a
secretary. The village treasurer shall be the treasurer of the fire pension
fund. The village treasurer has custody of all assets of the fund and is to be
bonded for the faithful performance of duties. The village treasurer shall keep
the financial records of the fire pension fund and sign all checks in
accordance with direction given by the board and/or state statute. Signature
cards at financial institutions should reflect the village treasurer as the
principal signer. (Ord. 00-2111, 1-24-2000)
2-10-6: MEETINGS:
Meetings of the fire pension board shall be held on call at the village hall.
(Ord. 00-2111, 1-24-2000)
2-10-7: COMPENSATION:
The board shall not receive any salary from the pension fund for services
performed as board members. (Ord. 00-2111, 1-24-2000)
2-10-8: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The board of the fire pension fund shall have all of the powers, duties and
obligations conferred or imposed upon it by state statutes and this code. (Ord.
00-2111, 1-24-2000)
CHAPTER 11
INFRASTRUCTURE COMMISSION
SECTION:
2-11-1: Establishment; Membership; Terms Of Office
2-11-2: Meetings
2-11-3: Duties
2-11-1: ESTABLISHMENT; MEMBERSHIP; TERMS OF OFFICE:
There is hereby created an infrastructure commission which shall consist of
seven (7) members. The members of the commission shall hold office for the term
of three (3) years. (Ord. 01-2187, 12-17-2001)
2-11-2: MEETINGS:
The infrastructure commission shall meet at the village hall every other month
on a regular date, or more often as necessary to complete their work. Special
meetings of the commission may also be called by the village president, or the
chairman of the public works and water committee. (Ord. 01-2187, 12-17-2001)
2-11-3: DUTIES:
It shall be the duty of the infrastructure commission to advise the president
and board of trustees on such matters related to the village's infrastructure
as are requested by the president and board of trustees for advice and counsel.
Infrastructure shall include the village's streets and alleys, sidewalks,
street lighting system, potable water system, sewer systems, cable TV system
and such other utilities as may occupy the village's public rights of way. The
infrastructure commission shall also have those other specific duties as may
from time to time be delegated by the president and board of trustees. (Ord.
01-2187, 12-17-2001)
CHAPTER 12
POLICE PENSION BOARD
SECTION:
2-12-1: Establishment Of The Pension Fund
2-12-2: Composition Of The Pension Fund
2-12-3: Board Of Trustees Of The Police Pension Fund; Terms Of Office
2-12-4: Officers
2-12-5: Elected Members Of The Board Of Trustees; Terms Of Office
2-12-6: Meetings
2-12-7: Compensation
2-12-1: ESTABLISHMENT OF THE PENSION FUND:
The village hereby adopts the provisions of act 5, article 3 of the Illinois
pension code, as amended, entitled "Police Pension Fund – Municipalities
500,000 and Under" (hereinafter referred to as the "Police Pension Fund"). The
police pension fund shall be established and administered in accordance with
the provisions of said article 3, for the benefit of the village's police
officers and their surviving spouses, children, and certain other dependents.
(Ord. 00-2111, 1-24-2000)
2-12-2: COMPOSITION OF THE PENSION FUND:
There shall be set apart by the village treasurer the following monies which
shall constitute the police pension fund:
   A.   All monies derived from the taxes levied pursuant to state statutes for
the police pension fund.
   B.   Nine percent (9%) per month, from January 1, 1987, which shall be paid
or deducted from the salary of each full-time police officer.
   C.   All monies which may have been accumulated by the village in conformity
with any previous legislation establishing a fund for the benefit of disabled
or superannuated police officers.
   D.   Donations, gifts or other transfers authorized by state statutes for
the police pension fund. (Ord. 00-2111, 1-24-2000)
2-12-3: BOARD OF TRUSTEES OF THE POLICE PENSION FUND; TERMS OF OFFICE:
There is hereby created a board of trustees (the "Board") of the police pension
fund to provide for the administration of said fund and to designate the
beneficiaries thereof as provided by state statute. The board shall consist of
five (5) members.
Two (2) members of the board shall be appointed by the village president. Two
(2) members of the board shall be elected from the active participants of the
pension fund by such active participants, if any. One member shall be elected
by and from the beneficiaries, if any. The members of the board appointed by
the village president shall hold office for the term of two (2) years each or
until their successors are appointed and have qualified. (Ord. 00-2111, 1-24-
2000)
2-12-4: OFFICERS:
The police pension board is to elect annually at the regular July meeting from
their body a president, vice president, secretary and assistant secretary. The
village treasurer shall perform all of the duties, functions and activities in
regard to collection and administration of the pension funds on behalf of the
police pension board as provided for by state statute. The village treasurer
has custody of all assets of the police pension fund and is to be bonded for
the faithful performance of duties. The village treasurer shall keep the
financial records of the police pension fund and sign all checks in accordance
with direction given by the board or state statute. Signature cards at
financial institutions should reflect the village treasurer as the principal
signer. (Ord. 00-2111, 1-24-2000)
2-12-5: ELECTED MEMBERS OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES; TERMS OF OFFICE:
   A.   Biennial Election: The election for board members shall be held
biennially on the third Monday in April, at such place or places in the village
and by secret ballot and such other regulations as shall be prescribed by the
appointed members of the board. Elected representatives to the board should
merit the confidence of their fellow police officers and should have an
interest in and be willing to serve the police pension fund. Pensions shall be
paid and said fund shall be held, invested and disbursed as provided in said
act.
   B.   Active Police Officers: The two (2) active police officers to serve on
the board are to be elected only from and by the active police officers on the
third Monday in April of the applicable year. They are to be elected by secret
ballot for a term of two (2) years.
   C.   Retired Police Officer: The retired police officer to be elected to the
board is to be elected only from and by the retired police officers on the
third Monday in April of the applicable year. The retired police officer(s) is
to be elected by secret ballot for a term of two (2) years.
   D.   Tie Votes: In case of a tie vote, the police pension board shall
determine by lot who has been elected and in the event that any elected member
is unable to serve his complete term, a special election for the unexpired term
shall be held in the same manner as the regular election.
   E.   Voting; Terms Of Office; Unexpired Terms: The active pension fund
participants shall be entitled to vote only for the active participant members
of the board. All beneficiaries of legal age may vote only for the member
chosen from among the beneficiaries. No person shall be entitled to cast more
than one ballot at such election. The term of elected members shall be two (2)
years, beginning on the second Tuesday of the first May after the election.
Upon the death, resignation or inability to act of any elected board member,
his or her successor shall be elected for the unexpired term at a special
election, to be called by the board and conducted in the same manner as the
regular biennial election. (Ord. 00-2111, 1-24-2000)
2-12-6: MEETINGS:
Meetings of the police pension board shall be held annually on a quarterly
basis in July, October, January and April at the village hall. (Ord. 00-2111,
1-24-2000)
2-12-7: COMPENSATION:
The board members shall not receive nor have any right to receive any salary
from the pension fund for services performed as board members. (Ord. 00-2111,
1-24-2000)
