3-4-8: DRY CLEANERS:
Cross Reference: Fire Prevention Code, Title 9, Chapter 6 of this Code. (Ord.
81-1601, 11-17-1981, eff. 1-1-1982; amd. 1997 Code)
3-4-9: FIRE INSURANCE COMPANIES:
   A.   Fee; Disposition: All corporations, companies and associations not
incorporated under the laws of the State and which are engaged in the Village
in effecting fire insurance shall pay to the Treasurer of the Foreign Fire
Insurance Board, for the use and benefit of the Department of Fire and
Inspectional Services, as determined by the Foreign Fire Insurance Board in
accordance with 65 ILCS 5/11-10, a sum equal in amount to two percent (2%) of
the gross receipts received by the agency of any such company, corporation or
association in the Village.
   B.   Report; Payment: Every person who shall act in the Village as agent or
otherwise, for and on behalf of any such corporation, company or association,
shall, on or before July 15 of each and every year, render to the Foreign Fire
Insurance Board a full, true and just account, made on his oath, of all the
premiums which, during the year ending on July 1 preceding such report, have
been received for fire insurance by them or any other person for their in
behalf of any such corporation, company or association; such agent shall also
pay to the Treasurer of the Foreign Fire Insurance Board, at the time of
rendering the aforesaid report, two percent (2%) of the gross receipts received
by them for fire insurance effected in the Village. (Ord. 81-1601, 11-17-1981,
eff. 1-1-1982; amd. 1997 Code; Ord. 23-3132, 4-24-2023)
3-4-10: FLORISTS:
   A.   Definition: The term "retail florist" means any person engaged in the
business of selling, offering for sale or keeping with the intention of selling
at retail flowers, bridal bouquets, funeral designs or growing plants.
   B.   Sanitation: Every place or establishment where the business of a
florist is conducted shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition and free
from vermin. No decayed, contaminated or diseased flowers or plants shall be
allowed to remain in or about said establishment. (Ord. 81-1601, 11-17-1981,
eff. 1-1-1982)
CHAPTER 5
SPECIAL BUSINESS REGULATIONS II
SECTION:
3-5-1: Application Of Provisions; Eligibility If Debt Owed To Village
3-5-2: Garages And Filling Stations
3-5-3: Hotels And Lodging Houses
3-5-4: Building Movers
3-5-5: Laundries
3-5-6: Paint Stores
3-5-7: Pawnbrokers
3-5-1: APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS; ELIGIBILITY IF DEBT OWED TO VILLAGE:
In addition to other requirements listed in this code, the following special
provisions shall apply to certain businesses and occupations.
   A.   Eligibility if Debt Owed to Village: See the provisions of Section
3-1-1(A) of this Code, which are incorporated by reference into this Title and
Chapter and are applicable to the grant or issuance of any Village approvals,
certificates, licenses or permits covered by this Chapter. (Ord. 81-1601, 11-
17-1981, eff. 1-1-1982; amd. Ord. 3091, 7-11-2022)
3-5-2: GARAGES AND FILLING STATIONS 1 :
   A.   Definitions: As used in this section, the following words and terms
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection:
FILLING STATION: Any building, structure or premises where gasoline and other
liquids used in the operation of motor vehicles are stored or kept in tanks or
containers, either stationary or portable, and are sold and dispensed from such
tanks or containers.
PUBLIC GARAGE: Any building or premises where three (3) or more motor vehicles
using inflammable liquids for fuel or power, which are operated otherwise than
on fixed rails, are kept for sale or rent or are housed, stored, serviced or
repaired for hire.
   B.   Frontage Consents: No person shall locate, construct or maintain any
filling station in connection with which there is installed any tank for the
storage of inflammable liquids on any lot or plot of ground without first
obtaining the written consents of the property owners representing the majority
of the total frontage in feet of any lots or plots of ground lying wholly or in
part within lines one hundred fifty feet (150') distant from and parallel to
the boundaries of the entire lot or plot of ground to be used for and with such
filling station, driveways and enclosing fences, if any; provided, however,
that for the purpose of this section there shall be considered only the
frontage of such lot or plot of ground, or that part of the frontage of any
part thereof, which comes within the one hundred fifty foot (150') limit herein
prescribed; and provided, further, that any and all petitions containing such
consents of property owners shall be based on and contain the legal description
of the property affected, and that, for the purpose of this section, whenever
the lot or plot of ground in which such tank is to be installed is in any shape
other than a rectangle, the one hundred fifty foot (150') limiting line
aforementioned shall not at any point exceed in distance one hundred fifty feet
(150') from the nearest point in the boundaries of such lot or plot of ground.
   C.   Application For License:
      1.   Application Procedure: Application for such license shall be made
and license be issued as provided in chapter 1 of this title. The application
shall also specify the location and describe the construction of the building
or place in which it is proposed to conduct such business and of the tanks or
other containers to be used in connection therewith, and shall be accompanied
by plans and specifications pertaining thereto and by frontage consents as
above provided. (Ord. 81-1601, 11-17-1981, eff. 1-1-1982)
      2.   Approval Of Construction Required: No tank or other equipment
described in such application and used or to be used at such garage or filling
station shall be covered or used until the installation, material and
workmanship have been finally accepted, approved and certified by the director
of fire and inspectional services or such other person as may be designated by
the president and board of trustees. (Ord. 81-1601, 11-17-1981, eff. 1-1-1982;
amd. 1997 Code)
   D.   Location: No public garage or filling station shall be operated within
one hundred feet (100') of the nearest lot line of any premises occupied by any
building used in whole or in part as a public theater or used exclusively for
school or church purposes. (Ord. 81-1601, 11-17-1981, eff. 1-1-1982)
 
Notes
1 1. See subsection
  9-10-10H of this code for sign regulations.
3-5-3: HOTELS AND LODGING HOUSES:
   A.   Definitions: As used in this section, the following words and terms
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection:
BOARDING HOUSE: A house, building or portion thereof in which meals or lodging
and meals are furnished, for compensation, by prearrangement for definite
periods, for three (3) or more but not exceeding six (6) persons, exclusive of
the owner, manager or members of their respective families.
HOTEL: Any building or structure used for lodging the public, especially
transients, where sleeping or lodging accommodations, with or without meals,
are furnished, for compensation, for more than six (6) guests.
LODGING HOUSE: Any house or building, or portion thereof, other than a hotel,
used for lodging the public, especially transients, where sleeping or lodging
accommodations, with or without meals, are provided, for compensation, for not
less than three (3) nor more than six (6) persons, exclusive of the owner,
manager or members of their respective families.
   B.   Application For License:
      1.   Application Procedure: Application for a hotel, lodging house or
boarding house license shall be made and license shall be issued as provided in
chapter 1 of this title. With the application shall be filed a plan of each
floor of the building proposed to be used as a hotel, lodging house or boarding
house, drawn to a scale of not less than one-fourth inch (1/4") to the foot,
showing all fire escapes, stairs, halls, the location and size of all windows,
bedrooms and exits on each floor, and indicating the number of persons proposed
to be accommodated on each floor and the number of persons to be housed in each
room. (Ord. 81-1601, 11-17-1981, eff. 1-1-1982)
      2.   Inspections: The application shall be referred to the director of
fire and inspectional services, who shall cause investigation to be made to
determine whether the building or premises in which such hotel or boarding
house is to be operated complies with the requirements of this code and of the
building code, in regard to construction, sanitation, and public health and
safety. If the director of fire and inspectional services approves the
application, license shall be issued upon payment of the prescribed fee 1 .
(Ord. 81-1601, 11-17-1981, eff. 1-1-1982; amd. 1997 Code; Ord. 98-2064, 12-21-
1998)
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  3-3-2 of this title.
3-5-4: BUILDING MOVERS:
   A.   Definition: The term "building mover", as used in this section, shall
mean and include any person engaged in the business of moving, raising or
shoring buildings, houses or other structures.
   B.   Bond: Before any license shall be issued to a building mover, the
proposed licensee shall execute a surety bond in the amount of one hundred
thousand dollars ($100,000.00), conditioned for observance and performance by
him or her of all provisions of this code relating to the moving, raising,
shoring or underpinning of buildings, houses or structures within the village
and conditioned further to pay all damages which may occur to any public right
of way, public infrastructure, public or private utilities or to any pole,
wire, cable or electrical equipment or appliance or to trees or shrubbery owned
by, or under the control or jurisdiction of the village, or to any privately
owned property in the village, caused by or resulting from the work undertaken
or the manner of doing the same. In the case of a building, house or structure
that is owned by a public entity or not for profit organization and the
relocation will occur within the village's corporate boundaries, the above
surety bond amount may be reduced to an amount not less than twenty thousand
dollars ($20,000.00) as determined and approved by the village board based on a
recommendation of the director of community development. Factors supporting a
reduction in the surety bond amount include: the relocation presents a reduced
risk of damage to the public right of way, public infrastructure, public or
private utilities or to any pole, wire, cable or electrical equipment or
appliance or to trees or shrubbery owned by, or under the control or
jurisdiction of the village, or to any privately owned property. (Ord. 08-2494,
5-12-2008)
   C.   Building Relocation Permit; Fee: No licensed building mover shall move
a building, house or structure in, on or over any street, alley or other public
place in the village without a permit issued for that purpose. Such permit
shall be issued by the director of community development upon application
therefor, and on payment of a permit fee of five hundred dollars ($500.00).
(Ord. 08-2510, 10-27-2008)
3-5-5: LAUNDRIES:
   A.   Definition: The word "laundry", as used in this section, is hereby
defined as any place, building, structure, room or portion thereof which is
used for the purpose of washing, drying, starching or ironing shirts, dresses,
underwear, collars, cuffs or other wearing apparel, table, bed or other
household linens, towels, curtains, draperies or other washable fabrics, such
work being done for the general public. The term "laundry" shall also mean and
include any private laundry maintained or operated in connection with a hotel,
restaurant or public institution, except a hospital or charitable institution
where no charge is made for laundry services.
   B.   Operating Rules And Regulations: In addition to other provisions of
this code, laundry operating rules and regulations may be established by
resolution of the board from time to time. Failure to comply with these rules
and regulations shall constitute just cause for license revocation. (Ord. 81-
1601, 11-17-1981, eff. 1-1-1982)
   C.   Inspections: The health officer shall inspect or cause to be inspected,
from time to time, all premises wherein laundries are conducted, for the
purpose of ascertaining whether the provisions of this code and the laws of the
state relative to the keeping and operation of laundries are being complied
with, and it shall cause the same to be strictly enforced.
   D.   Exemptions From Provisions: The provisions of this section shall not
apply to any person engaged in doing custom laundry work at home for a regular
family trade, nor to any room, rooms or portion thereof, located in an
apartment, house or other dwelling, in which domestic laundry work is done by
or for the occupants of such building exclusively. (Ord. 81-1601, 11-17-1981,
eff. 1-1-1982; amd. 1997 Code)
3-5-6: PAINT STORES:
   A.   Definition: The term "paint store", for the purpose of this section, is
defined to mean any building, room, place, establishment or part of an
establishment in which any paint, varnish, enamel, shellac, linseed oil, tung
oil, turpentine, benzine, naphtha, denatured alcohol or similar inflammable
liquids are held, stored, sold or offered for sale at retail otherwise than in
sealed containers, whether or not in connection with the sale of painter's
tools, supplies and equipment. (Ord. 81-1601, 11-17-1981, eff. 1-1-1982)
   B.   Licensing Requirements: No person shall conduct or operate a paint
store in the village without first obtaining a license therefor. The
application for license shall be made as provided in chapter 1 of this title
and shall describe the premises as well as the location of the same. The
application shall be referred to the health officer and to the director of fire
and inspectional services, who shall have an investigation and inspection made
to determine the suitability of the premises from the viewpoint of sanitation,
fire prevention and public safety. If the application is approved by the health
officer and the director of fire and inspectional services, license shall be
issued upon payment of the prescribed fee 1 . (Ord. 81-1601, 11-17-1981, eff.
1-1-1982; amd. 1997 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  3-3-2 of this title.
3-5-7: PAWNBROKERS:
No person shall conduct or operate the business of pawnbroker within the
village. (Ord. 81-1601, 11-17-1981, eff. 1-1-1982)
CHAPTER 6
SPECIAL BUSINESS REGULATIONS III
SECTION:
3-6-1: Application Of Provisions; Eligibility If Debt Owed To Village
3-6-2: Undertakers
3-6-1: APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS; ELIGIBILITY IF DEBT OWED TO VILLAGE:
In addition to other requirements listed in the Code, the special provisions of
this Chapter shall apply to certain businesses and occupations.
   A.   Eligibility if Debt Owed to Village: See the provisions of Section
3-1-1(A) of this Code, which are incorporated by reference into this Title and
Chapter and are applicable to the grant or issuance of any Village approvals,
certificates, licenses or permits covered by this Chapter. (Ord. 81-1601, 11-
17-1981, eff. 1-1-1982; amd. Ord. 22-3091, 7-11-2022)
3-6-2: UNDERTAKERS:
   A.   Definition: The word "undertaker", as used in this Chapter, is defined
as a person engaging in the practice of funeral directing, as provided by
statute, whether together with or without the practice of embalming. This
definition includes, but without limitation thereto, the preparation of dead
human bodies for burial or cremation, the management of a funeral, the
conducting or management of an undertaking establishment, the use in connection
with a person's name or business of the term "funeral director", "undertaker",
"mortician", "funeral home", "funeral parlor" or any other term indicating that
such person is engaged in the business of funeral directing. (Ord. 81-1601, 11-
17-1981, eff. 1-1-1982)
   B.   Certification Required: No person shall be entitled to a license who
does not hold and keep currently in force a certificate as a registered funeral
director and a certificate as a registered embalmer, issued by the Department
of Professional Regulation.
   C.   Application For License: Application for license shall be made as
provided in Chapter 1 of this Title. The application shall also be accompanied
by proof that the applicant holds a State certificate as registered funeral
director and a State certificate as registered embalmer, and by evidence that
he knows and is familiar with the Village Code provisions and the regulations
of the Health Officer relating to the removal, preparation and burial or
cremation of the dead, that he has a practical knowledge of approved sanitary
methods of caring for dead human bodies and preparing the same for burial or
cremation, including the embalming and disinfection thereof, and that he is of
good moral character and a fit person to be licensed as undertaker. The
application, together with the supporting evidence, shall be referred to the
Health Officer, which shall consider the same and forward the application, with
its recommendation endorsed thereon, to the Village President. (Ord. 81-1601,
11-17-1981, eff. 1-1-1982; 1997 Code)
   D.   Issuance And Content Of License: Upon approval of the application by
the President and Board of Trustees, and payment of the prescribed fee 1 ,
license shall be issued. The license shall designate the particular premises in
which the applicant is permitted to conduct the business of undertaker and
shall not be valid as to any other place or premises. (Ord. 81-1601, 11-17-
1981, eff. 1-1-1982)
 
Notes

  3-3-2 of this Title.
ARTICLE A. PUBLIC PASSENGER VEHICLES
SECTION:

3-6A-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this Chapter, the following words and phrases shall have
the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this Section:
AUTHORIZED GARAGE: Official State of Illinois testing station, or other
designated facility.
LICENSEE: Any person, firm or corporation who is the owner of one or more
licenses issued pursuant to this Article.
LIVERY VEHICLE: Any public passenger vehicle transporting not more than the
rated passenger load per vehicle, for hire as a result of individual contract,
on a trip or hourly basis.
PUBLIC PASSENGER VEHICLE: Taxicabs and livery vehicles used for transportation
of passengers for hire.
PUBLIC PASSENGER VEHICLE CHAUFFEUR: Any person who drives a public passenger
vehicle in use for the transportation of persons for compensation.
PUBLIC PASSENGER VEHICLE OWNER: Any person owning a public passenger vehicle
for hire.
RATE CARD: A card used by the Village for display in each taxicab which
contains the rates of fare then in force.
TAXICAB: Any public passenger vehicle equipped with a taximeter and licensed as
a taxicab for the carriage of not more than the rated passenger load per
vehicle, for hire or from such destination as directed by such passenger hiring
such vehicle.
TAXICAB STAND: Any place, public (where designated by the Village Board), or
private (as designated by the private owner), where taxicabs are placed on
display and presented for hire to prospective customers, accepting such persons
as may offer themselves for transportation. Examples of taxicab stands are:
railroad stations, shopping centers, theatres, restaurants and any prominent
gathering place.
TAXIMETER: Any mechanical or electronic device attached to a taxicab which
records and indicates a charge or fare in dollars and cents measured by
distance and waiting time.
WAITING TIME: Shall include the time when the taxicab is not in motion,
beginning with the arrival at the place to which it has been called, or the
time consumed while standing at the direction of the passenger, but no charge
shall be made for the time lost on account of inefficiency of the taxicab, or
its operator, or time consumed by a premature response to a call. (Ord. 88-
1755, 7-25-1988)
3-6A-2: BUSINESS LICENSE REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   License Required; Exemptions: No person shall operate or permit a
public passenger vehicle which is owned or controlled to be operated as a
vehicle for hire upon the streets and to occupy public taxicab stands of the
Village without first having obtained a business license. This provision does
not apply to a person who is merely an employee of the owner of the vehicle or
who leases the vehicle from the licensee.
   B.   Application For License: The business license application, accompanied
by a nonrefundable fee as provided in Chapter 3 of this Title, will contain the
same information as is required by the Village for all businesses and, in
addition, shall be accompanied by a letter providing all of the following
additional information, as applicable, if not on the standard application form:
      1.   The name, age and address of the applicant in the case of an
individual; in the case of a partnership, the persons entitled to share in the
profits thereof; and in the case of a corporation, for profit, the date of
incorporation, the objects for which it was organized, the names and addresses
of the officers and directors, and if a majority interest of the stock of such
corporation is owned by one person or his nominee, the name and address of such
person.
      2.   The citizenship of the applicant; if a natural person, the place of
applicant's birth, or if a naturalized citizen, the time and place of
naturalization.
      3.   Current occupation/employment, business address and telephone
number.
      4.   Educational background.
      5.   Previous employment history.
      6.   Previous military history (if any) and type of discharge.
      7.   Current financial status, including any unpaid judgments and
pertinent information relative to any such judgments.
      8.   Any previous convictions of felony and/or traffic violations.
      9.   Previous residences for past five (5) years.
      10.   The number of vehicles to be operated or controlled by the
applicant and the location of proposed depots and terminals.
      11.   The color scheme or insignia to be used to designate the vehicle or
vehicles of the applicant not in conflict with emergency vehicles or existing
public passenger vehicles, as required by subsection 3-6A-9C of this Article.
      12.   Such further information as may be required by the Village.
   C.   Insurance Required:
      1.   Amount Of Insurance: Applicants for a license or renewal of a
license to operate a public passenger vehicle in the Municipality shall
produce: a) a certificate from the Secretary of State showing compliance by the
owner for each public passenger vehicle with the provisions of the statutes of
the State now or hereafter in force relating to the bonding or insurance of
motor vehicles used for carriage of passengers for hire; and b) a policy of
insurance or certificate of insurance showing that there is in full force and
effect a policy of insurance in not less than the following amounts:
 
Personal injury, each person $ 500,000.00
Each accident                1,000,000.00
Property damage              500,000.00
 
The applicant shall furnish to the Municipality a certificate of insurance
requiring that the coverage may not be cancelled, or materially changed,
without thirty (30) days' prior written notice.
      2.   Filing Insurance; Cancellation: All bonds or insurance policies
required by this Article or copies thereof, certified by the insurers or
surety, shall be filed with the Village Clerk, and shall not be subject to
cancellation, except on thirty (30) days' previous notice to the Village Clerk.
If any insurance is cancelled or permitted to lapse for any reason, the Village
Clerk shall suspend the licenses for the vehicles affected for a period of not
to exceed thirty (30) days, to permit other insurance to be supplied in
compliance with the provisions of this Article. If any such other insurance is
not supplied within the period of suspension of the license, the Village
President shall revoke the license for such vehicles.
   D.   Regular Telephone Service Required: Every holder of a public passenger
vehicle business license shall have and keep in service at all times while his
license is in effect, regular telephone service within the Village by means of
which a person desiring to rent a public passenger vehicle may call the
licensee by calling a local telephone number. The licensee shall cause the
telephone number to be listed in the local telephone directory which is
published in and for the Municipality by the telephone company which furnishes
local telephone service in the Village.
   E.   Public Passenger Service: All persons engaged in the public passenger
vehicle business in the Village operating under the provisions of this Code
shall operate every public passenger vehicle regularly in the Village to the
extent reasonably necessary to meet the public demands for passenger service.
They shall maintain a central place of business for the purpose of receiving
calls and dispatching vehicles. They shall answer all calls received by them
for service within the corporate limits of the Village as soon as they can do
so, and if said service cannot be rendered within a reasonable time, they shall
notify the prospective passengers how long it will be before the said call can
be answered and give the reason therefor. Any licensee who shall refuse to
accept a call anywhere within the corporate limits of the Village at any time
when such licensee has available vehicles, or who shall fail or refuse to give
overall service, shall be deemed in violation of this Code.
   F.   License Fee; Issuance: If the applicant conforms to the provisions of
this Code, and the application and background reveal nothing of a nature that
might endanger the health, safety and welfare of the general public as a result
of the possession of a license, then the Village Clerk shall issue a business
license upon receipt of the fee set out in Chapter 3 of this Title, or the
prorated payment of the first year's license fee.
   G.   Renewal Of License: The business license may be renewed annually upon
payment of an annual business license fee as set out in Chapter 3 of this
Title.
   H.   Transfer Of License: No business license may be sold, assigned,
mortgaged, pledged or otherwise transferred.
   I.   Suspension Or Revocation Of License:
      1.   The business license may be suspended by the Village Clerk and
revoked by the Village President, if the holder has:
         a.   Violated any provisions of this Code.
         b.   Discontinued operations for more than thirty (30) days.
         c.   Violated any ordinance of the Village or the laws of the United
States or the State related to the fitness of the holder to offer public
transportation.
      2.   Prior to suspension or revocation, the holder shall be given thirty
(30) days' notice of the proposed action to be taken, and shall have an
opportunity to be heard.
   J.   Change Of Stock Ownership:
      1.   A corporation holding a public passenger business license shall
advise the Village thirty (30) days prior to any contemplated change of stock
ownership involving five percent (5%) or more of the stock of the corporation.
      2.   Each individual seeking to acquire five percent (5%) or more of the
stock of a corporation holding a public passenger vehicle license shall comply
with the provisions of this Article as though he were applying for a license as
an individual.
      3.   The provisions of this subsection do not apply to corporations whose
stock is traded publicly and listed on recognized stock exchanges. (Ord. 88-
1755, 7-25-1988; 1997 Code)
3-6A-3: PUBLIC PASSENGER VEHICLE LICENSE REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   License Required: It shall be unlawful to operate a public passenger
vehicle for hire within the corporate limits of the Village, or to utilize
designated public taxicab stands, unless such vehicle is licensed and operated
under the terms and provisions of this Chapter. (Ord. 88-1755, 7-25-1988)
   B.   License Fee; Expiration Date: License fees per public passenger vehicle
shall be as set forth in Chapter 3 of this Title and shall expire on December
31, following the date of issuance. Any applicant not meeting the requirements
set forth in this Chapter shall be refused a license which will cause the fee
to be nonrefundable. (Ord. 88-1755, 7-25-1988; 1997 Code)
   C.   License Fees In Addition To Other Fees: Public passenger vehicle
license fee shall be in addition to all other State and Village vehicle fees
and also such compensation as may be required to be paid for the use of public
ways of the Village by any ordinance granting authority to operate any public
passenger vehicle upon such public ways.
   D.   Limitation On Number Of Licenses: There shall be no limitation on the
number of public passenger vehicle licenses issued, until such time as the
Village Board deems necessary.
   E.   Register Of Licenses: It shall be the duty of the Village Clerk to keep
a register of names of persons to whom licenses are granted, the date issued,
the number of the license and the description of the vehicle licensed.
   F.   License Nontransferable: It shall be unlawful to transfer any public
passenger vehicle license from one vehicle to another. Transference of any
public passenger vehicle license shall be grounds for revocation of all license
privileges. (Ord. 88-1755, 7-25-1988)
   G.   Suspension Of Licenses:
      1.   Faulty, Unclean Equipment: If, after the inspection and approval of
any public passenger vehicle, as provided for in this Chapter, such public
passenger vehicle shall from any cause become unsafe for the transportation of
passengers, or shall become unclean or unsightly in appearance, the license of
such public passenger vehicle shall be suspended by the Village Clerk until the
public passenger vehicle and all its accessories shall be put in fit condition
for public use and has been approved and inspected, as provided in this
Chapter.
      2.   False Statements By Licensee: In the event that the Village Clerk,
after investigation, shall determine that any licensee has obtained any license
for any public passenger vehicle by fraud, or false representation, or
misstatement of facts, the Village Clerk may, at his discretion, suspend such
license.
      3.   Default In Observance Of Provisions: In the event that any licensee
shall make default in the observance or performance of any one or more of the
agreements, conditions or obligations imposed upon such licensee by this
Article, and if any such default shall continue for a period of five (5) days
after written notice thereof from the Village Clerk, or his representative, to
the licensee citing the alleged default on the part of the licensee, then in
each and every such case, in addition to all rights and remedies of the Village
in such case, the Village Clerk may suspend, or the President of the Board of
Trustees may revoke, all public passenger vehicle licenses held by such
licensee, as provided in this Code. (Ord. 88-1755, 7-25-1988; 1997 Code)
3-6A-4: VEHICLE REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Inspection:
      1.   The Director of Law Enforcement Services will cause inspection of
public passenger vehicles to be done two (2) times per year at a State licensed
inspection lane at the owner's/operator's expense. (Ord. 88-1755, 7-25-1988)
      2.   Any public passenger vehicle company, after being notified to bring
all their public passenger vehicles in for inspection, will be allowed seven
(7) days to bring their vehicles in for inspection. After seven (7) days, the
license of all public passenger vehicles not inspected will be suspended by
direction of the Village Clerk. Such inspection will include, but not be
limited to, the following: (Ord. 88-1755, 7-25-1988; 1997 Code)
         a.   Vehicle, make, year and vehicle identification number.
         b.   State license number and year.
         c.   Village business license number and year.
         d.   Village vehicle license number and year.
         e.   Vehicle color.
         f.   Vehicle number.
         g.   Company name.
         h.   Service brakes.
         i.   Emergency brakes.
         j.   Horn.
         k.   Rear view mirror.
         l.   Windshield wipers and washers.
         m.   Headlights.
         n.   Taillights.
         o.   Stop lights.
         p.   Turn signals.
         q.   Speedometer.
         r.   Taximeter.
         s.   Rates displayed.
         t.   Steering.
         u.   Interior condition.
         v.   Exterior condition.
         w.   Windows.
         x.   Tires.
         y.   Current bond sticker.
      3.   If any public passenger vehicle fails to pass inspection as required
in this Article, a period of five (5) working days will be extended to allow
repairs. The vehicle cannot be used as a public passenger vehicle for hire
until repairs have been completed and it passes reinspection. (Ord. 88-1755, 7-
25-1988)
      4.   If repairs are not completed and the public passenger vehicle does
not pass reinspection within the five (5) working day period, its public
passenger vehicle license will be suspended by direction of the Village Clerk.
(Ord. 88-1755, 7-25-1988; 1997 Code)
      5.   Notwithstanding passage of a State licensed inspection lane, all
public passenger vehicles licensed by the Village shall, at all times, be
maintained in good repair and in a clean and neat condition. Any vehicle found
by the Director of Law Enforcement Services not to be in good repair or in a
clean and neat condition shall be prohibited from being used as a public
passenger vehicle for hire until such time as repairs shall be made and the
vehicle returned to good repair, or a neat and clean condition.
   B.   Name Of Owner Displayed On Taxicabs; Advertising Prohibited: Every
licensed taxicab shall bear on both sides of the vehicle in lettering in
contrast to the color of the vehicle, not less than two inches (2") in height,
the name of the cab company and its telephone number. All other commercial
advertising, including flashing lights and other attention-getting devices, is
prohibited.
   C.   Vehicle License Decal: The Village Clerk shall assign to each public
passenger vehicle a numbered vehicle license decal which shall be affixed to
the certified inspection plate. Such inspection plate shall be visibly
displayed in the lower left- hand corner of the rear window of the public
passenger vehicle.
   D.   Identification Number On Taxicabs: Each taxicab shall bear on both
exterior sides of the vehicle a minimum of three inches (3") in height and in a
conspicuous location with the passenger compartment four inches (4") in height,
in Arabic numerals, the identification number assigned to such vehicle by the
taxicab company. (Ord. 88-1755, 7-25-1988)
3-6A-5: CHAUFFEUR'S LICENSE REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   License Required: It shall be unlawful for any person to drive any
public passenger vehicle for hire within the Village without first having
obtained a public passenger vehicle chauffeur's license.
   B.   Unlawful To Employ Unlicensed Driver: No person owning, controlling or
operating any public passenger vehicle for hire within the Village shall
employ, or permit any person other than a licensed chauffeur, to operate such
vehicle upon the public ways in the corporate limits of the Village.
   C.   Application For License; Issuance:
      1.   Application Required: Any person desiring to secure a license as a
chauffeur of any public passenger vehicle under this Chapter and used for the
carriage of passengers for hire and reward, shall make application in writing
therefor to the Village upon form provided.
      2.   Contents Of Application: The application for a license as a
chauffeur of any public passenger vehicle mentioned in this Chapter shall set
forth the name of the applicant, his/her residence and occupation, current
status of his/her Illinois driver's license and number as given by the
Secretary of State of Illinois. He/she should be a fit person to drive or
operate a public passenger vehicle. Such applicant shall also indicate whether
or not he/she has ever had his/her State driver's license suspended or revoked
and if so, for what cause. Said applicant shall also indicate whether or not
he/she has ever been arrested and if so, for what cause. (Ord. 88-1755, 7-25-
1988)
      3.   Qualifications Of Applicant; Issuance Of License: Every applicant
for a license under this Chapter shall be eighteen (18) years of age or over.
Upon such application, the Director of Law Enforcement Services shall make, or
cause to be made, a careful and diligent inquiry as to the character, moral
turpitude, criminal and driving record of the applicant, and if it shall be
found that such applicant is deficient in any respect, such license shall be
refused for the entire year for which the license is sought. If the Director of
Law Enforcement Services shall be satisfied that the applicant is a fit person
to be licensed, such application shall be approved and the license issued.
   D.   Display Of Public Passenger Vehicle Chauffeur's License: The public
passenger vehicle chauffeur's license required by this Article shall be
displayed at all times in the public passenger vehicle in plain view of the
passenger. The applicant is not permitted to drive on a paid receipt issued by
the Village. The applicant must await processing through the Department of Law
Enforcement Services and the issuance of the chauffeur's license to operate a
public passenger vehicle. (Ord. 88-1755, 7-25-1988; 1997 Code)
   E.   License Fee And Expiration Date: The fee for a public passenger vehicle
chauffeur's license shall be as set forth in Chapter 3 of this Title, and such
license shall expire on December 31 following the date of issuance.
   F.   Transfer Of Chauffeur's License Prohibited: It shall be unlawful to
transfer any public passenger vehicle chauffeur's license from one person to
another. Transference of such license shall be grounds for revocation. (Ord.
88-1755, 7-25-1988)
   G.   Suspension Or Revocation Of License: In the case of any violation of
any of the provisions of this Chapter, or any traffic ordinance or regulation,
or any State law, the Village Clerk, at his discretion, may suspend, or the
President of the Board of Trustees may revoke, any passenger vehicle
chauffeur's license, as provided in Section
3-1-20 of this Title. (Ord. 88-1755, 7-25-1988; 1997 Code)
3-6A-6: LIVERY VEHICLES:
   A.   Fee And Inspection Required: No livery vehicle offered for hire by a
business licensed in the Village shall be operated unless an annual fee as set
forth in Chapter 3 of this Title is paid to the Village for each vehicle
operated as a limousine. The payment of the annual fee will be evidenced by a
windshield sticker issued by the Village which will issue instructions for
display of the sticker. In addition, each limousine shall be required to
successfully complete the same safety inspections as prescribed for taxicabs
(subsection 3-6A-4A of this Article).
   B.   Chauffeur's License Required: No person shall operate a limousine in
the Village, and no person who owns or controls a limousine shall permit it to
be so driven, and no limousine licensed by the Village shall be so driven at
any time for hire, unless the driver of said limousine shall have first
obtained and shall have then in force a public passenger vehicle chauffeur's
license issued under the provisions of this Article.
   C.   Operation Restrictions:
      1.   Soliciting Passengers: Livery vehicles shall not pick up or solicit
passengers for hire from the streets.
      2.   Parking In Taxicab Stands: Livery vehicles shall not park in taxicab
stands.
      3.   Contract For Service Only: Livery vehicles shall not
indiscriminately accept passengers, but shall be limited in scope of operation
to carrying passengers for hire on a contract basis at a price agreed upon
prior to employment, and by arrangement of the parties at the time of initial
telephone contact by customer to livery company. (Ord. 88-1755, 7-25-1988)
3-6A-7: RATES AND CHARGES:
   A.   Submission To Village: All licensees, owners or operators of taxicabs
shall submit to the Village Clerk every six (6) months, on January 1 and July
1, a notarized copy of the taxicab rates in effect on those dates and not less
than sixty (60) days prior to the effective date of any proposed rate change.
Every person shall be entitled to the service of the licensee at such
established rates and charges. Notwithstanding the above, the Village reserves
the right to establish rates and charges for taxicabs at any time. (Ord. 88-
1755, 7-25-1988; 1997 Code)
   B.   Posting Required: There shall be affixed on the inside of each taxicab
in a conspicuous place and in such manner that the same may be easily and
conveniently read by any person riding in such taxicab, a card in a frame
covered by glass or other transparent material upon which card shall be printed
in plain, legible type the rates of fare as prescribed by subsection A above.
(Ord. 88-1755, 7-25-1988)
3-6A-8: TAXIMETERS:
   A.   Working Meter Required: No taxicab shall operate with passengers for
hire unless the taximeter shall be accurately recording the fare to be charged.
   B.   Flag On Meters: Taximeter shall be equipped with a flag at least three
inches (3") by two inches (2") in size, either painted red or bearing thereon
letters at least one inch (1") in height, the word "Vacant" or the words "For
Hire". The flag post of such flag shall be kept towards a vertical position
when the taxicab is for hire and such flag post shall be immediately pulled
down and kept in a horizontal position when such taxicab is engaged, and the
taximeter shall register the fare as provided in subsection 3-6A-7A of this
Article.
   C.   Position And Illumination Of Taximeter: A taximeter shall be so located
that its face can be seen by a passenger from the rear compartment of the
vehicle. Adequate lighting facilities shall be provided for so illuminating the
face of the taximeter that the indications thereof may be conveniently read by
the passenger, and the face of the taximeter shall be so illuminated whenever
the taximeter is in operation and artificial illumination is necessary for the
convenient reading of its indications. (Ord. 88-1755, 7-25-1988)
   D.   Taximeter Distance Test:
      1.   A distance test of a taximeter shall be conducted by the test method
prescribed by the Director of Law Enforcement Services. Any taxicab company,
after being notified to bring their vehicles in for inspection will be allowed
seven (7) days to produce their vehicle for inspection.
      2.   The Village shall designate and certify their public passenger
vehicle inspection station(s), supply them with certified inspection forms and
procedures, as well as the numbered certified vehicle inspection stickers.
Also, the Village shall be responsible for spot checks of their inspection
station(s) to ensure compliance of the inspection procedures. After seven (7)
days, the license of all taxicabs not inspected will be suspended by the
Village Clerk. (Ord. 88-1755, 7-25-1988; 1997 Code)
   E.   Transfer Of Meter: No person controlling or operating any taxicab shall
transfer any taximeter to any other taxicab, unless a new inspection and
certification of such taximeter is made.
   F.   Tampering With Meters Prohibited: No person shall tamper with, break or
mutilate any taximeter, cable or seal thereof. (Ord. 88-1755, 7-25-1988)
3-6A-9: RESTRICTED OR PROHIBITED ACTS AND CONDITIONS:
   A.   Picking Up Additional Passengers After Vehicle Engaged: After any
operator, or person in charge of any public passenger vehicle used for hire or
reward, has been hired by one or more persons traveling together, such operator
shall not pick up other persons without the express permission of the person
first engaging the public passenger vehicle. An appropriate sign shall be
posted indicating the restrictions on shared rides.
   B.   Cruising And Soliciting: No driver of a public passenger vehicle
licensed under the provisions of this Chapter shall seek employment by
repeatedly or persistently driving his/her vehicle to and fro in a short space
before any theatre, hotel, railway station, or by otherwise interfering with
the proper and orderly ingress to or egress from any such place.
   C.   Distinctive Color And Logo Required: No taxicab, or the owner of a
taxicab, shall be licensed under the provisions of this Chapter if the vehicle
sought to be licensed as a taxicab is painted or labeled as to be so similar to
the automobiles or similar vehicle of any other person licensed and engaged in
the business of operating taxicabs in the Village as to be imitation thereof,
and calculated to deceive the patrons of taxicabs into believing that such
vehicles are in reality the taxicabs of such other person.
   D.   Number Of Passengers: No driver or operator of a public passenger
vehicle shall carry more than the rated passenger load per vehicle. (Ord. 88-
1755, 7-25-1988)
3-6A-10: RIGHTS OF FOREIGN PUBLIC PASSENGER VEHICLES:
Foreign public passenger vehicle companies licensed in another municipality or
meeting the statutory requirements for public carriers shall be permitted to
deliver passengers picked up outside of the Village to a destination in the
Village and shall be permitted to pick up passengers who arrange for services
within the Village limits for delivery to a location outside the Village
limits, without a license. Public passenger vehicle companies shall not be
permitted to pick up passengers within the Village for delivery to a location
within the Village, or to occupy public taxicab stands without having first
obtained a license and otherwise complying with all of the provisions of this
Chapter. (Ord. 88-1755, 7-25-1988)
3-6A-11: TAXICAB STANDS:
   A.   Establishment: Public taxicab stands shall be established from time to
time by the Village Board of Trustees as follows:
Hillgrove Avenue - South side - two (2) adjacent spaces between Lawn Avenue and
Grand Avenue.
   B.   Marking: Each public taxicab stand shall be appropriately marked and
erected under supervision of the Village Manager.
   C.   Use Of Stands:
      1.   It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle other than a taxicab
licensed by the Village in any public taxicab stand.
      2.   Only taxicabs licensed by the Village may be parked in any public
taxicab stand while such taxicab is occupied by its driver on duty awaiting a
fare. (Ord. 88-1755, 7-25-1988)
3-6A-12: SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF LICENSES:
In case of any violation of any of the provisions of this Chapter, or any
traffic ordinance or regulation, or any State law, the Village Clerk, at his
discretion, may suspend, or the President of the Board of Trustees may revoke,
any license, as provided in Section
3-1-20 of this Title. (Ord. 88-1755, 7-25-1988; 1997 Code)
ARTICLE B. SCAVENGERS
SECTION:
3-6B-1: License Required
3-6B-2: Classification Of Scavengers
3-6B-3: Application For License; Issuance
3-6B-4: Number Of Licenses; Fees
3-6B-5: Insurance Requirements
3-6B-6: Vehicles And Equipment Requirements
3-6B-7: Disposal
3-6B-8: Special Definitions
3-6B-9: Title To Waste
CROSS REFERENCES

Occupations; Schedule Of Fees), Section 3-3-2 (License Fees)
   Title 5 (Public Health And Safety), Chapter 4 (Solid Waste, Landscape Waste
And Recycling)

   Household Goods Recycling Bins, see 65 ILCS 5/11-42-16

3-6B-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall engage in the business of scavenger activities, or the
collection of construction debris, electronic waste or e- recyclable items,
hazardous waste, landscape waste, medical waste, municipal solid waste, special
waste, solid waste or recyclable materials, as these terms are defined by this
Code or by applicable law or regulation, within the corporate limits of the
Village without having first secured a license to conduct such business. (Ord.
97-1992, 1-27-1997; amd. Ord. 19-2981, 11-25-2019)
3-6B-2: CLASSIFICATION OF SCAVENGERS:
   A.   Residential Scavengers: The Village may, from time to time, enter into
exclusive or non-exclusive contracts with one (1) or more scavengers to provide
collection and removal service of construction debris, electronic waste or e-
recyclable items, landscape waste, solid waste, or recyclable materials to
single- and multi-family dwelling units containing four (4) units or less
within the Village for the price and under terms and conditions contained in
the contracts and subject to the limitations contained in this Code. All
Village approved residential scavengers shall be issued a Village license prior
to providing such collection and removal services.
   B.   Commercial Scavengers: The Village may, from time to time, enter into
exclusive or non-exclusive contracts with one (1) or more commercial scavengers
or issue annual licenses to commercial scavengers subject to the limitations
contained in this Code to provide collection and removal service of
construction debris, electronic waste or e- recyclable items, hazardous waste,
landscape waste, medical waste, municipal solid waste, special waste, solid
waste or recyclable materials at commercial establishments (for example,
business establishments, medical facilities and offices, municipal buildings,
religious and civic organizations, construction work sites, industrial
establishments and dwelling units containing more than four (4) units) within
the Village. All Village approved commercial scavengers shall be issued a
Village license prior to providing such collection and removal services.
   C.   Intermittent Scavengers: The Village may issue annual licenses subject
to the limitations contained in this Code to scavengers not already licensed
under subsection A or B of this Section to provide for intermittent collection
and removal of construction debris, electronic waste or e- recyclable items,
hazardous waste, landscape waste, medical waste, municipal solid waste, special
waste, solid waste or recyclable materials within the Village. All Village
approved intermittent scavengers shall be issued a Village license prior to
providing such collection and removal services. (Ord. 97-1992, 1-27-1997; amd.
Ord. 19-2981, 11-25-2019)
3-6B-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; ISSUANCE:
Applications for scavenger licenses shall be made to the Village Clerk.
Licenses for the collection and removal of construction debris, electronic
waste or e-recyclable items, landscape waste, solid waste or recyclable
materials from single-family or multi-family residential units containing four
(4) units or less shall be issued only to the contractors having contracts for
the collection and removal of such materials with the Village. Other licenses
shall be issued by the Village Clerk after the application has been reviewed by
the Village Manager and signed by the Village President, and satisfactory
evidence has been received that the license complies with the terms of this
Chapter and all other sections of this Code. Each application shall be
accompanied by the following:
   A.   A list of all communities presently serviced by the applicant, and any
communities where service has been discontinued within the last two (2) years.
   B.   Satisfactory evidence of the availability to the applicant for the full
license period of a sanitary landfill site or other authorized disposal
facility at which all construction debris, electronic waste or e- recyclable
items, hazardous waste, landscape waste, medical waste, municipal solid waste,
special waste, solid waste or recyclable materials collected and removed from
the Village may be disposed of and evidence that such landfill or disposal
facility is operating in accordance with all applicable Federal, State, or
local regulations.
   C.   A list of the equipment to be used to render service in the event a
license is issued indicating the make, year, size and condition of each vehicle
to be utilized within the Village.
   D.   A customer list with service addresses within the Village that the
applicant provides services to. (Ord. 97-1992, 1-27-1997; amd. Ord. 19-2981,
11-25-2019)
3-6B-4: NUMBER OF LICENSES; FEES:
   A.   Number Of Licenses: The number of licenses issued by the Village shall
be limited as follows:
      1.   Residential Scavengers: Annual licenses shall be issued to a
residential scavenger only if the scavenger has a contract with the Village to
provide waste collection and removal services within the Village. Such licenses
shall not restrict the licensee(s) from collecting waste from multi-family
dwellings containing more than four (4) units or commercial establishments.
      2.   Commercial Scavengers: Annual licenses shall be issued to all those
applicants who apply for a license as a commercial scavenger for waste
collection and removal from multi-family dwellings or commercial establishments
on a regular basis within the corporate limits of the Village, provided the
applicants satisfy the requirements contained in this Code and pay the annual
license fee.
      3.   Intermittent Scavengers: Annual licenses shall be issued to all
those applicants who apply for a license as an intermittent scavenger and who
satisfy the requirements contained in this Code, and pay the annual license
fee.
   B.   Fees:
      1.   Fees Established: The fees for such licenses shall be established
from time to time by the Village Board and set forth in Chapter 3 of this
Title.
      2.   Nonrefundable Fee: Revocation of a license by action of the
President and Board of Trustees shall not entitle licensee to a refund of all
or any part of the license fee. (Ord. 97-1992, 1-27-1997; amd. Ord. 19-2981,
11-25-2019)
3-6B-5: INSURANCE REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Amount Of Insurance: Prior to the issuance of a license, the applicant
shall present to the Village Clerk a certificate of insurance issued by an
insurance company licensed to do business in the State that evidences insurance
covering the applicant against public liability and property damage with limits
of liability not less than the following:
 
Worker's compensation              Statutory as amended from time to time
Employer's liability               $ 500,000.00 each occurrence
Bodily injury liability, except    500,000.00 each occurrence
automobile                         1,000,000.00 aggregate
Property damage liability, except  500,000.00 each occurrence
automobile                         1,000,000.00 aggregate
Automobile bodily injury liability 1,000,000.00 each person
                                   3,000,000.00 each occurrence
Automobile property damage         500,000.00 each occurrence
 
   B.   Cancellation: Each such certificate shall have an endorsement to the
effect that such insurance may not be cancelled by the insurer thereof without
at least sixty (60) days' prior written notice to the Village. (Ord. 97-1992,
1-27-1997)
3-6B-6: VEHICLES AND EQUIPMENT REQUIREMENTS:
The licensee shall use only modern, enclosed, leakproof, packer-type disposal
truck bodies for all regularly scheduled residential and commercial service.
Other vehicles used for the purpose of removing and disposing of waste covered
by this Code shall be watertight and equipped with airtight covers. (Ord. 97-
1992, 1-27-1997; amd. Ord. 19-2981, 11-25-2019)
3-6B-7: DISPOSAL:
All waste covered by this Code collected in the Village shall be removed and
disposed of outside the corporate limits of the Village before the close of
business on the day collected. (Ord. 97-1992, 1-27-1997; amd. Ord. 19-2981, 11-
25-2019)
3-6B-8: SPECIAL DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this Code, the following definitions apply:
CONSTRUCTION DEBRIS: Shall have the same meaning as in the Illinois
Environmental Protection Act, 415 ILCS 5/1 et seq. and the regulations adopted
thereunder.
ELECTRONIC WASTE OR E-RECYCLABLE ITEMS: Any item defined as a "covered
electronic device" by 415 ILCS 150, the Illinois Electronics Products Recycling
and Refuse Act. E-recyclable items shall include, but not be limited to,
computers, computer monitors, televisions, printers, keyboards, fax machines,
videocassette recorders, portable digital music players, digital video disc
players, video game consoles, computer mice, scanners, digital converter boxes,
cable receivers, satellite receivers, digital video disc recorders or small-
scale servers, or any other electronic device banned from landfill disposal by
the State of Illinois pursuant to the Illinois Electronic Products Recycling
and Reuse Act.
HAZARDOUS WASTE: Waste or combination of wastes which, because of its quantity,
concentration, or physical, chemical or infectious characteristics, may cause
or significantly contribute to an increase in mortality or an increase in
serious, irreversible or incapacitating reversible illness; or pose a
substantial present or potential hazard to human health or the environment when
improperly treated, stored, transported or disposed of, or otherwise managed,
or which has been identified, by characteristics or listing, as being hazardous
or having such impacts pursuant to Section 3001 of the Resource Conservation
and Recovery Act of 1976 (P.L. 94-580), pursuant to Pollution Control Board,
Federal Regulations or other applicable laws, ordinances or regulations.
LANDSCAPE WASTE: All accumulations of grass or shrubbery cuttings, leaves, tree
limbs, trees and other material accumulated as the result of the care of lawns,
shrubbery, vines and trees, which are generated by a residential unit.
Christmas trees will be considered “landscape waste.” Christmas trees will be
considered “landscape waste,” but may be collected by the contractor under a
special pick-up schedule.
MUNICIPAL SOLID WASTE: Any solid waste resulting from the operation of Village
buildings, facilities and properties, other Village-designated public
buildings, facilities and properties, the Downtown Business District and from
Village-sponsored special events and other community activities.
PLACED FOR COLLECTION: Placement at the curb, alley, or at the back door for
collection by the Village.
SOLID WASTE: Refuse, garbage or other discarded material generated by those
residing in residential units and by those occupying non-residential structures
within the Village, including all waste, as defined by Section 3.53 of the
Illinois Environmental Protection Act, 415 ILCS 5/3.53, which is not hazardous,
and other discarded or abandoned material including, without limitation,
garbage, refuse, rubbish, bulk items and small amounts of building materials
and construction or demolition debris, or other similar waste. “Solid waste”
shall not include bulk items, construction debris, e-recyclables, hazardous
waste, landscape waste, recyclable materials and white goods. (Ord. 97-2004, 4-
28-1997; amd. Ord. 19-2981, 11-25-2019)
3-6B-9: TITLE TO WASTE:
Title to any waste covered by this Code shall pass to the scavenger when
collected by the scavenger, unless otherwise agreed to in writing by the
contracting parties. (Ord. 97-2004, 4-28-1997; amd. Ord. 19-2981, 11-25-2019)
CHAPTER 7
SPECIAL BUSINESS REGULATIONS IV: FOOD ESTABLISHMENTS
SECTION:
3-7-1: Application Of Provisions
3-7-2: Adoption Of Food Sanitation Code
3-7-3: Amendments To Food Sanitation Code
3-7-4: Home Kitchen Operations
3-7-1: APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS:
In addition to other requirements listed in this Code, the following special
requirements shall apply to food service, food processing and retail food
establishments. (Ord. 81-1601, 11-17-1981, eff. 1-1-1982)
3-7-2: ADOPTION OF FOOD SANITATION CODE:
There is hereby adopted by the Village for the purpose of prescribing
regulations governing the licensing and operation of food service, food
processing and retail food establishments, that certain code known as the "Food
Service Sanitation" recommended by the State of Illinois, Department of Public
Health, being particularly the 1975 Edition thereof, save and except such
portions as are hereinafter deleted, modified or amended (by Section
3-7-3 of this Chapter), of which Code not less than three (3) copies have been
and now are filed in the office of the Village Clerk, and the same are hereby
adopted and incorporated as fully as if set out at length herein, and from the
effective date hereof, the provisions thereof shall be controlling within the
limits of the Village. (Ord. 81-1601, 11-17-1981, eff. 1-1-1982)
3-7-3: AMENDMENTS TO FOOD SANITATION CODE:
The Food Sanitation Code is amended and changed in the following respects:
Rule 1.01(q): The following paragraph of the Food Sanitation Code shall be
amended to read as follows as Rule 1.01 (q):
"Regulatory authority" means the Illinois Department of Public Health, or the
Village of Western Springs.
Rule 2.01(b): The following paragraph shall be added to the Food Sanitation
Code as Rule 2.01(b):
No person shall manufacture for sale, produce, offer for sale or sell any
product, drug, or article of food which is adulterated, misbranded or
insufficiently labeled. The term "misbranded" as used herein, shall apply to
all articles of food or drink, the packages of which bear any statement, design
or device regarding such article or the ingredients or substance contained
therein which is false or misleading in any particular; it shall also apply to
any such products which are falsely branded as to the manufacturer, packer or
dealer who sells the same, or as to the state, territory or country in which it
is manufactured or produced. The term "insufficiently labeled" as used herein
shall mean if a package, bottle, or container of food does not bear the name of
the real manufacturer or jobber, the true grade or class of the product, and
the true net weight or volume of the contents or the capacity or trade size of
the container.
Rule 3.01(a): The following paragraph of the Food Sanitation Code shall be
amended to read as follows as Rule 3.01(a):
No person while affected with a disease in a communicable form or while a
carrier of such disease, or while afflicted with boils, infected wounds, or
acute respiratory infection, shall work in a food service, food processing, or
retail food establishment in an area and capacity in which there is a
likelihood of transmission of disease to patrons or to fellow employees, either
through direct contact or through the contamination of food or food contact
surfaces with pathogenic organisms. No such person shall be employed in such an
area and capacity in a food service, food processing or retail food
establishment.
   (Ord. 81-1601, 11-17-1981, eff. 1-1-1982)
Article 10: The following paragraphs shall be added to the Food Sanitation Code
as Article 10:
Rule 10.01 - Enforcement of Food Sanitation Code. The Health Officer, the
Village Manager, and the police officers of the Village shall have the power to
enforce all laws of the State and the provisions of this Code in relation to
the food sanitation regulations of the Village. And for the purpose of carrying
out the foregoing, the Health Officer, or any agent thereof, the Village
Manager or his agent, or any police officer of the Village shall have authority
at all times to enter into any food establishment to inspect and record the
conditions and to inspect any article there held or offered for sale, which he
has reason to believe is decayed, poisoned, adulterated, infected or in any way
unfit for human consumption, to seize and confiscate the same forthwith. Any
person, whether owner, operator, or occupant of said store, room, or premises,
who shall obstruct such entry or inspection or interfere with such seizure or
confiscation shall be guilty of a misdemeanor.
Rule 10.02 - Inspection of Food. The Health Officer or agent thereof, the
Village Manager or his agent and the police officers of the Village shall have
power and authority to open any package, can or vessel containing or supposed
to contain any article manufactured, sold, or exposed for sale, or held in
possession with intent to sell, in violation of the provisions of this Code,
and may inspect the contents thereof and may take samples therefrom for
analysis. All parties offering food products for sale shall render to such
officers all the assistance in their power, when so requested, in disclosing
the presence of any article prohibited by law, and in selecting samples of food
products as hereinafter provided.
Rule 10.03 - Samples and Selection. The Health Officer or the inspector taking
such samples as are provided in Rule 10.02 shall, in the case of bulk or broken
package goods, upon request of the dealer, divide the same into two (2) equal
parts, as nearly as may be, and in case of sealed and unbroken packages, he
shall select two (2) of said packages, which two (2) said packages shall
constitute the sample taken, and to properly identify the same, he shall in the
presence of the person from whom the sample is taken, mark or seal each half or
part or package of such sample with a paper seal or otherwise and shall write
thereon the date and the name of the dealer in whose place of business the
sample is found, and at the same time he shall give notice to the person from
whom said sample was taken, that said sample was obtained for the purpose of
chemical examination.
   (Ord. 81-1601, 11-17-1981, eff. 1-1-1982; 1997 Code)
3-7-4: HOME KITCHEN OPERATIONS:
A “home kitchen operation” means a person who produces or packages non-
potentially hazardous baked goods in the kitchen of that person’s primary
domestic residence for direct sale by the owner or a family member. A person
who produces non-potentially hazardous baked goods for sale by a religious,
charitable, or nonprofit organization for fundraising purposes is exempt from
these requirements.
Home kitchen operations are authorized in the village, subject to the following
requirements:
   A.   Home kitchen operations shall obtain and maintain a village-issued
business license pursuant to section
3-1-1  (Licenses Required), Chapter 1 (General Licensing Procedures and
Regulations) of Title 3 (Business Regulations) of the village code.
   B.   Home kitchen operations shall submit a written disclosure to the
village yearly, on or before each May 1, including a federal employer
identification number, a copy of a current food protection manager
certification from the Illinois department of public health and such other
information and materials as the health officer may require.
   C.   Home kitchen operations shall comply with the following requirements:
      1.   Packaging or production shall be limited to non- potentially
hazardous baked goods, as defined in 410 ILCS 625/4(a), as amended from time to
time, which shall occur in a kitchen of a primary domestic residence for direct
sale by the owner or a family member.
      2.   Non-potentially hazardous baked goods include goods such as, but not
limited to, breads, cookies, cakes, pies, and pastries are allowed. Only high-
acid fruit pies that use the following fruits are allowed: apple, apricot,
grape, peach, plum, quince, orange, nectarine, tangerine, blackberry,
raspberry, blueberry, boysenberry, cherry, cranberry, strawberry, red currants,
or a combination of these fruits.
      3.   Monthly gross sales shall not exceed one thousand dollars
($1,000.00).
      4.   A notice shall be provided to the purchaser that the product was
produced in a home kitchen.
      5.   The food package shall conform to the labeling requirements of the
Illinois food, drug and cosmetic act and the FDA and the food package shall be
affixed with a label or other written notice provided to the purchaser that
includes:
         a.   The common or usual name of the food product;
         b.   Allergen labeling as specified in federal labeling requirements
by the United States food and drug administration;
         c.   The phrase “This product was produced in a home kitchen not
subject to public health inspection that may also process common food
allergens.”;
         d.   The date made; and
         e.   The name and address of the home kitchen operation.
      6.   The food shall be sold directly to the consumer.
      7.   At the point of sale, a placard is displayed in a prominent location
that states the following: “This product was produced in a home kitchen not
subject to public health inspection that may also process common food
allergens.”
      8.   The food shall be stored in the residence where it is produced or
packaged.
      9.   A food protection manager certification from the Illinois department
of public health shall be maintained.
      10.   Additional requirements, if any, from 410 ILCS 625/3.6, as amended
from time to time.
   D.   Upon receipt of a complaint regarding a home kitchen operation, the
health officer shall make or cause to have made an inspection of a home kitchen
operation. Other inspections, surveys, investigations and studies of home
kitchen operations shall be performed by the health officer as may be necessary
to determine that home kitchen operations are constructed, operated and
maintained in compliance with the standards and requirements set forth herein.
   E.   All applicable regulations of Title 10 (Development Control Ordinance)
(“DCO”) of the village code, specifically sections
10-4-4  (Accessory Uses And Structures) and
10-4-6  (Home Occupations) of Chapter 4 (Development Standards Of General
Applicability) of the DCO apply to home kitchen operations. (Ord. 21-3043, 5-
24-2021)
CHAPTER 8
SPECIAL BUSINESS REGULATIONS VI: PEDDLERS,
SOLICITORS AND CANVASSERS
SECTION:
3-8-1: Application Of Provisions
3-8-2: Definitions
3-8-3: Village Policy On Peddling, Soliciting And Canvassing
3-8-4: Hours And Days For Peddling, Soliciting Or Canvassing
3-8-5: Exception For Local Charitable Organizations
3-8-6: Exemption
3-8-1: APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS:
In addition to other requirements listed in this code, the special provisions
of this chapter shall apply to certain businesses and occupations. (Ord. 81-
1601, 11-17-1981, eff. 1-1-1982)
3-8-2: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the following words and terms shall have the meanings
ascribed to them in this section:
CANVASSER: A person who travels from residence to residence, or place to place,
without appointment, attempting to obtain signatures on petitions on behalf of
political parties or on petitions related to public policy questions, or a
"canvasser" may also solicit for gifts or contributions of money or property of
any kind while canvassing for signatures on petitions.
CHARITABLE ORGANIZATION: Any religious, benevolent, civic, educational, social
service, philanthropic, patriot, not for profit group, association or
corporation.
ITINERANT VENDOR: Any person who transports tangible personal property for
retail sale within the village who does not maintain in the village an
established office, distribution house, sales house, warehouse, service center
or residence from which such business is conducted. However, the provisions of
this chapter do not apply to any person who delivers tangible personal property
within the village who is fulfilling an order for such property which was
solicited or placed by mail or other means. This chapter does not apply to any
person holding a valid license, issued by the village, to engage in retail
sales.
PEDDLER: A person commonly referred to as a peddler or hawker who sells or
offers for sale goods, insurance or services of any character or description
and merchandise, traveling from residence to residence or place to place
without appointment, or who sells or offers for sale and delivery from any
vehicle going from place to place, goods, wares and merchandise to purchasers.
PEDDLING: Means and includes the activities of any person, firm or agent or
employee of any corporation going in or upon any private residence, apartment
or premises in the village, without appointment, for the purpose of selling or
soliciting from the occupants thereof, or canvassing for, orders for goods,
wares and merchandise or services of any character or description or for the
purpose of offering to give or to furnish or giving or furnishing any goods,
wares, merchandise or services to any such occupants or inviting such orders
without first having obtained the consent of the occupant or occupants thereof.
RESIDENCE: Means and includes every separate living unit occupied for
residential purposes by one or more persons, contained within any type of
building or structure.
SOLICITOR: A person who travels from residence to residence, or place to place,
without appointment and who, on behalf of a charitable organization, seeks to
obtain gifts or contributions of money or property of any kind or value,
including the payment for literature.
TRANSIENT MERCHANT: Any person who is engaged temporarily in the retail sale of
goods, wares or merchandise in the village and who, for the purpose of
conducting such business, occupies any building, room, vehicle, structure of
any kind, or vacant lot. However, this chapter does not apply to any person
selling goods, wares or merchandise which are raised, produced or manufactured
by him, to any person selling vegetables, fruit or perishable farm products at
an established village market, to any person operating a store or refreshment
stand at a resort, to any person operating a stand or booth on or adjacent to
property owned by him or upon which he resides, to any person operating a stand
or booth at any fair in the village, or to any person operating a stand or
booth at a trade show, exposition, convention or similar event. This chapter
does not apply to any person holding a valid license, issued by the village, to
engage in retail sales. (Ord. 81-1601, 11-17-1981, eff. 1-1-1982; amd. 1997
Code; Ord. 05-2357, 9-26-2005)
3-8-3: VILLAGE POLICY ON PEDDLING, SOLICITING AND CANVASSING:
   A.   Policy On Peddling, Soliciting And Canvassing: It is hereby declared to
be the policy of the corporate authorities of the village that the occupants of
the residences in the village shall make the determination of whether peddlers,
solicitors, canvassers, transient merchants or itinerant vendors shall be, or
shall not be, invited to their respective residences. If no determination is
made, as is provided in subsection B of this section, then in that event, the
peddling, soliciting or canvassing is permitted.
   B.   Notice Regulating Peddling, Soliciting And Canvassing: Every person
desiring to secure the protection intended to be provided by the regulations
pertaining to peddling, soliciting or canvassing contained in this chapter
shall comply with the following directions:
      1.   Notice To Peddlers, Solicitors, Canvassers, Transient Merchants And
Itinerant Vendors: Notice of the determination by the occupant of giving
invitation to peddlers, solicitors, canvassers, transient merchants or
itinerant vendors or the refusal of invitation to peddlers, solicitors,
canvassers, transient merchants or itinerant vendors to any residence shall be
given by exhibiting upon request or near the main entrance door to the
residence, a weatherproof card approximately three inches by four inches (3" x
4") in size, indicating the determination by the occupant, containing the
applicable words, as follows:
ONLY PEDDLERS, SOLICITORS, CANVASSERS TRANSIENT MERCHANTS OR ITINERANT VENDORS
REGISTERED IN WESTERN SPRINGS INVITED
   or
NO PEDDLERS, SOLICITORS, CANVASSERS TRANSIENT MERCHANTS OR ITINERANT VENDORS
INVITED.
      2.   Print Requirements; Issuance Of Cards: The letters shall be at least
one-third inch (1/3") in height. For the purpose of uniformity, the cards shall
be provided free of charge at the village hall by the village clerk to persons
requesting same.
      3.   Effect Of Notice: Such card so exhibited shall constitute sufficient
notice to any peddler, solicitor, canvasser, transient merchant or itinerant
vendor of the determination by the occupant of the residence of the information
contained thereon.
   C.   Duties Of Peddler, Solicitor, Canvasser, Transient Merchant Or
Itinerant Vendor: It shall be the duty of every peddler, solicitor, canvasser,
transient merchant or itinerant vendor upon going onto any premises in the
village upon which a "residence", as defined in section
3-8-2 of this chapter, is located, to first examine the notice provided for in
subsection B of this section, if any is attached, and be governed by the
statement contained on the notice. If the notice states "ONLY PEDDLERS,
SOLICITORS, CANVASSERS, TRANSIENT MERCHANTS OR ITINERANT VENDORS LICENSED IN
WESTERN SPRINGS INVITED", then the peddler, solicitor, canvasser, transient
merchant or itinerant vendor not possessing a valid license, as provided in
this chapter, shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises; and if
the notice states, "NO PEDDLERS, SOLICITORS, CANVASSERS, TRANSIENT MERCHANTS OR
ITINERANT VENDORS INVITED", then the peddler, solicitor, canvasser, transient
merchant or itinerant vendor, whether registered or not, shall immediately and
peacefully depart from the premises. Any peddler, solicitor, canvasser,
transient merchant or itinerant vendor who has gained entrance to any
residence, whether invited or not, shall immediately and peacefully depart from
the premises when requested to do so by the occupant.
   D.   Uninvited Peddling, Soliciting Or Canvassing Prohibited: It is hereby
declared to be unlawful and shall constitute a nuisance for any person to go
upon any premises and ring the doorbell upon or near any door, or create any
sound in any other manner calculated to attract the attention of the occupant
of such residence, for the purpose of securing an audience with the occupant
thereof and engage in "peddling", "soliciting" or "canvassing", as defined in
section
3-8-2 of this chapter, in defiance of the notice exhibited at the residence in
accordance with the provisions of subsection B of this section. (Ord. 81-1601,
11-17-1981, eff. 1-1-1982; amd. 1997 Code)
3-8-4: HOURS AND DAYS FOR PEDDLING, SOLICITING OR CANVASSING:
It is hereby declared to be unlawful and shall constitute a nuisance for any
person, whether registered under this chapter or not, to go upon any premises
and ring the doorbell upon or near any door of a residence located thereon, or
rap or knock on any door, or create any sound in any other manner calculated to
attract the attention of the occupant of such residence, for the purpose of
securing an audience with the occupant thereof and engage in "peddling",
"soliciting" or "canvassing", as herein defined, prior to nine o'clock (9:00)
A.M. or after eight o'clock (8:00) P.M. of any weekday and Saturday or at any
time on a Sunday or on a state or national holiday. (Ord. 05-2357, 9-26-2005)
3-8-5: EXCEPTION FOR LOCAL CHARITABLE ORGANIZATIONS:
The registration and license requirements of this chapter may be waived by the
village clerk in those instances where the clerk has determined, following an
investigation made upon receipt of an application by an organization complying
with all of the conditions of this chapter as follows: The proposed peddling,
soliciting or canvassing is to be a single peddling, soliciting or canvassing
conducted for or on behalf of a charitable or nonprofit association,
organization, corporation or project solely by residents of the village who
shall not be compensated for conducting said peddling, soliciting or canvassing
and who have not violated any provisions of this chapter which would otherwise
cause a revocation of a registration certificate. This section shall in no way
modify the notice provisions of subsection
3-8-3B of this chapter, and no peddling, soliciting or canvassing pursuant to
this section shall be made of those residents displaying either of the two (2)
notices described in said subsection
3-8-3B of this chapter. (Ord. 81-1601, 11-17-1981, eff. 1-1-1982; amd. 1997
Code)
3-8-6: EXEMPTION:
