rights-of-way, drainage, easements, and other public properties not under
direct jurisdiction of the Director.
      3   Interference. No person shall hinder, prevent, delay, or interfere
with the Director or their agents while engaged in carrying out the execution
or enforcement of this chapter.
   B.   The Village shall have on staff or contract with at least two (2)
certified arborists or foresters. Any urban forestry work completed by a
contractor within the Village shall be under the direction of a certified
arborist or the Village Forester. These individuals are responsible for
enforcement and compliance of the Urban Forest Management Plan.
   C.   The Village shall have an urban forest inventory of publicly owned
trees. This inventory shall be maintained in a current state. Reinventory may
be required every five (5) to seven (7) years unless the inventory is updated
with the pruning cycle or is updated as part of routine tree maintenance.
   D.   The Village shall have an approved Urban Forest Management Plan. This
plan shall be the framework for the protection, management and planting of
trees within the Village and shall support and clearly define regulations
identified in the Tree Preservation Ordinance. This plan shall include the
following:
      1.   A defined ten (10) year urban forestry strategy with clearly
identified one (1), five (5), and ten (10) years goals;
      2.   Community canopy mapping identifying existing tree canopy and
priority locations for planting;
      3.   A strategy for completion and maintenance of a tree inventory on
public and private property;
      4.   Clear guidelines on tree species and age diversity;
      5.   Clear identification of replacement value and requirements for tree
removal or damage;
      6.   A preferred tree list;
      7.   Clearly defined specifications for tree planting, pruning, and
impact reduction;
      8.   A risk assessment and management program;
      9.   A legacy tree preservation and protection program including a legacy
tree list;
      10.   A strategy for management, preservation and protection of
naturalized areas;
      11.   A strategy for administration and implementation of a volunteer
program;
      12.   Clear identification of staff qualifications, training, support and
needs;
      13.   Specifications for contracted labor and consulting;
      14.   Clear identification of forestry equipment and resource needs; and
      15.   A forestry budget with one (1), five (5) and ten (10) year
commitments.
   E.   The Village shall require that any contractor, working for the Village
who may interact or have impact on the Village public property urban forest
utilize a certified arborist for all work pertaining to trees, including but
not limited to removal, pruning and planting activities.
   F.   Legacy and underrepresented trees are provided special protection by
the Village.
   G.   All tree planting, selection and management shall be in compliance with
the Village Urban Forest Management Plan.
   H.   It is recognized that diverse species and age structure of urban trees
throughout the Village are critical to the health of the forest structure and
protects the Village from catastrophic loss and improved longevity.
Specifications for species and age diversity, planting and management are
contained in the Urban Forest Management Plan. (Ord. 20-3006, 6-22-2020; amd.
Ord. 23-3128, 3-20-2023; Ord. 23-3149, 10-23-2023)
5-5-4: TREE CARE:
Tree care within the Village, on public lands, shall comply with requirements
identified in the Urban Forest Management Plan. It is recommended that tree
care on private property meet these same requirements. (Ord. 20-3006, 6-22-
2020)
5-5-5: TREE PERMIT REQUIREMENTS GENERALLY:
   A.   Permit Required: No person shall plant, spray, trim, remove or fasten
any wire or rope to or otherwise interfere with the health or growth of any
tree in a park, parkway, or other Village property (excluding approved methods
for systemic elm injections) without procuring a Village-issued tree permit
from the Community Development Department, as herein provided. In the case of
tree management practices, these practices shall comply with the requirements
identified in the Village-approved Urban Forest Management Plan. If a removal
or planting is significant or in conjunction with any type of development, then
a full tree preservation and management plan and inventory for the area to be
impacted shall be required. The Director of Municipal Services, or their
designee, shall review the tree permit application. This review shall include
an inspection of the site and referral of the application for recommendation to
other appropriate administrative departments or agencies. The Director of
Municipal Services, or their designee, shall render a decision on the
application within ten (10) business days of its receipt of a properly
completed application.
   B.   Application For Tree Permit: Applications for tree permits shall be
made on blanks furnished by the Community Development Department. Such
applications shall describe in detail the variety, size and precise location of
each tree that the permittee desires to plant and/or the nature of all other
planned tree work.
   C.   Documents On Site: Copies of all appropriate Village permits and other
applicable government permits and related documents shall be kept at the
project site and promptly be made available to any Village employee or the
Village certified arborist or forester retained upon request.
   D.   Suspension Or Revocation or Withdrawal Of Permits:
      1.   The Village may revoke or suspend or withdraw a tree permit issued
pursuant to this chapter for one or more of the following reasons:
         a.   Fraudulent, false, misrepresenting, or materially incomplete
statements in the tree permit application;
         b.   Noncompliance with this chapter; or
         c.   Violation of or deviation from any element of a Village-issued
permit.
      2.   Suspension, revocation or withdrawal of a Village-issued permit
under this chapter may also be sufficient grounds for the suspension or
revocation of any other permits issued by the Village for the property,
including building construction permits.
      3.   Notice Of Revocation Or Suspension or Withdrawal: The Village shall
send written notice of its intent to revoke or suspend a permit issued pursuant
to this chapter, stating the reason or reasons for the revocation or suspension
and the alternatives available to permittee under this section.
      4.   Permittee Alternatives Upon Receipt Of Notice Of Revocation Or
Suspension Or Withdrawal: Upon receipt of a written notice of revocation or
suspension or withdrawal of a tree permit from the Village, the permittee shall
have the following options:
         a.   Immediately provide the Village with evidence that no cause
exists for the revocation or suspension or withdrawal;
         b.   Immediately correct, to the satisfaction of the Village, the
deficiencies stated in the written notice, providing written proof of such
correction to the Village within five (5) working days after receipt of the
written notice; or
         c.   Immediately take action to develop, implement and actively pursue
a corrective plan to resolve the deficiencies (i.e., secure the area, hire a
contractor to resolve the deficiencies, etc.) to the satisfaction of the
Village, providing written proof of such actions, contractor agreement and
milestone schedule to resolve the deficiencies to the Village within ten (10)
calendar days after receipt of the written notice from the Village. The Village
may, in its discretion, for good cause shown, extend the time periods provided
in this subsection.
      5.   Stop Work Order: In addition to the issuance of a notice of
revocation or suspension or withdrawal, the Village may issue a stop work order
immediately upon discovery of any of the reasons for revocation or suspension
or withdrawal set forth within this subsection D.
      6.   Failure Or Refusal Of The Permittee To Comply: If the permittee
fails to comply with the provisions of this section, the Director of Municipal
Services, or their designee, at its sole discretion, may: (1) issue one or more
code citations and file and pursue administrative adjudication action and/or
legal action relative to the code citation(s) to enforce this chapter; and (2)
correct the deficiencies and file a lien against the property for the value of
the corrective work and the Village’s related expenses. If the Village or its
agents or contractors perform any corrective or remedial work to resolve the
deficiencies, the permittee shall be liable to the Village for all such costs
incurred by the Village, including but not limited to disposal fees, contractor
fees, consultant fees or legal fees and related expenses as a consequence of
the permittee’s failure or refusal to comply with this chapter.
   E.   Cash Bonds:
      1.   If tree replacement is required by this Chapter, then, as a
condition of the tree permit, the permittee shall submit a cash bond as
identified by the Village. The bond shall be held for the purpose of assuring
that the replacement tree(s) are purchased and planted.
      2.   If it is determined that practices which violate any portion of the
Village Code have resulted in tree damage, then the Village may require that a
cash bond, as determined by the Village, shall be submitted at the time the
violation occurs. The bond shall be held for the purpose of assuring that all
remedial actions to minimize tree damage are taken, and/or for the purpose of
assuring tree replacement should any damaged tree die or show noticeable signs
of decline as determined by a certified arborist. If it is determined that
residual damage may not be apparent, then the bond may be held for a period of
sixty (60) months or five (5) years. At the end of the 60-month period, if the
tree survives and is in good health, as determined by a certified arborist, the
bond shall be returned to the permittee. If the tree does not survive, and was
not further impacted by an act of God, or is in poor health, then removal of
the existing tree and planting of a replacement tree shall be required, as
identified above and according to Village Code, and cash bond shall be used to
pay for the tree removal and replacement work.
      3.   If a cash bond is posted for a tree and the property owner wishes to
transfer ownership to the property to another person, then a replacement cash
bond shall be required to be paid by the purchaser of the property prior to
transfer of the property. Once a replacement cash bond is received, the cash
bond on deposit with the Village shall be refunded to the original property
owner. A replacement cash bond is not needed if the current property owner and
the purchaser submit a written, executed agreement that the cash bond has been
assigned to the purchaser of the property and shall remain with the Village for
the benefit of the purchaser of the property.
   F.   Inspection: Final approval shall be issued when all relocation,
replacement or remediation of trees is completed and a final inspection has
been conducted by the Village. Should the Village determine that the season is
inappropriate for planting, then relocation or replacement shall be deferred
until the next planting season. All bonds and fees will remain in the custody
of the Village until final inspection and approval has been provided in
writing.
   G.   Compliance: The Village shall retain jurisdiction to ensure compliance
with this section and shall have the right to issue a stop work order for non-
compliance. No stop work order issued pursuant to this section shall be removed
by the Village unless the permittee has paid a re-inspection fee in accordance
with this Code.
   H.   Insurance Requirements: Each contractor who performs work that is
governed by and subject to permitting under this Chapter shall comply with the
public contract insurance provisions and coverage requirements of the Village
as set forth under the Insurance Requirements Section of the Urban Forest
Management Plan, which public contract insurance provisions and coverage
requirements are incorporated by reference into this Subsection H. (Ord. 20-
3006, 6-22-2020; amd. Ord. 22-3083, 6-13-2022; Ord. 23-3149, 10-23-2023)
5-5-6: PLANTING TREES:
   A.   Tree Permit Requirements: No tree shall be planted on Village parkway
(i.e., property adjoining a roadway and forming part of a platted right of way)
or other Village property without first obtaining a tree permit from the
Department of Community Development. Tree permit applications shall be approved
or denied on the basis of compliance with this Chapter.
   B.   As outlined in the Urban Forest Management Plan, the Village shall
plant, and recommend to private landowners the planting of, diverse species
with the ratio of not more than fifteen percent (15%) of any one family, ten
percent (10%) of any one genus or five percent (5%) of any one species, with
the exception of naturalized areas where species selections are based on the
natural species assemblages as defined in the Urban Forest Management Plan.
Diverse species composition protects the Village from catastrophic loss.
   C.   All trees planted by the Village, or their agents, shall be planted in
accordance with the Urban Forest Management Plan.
   D.   Permitted Species: A list of permitted species shall be maintained by
the Department of Municipal Services. The approval of a species for a
particular site shall be dependent upon the following criteria:
      1.   Compliance with permitted species list.
      2.   Compatibility of the species with the site.
      3.   The overall species balance in the immediate area surrounding the
proposed location as well as the overall species balance in the Village.
   E.   Species Not Permitted: The following trees shall not be planted within
the Village corporate limits: all members of the willow family (Salicaceae,
salix and populus), silver maple (Acer saccharinom), box elder (Acer negundo),
tree-of-heaven (Ailanthus altissima), and any other species which are expressly
prohibited as set forth in the Urban Forest Management Plan, as amended. The
prohibited species set forth in the Urban Forest Management Plan are
incorporated by reference into this Subsection for enforcement purposes.
   F.   Spacing Requirements: Spacing and location of trees shall be at the
discretion of the Department of Municipal Services, with consideration given to
the following tree spacing requirements: trees shall be located a minimum of
thirty feet (30') from the curb line at intersections; a minimum of eight feet
(8') from driveways; a minimum of fifteen feet (15') from street lights; a
minimum of five feet (5') from fire hydrants, shut-off boxes, vaults and other
miscellaneous utility structures; and a minimum of three feet (3') back from
the curb line and two feet (2') from the outside edge of the pavement. Spacing
between trees is dependent upon the species to be planted, neighboring species
and site characteristics as determined by the Director of Municipal Services.
   G.   Trees purchased by the Village shall meet the specifications required
in the Urban Forest Management Plan.
   H.   It shall be unlawful to plant any tree under utility wires that is
anticipated to grow to a height that will interfere with the wires.
   I.   The Village shall implement a contract growing program. This contract
will allow for stable pricing and broader species diversity to improve the
overall diversity of the urban forest. This contract may be for a period of
five (5) to ten (10) years.
   J.   The Village shall provide education and outreach to private landowners
on the need for species and age diversity, proper selection and planting
practices, and how to select species for particular sites. (Ord. 20-3006, 6-22-
2020; amd. Ord. 22-3083, 6-13-2022)
5-5-7: LEGACY AND UNDERREPRESENTED TREE PRESERVATION:
A legacy or underrepresented tree is a special designation issued in writing by
the Director of Municipal Services, or their designee. The criterion for
designation is provided in the Legacy and Underrepresented Tree Program and
Legacy Tree List and as detailed in the Urban Forest Management Plan. (Ord. 20-
3006, 6-22-2020; amd. Ord. 22-3083, 6-13-2022; Ord. 23-3128, 3-20-2023)
5-5-8: TRIMMING AND SPRAYING TREES:
   A.   Tree Permit Requirements: No public tree shall be trimmed, pruned or
sprayed without first obtaining a tree permit from the Department of Municipal
Services. If the Director of the Department of Municipal Services, or their
designee, determines that the proposed trimming represents a potential safety
problem, the Village may require the permittee to obtain insurance in such
amounts as is decreed necessary.
   B.   Method Of Trimming And Spraying: All trimming, pruning or spraying
shall be performed in compliance with the guidelines provided by the Department
of Municipal Services, which shall be based on applicable horticultural and
arboricultural standards. (Ord. 20-3006, 6-22-2020; amd. Ord. 22-3083, 6-13-
2022)
5-5-9: PROTECTION OF EXISTING TREES:
   A.   All construction projects within or adjacent to the public right of way
that have a potential damage or impact on existing public trees shall require a
tree permit from the Village. The Director of the Department of Municipal
Services, or their designee, may direct whatever reasonable measures are
necessary to protect the tree, including but not limited to root zone
protection, bark protection, root pruning, construction pruning and liquid
fertilization. Failure to abide by the terms of the tree permit may result in
the revocation of the tree permit and any other permit issued by the Village,
including building construction permits and Village contracts.
   B.   In the event of any site improvement which may damage or impact public
property trees, a tree preservation plan is required to be prepared and filed
by the property owner with the Community Development Department, must be
approved by the Director of the Department of Municipal Services, or their
designee, and implemented prior to the start of any work or delivery of any
materials to the building activity area. The approved tree preservation plan
shall be available on the site throughout the entire construction period until
final approvals for all site work shall be received in writing.
   C.   In instances where the activity requires the use of heavy equipment and
where that activity may damage or impact trees on public or private property,
all appropriate tree protection measures must be taken and identified in the
tree preservation plan. In addition, all tree protection measures shall be in
compliance with the Urban Forest Management Plan. (Ord. 20-3006, 6-22-2020;
amd. Ord. 22-3083, 6-13-2022)
5-5-10: TREE REMOVAL:
Tree removals are considered an impact to the entire Village, whether on public
or private land. It is clearly documented that larger trees provide larger
benefits and, as such, tree removal fees and fines are based on species and
diameter. It is recognized that the planting of smaller trees does not replace
the value of larger trees that are lost. It will take tens of years for that
value to be replaced and, for that reason, efforts should be made to preserve
and protect trees where they are growing. In regard to tree removals, the
corporate authorities of the Village have made the following findings and have
enacted the following requirements:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any individual to remove or cause damage to
any tree located on public property without first receiving a tree permit from
the Village.
   B.   No live, dead or dying tree, or grouping of trees, on public property
may be removed without first obtaining a tree permit from the Village.
   C.   A nuisance tree is a tree that has already died, is in a state of
irrevocable decline, has the capacity to damage a person or thing, or is an
invasive species.
   D.   Any tree removed from a parcel or transplanted off-site must be
replaced according to the requirements outlined in the Urban Forest Management
Plan, this Chapter and the Village Municipal Code.
   E.   All stump removals shall require identifying underground utility
locations prior to any action.
   F.   If a tree is removed or damaged which is not on the tree permit, it
must be replaced or bonded as set forth in this Chapter.
   G.   Removal of invasive woody plants such as buckthorn does not require a
tree permit and is encouraged. These invasive plants can quickly colonize an
area, reducing the health and vitality of non-invasive plants. A list of
invasive woody plants is provided in the Urban Forest Management Plan and in
the Illinois Exotic Weed Act, 525 Illinois Compiled Statutes 10. (Ord. 20-3006,
6-22-2020; amd. Ord. 22-3083, 6-13-2022)
5-5-11: TREE REPLACEMENT:
In regard to tree replacements, the corporate authorities of the Village have
made the following findings and have enacted the following requirements:
   A.   It is required that tree replacement species come from the preferred
species list. The preferred species list is provided in the Urban Forest
Management Plan.
   B.   Any tree which is required to be removed or which has been damaged
shall require a tree permit bond to be posted by the permittee or other person
responsible for the damage or removal until adequate tree replacements or
remediation can be made. The bond amount shall be set by the Director of the
Department of Municipal Services, or their designee (i.e., the Assistant to the
Director, a Village Code Officer, a certified arborist or forester retained by
the Village), based on the formulas and techniques set forth in the Council of
Tree and Landscape Appraisers “Guide for Plant Appraisal”, latest edition, or
otherwise provided by this Code. Determination of the extent of tree damage
shall be made by the Director of the Department of Municipal Services, or their
designee, in consultation with the Forestry Consultant.
   C.   Any tree species removed by a homeowner, private developer or
contractor, six inches (6") DBH or six inch (6") group of trees, which is not
identified on the invasive species list, but is identified on the preferred
species list, is required to be replaced in accordance with the this section.
These trees shall be replaced based on the standards set forth in the “Guide
for Plant Appraisal”, latest edition. All replacements shall be located
appropriately as confirmed by a certified arborist and as approved by the
Director of the Department of Municipal Services, or their designee.
   D.   When a tree removal is required as a result of any project, tree
replacement shall occur within the landscape season. In the event of weather
conditions or species-specific needs, which prohibit proper replacement of a
tree, the Director of the Department of Municipal Services, or their designee,
may issue written notice of an extension of up to one hundred eighty (180)
calendar days upon written request by the permittee. If an extension is granted
to the permittee, the permittee shall notify the Village when replacement is
complete. If the extension period expires and the tree is not replaced or the
permittee has not notified the Village that installation is complete, all bonds
shall be forfeited and the bond money shall be placed in the Tree Bank (defined
above in Section
5-2-2). Tree removal requirements, associated with a development project, are
set forth in Section
5-5-10 (Tree Removal) of this Chapter.
   E.   All tree replacement plantings shall require identifying an underground
utility (“JULIE”) location prior to planting.
   F.   If the property where a tree removal has taken place does not have
adequate space to plant a replacement tree, then the permittee shall be
required to pay the Village a dollar amount based on the Council of Tree and
Landscape Appraisers “Guide for Plant Appraisal”, latest edition, or otherwise
provided by this Code. Funds shall be placed in the Tree Bank for tree
replacement or tree care in another area of the Village.
   G.   It shall be encouraged that any species identified on the invasive
species list be removed. There is no tree replacement requirement for removal
of these species. (Ord. 20-3006, 6-22-2020; amd. Ord. 22-3083, 6-13-2022)
5-5-12: SPECIAL RULES FOR CONSERVANCY OR PRESERVATION AREAS:
If a conservancy or preservation area (as defined above in Section
5-5-2) is impacted or may be impacted in any way by work or activities of a
permittee or any other responsible person, the following shall be required:
   A.   A cash bond (i.e., tree conservancy / preservation area bond), which is
in addition to the tree permit bond required by Subsection
5-5-5(F) (Permits Requirements Generally; Cash Bonds), is required to be
deposited with the Village as a condition of approval of a tree permit
application or as a condition of restoring an impacted conservancy or
preservation area. The dollar amount of the tree conservancy / preservation
area bond shall be calculated as follows: One hundred dollars ($100.00) per
caliper inch for each living significant surveyed tree (regardless of species)
lying within any tree conservancy / preservation area. The developer shall be
required to post the tree conservancy / preservation area bond prior to
commencing any grading, earthmoving or other construction activities on the
development parcel to help ensure that there is a fund in place to pay for the
removal and replacement of any fallen, damaged, diseased, decayed or dead trees
within the tree preservation area or easements with trees at a ratio of one to
one (1:1) having a minimum diameter of four inches (4") measured at DBH and of
like species if approved by the Village, or species selected from the varieties
approved by the Village.
   B.   The purpose of this tree conservancy / preservation area bond is to pay
for restoration of any portion of the conservancy or preservation area damaged,
directly or indirectly, as a result of the activities of any permittee or any
other responsible person. All restoration shall be performed with like-kind and
like-quality materials and be completed under the review of the Municipal
Services Department and under the “Tree Preservation and Management During
Construction” section of the UFMP.
   C.   Any tree maintenance made necessary as a result of damage or impact,
including but not limited to the removal of dead trees or preventative measures
such as root pruning or crown reduction of existing trees, shall be paid for by
the permittee or any other responsible person.
   D.   Any expenses incurred by the Village, as a result of any damage or
impact in administering or enforcing the provisions of this Chapter, this Code
or the Urban Forest Management Plan shall be paid for by the permittee or any
other responsible person. The amount of the tree conservancy / preservation
bond shall in no way limit the developer’s obligation or the liability of the
developer if the cost to remove and/or replace such fallen, damaged, diseased,
decayed or dead trees exceeds the tree conservancy / preservation bond, except
that the developer’s obligations with respect to the tree preservation in the
development shall cease upon the termination date of the developer’s tree
preservation obligations as defined in this section.
   E.   The tree conservancy / preservation area bond will be refunded one year
after the repairs have been made and all maintenance is completed and approved
by the Director of the Department of Municipal Services, or their designee.
(Ord. 20-3006, 6-22-2020; amd. Ord. 22-3083, 6-13-2022)
5-5-13: TREE PRESERVATION AND/OR REMOVAL PLAN FOR SIGNIFICANT REMOVALS,
CONSTRUCTION AND/OR DEVELOPMENT:
An applicant seeking a permit for significant tree removals or tree removal
and/or planting related to construction and/or development shall comply with
all requirements of this Chapter and the Urban Forest Management Plan. (Ord.
20-3006, 6-22-2020)
5-5-14: NUISANCE TREES:
A tree which is determined by the Director of the Department of Municipal
Services, or their designee, to be a nuisance tree is one which is dead or
declining and has the potential to damage other trees, people, or structures.
These trees may be located on public or private property.
   A.   It shall be the duty of the property owner on any parcel to promptly
remove any trees which pose a risk to personal property or human safety.
   B.   When the Village notifies the property owner, in writing, of a tree
which is a potential risk to personal property or human safety, the property
owner shall have twenty (20) calendar days to remove the tree. If the property
owner has not removed the tree within the 20-day period, then the Village may
take action to have the tree removed. If the tree is removed by the Village, a
Village invoice shall be sent to the property owner that contains all costs
associated with the removal, including but not limited to expended Village
staff time, Village equipment use charges, Village consultant fees and charges,
contractor charges and materials, and oversight of said removal. If the
property owner fails or refuses to reimburse the Village within thirty (30)
calendar days of issuance of a written invoice, the Village shall place a lien
on the property until all expenses related to the removal and subsequent lien
are paid, and the Village may file a legal action to collect the costs
contained in the invoice.
   C.   Infected, Infested Trees Due To A Pest Or Pathogen Are Defined As A
Nuisance:
      1.   Any tree which is in a state of irreparable or untreatable decline
due to heavy infestation or disease is included in the definition of a
nuisance. Infested or infected trees, which are identified by Federal or State
Departments of Agriculture to be in quarantine or can potentially infect or
infest other trees are defined as a nuisance. This would include but not be
limited to Ash (Fraxinus) trees infested with emerald ash borer which are not
being treated or whose treatment is ineffectual, or Elm trees (Ulmus) infected
with Dutch elm disease. Trees infected with Dutch elm disease or Emerald Ash
Borer shall be subject to the additional regulations set forth in section
5-5-17 of this Code.
         a.   The Village shall enforce State and Federal regulations governing
quarantine zone boundaries, and regulated articles.
         b.   For the purposes of this section, “Regulated Articles” are hereby
defined as any insects at any living state of development, any quarantines
materials such as wood products including, but not limited to chips, limbs,
lumber, firewood or any other product or means of conveyance which may be
determined by Federal or State departments of agriculture to pose a risk of
spread of any infestation or infection.
         c.   It shall be illegal to move out of established quarantine zone(s)
regulated articles unless those articles have met all requirements of the
local, Federal and State regulatory agencies.
         d.   It shall be illegal for any person or entity to transfer from a
quarantine zone into a non-quarantine zone including the Village any regulated
articles.
         e.   Any person or entity found to be in violation of any local, State
or Federal regulations related to tree infestations or infections shall be
prosecuted to the full extent of the law.
         f.   All contractors working within and near any quarantine zone(s)
are required to comply with the quarantine regulations and supply records that
may be required for inspection to the Village, County, State or Federal
agencies upon request.
      2.   Trees In Decline Or Dead Are Defined As A Nuisance:
         a.   Any tree or part of a tree which is dead which could potentially
fall on a person or structure is defined as a nuisance.
         b.   It shall be unlawful for any owner of any lot or land in the
Village to permit or maintain on any such lot or land, any tree which is dead,
or declining to the state where it may create a potential risk for structures
or people. It shall be the duty of any such owner to promptly cause the removal
of any such tree. (Ord. 20-3006, 6-22-2020; amd. Ord. 22-3083, 6-13-2022)
5-5-15: INVASIVE SPECIES CONTROL:
   A.   Invasive Woody Plants: Invasive plants cause ecological disruption to
natural ecosystems. The type of impact varies based on the species and the
traits of that species. The Woody Invasive Species List is included in the
Urban Forest Management Plan or as defined by the defined by the Illinois
Exotic Weed Act, 525 Illinois Compiled Statutes 10. These species shall not be
planted and should be removed and controlled to reduce impacts to other
vegetation.
      1.   Typical impacts include:
         a.   Chemical disturbance to the soil limiting development of other
species;
         b.   Dense plant growth limiting light to soil surface resulting in
exposed soil allowing erosion;
      2.   Displacement of naturally occurring species resulting in a
monoculture of invasive species and aggressive tendencies.
      3.   Private Property Owner Outreach: The Village shall have
implementation and outreach plan to educate property owners of the potential
impacts and remediation strategies, including a suggested planting list of
alternative species to assist property owners in dealing with the problem. This
plan is located in the Urban Forest Management Plan.
   B.   Invasive Diseases And Insects:
      1.   Impacts To Trees: Invasive diseases and insects can create
significant stress to trees and in some instances kill trees. The Village has
developed a list of invasive diseases and insects that pose significant threats
to trees from information identified by State and Federal Departments of
Agriculture. This list is included in the Urban Forest Management Plan.
      2.   Invasive Species Management Plan: Management of invasive diseases
and insects is included in the Urban Forest Management Plan.
      3.   Private Property Owner Outreach: The Village shall have an
implementation and outreach plan to educate property owners of the potential
impacts and remediation strategies to help property tree owners in dealing with
pests or pathogens. This plan is located in the Urban Forest Management Plan.
(Ord. 20-3006, 6-22-2020)
5-5-16: RESTRICTED AND PROHIBITED ACTS AND CONDITIONS:
   A.   Defacing Trees: No person shall destroy, mutilate, drive nails in or in
any way interfere with any tree or shrub that is now or may hereafter be
growing on any public property in the village.
   B.   Attaching Electric Wires And Supports: No person shall attach any
electric wire, radio antenna, insulator or any other device for holding
electric wire to any tree now or hereafter growing on any public property in
the village.
   C.   Obstructing Streetlights: No person shall be permitted to maintain a
tree on private property in such a manner as to obstruct the rays of a
streetlight.
   D.   Obstructing Earth Space: No person shall be permitted to place or
maintain on public property any cement, stone or other material which shall
impede the free passage of water or air to the roots of any tree without having
an open space, not less than two feet (2') in width all around the trunk of
such tree; provided, however, that the maintenance of such open space shall not
require the breaking or destroying of any part of any sidewalk, driveway apron
or pavement already constructed.
   E.   Low Hanging Branches: All trees standing on private property abutting
on any sidewalk, street or alley shall have their branches cut or trimmed so
that no part thereof shall overhang such sidewalk, street or alley at the
height of less than ten feet (10') above the sidewalk or fourteen feet (14')
above the street roadway or alley.
   F.   Danger To Public Ways: All trees standing on private property shall be
maintained in such a manner as to pose no probable danger to the public ways or
to users of public ways.
   G.   Tall Shrubs And Plants: No shrub or low growing ornamental tree shall
be planted in any public parkway of the village, nor shall any herbaceous plant
or flower be planted therein which at its maturity attains a height of over
twenty four inches (24"). (amd. Ord. 20-3006, 6-22-2020)
5-5-17: DUTCH ELM DISEASE AND EMERALD ASH BORER:
   A.   Incorporation Of Certain Provisions Of The Illinois Municipal Code: For
purposes of implementing and enforcing the applicable provisions of the
Illinois municipal code, as amended, that relate to property maintenance,
removal of nuisances and filing and enforcing liens for associated removal
costs, the village incorporates by reference the following provisions and all
updates and amendments: division 2 (ordinances) of the Illinois municipal code
1 , including, but not limited to, sections 11-20-7, 11-20-11, 11-20-12, 11-20-
15 and 11-20-15.1. Any conflict between this code and the incorporated
provisions of the Illinois municipal code, as amended, shall be resolved by
following the state law provisions.
   B.   Nuisance: All species and varieties of elm trees (Ulmus and Zelkova)
infected with Dutch elm disease (the fungus Ceratostomella ulmi), as
determined, when an owner is directed by the Village Forester to do so, by
laboratory analysis or another method of analysis approved by the Village
Forester and paid for by the owner, are declared to be a public nuisance, and
shall be removed and burned within twenty (20) days following notification of
the discovery of such infection. The results of the analysis shall be given to
the Village Forester within seven (7) days of the owner’s receipt of the
results. All other similarly infected trees are declared to be a public
nuisance and shall be removed and burned within twenty (20) days following
notification of the discovery of such infection, unless the tree is placed in
or is being actively treated under a nationally recognized treatment program
overseen by a licensed arborist hired by the owner and approved by the village
forester. It shall be unlawful for the owner of real estate where such a tree
is situated to possess or keep such a tree, after the expiration of twenty (20)
days following notification issued by the village of the discovery of said
infection, unless the owner initiates and maintains a treatment program
overseen by a licensed arborist and approved by the village forester. See 65
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-20-12(c) for definition of "treatment".
   C.   Elm Bark Beetle Breeding Places: Trees or parts thereof of Ulmus (elm)
or Zelkova in a dead or dying condition that may serve as a breeding place for
the European elm bark beetle, Scolytus multistriatus, are declared to be a
public nuisance, and it shall be unlawful for the owner of real estate where
the tree is situated to possess or keep the same.
   D.   Emerald Ash Borer: Trees of all species and varieties of ash trees
(Fraxinus) infected with the emerald ash borer beetle (Agrilus planipennis
Fairmaire) that are dead or have lost at least fifty percent (50%) of their
crown, as determined by the village forester, shall be declared to be a public
nuisance and shall be removed and burned within twenty (20) days following
notification of the discovery of such infection. All other similarly infected
trees are declared to be a public nuisance and shall be removed and burned
within twenty (20) days following notification of the discovery of such
infection, unless the tree is placed in or is being actively treated under a
nationally recognized treatment program overseen by a licensed arborist hired
by the owner and approved by the village forester. It shall be unlawful for the
owner of real estate where such a tree is situated to possess or keep such a
tree after the expiration of twenty (20) days following notification of the
discovery of said infection by the village, unless the owner initiates and
maintains a treatment program overseen by a licensed arborist and approved by
the village forester. See 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-20-12(c) for
definition of "treatment".
   E.   Enforcement: The director of municipal services, or his/her designated
representative, is charged with the enforcement of this section. When the
director is unable to effect voluntary entry onto private real estate for the
purpose of inspecting the trees thereon, the director shall seek the necessary
authorization to make or cause entry to be made onto the real estate.
   F.   Removal Of Public Nuisances: Unless the owner initiates and maintains a
treatment program overseen by a licensed arborist and approved by the village
forester, the director of municipal services, or his/her designated
representative, shall give to the owner of the real estate where the public
nuisances described in this section are found a written notice of the existence
of such nuisance and requiring the removal and burning of the same within
twenty (20) days following such notice, such removal and burning to be done
under the direction and supervision of the director of municipal services, or
his/her designated representative. The notice shall also notify the owner of
the real estate that, unless such nuisance is removed and burned in compliance
with the terms thereof within such twenty (20) day period, the village will
proceed with the removal and burning of such nuisance, and assess the cost
thereof against the owner.
   G.   Duty Of Owner To Remove Diseased Or Dead Tree Or Breeding Place: Upon
receipt of notice, it shall become the duty of the owner of the real estate to
cause such tree or breeding place to be removed and burned under the
supervision of the director of municipal services, or his/her designated
representative. In lieu thereof, the person charged with such removal and
burning may request in writing that the same be done by the director of
municipal services, or his/her designated representative. If the village shall
remove and burn any tree or breeding place, all costs incurred in connection
therewith shall be assessed against and paid by such owner.
   H.   Lien: Notice of the lien claim for removal activities performed to
abate the nuisances under this section shall be mailed by the village manager,
or his/her designated representatives, to the owner of the real estate whenever
such bill remains unpaid for a period of thirty (30) days after it has been
rendered. The failure of the village manager, or his/her designated
representatives, to record such lien claim or to mail such notice or the
failure of the owner to receive such notice shall not affect the right to
foreclose the lien for unpaid bills for removal activities as provided herein.
This lien upon the real estate is superior to all other liens and encumbrances,
except tax liens and as otherwise provided by state law; provided that notice
has been given as herein described, and further provided that within one year
after such removal costs are incurred the village, or person performing the
service by authority of the village, in his/her or its own name, files notice
of lien in the office of the recorder of deeds of Cook County. The notice shall
consist of a sworn statement setting out: 1) a description of the real estate
sufficient for identification thereof, including the identification of the real
estate by common description; 2) a description of the removal activities; 3)
the amount of money representing the removal costs; 4) the date or dates when
such removal costs were incurred by the village; and 5) a statement that the
lien has been filed pursuant to applicable provisions of this code and the
provisions of 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-20-7, 11-20-8(d), 11-20-12(d),
11-20-13(e), 11-20-15, 11-20-15.1 or 11-31-1.01, as applicable.
   I.   Service Of Notice: Prior to filing the lien, the following notice shall
be personally served on, or sent by certified mail to, the person whom was sent
the tax bill for the general taxes on the real estate for the last preceding
year. The notice shall be delivered or sent after the removal activities have
been performed. The notice shall: 1) state the substance of 65 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/11-20-12 and 5/11-20-15 and the substance of any ordinance
implementing those laws; 2) identify the real estate at issue by common
description; and 3) describe the removal activities. See 65 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 11-20-7 and 11-20-15.
   J.   Release Of Lien: Upon payment of the removal costs, the lien filing
fees and the release filing fees by the owner of or persons interested in such
real estate, after notice of lien has been filed, the lien shall be released by
the village or person in whose name the lien has been filed and the release may
be filed of record as in the case of filing the notice of lien. See 65 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/11-20-15(h) or 11-20-15.1(e).
   K.   Trees Partly On Private Real Estate And Partly On Public Real Estate:
Dutch elm diseased trees and emerald ash borer infected trees, the trunks of
which, in the opinion of the director of municipal services, or his/her
designated representative, are partly on village owned real estate and partly
on privately owned real estate, shall be removed by the village. The cost of
such tree removal shall be shared equally by the village and the owner of
record of the privately owned real estate. In the event that the owner of the
privately owned real estate, upon notice from the village, fails to pay one-
half (1/2) of said cost within thirty (30) days, then the village shall pay the
entire cost of the tree removal and shall have the right to collect from the
owner one-half (1/2) of the cost by lien or suit for judgment. The cost shall
be a lien upon the real estate, provided that notice is given to the owner
prior to thirty (30) days before the tree removal and a notice of lien is
recorded in the recorder's office within sixty (60) days after the removal
costs are incurred, as provided by 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-20-12.
For purposes of this section, the village property line shall be deemed to be
thirty three feet (33') from the centerline of each street, except in those
instances where a street may be more than sixty six feet (66') in width, in
which case the village engineer, or his/her designated representative, shall
determine the location of the property line. In the sole discretion of the
director of municipal services, or his/her designated representative, the
village may agree to place the tree in a nationally recognized treatment
program overseen by a licensed arborist hired by the owner and approved by the
village forester. The village and the private owner shall share equally the
costs of such treatment program.
   L.   Village To Remove Its Own Trees: Unless the tree is placed in or is
being actively treated under a nationally recognized treatment program overseen
by the village forester, infected trees on village owned real estate and on
public streets and highways within the corporate limits shall be removed at the
expense of the village.
   M.   Abandoned Residential Property; Removal; Lien: See process set forth in
65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-20-12(d) and 11-20-15.1.
   N.   Foreclosure Of Lien: See foreclosure process set forth in 65 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/11-20-15.1(d). (Ord. 15-2803, 5-18-2015; amd. Ord. 20-3006,
6-22-2020)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/1-2-1 et seq.
5-5-18: REPLACEMENT OF DAMAGED AND/OR DESTROYED TREES:
Whenever any Village owned tree is damaged for any reason to the point that it
is no longer an acceptable tree, as determined by the Director of the
Department of Municipal Services, or their designee, the person responsible for
the damage shall be obligated to replace the tree on a “wood for wood” basis at
a value as calculated by the Village Forestry Consultant in accordance with the
tree replacement formula set forth in the Council of Tree and Landscape
Appraisers “Guide for Plant Appraisal”, latest edition, or otherwise provided
by this Code.
If the site does not have sufficient space for the number of replacement trees
required, the excess shall be planted elsewhere in the Village where needed.
This determination of where the replacement trees shall be planted
shall be made on a case-by-case basis by the Director of the Department of
Municipal Services, or their designee. (Ord. 20-3006, 6-22-2020; amd. Ord. 22-
3083, 6-13-2022)
5-5-19: PROPERTIES AND RECREATION COMMITTEE:
   A.   Establishment: The Village Properties and Recreation Committee shall
serve as the recommending body to provide assistance and direction and
expertise to the Village regarding the preservation, planting, management and
protection of trees. The Properties and Recreation Committee shall develop and
recommend implementation of an Urban Forest Management Plan for guidance on
urban forestry issues.
   B.   Procedures: The Properties and Recreation Committee shall hold meetings
in accordance with the Open Meetings Act and provide recommendations to the
corporate authorities of the Village after consideration of Village policies,
and amendments to rules and regulations of the Village, Village policies and
the Village Code relating to matters that are within the scope of its listed
Powers and Duties. The Properties and Recreation Committee shall keep written
records of its proceedings, which shall be open at all times to public
inspection. The Properties and Recreation Committee shall file an annual report
to the Village Board setting forth its past-year activities and recommendations
for future action by the Village.
   C.   Powers And Duties: The Properties and Recreation Committee shall have
the following powers and duties with respect to this Chapter, in addition to
any other powers and duties established by this Code, subject to the approval
of the Village Board:
      1.   To provide guidance on the preservation, care, management and
protection of trees within the Village in accordance with the Urban Forestry
Management Plan, and regional and local best management practices.
      2.   To prepare and recommend to the Village Board from time to time
recommendations for specific improvements of the preservation, care, management
and protection of trees within the Village.
      3.   To recommend rules and regulations to the Village Board for budget,
plans, projects and schedules regarding the preservation, care, management and
protection of trees within the Village.
      4.   To review the Village Urban Forest Management Plan and provide
recommendations for improvements to the Village Board.
      5.   To review reports from Village forestry staff to support the Village
ordinances and the Urban Forest Management Plan.
      6.   Oversee staff management and administration of all plans, programs,
projects and tasks delegated by the Village Board. (Ord. 20-3006, 6-22-2020;
amd. Ord. 22-3083, 6-13-2022)
5-5-20: PENALTY:
   A.   Any person found guilty of violating any provision of this Chapter
shall be assessed at a cost as prescribed in Section
1-4-1 (General Penalty) of this Code, which is incorporated by reference into
this Chapter. Each tree cut down, destroyed, damaged, removed or moved shall
constitute a separate offense. In addition to these penalties, if a tree is
removed in violation of this Chapter, all replacement requirements of this
Chapter shall be applied.
   B.   In addition to any other remedies provided by this Section
5-5-20 (Penalty), the Village shall have the following judicial remedies
available for violations of this Chapter or any tree permit condition
promulgated under this Chapter:
      1.   The Village may institute a civil action in a court of competent
jurisdiction to establish liability and to recover damages for any injury
caused by the removal or damage of trees in contravention of the terms of this
Chapter.
      2.   The Village may institute a civil action in a court of competent
jurisdiction to seek injunctive relief to enforce compliance with this Chapter
to enjoin any violation, and to seek injunctive relief to prevent irreparable
injury to the trees or properties encompassed by the terms of this Chapter.
(Ord. 20-3006, 6-22-2020; amd. Ord. 22-3083, 6-13-2022)
5-5-21: ENFORCEMENT:
   A.   Enforcement Of Right Of Entry Of Village Officers: To carry out the
purposes of this Chapter and to implement its enforcement, the Village is
authorized and empowered, upon twenty-four (24) hours’ notice, to enter upon
any lot or parcel of land in the Village at all reasonable hours to inspect any
tree or wood and to remove specimens from any such tree to determine their
condition. It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere with the Director
of the Department of Municipal Services, or their designee, including any
Village Code Enforcement Officer, carrying out the duties authorized in this
Chapter or this Code or the Urban Forest Management Plan.
   B.   Duty Of Property Owner To Abate Nuisance Or Potential Risk: If it is
determined by the Director of the Department of Municipal Services, or their
designee, that there exists a public nuisance or a risk of injury to personal
property or human health as declared in this Chapter, the Village shall serve
or cause to be served upon the owner of the lot or parcel of land on which such
nuisance or risk is located a written notice identifying the nuisance or risk
and requiring the property owner to comply with the provisions of this Chapter.
If the person upon whom such notice is served fails, neglects or refuses to
remove and dispose of the tree or dead wood within twenty (20) calendar days
after service of such notice, the Village may proceed to remove and dispose of
such tree or dead wood and the costs shall be paid by the owner to the Village.
If the person refuses to pay the Village for the removal costs, the Village may
pursue legal action to collect the removal costs and all Village-incurred legal
fees and costs associated with the legal action and may file a lien against the
property owner’s property relative to the removal costs and related legal fees
and costs.
   C.   Service Of Notice To Property Owner: Service of notice provided for in
this Section shall be delivered by personal service or by certified mail
addressed to the property owner, the occupant or to the person to whom, and at
the address, to which the tax bill was sent for the general taxes for the last
preceding year on the lot or parcel on which the nuisance is located.
   D.   Village Abatement And Assessment Of Costs: Any costs incurred by the
Village in the abatement of a public nuisance or risk of injury to personal
property or human health as declared in this Chapter shall be assessed against
the record owner of the land involved and the Village shall place a lien upon
such property for those costs in the manner provided by law and the Village may
file a legal action to collect the costs contained in the lien. (Ord. 20-3006,
6-22-2020; amd. Ord. 22-3083, 6-13-2022)
5-5-22: EXCEPTIONS:
If because of emergency weather or other casualty conditions a tree is
endangering health, safety or property and requires immediate removal, verbal
authorization may be given by the Director of the Department of Municipal
Services, or their designee, for the tree removal without obtaining a written
tree permit. Such verbal authorization shall later be confirmed in writing by
the Director of the Department of Municipal Services, or their designee. (Ord.
20-3006, 6-22-2020; amd. Ord. 22-3083, 6-13-2022)
5-5-23: VARIANCES; APPEALS:
   A.   Variances: No variances in the strict application of the provisions of
this Chapter shall be recommended for approval by the Village Board, unless it
finds:
      1.   There are special circumstances or conditions, fully described in
the written notice of appeal, which are peculiar to the property (properties)
and do not apply generally to properties within the Village, and that said
circumstances or conditions are such that the strict application of the Code
would deprive the permittee of the reasonable use of the subject property
(properties).
      2.   For the reasons fully set forth in the written notice of appeal, the
granting of the variance is necessary for the reasonable use of the property
(properties) and that the variance, as recommended for approval by the Village
Board, is the minimum variance that will accomplish this purpose.
      3.   The result of granting of the variance will be in harmony with the
general purpose and intent of standards set forth within this Code and in
harmony with this Chapter, and will not be injurious to adjacent property or
otherwise detrimental to the public welfare.
   B.   Appeal of Decisions: Any person aggrieved by any administrative
decision of the Director of the Department of Municipal Services, or their
designee, or the Director of the Community Development Department, or their
designee, in the enforcement of any terms or provisions of this Chapter may,
within ten (10) business days after the date of the decision, appeal to the
Village Manager, or their designee, by filing a written notice of appeal with
the Village Clerk. The notice of appeal shall set forth concisely the decision
and the reasons or grounds for the appeal. The Village Manager, or their
designee, will meet with the person who filed the appeal and the Village
employee or representative who issued the decision to provide them with an
opportunity to be heard and to present their respective positions and evidence
relative to the appeal. The Village Manager, or their designee, will first
attempt to resolve the matter in a manner that is agreeable to all parties, and
if such a resolution is not achieved, then the Village Manager, or their
designee, will issue a decision that affirms, modifies, or reverses the
administrative decision. The decision of the Village Manager, or their
designee, will be transmitted to the Director of the Department of Municipal
Services, or their designee, and the person who filed the appeal within ten
(10) business days of its issuance. The decision of the Village Manager, or
their designee, shall be final and no petition for reconsideration shall be
available. Reasonable notice of the meetings with the Director of Municipal
Services and the Village Manager, or their designees, shall be provided by the
Village to all affected parties. (Ord. 20-3006, 6-22-2020; amd. Ord. 22-3083,
6-13-2022)
CHAPTER 6
OPEN BURNING
SECTION:
5-6-1: Open Burning Regulations
5-6-1: OPEN BURNING REGULATIONS:
   A.   Definitions: For purposes of this section the following definitions
apply:
APPROVED COMBUSTIBLE MATERIALS: Burning charcoal briquettes, natural gas,
propane, approved wood, or commercially prepared seasoned wood chips in
conjunction with any of the foregoing for cooking purposes.
APPROVED CONTAINER: Any outdoor fireplace or firepit constructed of stone or
fireproof blocks or brick, which may be freestanding or attached to a
residential dwelling or constructed as part of a residential dwelling chimney.
A commercially manufactured device specifically designed, intended, advertised
and utilized for the purpose of campfires, such as chimineas and portable
outdoor fireplaces. Such approved container may be located aboveground or may
be built into the ground or located below grade.
APPROVED WOOD: Seasoned dry firewood of dimensions appropriate to safely fit
within the approved container. In particular, but without limitation, approved
wood shall not include any green or fresh materials; nor shall it include any
leaves, grass, bushes, roots or other similar materials, nor shall it include
any construction materials, such as treated woods, plywood or pressure treated
wood, or any other materials which produce excessive smoke, cinders or other
emissions characteristics of nonseasoned wood.
BONFIRE: A safely conducted and controlled outdoor fire utilized for ceremonial
purposes or as part of a civic or community event. In order to conduct a
bonfire, the issuance of a village permit in accordance with this section is
required. A bonfire is a large scale open fire of that which exceeds the
capacity of an approved container and is typically constructed as a large pile
of combustible materials.
CONTROLLED BURN: A safely conducted and controlled outdoor fire utilized to
remove trees, grasses and other vegetation for purposes of eliminating natural
wildfire threats and preparing areas for new tree, grass and vegetation growth.
A controlled burn can also involve the intentional burning of a structure, like
a house, by fire department personnel for fire training purposes or a bonfire.
In order to conduct a controlled burn, the issuance of a village permit in
accordance with this section is required.
OPEN FIRES: Any fire from which the products of combustion are emitted directly
into the open air without passing through a stack or chimney designed to
control air pollution emissions. Backyard incineration in a container of any
type shall be considered an open fire. This definition shall not include open
fires used for the purpose of barbecuing, bonfires, campfires, fires in private
indoor fireplaces or fires in an outdoor approved container using approved wood
or other approved combustible materials. Smoke emissions from open fires used
for barbecuing or private indoor fireplaces shall not exceed the limits set
forth in this section.
PERSON: Any individual, company, organization, operator, user, owner, employee
or any representative thereof acting in any capacity. The masculine, feminine,
singular or plural is included in any circumstance.
PREMISES: Any real estate or real property.
RECREATIONAL CAMPFIRE: A safely conducted outdoor fire utilized for comfort or
relaxation. No village permit is required to conduct a recreational campfire.
REFUSE: Combustible trash including, but not limited to, paper, cartons, boxes,
barrels, wood, excelsior, tree branches, yard trimmings, wood furniture,
bedding; noncombustible trash including, but not limited to, metals, tin cans,
metal furniture, dirt, small quantities of rocks and pieces of concrete, glass,
crockery, other mineral wastes; street rubbish including, but not limited to,
street sweepings, dirt, leaves, catch basin dirt, contents of litter
receptacles; and all trade wastes resulting from industrial processes and
manufacturing operations, such as food processing wastes, boiler house cinders,
lumber from lumber processing, and other trade wastes not specifically
enumerated.
RINGELMANN CHART: The chart published and described in the bureau of mines,
U.S. department of the interior, information circular no. 8333, and on which
are illustrated graduated shades of gray for use in estimating the light
obscuring capacity of smoke.
RINGELMANN NUMBER: The number according to each card described in the bureau of
mines, U.S. department of the interior, information circular no. 8333 which
corresponds to the density or equivalent opacity of the smoke emission.
SMOKE: Small gasborne particles, other than water, in sufficient number to be
observable. Measurements of smoke violations will be based on the percent of
visibility obscuration (equivalent capacity).
SMOKE UNIT: Ringelmann number times the minutes of emission.
STACK OR CHIMNEY: Any conduit, duct, vent, flue or opening arranged to conduct
products of combustion to the atmosphere and designed to control air pollution
emissions.
   B.   Open Burning Generally Prohibited: It shall be unlawful within the
village for any person to cause, suffer or allow "open fires" as defined in
this section, unless the open fire is conducted in accordance with the
exceptions listed below. This prohibition includes, but does not limit the
generality of the foregoing, fires for the burning of wood, fibers, plastics,
papers, cardboard, garbage, debris, leaves, tree trimmings, twigs, branches,
grass clippings, or other refuse from farming or gardening, or other
combustible materials of any kind, excluding the exceptions listed below.
   C.   Open Burning Exception; Controlled Burn Permit: Open burning of trees,
grasses and other vegetation on virgin prairie or other open fields, under a
controlled burn, may be allowed upon issuance of a permit by the village. The
controlled burn of a structure, like a house, by fire department personnel for
fire training purposes or a bonfire may be allowed upon issuance of a permit by
the village. Any person seeking to conduct a controlled burn shall submit an
application for such permit to the director of fire and emergency medical
services, who shall review such application with all applicable village
directors when necessary and shall issue such permit if he makes the following
findings:
      1.   Location; Permission: The applicant is a village resident or an
organization located in the village. The applicant must provide proof that he/
she/it has permission from the property owner to use the property for the
controlled burn.
      2.   Proper Management Of Controlled Burn: The applicant must provide
proof that he/she/it has the necessary people to properly manage the controlled
burn. The applicant is required to clean up and properly dispose of any debris,
litter or waste caused by the controlled burn. Where the applicant fails to
perform its obligations under this permit, the applicant shall agree to pay for
such special municipal services provided by the village which the village deems
as necessary to protect the health, welfare and safety of the public in regard
to the controlled burn and/or to clean up and dispose of any debris, litter or
waste caused by the controlled burn. The charges for such special municipal
services, if provided, will be based on the actual out of pocket costs incurred
by the village and will result in recouping one hundred percent (100%) of
billable expenses, including, but not limited to, staff hours and any
dispensable village resources used.
      3.   No Harm Anticipated: It is anticipated that no harm will result from
the controlled burn and that it is being done for the purpose of preserving or
restoring virgin prairie flora for historical, cultural, educational and
conservation reasons or for fire training purposes or for ceremonial purposes
or as part of a civic or community event.
      4.   Other Village Assets Deployed: As directed by the director of fire
and emergency medical services, in his discretion, the following village assets
may be deployed to include one or more personnel from the department of fire
and emergency medical services, the village engineer's office and the village
forester's office. These additional resources may be assigned to be present at
the controlled burn site and present during all open burning periods.
      5.   Notification To Adjacent Property Owners: The applicant shall
provide the director of fire and emergency medical services with proof that the
applicant hand delivered written notification of the date, time and expected
duration of the controlled burn to all village residents and village businesses
located immediately adjacent to and within two hundred fifty feet (250') of the
controlled burn site prior to conducting the controlled burn.
      6.   Notification To Other Municipalities: If the controlled burn site is
within two hundred fifty feet (250') of the village's corporate boundaries, the
applicant shall provide the director of fire and emergency medical services
with proof that the applicant hand delivered written notification to all
immediately adjacent municipal governmental entities and agencies including
quasi-governmental agencies such as the Illinois toll highway authority prior
to conducting the controlled burn.
      7.   Notification Of Stoppage In Writing: If the controlled burn is
stopped for any foreseeable reason prior to the set date by any governmental
entity or agency, all previously notified governmental entities and agencies
shall be immediately notified in writing of the stoppage. In addition, the
director of fire and emergency medical services or his designee will be called
twenty four (24) hours in advance of the cancellation in order to notify
previously scheduled municipal resources they won't be necessary.
      8.   Notification Of Stoppage Via Phone: If the controlled burn must be
stopped on that date or while in progress all previously notified governmental
entities and agencies and the director of fire and emergency medical services
or his designee shall be notified via phone contact immediately. Twenty four
(24) hour written notification shall be provided to those who received notice
under subsections C5, C6 and C7 of this section prior to restarting the
controlled burn.
      9.   Statements: The following statements shall be included on the
village permit and signed by the applicant:
         a.   The applicant agrees to release, waive, indemnify and hold
harmless the village of Western Springs, its present and future elected or
appointed officers and officials, president and trustees, agents, attorneys,
engineers, volunteers, representatives and employees for all claims or causes
of action, liabilities, losses and damages of any kind arising from or relating
to the issuance of this permit or conducting the controlled burn.
         b.   The village reserves the right to charge the applicant for
special municipal services, such as police, fire and public works personnel and
services that are necessary to protect the health, welfare and safety of the
public in regard to the controlled burn and/or to clean up and dispose of any
debris, litter or waste caused by the controlled burn in the case where the
applicant fails to perform its obligations under this permit. The applicant
agrees to pay for such special municipal services provided by the village which
are necessary to protect the health, welfare and safety of the public in regard
to the controlled burn. The charges for such special municipal services, if
provided, will be based on the actual out of pocket costs incurred by the
village.
      10.   Necessary Governmental Permits: The applicant shall provide the
director of fire and emergency medical services with proof that the applicant
secured all necessary governmental permits, if any, from governmental entities
or agencies with jurisdiction prior to conducting the controlled burn.
      11.   Permit For Controlled Burn Required: It shall be unlawful for any
person to conduct a controlled burn without first obtaining a permit.
      12.   Controlled Burn Application Fee: The applicant shall pay a
nonrefundable application fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) at the time of
submittal of the controlled burn application.
   D.   Permitted Open Fires: The following open fires shall be permitted as
follows:
      1.   The burning of approved wood or approved combustible materials
within an approved container; provided that any refuse burning incinerator
installed in any residence building shall comply with the rules and regulations
of the Illinois pollution control board as the same may from time to time be in
effect (see state of Illinois air pollution control requirements technical
release no. 140-2, dated October 1969, and subsequent releases); and
      2.   The burning of charcoal briquettes, natural gas, propane, approved
wood, or commercially prepared seasoned wood chips in conjunction with any of
the foregoing for cooking purposes; and
      3.   The burning of "approved wood", as defined in this section, in an
outdoor bonfire at a gathering conducted by religious, educational or other not
for profit organization; provided that a permit therefor is previously issued
by the village and that such bonfire is attended by adult supervision and
otherwise is in compliance with this code; and
      4.   The burning of "approved wood" in an "approved container" for
recreational campfires, as these terms are defined in this section, or in an
exterior masonry fireplace in a safe and controlled manner, provided compliance
with the following:
         a.   Such fire shall be under the control of and attended at all times
by a person eighteen (18) years of age or older; and
         b.   A portable fire extinguisher having a minimum rating of 4-A or
other approved extinguishing agent such as sand, dirt or water of sufficient
quantity shall be available for immediate use; and
         c.   Such fire shall at all times be safely managed and shall not be
permitted whenever atmospheric conditions or local circumstances make such fire
hazardous; and
         d.   Such approved containers of fire shall be located in an area
separated from any building or structure, including wooden decks, or other
combustible materials, by not less than ten feet (10'), except for fires
located in exterior masonry fireplaces attached to occupied residences or
buildings. The approved container shall be located at least five feet (5') away
from any lot line; and
         e.   Such fire shall not be permitted to create excessive flames,
odors, flying cinders or smoke so that flames, odors, cinders or smoke travels
across the property boundary from which the fire originates; and
         f.   At no time shall such fire be utilized for waste disposal
purposes.
   E.   Dense Smoke:
      1.   It is unlawful to cause or permit the emission of dense smoke from
any fire, chimney, engine, oil burner, or any approved container in the
village.
      2.   For the purpose of testing and grading the density of smoke, the
Ringelmann smoke chart, as published and used by the United States geological
survey, shall be, and is adopted as, a standard for such grading, and "smoke"
shall be, and is, defined as and declared to be dense when it is of a degree of
density of number three of the chart, or greater, for more than six (6) minutes
in any one hour; whether such period of time is consecutive or not. (Ord. 13-
2719, 5-20-2013)
CHAPTER 7
SMOKING IN PUBLIC PLACES
SECTION:
5-7-1: Clean Indoor Air/Smoking Regulations
5-7-1: CLEAN INDOOR AIR/SMOKING REGULATIONS:
   A.   Controlling Regulations: For the purposes of regulating clean indoor
air and smoking in the Village of Western Springs, the provisions of the Smoke
Free Illinois Act, 410 Illinois Compiled Statutes 82/1 et seq., as amended, and
the regulations of the Illinois Department of Public Health, as amended, along
with any applicable regulations under Federal law, shall be controlling except
to the extent that the Village has adopted the following definition of "smoke"
or "smoking":
SMOKE OR SMOKING: Means: 1) inhaling, exhaling, burning, or carrying any
lighted cigar, cigarette, pipe, or other lighted tobacco product in any manner
or in any form; 2) inhaling or exhaling from, turning on, powering, ingesting
or utilizing in any form any device intended for the atomization, charring,
burning, piezoelectronic ignition of or ingestion of tobacco products or
nicotine in any gaseous, smoke, aerosol, vaporous or other similar form,
including but not limited to the use of any e-cigarette, personal vaporizer
used with nicotine or tobacco derivatives, electronic nicotine delivery system,
e-puffer, cartomizer or other similar device; 3) use of any other device
intended for the gaseous, smoke, aerosol, vaporous or other similar airborne
ingestion of tobacco, tobacco derivatives, nicotine, or nicotine derivatives;
or, 4) completing any of the foregoing actions utilizing any form of smoked,
aerosolized, ionized, vaporous or similar airborne ingestion of marijuana,
cannabis or any derivative thereof. Smoking shall not include non-airborne
forms of tobacco, nicotine or medical cannabis ingestion such as use of chewing
tobacco or use of nicotine patches. "Smoke" or "smoking" also does not include
smoking that is associated with a native recognized religious ceremony, ritual,
or activity by American Indians that is in accordance with the Federal American
Indian Religious Freedom Act, 42 USC 1996 and 1996a.
This definition of "smoke" or "smoking" shall be used in the Village's
enforcement of the provisions of the Smoke Free Illinois Act, 410 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 82/1 et seq., as amended, and the regulations of the Illinois
Department of Public Health, as amended, along with any applicable regulations
under Federal law.
   B.   Violations:
      1.   A person, corporation, partnership, association or other entity who
violates the Smoke Free Illinois Act shall be fined pursuant to this section.
Each day that a violation occurs is a separate violation.
      2.   A person who smokes in an area where smoking is prohibited under the
Smoke Free Illinois Act shall be fined in an amount that is not less than one
hundred dollars ($100.00) and not more than two hundred fifty dollars
($250.00). A person who owns, operates, or otherwise controls a public place or
place of employment that violates the Smoke Free Illinois Act shall be fined:
a) not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for the first violation,
b) not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for the second violation within
one year after the first violation, and c) not less than two thousand five
hundred dollars ($2,500.00) for each additional violation within one year after
the first violation.
      3.   A fine imposed under this section shall be allocated as follows:
         a.   One-half (1/2) of the fine shall be distributed to the Illinois
Department of Public Health; and
         b.   One-half (1/2) of the fine shall be distributed to the Village of
Western Springs. (Ord. 18-2930, 8-20-2018)
TITLE 6
POLICE REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1
GENERAL OFFENSES
SECTION:
6-1-1: State Of Illinois Statutes Adopted By Reference
6-1-2: Weapons
6-1-1: STATE OF ILLINOIS STATUTES ADOPTED BY REFERENCE:
   A.   Incorporation Of State Statutes: Except insofar as the application
thereof is clearly impractical or inappropriate, in view of the context of
purposes or penalty as provided, all of the definitions, requirements,
regulations, prohibitions, provisions and sections of the following state of
Illinois statutes, as amended, are adopted by reference by the village:
      1.   Pyrotechnic use act, 425 Illinois Compiled Statutes 35/0.01 et seq.;
      2.   Illinois vehicle code, criminal damage to property, 625 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/4-102(a)(1);
      3.   Illinois vehicle code, bridge and railroad signals, 625 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/11-1011;
      4.   Illinois vehicle code, trespassing on railroad property, terminal
security, 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/18C-7503;
      5.   Criminal code, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-1 et seq.;
      6.   Cannabis control act, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 550/1 et seq.;
and
      7.   Drug paraphernalia control act, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 600/
1 et seq.
   B.   Penalty: Any and all violations of the state of Illinois statutes
adopted by reference herein shall be considered violations of this section, and
each such violation shall subject the violator thereof to a fine not to exceed
seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. (Ord. 15-2802, 5-18-
2015)
6-1-2: WEAPONS:
   A.   Discharging Firearms And Air Guns: It shall be unlawful to discharge
any firearm or air gun in the village; provided, however, that this subsection
shall not be construed to prohibit any law enforcement officer from discharging
a firearm or an air gun in the performance of his duty; nor to any citizen from
discharging a firearm or air gun when lawfully defending his person or
property. It shall not be a violation of this subsection for a law enforcement
officer or other authorized person to discharge a firearm or an air gun on
premises used by the department of law enforcement services as a target
shooting range.
   B.   Discharge Of Other Weapons: It shall be unlawful to discharge or
