operate any toy firearm, bow, crossbow, slingshot or other device which
discharges a bullet, arrow, pellet or other projectile; provided, however, that
nothing in this subsection shall prohibit: 1) the use of such weapons at indoor
shooting galleries or inside any private residence; and 2) the use of archery
equipment as part of a department of recreation sponsored program.
   C.   Definitions:
AIR GUN: Any air gun, air pistol, spring gun, spring pistol, BB gun, paintball
gun, pellet gun or any other implement or device that is not a firearm but
which expels a pellet constructed of hard plastic, steel, lead or other hard
materials or any other type of projectile or projectiles by the action of an
explosion, expansion or escape of gas or other mechanical means with a force
that may be reasonably expected to cause bodily harm.
FIREARM: As used in this section shall include the definition of "firearm" as
contained in the "firearm owners identification card act" 1 , as amended, which
is incorporated into this section by reference and shall also include any other
device, by whatever name known, which is designed to expel a projectile or
projectiles by the action of an explosion, expansion or escape of gas or other
mechanical means.
The terms "firearm" and "air gun" and "weapon" are interchangeable.
   D.   Hunting: It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in killing or to
hunt any bird or animal in the village using a firearm, air gun or other
weapon.
   E.   Concealed Weapons: It shall be unlawful to carry any concealed weapons
in the village without having first secured a license to carry such concealed
weapons issued under the laws of the state.
   F.   Penalties; Confiscation: In addition to all other penalties provided
for in this code or under state or federal law, any firearm, air gun or weapon
used in violation of this section shall be forfeited to and confiscated by the
village. (Ord. 04-2305, 6-28-2004)

1 1. 430 ILCS 65/1.1.
CHAPTER 2
ANIMALS
SECTION:
6-2-1: Definitions
6-2-2: Status Of Animals Within The Village
6-2-3: License Fee; Registration; Eligibility If Debt Owed To Village
6-2-4: Register; Tags; Collars
6-2-5: Vaccination Against Rabies
6-2-6: Lost Tags
6-2-7: Removing License Tags
6-2-8: Number Of Animals Permitted
6-2-9: Running At Large Prohibited
6-2-10: Complaint Procedure
6-2-11: Disposition Of Animals
6-2-12: Holding Facility Registry
6-2-13: Redemption Of Animals; Impoundment Procedures
6-2-14: Dangerous Or Vicious, Biting And Barking Dogs Or Animals
6-2-15: Animal Waste
6-2-16: Owner's Duties
6-2-17: Prohibited Acts And Conditions
6-2-18: Electric Or Electronic Pet Containment Systems
6-2-19: Penalties
6-2-1: DEFINITIONS:
Whenever used in this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings
respectively ascribed to them in this section:
ANIMAL: Every living creature, domestic or wild, but does not include human
beings.
AT LARGE: Be off the premises of its owner or keeper and not under restraint of
a competent person.
CATS: All members of the feline species.
COMPETENT PERSON: A person who is physically and mentally capable of
controlling an animal under restraint.
DOGS: All members of the domestic canine species.
ELECTRIC OR ELECTRONIC PET CONTAINMENT SYSTEM: Any electric or electronic pet
containment system, located either aboveground or underground, that is designed
and installed for the purpose of containing pets within any geographic area
through electric or electronic means.
HOLDING FACILITY: Any facility for the purpose of impounding or harboring
seized, stray, homeless, abandoned or unwanted animals or any veterinary
hospital or clinic authorized by the Village.
LEASH: A cord, thong, rope, strap or chain which shall be securely fastened to
the collar or harness of a dog or other animal and shall be of sufficient
strength to keep such dog or other animal under control.
LIVESTOCK: Any animal of the species of horse, ass, mule, oxen, cattle, sheep,
goat or swine.
NUISANCE: Any undue and repeated disturbance, imminent danger to any property,
imminent danger to a person's safety or other animals' safety and/or assessable
damage to a person or other animals or to property caused by the presence of an
animal upon the premises or property of the complainant.
OWNER: Any person owning, harboring or keeping an animal. The occupant or
person in control of any premises on which an animal remains or to which it
customarily returns daily for a period of ten (10) days or more shall be
presumed to be harboring or keeping the animals.
POULTRY: Chickens, ducks, geese, turkeys or pigeons.
RESTRAINT: An animal is under restraint within the meaning of this chapter if
it is on its owner's or keeper's premises in a fenced yard or on a leash of not
more than ten feet (10') in length.
WILD GAME: Deer, raccoon, possum, skunk, lion, tiger, leopard, ocelot, jaguar,
cheetah, margay, mountain lion, Canada lynx, bobcats, jaguarundi, hyena,
coyote, fox, poisonous reptile or wild rabbit. (Ord. 83-1657, 12-19-1983; amd.
Ord. 09-2525, 2-23-2009; Ord. 12-2665, 3-26-2012; Ord. 16-2852, 11-28-2016)
6-2-2: STATUS OF ANIMALS WITHIN THE VILLAGE:
Animals kept within or on the property or premises of their owners; maintained
by and provided with food or by being given other privileged use of privately
owned property; brought into the Village; or otherwise present in the Village
shall, for purposes of application of this chapter, be divided into two (2)
classes:
   A.   Those animals whose ownership is established by a readable and current
license tag, or whose ownership is promptly traceable by means of any other
readable identification affixed to a collar or harness, or those animals whose
ownership is certified to by a reliable witness and is immediately verifiable,
are hereinafter classified as domesticated and protected animals.
   B.   Animals whose ownership cannot readily be established by any of the
means stated in subsection A of this section are hereinafter classified as
nondomesticated and unprotected animals. (Ord. 83-1657, 12-19-1983)
6-2-3: LICENSE FEE; REGISTRATION; ELIGIBILITY IF DEBT OWED TO VILLAGE:
Every resident of the Village who shall own or keep a dog or cat at any place
within the Village shall, at six (6) months of age or within six (6) months
after acquiring such dog or cat, or bringing the same into the Village,
whichever comes first, register such dog or cat and pay as an annual license
fee the sum of ten dollars ($10.00) for each dog or cat so registered.
   A.   Eligibility if Debt Owed to Village: See the provisions of Section
3-1-1(A) of this Code, which are incorporated by reference into this Title and
Chapter and are applicable to the grant or issuance of any Village approvals,
certificates, licenses or permits covered by this Chapter. (Ord. 95-1925, 1-23-
1995; amd. 1997 Code; Ord. 22-3091, 7-11-2022)
6-2-4: REGISTER; TAGS; COLLARS:
   A.   Register Kept; Tags Issued: The Village Clerk shall keep a complete
register in a book for that purpose of all licensed animals, describing them by
name, breed, color and sex, and shall also enter the name and address of the
owner or keeper as given in the application and the number of the license tag.
The Clerk shall provide each year metallic tags (the shape to be changed each
year) having stamped thereon the year for which the tax is paid, the words
"Western Springs dog/cat tax", and also the number of the tag. The Village
Clerk shall deliver one tag, bearing the appropriate registered number, to each
person having paid the tax upon any such dog or cat. The tax shall be due on
April 1 of each year. (Ord. 16-2852, 11-28-2016)
   B.   Collars Required: It shall be unlawful for the owner or keeper of any
licensed animal to keep such animal at any place within the Village unless such
animal at all times has a collar firmly attached around its neck with the
license tag for the current year attached to such collar. (Ord. 83-1657, 12-19-
1983)
6-2-5: VACCINATION AGAINST RABIES:
The owner or keeper of a dog, cat or ferret or other animal capable of being
infected with rabies, except for animal shelters, animal impounding facilities
and laboratory animal facilities shall have such animal vaccinated against
rabies by a licensed veterinarian at four (4) months of age and annually
thereafter or as required by State law and Cook County ordinance. Evidence of
vaccination shall be the standard vaccination tag and certificate issued by a
licensed veterinarian. It shall be unlawful to keep or harbor in the Village an
animal that has not been vaccinated against rabies for the current year. Any
animal placed in a holding facility shall not be released until vaccination
against rabies has been accomplished. (Ord. 09-2525, 2-23-2009)
6-2-6: LOST TAGS:
If the license tag authorized to be issued to a licensee is lost or stolen, a
duplicate license tag to correspond with the one originally issued shall be
issued upon payment to the Village by such licensee of a fee of three dollars
($3.00). (Ord. 95-1925, 1-23-1995)
6-2-7: REMOVING LICENSE TAGS:
No person, other than the animal owner, animal control officer, police officer,
veterinarian or holding facility master shall remove the collar or license tag
from any animal within the limits of the Village, unless it is with the consent
of the owner or keeper of the animal. (Ord. 83-1657, 12-19-1983)
6-2-8: NUMBER OF ANIMALS PERMITTED:
No person shall keep or allow to be kept upon the premises he occupies or uses
within the Village, more than three (3) dogs, cats, or a combination of both,
of the age of three (3) months or over at any one time. For any person to keep
more than three (3) such animals at one time shall constitute a nuisance. This
shall not apply to licensed veterinary hospitals or licensed pet shops. (Ord.
83-1657, 12-19-1983)
6-2-9: RUNNING AT LARGE PROHIBITED:
All running at large of dogs, cats and other domesticated animals is
prohibited. The provisions of this section shall not apply to professionally
trained dogs or other animals used for law enforcement purposes. Running "at
large" is defined in this chapter to mean that the animal is off the premises
of its owner or keeper and not under restraint of a competent person. An animal
is under "restraint" within the meaning of this chapter if it is on its owner's
or keeper's premises in a fenced yard or on a leash. Any dog or cat or other
domesticated animal running at large shall be processed as hereinafter
provided. Absent express authority of the governing public body, no dogs or
cats or other domesticated animals shall be permitted to run at large as
follows:
   A.   Parks: In parks lying within the boundaries of the Western Springs Park
District.
   B.   School Areas: On land owned by public school districts and lying within
the boundaries of the Village.
   C.   Near Public Buildings: On public grounds adjacent to buildings owned by
the Village. (Ord. 09-2525, 2-23-2009)
6-2-10: COMPLAINT PROCEDURE:
Upon the receipt of an animal complaint from a citizen, a police officer or an
Ordinance Control Officer shall assist the complainant as follows:
   A.   Apprehension Of Animal: Make a reasonable effort to apprehend the
animal referred to by the complainant which is in violation of the provisions
of this chapter and to proceed as otherwise provided.
   B.   Provide Information: Assist the complainant by providing information
and instructions on how to file a formal complaint for violation of this
chapter. (Ord. 83-1657, 12-19-1983)
6-2-11: DISPOSITION OF ANIMALS:
Animals accepted or apprehended as nondomesticated and unprotected 1  shall
immediately be designated as surplus to the capabilities of the Village to
accommodate or otherwise provide for, and they shall be delivered forthwith to
the designated animal holding facility for whatever disposition the holding
facility elects to make of them after the elsewhere stipulated holding period.
Further, neither the Village nor said holding facility shall be placed under
obligation to disclose such disposal or to answer in any manner for their
action to any party who later may seek to claim ownership. (Ord. 83-1657, 12-
19-1983)
 
Notes
1 1. See subsection
  6-2-2B of this chapter.
6-2-12: HOLDING FACILITY REGISTRY:
The Village shall keep a record of the breed, color and sex of the animal and
name and address of the owner, if known, and subsequent disposition of the
animal coming into its custody. (Ord. 83-1657, 12-19-1983)
6-2-13: REDEMPTION OF ANIMALS; IMPOUNDMENT PROCEDURES:
   A.   Notice To Owner: If the owner of the animal is known, or shall
subsequently become known during impoundment, the Village shall notify the
owner of the impoundment and the procedure whereby the animal may be redeemed.
The Village shall also inform the holding facility wherein the animal is
impounded of the date that such notification has been given to the animal's
owner.
   B.   Redemption: In the event that the owner of any impounded animal desires
to make redemption thereof, the owner shall do so on the following conditions:
(Ord. 83-1657, 12-19-1983)
      1.   The owner shall present proof of valid rabies inoculation. (Ord. 83-
1657, 12-19-1983; amd. 1997 Code)
      2.   The owner shall pay to the Village an impoundment fee which shall be
in addition to any fine or other penalty provided under this section and in
addition to any costs of the holding facility.
      3.   The owner shall pay to the holding facility any daily kennel costs
and the costs of any services provided.
   C.   Adoption; Disposal: When an animal is not redeemed by the owner as
provided in subsection B of this section, the animal shall become the property
of the holding facility to be disposed of in a humane manner or made available
for adoption according to procedures established by said holding facility,
provided:
      1.   In any case where the identity of the owner is known or becomes
known, the animal may not be disposed of unless the animal is unredeemed by the
owner within seven (7) days after notice of the impoundment is given.
      2.   In any case where the identity of the owner is not known, the animal
may be disposed of only if the owner fails to redeem it within five (5) days of
the impoundment. (Ord. 83-1657, 12-19-1983)
6-2-14: DANGEROUS OR VICIOUS, BITING AND BARKING DOGS OR ANIMALS:
   A.   Dangerous Or Vicious Dogs Or Animals; Biting And Howling: No dangerous,
or vicious dog or other animal, or dog which disturbs the peace and quiet of
any persons as by howling or barking, shall be harbored or kept within the
Village. Any such dog or animal, and any dog or animal which bites a person or
another animal or so injures a person or other animal as to cause an abrasion
of the skin, is hereby declared to be a nuisance and may be impounded. A dog or
other animal is declared to be dangerous or vicious within the meaning of this
section when a propensity to attack or to bite human beings or animals exists
or as provided for under provisions of the Illinois Animal Control Act 1 .
Where a dog or other animal injures a person or another animal or is otherwise
determined to be a dangerous or vicious dog or animal by a Village or other
governmental Code officer, animal control officer or law enforcement officer
based on the documented conduct of the dog or animal, the Village shall file a
report with the Cook County Department of Animal Control or such other
governmental agency with regulatory authority for processing under the
applicable provisions of the Illinois Animal Control Act 2 , or the Village may
take such other action as is authorized and provided for by this chapter, other
chapters of this Code or other applicable laws, including filing a nuisance
abatement action as provided for under section
5-1-6, "Abatement Of Nuisance", of this Code.
   B.   Disposition: No owner of any animal, having knowledge that such dog or
animal has bitten any person or another animal or so injured any person or
animal as to cause an abrasion of the skin, shall sell or give away such
animal, or allow such animal to be taken beyond the limits of the Village. Such
owner shall place such animal in a recognized veterinary hospital acceptable to
the Director of Law Enforcement Services and under the supervision of a
registered veterinarian for a period required by law. The hospitalization shall
be at the expense of the owner.
   C.   Seizure; Right Of Entry: Any police officer may enter upon the premises
of any owner of a dangerous or vicious animal, or any animal suffering from
rabies, or of one bitten by another animal suffering from rabies, and seize and
impound said animal. Such entry may be made on the basis of the officer's
personal knowledge of the facts, upon the filing with him of an affidavit by
any resident of the Village that there is such an animal on said premises, or
on the certificate of the Director of Law Enforcement Services that an animal
suffering from rabies or one bitten by one suffering from rabies is on said
premises. If such entry be made and the owner of said animal, or an immediate
member of his family over sixteen (16) years of age, shall refuse to deliver
such animal to such officer, and the officer cannot, with reasonable effort,
catch the animal, he may kill it forthwith. (Ord. 16-2852, 11-28-2016)
   D.   Rabid Animals; Report; Disposal: Every veterinarian or other person
discovering an animal suffering from rabies shall immediately report such fact
to the Director of Law Enforcement Services. Such report shall give the name,
if known, and the place of residence of the person owning, harboring or keeping
such animal, the place where such animal can be found, and the license number
of said animal, if known. Such animal shall be immediately taken up and placed
in a recognized veterinary hospital where it shall be observed by a qualified
veterinarian until it dies or is destroyed, after which the head shall be
removed and a suitable pathological examination of the brain shall be carried
out to determine whether or not the animal died of rabies. (Ord. 83-1657, 12-
19-1983; amd. 1997 Code)
   E.   Barking Dogs: It shall be unlawful to allow a dog to disturb the peace
and quiet of any persons by barking or howling. Barking or howling dogs must be
quieted by the owner or taken inside. (Ord. 03-2245, 6-23-2003)
 
Notes
1 1. 510 ILCS 5/1 et seq.
2 2. 510 ILCS 5/1 et seq.
6-2-15: ANIMAL WASTE:
It shall be unlawful for any person to cause or permit any animal to be on any
property, public or private, not owned or possessed by such person unless such
person has in his immediate possession a device for the immediate removal of
excrement and removes it to a receptacle located upon property owned or
possessed by such person. It shall be unlawful for any person in control of,
causing or permitting any animal to be on any property, public or private, not
owned or possessed by such person to fail to immediately remove excrement left
by such animal to a proper receptacle located on property owned or possessed by
such person. (Ord. 83-1657, 12-19-1983; amd. 1997 Code)
6-2-16: OWNER'S DUTIES:
Each owner shall provide for each of his animals the following:
   A.   Food And Water: Sufficient quantity of good quality wholesome food and
water.
   B.   Shelter: Adequate shelter and protection from weather.
   C.   Veterinary Care: Veterinary care when needed to prevent suffering.
(Ord. 83-1657, 12-19-1983)
   D.   Humane Treatment: Humane care and treatment. Any animal having a
contagious disease shall be isolated and properly treated. (Ord. 12-2665, 3-26-
2012)
6-2-17: PROHIBITED ACTS AND CONDITIONS:
   A.   Female Animals In Heat: The owner or keeper of any female animal who
permits such animal, while in heat, to be upon any sidewalk, street, parkway,
alley or other public place, or upon any private premises, other than the
premises of the owner or keeper which is closer to the sidewalk, street,
parkway or other public place than ten feet (10'), shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor. The court may, upon conviction, order such animal committed to a
kennel at the owner's expense until such period of heat shall terminate.
   B.   Abandoning Animals: No owner may abandon any animal where it may become
a public charge or where the animal may suffer injury, hunger or exposure. Any
person who shall take, drive or drop off any animal from outside the Village
limits, into the Village limits, with the intent that such animal may be
impounded, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor.
   C.   Cruelty To Animals: No person or owner may beat, cruelly treat,
torment, overload, overwork or otherwise abuse any animal.
   D.   Animal Fights:
      1.   No person may own, capture, breed, train or lease any animal which
is intended for use in any activity involving a fight between such animal and
any other animal or the intentional killing of any animal for the purpose of
sport, wagering or entertainment.
      2.   No person shall promote, conduct, carry on, advertise, collect money
for, or in any other manner assist or aid in the presentation for purposes of
sport, wagering or entertainment, any show, exhibition, program or other
activity involving a fight between two (2) or more animals or the intentional
killing of any animal.
      3.   No person shall sell, offer for sale, ship, transport or otherwise
move, deliver or receive any animal which has been captured, bred or trained,
or will be used to fight another animal or be intentionally killed, for the
purpose of sport, wagering or entertainment.
      4.   No person shall manufacture for sale, shipment, transportation or
delivery any device or equipment which is intended for use in any activity
featuring or otherwise involving a fight between two (2) or more animals or the
intentional killing of any animal for purposes of sport, wagering or
entertainment.
      5.   No person shall sell or offer for sale, ship, transport or otherwise
move any equipment or device which is intended for use in connection with any
show, exhibition, program or activity featuring or otherwise involving a fight
between two (2) or more animals or the intentional killing of any animal for
purposes of sport, wagering or entertainment.
      6.   No person shall make available any site, structure or facility,
whether enclosed or not, which is intended to be used for the purpose of
conducting any activity involving a fight between two (2) or more animals or
the intentional killing of any animal. (Ord. 83-1657, 12-19-1983)
   E.   Keeping Certain Animals: No animal defined in this chapter as
"livestock" or "wild game" shall be kept, stabled or harbored in the Village.
Animals defined in this chapter as "poultry" shall be kept and maintained
within the Village only in accordance with the regulations set forth at
subsection
5-1-1N of this Code. (Ord. 11-2619, 2-28-2011)
   F.   Leghold Traps: No person shall use or permit the use of any leghold
animal trap or similar device with spring activated jaws of the type used for
the trapping of furbearing animals which is capable of inflicting cruelty upon
dogs, cats or other animals, or which constitutes a hazard to small children.
(Ord. 83-1657, 12-19-1983)
6-2-18: ELECTRIC OR ELECTRONIC PET CONTAINMENT SYSTEMS:
   A.   Definitions: For the purpose of this section, the definition of
"electric or electronic pet containment system", as set forth in section
6-2-1 of this chapter, shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or
requires a different meaning.
   B.   Compliance Required: Every electric or electronic pet containment
system constructed, installed and maintained hereafter shall comply with all
applicable provisions of this section.
   C.   Location Of System: Electric or electronic pet containment systems
shall be a permitted accessory use in any residence district, provided that it
conforms with this section and other applicable ordinances of the Village,
including the zoning ordinance. Electric or electronic pet containment systems
shall be permitted in the front, rear and corner side yard of a property only
if it is to be located at a distance not less than six feet (6') from said
property line. If the fence is proposed for any property line (such as side or
rear) which abuts a public sidewalk, the electric or electronic pet containment
systems shall be located at a distance not less than six feet (6') from the
sidewalk.
   D.   Permit Required: It shall be unlawful to proceed with construction,
installation, enlargement or alteration of any electric or electronic pet
containment system within the Village unless permits therefor shall have first
been obtained from the Community Development Department.
   E.   Drawings And Plans:
      1.   All specifications, drawings and plans for the construction,
installation, enlargement or alteration of any electric or electronic pet
containment system for which a permit is required shall first be presented to
the Building Commissioner for examination and approval as to proper location,
construction and use.
      2.   All plans and drawings shall be drawn to a scale of not less than
one-eighth (1/8) of an inch to the foot, on paper or cloth, in ink, or by some
process that will not fade or obliterate. All distances and dimensions shall be
accurately figured and drawings made explicit and complete, showing the lot
lines and including information pertaining to the electric or electronic pet
containment system, and all appurtenances thereto.
      3.   All electric or electronic pet containment systems shall be
constructed in conformity with the approved plans. If any deviations from such
plans are desired, a supplementary plan covering that portion of the work
involved shall be filed for approval and shall conform to the provisions of
this section.
   F.   Signs:
      1.   For any property on which an electric or electronic pet containment
system has been installed within the front yard of the property, the presence
of the system shall be indicated by the placement of no less than two (2) signs
on the property, with one sign to be located at each corner of the front yard
or corner side or rear yard property line. Such signs shall be located in such
a manner that they are able to be read from the front yard or corner side
parkway. Any signs required by this subsection shall measure no more than one
square foot in area. Any signs required by this subsection shall not require a
separate permit under any other provision of the Village's ordinances,
including the zoning ordinance.
      2.   If a property has a front yard measuring greater than sixty six feet
(66') in length, an additional sign indicating the presence of an electric or
electronic pet containment system shall be required, to be located near the
middle of the front yard property line.
   G.   Permit Fees: The fee for a permit for the construction, installation,
alteration or enlargement of an electric or electronic pet containment system
shall be twenty five dollars ($25.00). (Ord. 12-2665, 3-26-2012)
6-2-19: PENALTIES:
   A.   Violations of this chapter shall be punishable by a fine of not less
than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00) for each occurrence.
   B.   For all construction, installation, alteration or enlargement of an
electric or electronic pet containment system that occurs after the effective
date of section
6-2-18, "Electric Or Electronic Pet Containment Systems", of this chapter, in
addition to any other penalties provided by this chapter, any person convicted
of violating any provision of this chapter shall be required to immediately
comply with all other applicable provisions of this chapter, including, but not
limited to, compliance with the front yard setback requirements for electric or
electronic pet containment systems described in subsection
6-2-18C of this chapter. (Ord. 12-2665, 3-26-2012)
CHAPTER 3
CURFEW; CIVIL EMERGENCIES
SECTION:
6-3-1: Definitions
6-3-2: Civil Emergency Declared
6-3-3: General Curfew
6-3-4: Curfew Restrictions
6-3-5: Effective Period
6-3-6: Notify News Media
6-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the following words and terms shall have the meanings
ascribed to them in this section:
CIVIL EMERGENCY:
   A.   A riot or unlawful assembly characterized by the use of actual force or
violence or any threat to use force if accompanied by immediate power to
execute by three (3) or more persons acting together without authority of law;
or
   B.   Any natural disaster or manmade calamity, including flood,
conflagration, cyclone, tornado, earthquake or explosion within the corporate
limits of the village, resulting in the death or injury of persons or the
destruction of property to such an extent that extraordinary measures must be
taken to protect the public health, safety and welfare.
CURFEW: A prohibition against any person or persons walking, running,
loitering, standing or motoring upon any alley, street, highway, public
property or vacant premises within the corporate limits of the village,
excepting officials of any governmental unit and persons officially designated
to duty with reference to said civil emergency. (Ord. 13-2711, 2-25-2013)
6-3-2: CIVIL EMERGENCY DECLARED:
Whenever an "emergency", as defined in section
6-3-1 of this chapter, exists, the village president shall declare the
existence by means of a written declaration setting forth the facts which
constitute the emergency. (Ord. 13-2711, 2-25-2013)
6-3-3: GENERAL CURFEW:
After proclamation of a civil emergency by the village president, he/she may
order a general curfew applicable to such geographical areas of the village, or
to the village as a whole, as he/she deems advisable and applicable during such
hours of the day or night as he/she deems necessary in the interest of the
public safety and welfare. (Ord. 13-2711, 2-25-2013)
6-3-4: CURFEW RESTRICTIONS:
After the proclamation of a civil emergency, the village president may also in
the interest of public safety and welfare make any or all of the following
orders:
   A.   Distributing Flammable Materials: Order the discontinuance of selling,
distributing or giving away gasoline or other liquid flammable or combustible
products in any container other than a gasoline tank properly affixed to a
motor vehicle.
   B.   Distributing Firearms: Order the discontinuance of selling,
distributing, dispensing or giving away of any firearms or ammunition of any
character whatsoever.
   C.   Other Orders: Issue such other orders as are imminently necessary for
the protection of life and property. (Ord. 13-2711, 2-25-2013)
6-3-5: EFFECTIVE PERIOD:
The proclamation herein authorized shall be effective for a period of forty
eight (48) hours, unless sooner terminated by a proclamation of the village
president indicating that the civil emergency no longer exists. The village
president shall have the power to reproclaim the existence of a civil emergency
at the end of each forty eight (48) hour period during the time the said civil
emergency exists. (Ord. 13-2711, 2-25-2013)
6-3-6: NOTIFY NEWS MEDIA:
Upon issuing the proclamation herein authorized, the village president or their
designee shall designate a public information officer who shall notify the news
media situated within the village and shall cause three (3) copies of the
proclamation declaring the existence of the emergency to be posted at the
following places within the village: the village hall, the water tower and the
post office. (Ord. 13-2711, 2-25-2013)
CHAPTER 4
AUTOMATIC AND MANUAL BURGLAR AND FIRE ALARMS
SECTION:
6-4-1: Definitions
6-4-2: Permit Requirements
6-4-3: Inspection
6-4-4: Alarm Systems Annual Permit Fee
6-4-5: Revocation Or Suspension Of Permit
6-4-6: False Alarm Service Charge
6-4-7: Liability Of Village Limited
6-4-8: Penalties
6-4-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the following words and terms shall have the meanings
ascribed to them in this section:
ALARM EQUIPMENT SUPPLIER: Any person, firm or corporation that sells, leases or
installs automatic alarm systems which transmit alarms upon receipt of a
stimulus from a detection apparatus.
ALARM SYSTEM: Any assembly of equipment, mechanical or electrical, designed to
signal the occurrence of an illegal entry, fire or other activity requiring
urgent attention and response by the appropriate law enforcement department or
fire and emergency medical services departments or a private security company.
The definition of "alarm system" shall be interpreted broadly to include any
type of alarm system that is based on any type of technology and further
includes each of the alarm systems defined in this chapter, as amended:
"automatic telephone dialing system", "central station alarm system", "direct
connect alarm system" and "wireless alarm system".
ALARM USER: The person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or
organization of any kind in control of any building, structure or facility or
portion thereof wherein an alarm system is maintained.
AUTOMATIC TELEPHONE DIALING SYSTEM: Any alarm system which upon being activated
automatically transmits by telephone or telephone line to the Western Springs
department of law enforcement services a recorded message or code signal
indicating a need for emergency response. This system may only be programmed
for use with a seven (7) digit phone number, as designated by the permit issued
under the provisions of this chapter.
CENTRAL STATION ALARM SYSTEM: An alarm system in which the alarm signal is
maintained by an agency or private security company other than the Western
Springs department of law enforcement services.
DIRECT CONNECT ALARM SYSTEM: An alarm system which has the capability of
transmitting system signals to and receiving them at the Western Springs
department of law enforcement services communications center.
FALSE ALARM:
   A.   A visual and/or audible signal transmitted by an alarm system which
indicates the existence of an emergency situation, when in fact, no such
emergency exists, and, shall include any activation of an alarm system by
whatever means, but shall not include alarms resulting from any of the
following causes:
      1.   Criminal activity.
      2.   Acts of nature: earthquake, tornado, flooding, lightning or high
winds.
      3.   Fire or smoke causing structural or property damage to the protected
premises.
      4.   Telephone line malfunction.
      5.   Electrical service interruption.
      6.   Wireless service interruption.
   B.   If the alarm, when communicated to the department of law enforcement
services before an officer or fire unit is dispatched to investigate, is
clearly identified to the department as resulting from authorized entry,
authorized system test or other noncriminal cause, presence of smoke due to
accidental activation (e.g., burnt food) or any other related incident where
the system operated properly, it shall not be considered a false alarm. If
police and/or fire units responding to an alarm and checking the protected
premises, do not discover any evidence of unauthorized entry, criminal activity
or fire, there shall be a rebuttable presumption that the alarm is false.
Department of law enforcement services and department of fire and emergency
medical services records shall be prima facie evidence of the facts stated
therein with regard to alarms and responses.
WIRELESS ALARM SYSTEM: Any assembly of equipment, mechanical and/or electrical,
that utilizes wireless technology to signal and receive the occurrence of an
illegal entry, fire or other activity requiring urgent attention and response
by the appropriate law enforcement or fire and emergency medical services
departments or a private security company. See also, the definition of
"wireless protection system" as defined in section 3.3.212 of the "National
Fire Alarm Code Handbook Of 2002", as amended, which is incorporated herein by
reference. (Ord. 12-2690, 8-27-2012)
6-4-2: PERMIT REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Permit Required: No person shall install, operate or maintain any
"alarm system", as defined in this chapter, prior to obtaining a permit as
required by this section. Exception: Due to their low voltage electrical
design, wireless alarm systems that are not mandated by another section of code
do not require a permit, but shall require a certificate of registration
("certificate") as provided for below. The purpose of the certificate is to
provide the village with information of the existence of the alarm system and
sufficient contact information for the property owner, property manager and the
designated security alarm company for a property that has an active alarm
system operating within the village, but not connected to the village's
communication centers, in order to assist the village police and fire personnel
when they respond to any type of service call at the property.
   B.   Application For Permit Or Certificate Of Registration; Fee:
Applications for permits to install, maintain and operate a code mandated alarm
system shall be filed with the department of code enforcement on forms supplied
by the village and shall be accompanied by an application fee of fifty dollars
($50.00). Applications for certificates pertaining to the installation,
maintenance and operation of a wireless alarm system not mandated by code,
installed at the owner's request not connected to the village's communications
centers shall be filed with the department of law enforcement services on forms
supplied by the village and shall be accompanied by an application fee of
twenty five dollars ($25.00).
   C.   Contents Of Application: The application shall contain the following
information:
      1.   Name and address of alarm user.
      2.   Name and address of the premises where the alarm system is located.
      3.   Designation of the type of alarm system (automatic telephone dialing
system, central station alarm system, direct connect alarm system and wireless
alarm system) and a general description of the alarm system which classifies it
as burglary, safe, hold up, fire, medical or other, and the presence of silent
alarms and any audible or visual alerting signals on the premises. Any alarm
system classified as other shall include a brief description as to category
type.
      4.   The names, addresses and telephone numbers of at least three (3) or
more persons who are responsible for the premises where the alarm system is
located, and who may be contacted to reset the alarm system.
      5.   The name, address and telephone number of the person, firm or
corporation authorized to reset the alarm system when no person described in
subsection C4 of this section can be reached.
      6.   The name, address and telephone number of the person, firm or
corporation which installed the alarm system and of the person, firm or
corporation responsible for the maintenance and repair of the alarm system.
      7.   A provision which the alarm user has read and signed which reads as
follows:
By signing this application, the alarm user agrees that he/she has read and
understood the following release, indemnification and hold harmless provisions:
the alarm user agrees to release and not hold liable the Village of Western
Springs, and its appointed and elected officials, officers, employees, contract
employees, volunteers and agents (the "Village Affiliates") for any claims,
causes of actions, losses, damages or liabilities of any kind brought by any
person, including but not limited to any property damage and any death, injury
or illness that arises from or relates to any actual or claimed failure of
service or any consequential damages claimed to result from such failure, or
the installation, inspection, surveillance or operation of the user's alarm
system or the Village's alarm system or its receiving panels or of any other
component part of the alarm system, whether or not due to the negligent,
willful or reckless acts or omission of the Village or any of the Village
Affiliates. The alarm user further agrees that the alarm user shall defend,
indemnify and hold harmless the Village of Western Springs and the Village
Affiliates from any claims, causes of actions, losses, damages or liabilities
of any kind brought by any person, including but not limited to any property
damage and any death, injury or illness, arising out of or relating to this
application or any permit or any certificate issued by the Village, any act or
omission by the Village or the Village Affiliates in regard to this
application, the alarm user's connection to the Village system, the alarm
user's decision to not connect to the Village's system, where not mandated by
another code provision, the operation of the alarm user's alarm system, the
operation of the Village alarm system, or the response or non-response of any
Village Affiliates to the alarm user's property.
   D.   Approval Of Permit: The community development department, department of
law enforcement services and department of fire and emergency medical services,
whichever is mandating the alarm, may approve such application if it is found
that:
      1.   The use of the alarm system will not interfere with the orderly
conduct of village business.
      2.   The alarm equipment supplier installing the system maintains a
service organization capable of promptly and effectively repairing, maintaining
and otherwise servicing the alarm sold or leased by the supplier.
      3.   All installations shall comply with the village electrical code 1 .
      4.   For fire alarm systems, the most current National Fire Protection
Association (NFPA) standard for the installation, maintenance and testing of
fire alarm systems shall be followed.
Notwithstanding the above, the department of law enforcement services and the
department of fire and emergency medical services may impose reasonable
conditions on the issuance and exercise of permits relating to the ability of
the department of law enforcement services/department of fire and emergency
medical services to respond to such alarms based upon the location of the alarm
system and access thereto.
   E.   Exemptions: No permit shall be required for any alarm system legally in
place and legally operational at the date of passage of this chapter, November
22, 1993. However, any substantial modification or repair to an existing system
or equipment shall require the alarm user to apply for a permit and comply with
provisions of this chapter and follow the most current National Fire Protection
Association (NFPA) standard for the installation, maintenance and testing of
fire alarm systems. Substantial modification or repair shall be determined by
the community development department in conjunction with the department of law
enforcement services and department of fire and emergency medical services, if
needed.
   F.   Approval Of Certificates For Wireless Alarm Systems Not Connected To
The Village: The department of law enforcement services may approve such
application if it is found that:
      1.   The use of the alarm system will not interfere with the orderly
conduct of village business.
      2.   The alarm equipment supplier installing the system maintains a
service organization capable of promptly and effectively repairing, maintaining
and otherwise servicing the alarm sold or leased by the supplier.
      3.   The alarm equipment supplier installing the alarm system shall
verify to the village that the system and installation conforms to the
applicable village code provisions and the most current National Fire
Protection Association (NFPA) standard for the installation, maintenance and
testing of wireless fire alarm systems.
      4.   The approval of the application does not constitute that a system
inspection has been conducted by either the department of law enforcement
services or department of fire and emergency medical services. (Ord. 12-2690,
8-27-2012)
 
Notes
1 1. See title 9, chapter 3 of this code.
6-4-3: INSPECTION:
   A.   General: The community development department and/or the department of
fire and emergency medical services, whichever applies based on the statutory
requirements for the system shall have the right to inspect any alarm system
installed pursuant to this chapter, both prior to and subsequent to the
issuance of a permit, at any reasonable time to determine whether a permit
should be issued, or if issued, whether the alarm system is being used in
conformity with the terms of the permit and the provisions of this chapter.
   B.   Wireless Alarm Systems: In general, there will not be a village
inspection of the installation of a wireless alarm system that is not mandated
by code. However, the community development department and/or the department of
fire and emergency medical services, whichever applies based on the statutory
requirements for the system, will have the right but not the obligation to
inspect any such wireless alarm system installed pursuant to this chapter, both
prior to and subsequent to the issuance of a certificate of registration, at
any reasonable time, to determine whether a certificate should be issued, or,
if issued, whether the alarm system is being used in conformity with the terms
of the certificate and the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 12-2690, 8-27-
2012)
6-4-4: ALARM SYSTEMS ANNUAL PERMIT FEE:
Each holder of a permit for a direct connect alarm system only shall pay to the
village, on or before April 1 of each year, a service fee in the amount of
twenty five dollars ($25.00). (Ord. 12-2690, 8-27-2012)
6-4-5: REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION OF PERMIT:
The department of law enforcement services and department of fire and emergency
medical services may revoke or suspend any permit issued pursuant to the
provisions of this chapter, and may cause an alarm user, where permit is
revoked or suspended, to be disconnected from the authorized alarm panel
located in the department of law enforcement services communications center,
after giving written notice to the permit holder and an opportunity for the
permit holder to be heard, upon a determination that the alarm system covered
by the permit has been installed, maintained or operated in violation of any of
the provisions of this chapter or of any term or condition of the permit, or
for failure to pay any applicable service fee or charge. (Ord. 12-2690, 8-27-
2012)
6-4-6: FALSE ALARM SERVICE CHARGE:
An alarm user shall be assessed a service charge for each "false alarm" as
defined in section
6-4-1 of this chapter in excess of one per billing quarter. An alarm owner
shall be assessed a service charge of fifty dollars ($50.00) for an illegal
entry false alarm, one hundred dollars ($100.00) for a residential fire false
alarm, and two hundred dollars ($200.00) for a commercial fire false alarm.
Such service charge shall be remitted to the village by the alarm user upon
receipt of a statement for such service charge. The director of law enforcement
services or the director of fire and emergency medical services, whichever
applies, shall be granted the ability to waive any and all charges if he deems
it necessary or in the best interests of the village. (Ord. 12-2690, 8-27-2012)
6-4-7: LIABILITY OF VILLAGE LIMITED:
The village assumes no liability for any defects in the operation of an alarm
system because of the failure or neglect of any person associated with the
installation, operation or maintenance of the alarm system, or for the
transmission of alarm signals or the relaying of such signals and messages.
(Ord. 12-2690, 8-27-2012)
6-4-8: PENALTIES:
Any person who violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be subject
to a fine of not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each
violation for each day that the violation continues, and each day that the
violation continues shall be deemed a separate offense subject to a separate
penalty. Such a fine shall be in addition to any other fee or charge authorized
pursuant to the terms of this chapter. (Ord. 14-2767, 10-27-2014)
CHAPTER 5
MINORS
SECTION:
6-5-1: Possession Or Sale Of Tobacco Products (Minors)
6-5-2: Parental Responsibility
6-5-1: POSSESSION OR SALE OF TOBACCO PRODUCTS (MINORS):
   A.   Definitions:
ALTERNATIVE NICOTINE PRODUCT: Means a product or device not consisting of or
containing tobacco that provides for the ingestion into the body of nicotine,
whether by chewing, smoking, absorbing, dissolving, inhaling, snorting,
sniffing, or by any other means and includes, but is not limited to, e-
cigarettes. Alternative nicotine product excludes cigarettes, smokeless
tobacco, or other tobacco products as these terms are defined in section 1 of
the Prevention of Tobacco Use by Minors and Sale and Distribution of Tobacco
Products Act 1  and any product approved by the United States Food and Drug
Administration as a non-tobacco product for sale as a tobacco cessation
product, as a tobacco dependence product, or for other medical purposes, and is
being marketed and sold solely for that approved purpose.
E-CIGARETTE: Means a device, usually battery-powered, that heats nicotine,
releasing a nicotine vapor that can be inhaled by the user of the device. Not
by way of limitation, the term "e-cigarette" includes e-cigar, e-cigarillo, e-
pipe, e-hookah, or any other device that heats nicotine, releasing a nicotine
vapor that can be inhaled by the user of the device.
TOBACCO PRODUCTS: Means any substance containing tobacco leaf, including, but
not limited to, cigarettes, cigars, pipe tobacco, snuff, chewing tobacco or
dipping tobacco. The term "tobacco products" also includes "e-cigarette" even
if certain e-cigarettes do not contain any tobacco. (Ord. 18-2930, 8-20-2018)
   B.   Prohibitions:
      1.   Sale Of Tobacco To Minor: No person in this Village shall sell, buy
or furnish any cigar, cigarette, e-cigarette, alternative nicotine product or
tobacco in any of its forms, to any minor under twenty one (21) years of age.
      2.   Possession Of Tobacco By Minor: It shall be unlawful for any person
under the age of twenty one (21) years to possess any tobacco products or
alternative nicotine products including, but not limited to, e-cigarettes,
provided, that the possession by a person under the age of twenty one (21)
years under the direct supervision of the parent or guardian of such person in
the privacy of the parent's or guardian's home shall not be prohibited. It
shall be unlawful for any person under the age of twenty one (21) years to
misrepresent his identity or age, or to use any false or altered identification
for the purpose of purchasing tobacco products or alternative nicotine products
including, but not limited to, e-cigarettes.
      3.   Purchase By Minors: It shall be unlawful for any person under the
age of twenty one (21) years to purchase tobacco products or alternative
nicotine products including, but not limited to, e-cigarettes, or to
misrepresent his identity or age, or use any false or altered identification
for the purpose of purchasing tobacco products or alternative nicotine products
including, but not limited to, e-cigarettes.
      4.   Certain Free Distributions: It shall be unlawful for any licensee or
any person in the business of selling or otherwise distributing, promoting or
advertising tobacco products, or any employee or agent of any such licensee or
person, in the course of such licensee's or person's business to distribute,
give away or deliver tobacco products or alternative nicotine products
including, but not limited to, e-cigarettes free of charge to any person on any
right-of-way, park, playground or other property owned by the Village, any
school district or any park district.
   C.   Signs Posted: Signs informing the public of the age restrictions
provided for herein shall be posted by every licensee at or near every display
of tobacco products or on or upon every vending machine which offers tobacco
products for sale. Each such sign shall be plainly visible and shall state:
THE SALE OF TOBACCO PRODUCTS TO PERSONS UNDER TWENTY-ONE YEARS OF AGE IS
PROHIBITED BY LAW
(Ord. 19-2958, 6-24-2019)
   D.   Penalty: In addition to any other penalty provided for in this Code,
including section
3-9-11 of this Code, whoever violates any provision of this section shall be
fined an amount not to exceed seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each
offense. Each day such violation shall continue shall constitute a separate
offense. (Ord. 18-2930, 8-20-2018)
 
Notes
1 1. 720 ILCS 675/1 et seq.
6-5-2: PARENTAL RESPONSIBILITY:
   A.   Definitions: As used in this Code, unless the context otherwise
requires, the terms specified have the meanings ascribed to them as follows:
LEGAL GUARDIAN: A person appointed guardian or given custody of a minor by a
Circuit Court of the State but does not include a person appointed guardian or
given custody of a minor under the Juvenile Court Act.
MINOR: A person who has not yet reached eighteen (18) years of age. (1978 Code
§ 7-3-12; amd. Ord. 02-2201, 7-15-2002)
   B.   Failure To Exercise Proper Parental Responsibility: The parent or legal
guardian of an unemancipated minor residing with such parent or legal guardian
shall be presumed, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, to have failed
to exercise proper parental responsibility and said minor shall be deemed to
have committed the acts described below with the knowledge and permission of
the parent or guardian, in violation of this Code, upon the occurrence of the
events described below:
      1.   An unemancipated minor residing with said parent or legal guardian
shall either be adjudicated to be in violation of any ordinance, law or statute
prohibiting wilful and malicious acts causing injury to a person or property,
or shall have incurred nonjudicial sanctions from another official agency
resulting from an admission of guilt of violation of any ordinance, law or
statute prohibiting wilful and malicious acts causing injury to a person or
property; and (1978 Code § 7-3-12)
      2.   Said parent or legal guardian shall have received a written notice
thereof, either by certified or registered mail, return receipt requested, or
by personal service, with a certificate of personal service returned, from the
Department of Law Enforcement Services following said adjudication or
nonjudicial sanction; and (1978 Code § 7-3-12; amd. 1997 Code)
      3.   If at any time within one year following receipt of the notice set
forth above, said minor is either adjudicated to be in violation of any
ordinance, law or statute as described above, or shall have incurred
nonjudicial sanctions from another official agency resulting from an admission
of guilt of violation of any ordinance, law or statute as described above.
(1978 Code § 7-3-12)
CHAPTER 6
LASER POINTERS
SECTION:
6-6-1: Possession By Underage Persons Prohibited
6-6-2: Aiding Or Assisting Underage Person In Obtaining Prohibited
6-6-3: Liability Of Parent Or Legal Guardian
6-6-4: Penalties
6-6-1: POSSESSION BY UNDERAGE PERSONS PROHIBITED:
   A.   No person under the age of eighteen (18) shall possess within the
Village any laser pointers of the following type:
      1.   A Helium Neon (HeNe) laser which typically operates at a wavelength
of 632.8nMe with the mandated power limit of 5mW of power. Said lasers are
considered Class 2 lasers with the potential for eye injury; and
      2.   A diode laser which typically operates at a wavelength of 670nMe
(although others are possible) with a power source providing 5mW. Said lasers
are considered Class 3A lasers, with the potential for eye injury.
      3.   Any other type of laser which has the potential for eye injury.
   B.   This prohibition shall not apply to:
      1.   A child using such a laser pointer while under the immediate
supervision of his or her parent or legal guardian;
      2.   A student using such a laser pointer while under the immediate
supervision of his or her teacher;
      3.   An employee using such a laser pointer at the direction and under
the supervision of his or her employer. (Ord. 99-2078, 3-22-1999)
6-6-2: AIDING OR ASSISTING UNDERAGE PERSON IN OBTAINING PROHIBITED:
No person shall aid, assist or abet a person under the age of eighteen (18) in
obtaining possession of laser pointers, as defined herein. This prohibition
shall not apply to:
   A.   A parent or legal guardian assisting and supervising his or her own
child or ward in the use of such laser pointers;
   B.   A teacher assisting and supervising his or her student in the use of
such laser pointers;
   C.   An employer assisting and supervising his or her employee in the use of
such laser pointers. (Ord. 99-2078, 3-22-1999)
6-6-3: LIABILITY OF PARENT OR LEGAL GUARDIAN:
The parent or legal guardian of an unemancipated minor who resides with such
parent or legal guardian shall be subject to those penalties enumerated in
subsection
6-5-2 of this Title. (Ord. 99-2078, 3-22-1999)
6-6-4: PENALTIES:
Any person found guilty of an offense of this Chapter shall be subject to the
penalty set forth in Section
1-4-1 of this Code. (Ord. 99-2078, 3-22-1999)
CHAPTER 7
RULES OF CONDUCT FOR VILLAGE BUILDINGS AND VILLAGE LAND
SECTION:
6-7-1: Rules Of Conduct
6-7-1: RULES OF CONDUCT:
No person shall:
   A.   Intentionally or wilfully annoy, harass, threaten, throw objects, use
profane or obscene language against another person, whether physical, verbal or
nonverbal, that is "intense" or made with intent to imminently commit an
assault, or use any threats that continue to be made after intervention by
village personnel, including disorderly, loud or boisterous behavior.
   B.   Damage or deface public property.
   C.   Improperly remove village property.
   D.   Loiter in any village building, lobby or front of any village building,
or on any village property in an unreasonable manner that alarms or disturbs
others or provokes a breach of the peace.
   E.   Enter or remain in any village building without wearing shoes and a
shirt.
   F.   Pander or beg in any village building, lobby or front of any village
building, or on any village property. Solicitation activity in accordance with
regulations of this code is permitted.
   G.   Engage in loud or boisterous conduct.
   H.   Unlawfully use, possess or sell alcoholic liquors or controlled
substances as defined by 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 570/102.
   I.   Be in a state of noticeable intoxication, or in possession of
intoxicants (unless the intoxicants have not been opened and are in their
original sealed packaging or a wine bottle that has been sealed in accordance
with state liquor law).
   J.   Utter profane, obscene or injurious language directed at another
person.
   K.   Remain in any village building or on village property after regular
closing hours, except with the approval of the village manager.
   L.   Move furniture or fixtures from their original placement without
village approval.
   M.   Obstruct in any manner any public street, public highway, public
sidewalk, or any other public place or building by hindering or impeding, or
tending to hinder or impede, the free and uninterrupted passage of vehicles,
traffic or pedestrians, except for police, law enforcement, fire or other
authorized village or government personnel to protect the health, safety and
welfare of the public or for a public purpose.
   N.   Interfere with the free access or passage of any person to or from or
within any village building or any village property, including blocking the
entrance or exit of any village building or any village property with their
person, except for police, law enforcement, fire or other authorized village or
government personnel to protect the health, safety and welfare of the public or
for a public purpose.
   O.   Obstruct or interfere in any manner with the free and uninterrupted use
of property or with any business lawfully conducted by anyone in or upon or
facing or fronting on any public street, public highway, public sidewalk or any
other public place or building, all of which prevents the free and
uninterrupted ingress, egress and regress therein, thereon and thereto, except
for police, law enforcement, fire or other authorized village or government
personnel to protect the health, safety and welfare of the public or for a
public purpose.
   P.   Possess or display any weapon or firearm or any object that can be
construed to be a weapon or firearm or any other instrument that can be used as
a weapon in any village building or on any village property, unless the
possession and display of the weapon or firearm is in accordance with
applicable state law.
   Q.   Bring more than two (2) bags of personal belongings per person into any
village building or on any village property.
   R.   Commit indecent exposure as defined by 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes
5/11-30.
   S.   Deposit garbage and trash in any village building or on any village
property, except in a trash receptacle.
   T.   Listen to an electronic device, in any village building, that is
audible within five feet (5') without the use of earphones.
   U.   Fight, including verbal altercations, in any village building or on
village property.
   V.   Use a bathroom in a nonhygienic or irresponsible manner that would have
a negative effect or impact on subsequent users.
   W.   Do any act, harass, disrupt, interfere with or obstruct in any manner
any village, public or governmental business or function being conducted within
any village building or on any village land.
   X.   Refuse to depart from the premises or grounds of any building owned,
operated or used by any unit of local government including, but not limited to,
schools, libraries, the park district or the village, if requested to leave,
either orally or in writing, by a government staff member, police officer or
other appropriate public official when the continued presence of the person
presents a risk of injury or damage to or endangers the safety of the building
or its occupants or unreasonably interferes with the administration thereof.
   Y.   Refuse to depart from any village building or any village land, if
requested to leave, either orally or in writing, by a village staff member,
police officer or other appropriate village official due to a violation of
these rules or any other law or ordinance of the village.
   Z.   Violate any law or ordinance of the village. (Ord. 12-2666, 3-26-2012)
TITLE 7
MOTOR VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC
CHAPTER 1
TRAFFIC CODE; GENERAL TRAFFIC PROVISIONS
SECTION:
7-1-1: Illinois Vehicle Code Adopted By Reference
7-1-2: Traffic Signs And Signals
7-1-3: Disregarding A Traffic Control Device
7-1-4: Private Regulation Of Traffic And On-Street Parking On Certain Private
Streets And On-Street Parking
7-1-1: ILLINOIS VEHICLE CODE ADOPTED BY REFERENCE:
Except insofar as the application thereof is clearly impractical or
inappropriate, in view of the context of purposes or penalty as provided, all
of the definitions, requirements, regulations, prohibitions, provisions and
sections of the Illinois vehicle code 1 , as amended, are hereby adopted by the
village. Any and all violations thereof shall be considered violations of this
title, and each such violation shall subject the violator thereof to penalty
provisions under this title if proceeded hereunder. (1997 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. 625 ILCS 5/1-100 et seq.
7-1-2: TRAFFIC SIGNS AND SIGNALS:
   A.   Unauthorized Signs: No person shall place, maintain or display upon or
in view of any street any unauthorized sign, signal, marking, light, reflector
or device which purports to be or is an imitation of or resembles an official
traffic control device or railroad sign or signal, or which attempts to direct
the movement of traffic, nor shall any person place, maintain or display upon
or in view of any street any other sign which hides from view or interferes
with the movement of traffic or effectiveness of any traffic control device or
any railroad sign or signal, and no person shall place or maintain nor shall
any public authority permit upon any highway any traffic sign or signal bearing
thereon any commercial advertising. No fence, tree, bush or foliage of any kind
shall be so placed, maintained, allowed to remain or displayed upon either
public or private property in such a manner as to hide from view or interfere
with the movement of traffic or the effectiveness of any traffic control
devices, signs or signals. All such obstructions or unauthorized devices are
hereby declared to be nuisances and may be removed by any police officer or a
person acting under his direction and supervision. (1978 Code § 9-1-7; amd.
1997 Code)
   B.   Interference With Signs Or Signals: It shall be unlawful for any person
to deface, injure, move or interfere with any official traffic sign or signal.
(1978 Code § 9-1-8)
   C.   Advertising Signs:
      1.   Imitation Of Traffic Signs: It shall be unlawful to maintain
anywhere in the village any sign, signal, marking or device, other than a
traffic sign or signal authorized by the village board or the Illinois state
department of public works and buildings, which purports to be or is an
imitation of or resembles an official traffic control device or railroad sign
or signal, in view of any street or highway, and it shall be unlawful to place
or maintain any sign which hides from view any lawful traffic control device.
      2.   Flashing Signs: It shall be unlawful to maintain or operate in view
of any street or highway any flashing or rotating beacon or light. (1978 Code §
9-1-9)
7-1-3: DISREGARDING A TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICE:
It shall be a violation of this section for a vehicle to disregard a traffic
control device or a no turn on red signal. For purposes of this section,
"disregarding a traffic control device" shall mean a failure to stop and remain
stopped before an intersection that is controlled by a red signal as provided
for in section 11-306 of the Illinois vehicle code. For purposes of this
section, "disregarding a no turn on red signal" shall mean a failure to stop
and remain stopped, and to refrain from proceeding to turn right at, an
intersection controlled by a sign indicating "no turn on red" or other similar
language or signal, at a red signal as provided for in section 11-306 of the
Illinois vehicle code. Violations of this section captured by an "automated
traffic law enforcement system", as defined in section
7-5-2 of this title, may be prosecuted under the village's administrative
adjudication of vehicle regulation violations program pursuant to chapter 5 of
this title. (Ord. 08-2493, 5-12-2008)
7-1-4: PRIVATE REGULATION OF TRAFFIC AND ON-STREET PARKING ON CERTAIN PRIVATE
STREETS AND ON-STREET PARKING:
Timber Trails Subdivision: The corporate authorities of the Village have
authorized the posting and enforcement of traffic regulation and on-street
parking signs that regulate and control motor vehicle traffic and the use of
on-street motor vehicle parking areas on and within the roadways and on-street
motor vehicle parking areas within the Timber Trails Subdivision, which are
owned and/or controlled by the Timber Trails Development Company, LLC pursuant
to this section.
   A.   Timber Trails Subdivision Traffic And Parking Enforcement Agreement: A
copy of the agreement by and between the Village Of Western Springs and Timber
Trails Development Company, LLC, regarding snowplowing and salting services and
the enforcement of posted motor vehicle traffic and on-street parking
regulation signs for the private roadways in the timber trails subdivision is
incorporated by reference into this Section
7-1-4, is on file with the Village Clerk's Office and is also posted on the
Village's website at www.wsprings.com.
   B.   Traffic And Parking Regulation Inventory: A copy of the traffic and
parking signage and street markings regulation inventory for timber trails
subdivision indicating the location of pavement markings and traffic and
parking regulation signs in regard to the traffic and on-street motor vehicle
parking regulations is incorporated by reference into this Section
7-1-4, is on file with the Village Clerk's Office and is also posted on the
Village's website at www.wsprings.com. A copy of the traffic and parking
signage and street markings regulation inventory for timber trails subdivision
is attached to the traffic and parking regulation enforcement agreement as
Exhibit "A" and made a part thereof.
   C.   Continuation Of Enforcement After Acceptance of Roadways: The traffic
and on-street parking signs and regulations shall automatically continue and be
enforced after acceptance of title and ownership of the private roadways and
on-street parking areas by the Village in accordance with the terms of the 2005
Annexation Agreement for the Timber Trails Subdivision. (Ord. 20-2995, 1-27-
2020)
CHAPTER 2
VEHICLE LICENSES
SECTION:
7-2-1:    License Required; Eligibility If Debt Owed To Village
7-2-2: License Application; Issuance
7-2-3: License Fees; Terms; Revenues
7-2-4: License Emblems; Motorcycles, Trailers, Semitrailers
7-2-5: License Emblems; Motor Vehicles
7-2-6: Sale Of Vehicles
7-2-7: Loss Of License Emblem
7-2-8: Scope Of Chapter
7-2-9: Antique Vehicle Registration
7-2-10: Failure To Purchase; Delinquency Penalty
7-2-11: Senior Citizen Discount
7-2-12: Penalty
7-2-1: LICENSE REQUIRED; ELIGIBILITY IF DEBT OWED TO VILLAGE:
   A.   Owner To Be Licensed: It shall be unlawful for any resident of the
Village to own a motor vehicle (registered to a resident at an address in the
Village), or for any person to use a motor vehicle owned by a resident of the
Village, within the Village, unless the owner of such vehicle is licensed for
the current year by the Village to use the same, and said license is displayed
on the windshield of the motor vehicle. If an application for a state vehicle
registration represents, or a state vehicle registration database identifies,
that the owner of the vehicle resides within the corporate boundaries of the
Village, that shall be deemed to be proof of these facts for the purposes of
this Section.
   B.   Vehicle To Be Licensed: It shall also be unlawful for any motor vehicle
which has its situs or base within the Village (a motor vehicle leased by a
resident of the Village and used by the resident and garaged at the resident's
home or a company car, leased or owned by a company with its principal place of
business located outside of the Village, and used by a resident-employee and
garaged within the Village) unless such motor vehicle is licensed by the
Village or by the municipality from which any such vehicle is registered, for
use for the current year and said license is displayed on the windshield of the
motor vehicle. If an application for a state vehicle registration represents or
a state vehicle registration database identifies that the vehicle has a situs
within the corporate boundaries of the Village, that shall be deemed to be
proof of these facts for the purposes of this Section.
   C.   Definitions: For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms
shall have the following meanings:
   COMMERCIAL VEHICLE: Motor trucks, tractors, trailers and motor buses,
whether or not actually used for commercial purposes, and all motor vehicles
used for public hire.
   MOTOR BUSES: All vehicles used or designed for use for carriage of more than
seven (7) persons.
   MOTOR TRUCKS: All motor vehicles, including tractor trucks, used or designed
to be used to carry goods.
   MOTOR VEHICLE: Every self-propelled device in, upon or by which any person
or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a street, except devices
moved by human power or used exclusively on stationary rails or tracks.
   PERSON: Any individual, entity, firm, proprietorship, partnership,
association, corporation or organization of any kind.
   PLEASURE VEHICLES: All motor vehicles used or designed to be used to carry
not more than seven (7) passengers, and all recreational vehicles, excepting
motor bicycles, tricycles and commercial vehicles.
   RESIDENT OF THE VILLAGE: A corporation or any business entity whatsoever
having its principal place of business in the Village.
   SITUS OR BASE: When applied to a person, the place where that person or
business is principally located and, when applied to a motor vehicle, the place
where that motor vehicle is principally garaged, or from whence it is
principally dispatched, or where its movements usually originate.
   TRAILER: Includes every vehicle without motor power designed to carry
passengers or property and to be drawn by a motor vehicle.
   VEHICLE: Includes every device in, upon or by which any person or property
is or may be drawn upon a street except devices moved by human power or used
exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks.
   D.   Exemption:
      1.   A license shall not be required and imposed upon any person who
satisfies the following criteria:
         a.   The person is a full time, active member of the United States
armed services;
         b.   The person maintains his or her permanent residence (and
domicile) in a municipality and/or state other than the Village;
         c.   But for his or her service in the United States armed services,
the person would not reside in the Village;
         d.   The person uses his or her residence within the Village as a home
base as a result of his or her present military assignment in the Chicagoland
area, not a domicile; and
         e.   The person must provide proof of full time, active service in one
of the United States armed services.
      2.   A person who is a member of any of the United States military
reserves or the United States National Guard shall not be entitled to this
exemption.
   E.   Eligibility If Debt Owed To Village: See the provisions of Section
3-1-1 A of this Code, which are incorporated by reference into this Chapter and
are applicable to the licenses and permits covered by this Chapter. (Ord. 99-
2073, 2-22-1999; amd. Ord. 19-2982, 11-25-2019)
7-2-2: LICENSE APPLICATION; ISSUANCE:
   A.   Contents Of Application: All persons who are required to have a license
for a vehicle shall file with the Finance Department, upon a form provided by
said department, an application setting forth:
      1.   The name, residence and mailing address of the owner.
      2.   A description of the vehicle, including its make, identifying number
and type of body.
      3.   Such other information as may be required. (Ord. 83-1655, 10-24-
1983)
   B.   Issuance Of License: The Finance Department, upon the payment to said
department of a license fee hereinafter provided, shall issue a vehicle
license. Each issued license shall be valid for the time period of May 1 to
April 30 of the next calendar year.
   C.   Denial Of License: The Finance Department may refuse issuance of a
vehicle license if any required fee is not paid or if the department has
reasonable grounds to believe that:
      1.   The application contains a false or fraudulent statement; or
      2.   The application fails to furnish required information or documents
or any additional information that is reasonably required to comply with this
section. (Ord. 83-1655, 10-24-1983; amd. 1997 Code; Ord. 19-2982, 11-25-2019)
7-2-3: LICENSE FEES; TERMS; REVENUES:
   A.   Annual License Fees: The license fees to be paid annually to the
Village, effective February 1, 2017, shall be as follows:
