   B.   Expiration Of License: All licenses shall expire on April 30 for each
year following the date of issue. Where a license is issued prior to November
1, the full annual fee specified in this chapter shall be paid. Where a license
is issued on or after November 1, the fee to be paid shall be a sum equal to
one-half (1/2) of the annual license fee specified in this chapter. Except for
new residents, a person who has failed to purchase annual vehicle tags and
attempts to do so after November 1 of any year will be required to pay the full
annual fee, plus the late registration fee.
   C.   Administrative Grace Period: The Village Manager shall waive the
license fees specified in this chapter in total for any resident who moves out
of the Village by May 30 of any license year. Any resident seeking such a
waiver must submit a written request addressed to the Village Manager stating
the following:
      1.   The resident's current address in the Village.
      2.   That the resident has sold their property or that their lease on a
property in the Village has expired.
      3.   The date before May 30 on which the resident will move or has moved
from the Village.
   D.   Refunding Of License Fee Due To Move: If a resident moves from the
Village after May 30, but before July 31, a partial refund of the license fees
specified in this chapter equal to one-half (1/2) of the annual license fee is
available if applied for by the resident at the time that the residential water
and sewer utility account is closed. The resident requesting the refund must
have paid the full license fees as specified in this section prior to April 30
and shall not owe any other debts or obligations to the Village in order to
qualify for the refund.
   E.   Use Of Revenues: All revenues derived from such licenses and transfer
fees, after deducting the actual cost of collection and disbursement thereof,
shall be used for purposes of improving, paving, repairing or maintaining the
streets and other public roadways within the Village, and such revenues, but
not to exceed thirty five percent (35%) of such revenues, may also be used for
the payment of salaries and wages of police officers engaged in the duty of
regulating traffic within the Village. The allocation of such revenues shall be
made in the manner provided for in the annual budget or in such other manner as
the Village Board may direct from time to time. (Ord. 15-2818, 11-23-2015)
7-2-4: LICENSE EMBLEMS; MOTORCYCLES, TRAILERS, SEMITRAILERS:
   A.   Issuance Of License Sticker: Upon the issuance of such license for a
motor bicycle, motor tricycle, trailers or semitrailers, the Finance Department
shall deliver to the applicant therefor a decalcomania sticker license emblem
bearing the words "Western Springs", a serial number, the name of the group or
class to which such vehicle belongs, and the year for which such license is
issued. (Ord. 83-1655, 10-24-1983; amd. 1997 Code)
   B.   Placement Of Sticker: The holder of a license for a motor bicycle,
motor tricycle, trailer or semitrailer shall affix such emblem in a conspicuous
position upon the front of such motor bicycle or motor tricycle, free from an
obstruction to the view of such emblem, and upon the rear end of such trailer
or semitrailer, so that the emblem can be easily seen.
   C.   Unlawful Removal Of Sticker: Any person who shall take or remove any
such license tag or emblem from any vehicle without the consent of the owner of
the vehicle shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction
thereof, shall be fined in accordance with the provisions of this Code for each
offense. Every wrongful removal of a license tag or emblem from any vehicle
shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 83-1655, 10-24-1983)
7-2-5: LICENSE EMBLEMS; MOTOR VEHICLES:
   A.   Issuance And Placement Of Emblem: Upon issuance of such license for any
motor vehicle, except a motorcycle, the Finance Department shall deliver to the
licensee a decalcomania sticker license emblem, bearing the numerals
designating the year for which said license is issued, the designation of the
group or class to which such vehicle belongs, a serial number in figures, and
the words "Western Springs". The licensee shall affix the same in the lower
right-hand corner on the inside of the glass part of the windshield of such
motor vehicle not later than one minute after twelve o'clock (12:01) A.M.,
April 30 of each year. (Ord. 17-2865, 1-23-2017)
   B.   Emblem Specifications: The Finance Department shall change, annually,
the predominant background color of such sticker emblem. Said sticker emblem
shall be impervious to weather and not removable from the windshield without
destruction or mutilation. (Ord. 83-1655, 10-24-1983; amd. 1997 Code)
   C.   Unlawful Removal Of Emblem: Any person who shall remove, obliterate or
destroy the sticker emblem affixed to any vehicle without the consent of the
owner of such vehicle shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. Every such
wrongful removal, obliteration or destruction of such sticker emblem from any
vehicle shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 83-1655, 10-24-1983)
7-2-6: SALE OF VEHICLES:
   A.   Notice Of Sale To Village: Immediately upon the sale of any vehicle
licensed under this chapter, when such sale is made prior to the date of
expiration of such license, the owner shall remove the license emblem from the
vehicle so sold, and within three (3) days after the date of such sale, the
owner shall give to the Finance Department a written notification of such sale
showing the date thereof, the license number of the vehicle so sold and the
name and address or place of business of the purchaser; thereupon such license
emblem shall cease to apply to the vehicle so sold.
   B.   Transfer Of License; Fee:
      1.   Whenever the owner of any vehicle licensed under this chapter,
before the expiration of such license, sells or otherwise disposes of such
vehicle, and acquires another vehicle and desires to transfer the original
license to the newly acquired vehicle and notifies the Finance Department of
the sale as hereinabove provided, such owner shall make application to the
Finance Department for such transfer. The application shall be in compliance
with section
7-2-2 of this chapter.
      2.   Upon surrender of the original license emblem (or upon filing with
the Finance Department satisfactory proof that the emblem has been lost or
destroyed), and upon payment of the appropriate fee, the Finance Department
shall transfer such license to apply to the newly acquired vehicle. (Ord. 83-
1655, 10-24-1983; amd. 1997 Code)
      3.   The transfer fee shall be three dollars ($3.00); provided, that if
the newly acquired vehicle is of a class requiring a higher license fee than
was paid for the original license, the transfer fee shall be the amount of
difference between the fee paid for the original license and the license fee
fixed for the newly acquired vehicle, plus the sum of three dollars ($3.00).
(Ord. 90-1812, 12-17-1990)
7-2-7: LOSS OF LICENSE EMBLEM:
In case of the loss or destruction, total or partial, of any license emblem
issued by the Village and covering any vehicle, the owner of such vehicle,
within three (3) days after learning thereof, shall give the Finance Department
written notification of such loss or destruction. Upon surrender to the Finance
Department of such portion of the license emblem as is sufficient to identify
the same (or, if such surrender is impossible), upon filing with the Finance
Department satisfactory proof of loss, and the payment of a fee of two dollars
($2.00), the Finance Department shall issue to said owner a duplicate of such
license emblem. (Ord. 83-1655, 10-24-1983)
7-2-8: SCOPE OF CHAPTER:
Nothing contained in this chapter shall be construed as in any manner repealing
any provisions of this Code relating to any particular business now being
licensed by the Village in which vehicles are being used upon the streets or
alleys of the Village for the purpose of such business. (Ord. 83-1655, 10-24-
1983)
7-2-9: ANTIQUE VEHICLE REGISTRATION:
The owner of an antique vehicle shall register such vehicle for a fee in an
amount and for a term stated in subsection
7-2-3A of this chapter, if the owner drives or intends on driving the vehicle
on any street or highway, excluding any such vehicle owned by the Village. The
application for registration must be accompanied by an affidavit of the owner
that such vehicle will be driven on the highway only for the purpose of going
to and returning from an antique auto show or an exhibition, or for servicing
or demonstration, and such affidavit shall also affirm that the mechanical
condition, physical condition, brakes, lights, glass and appearance of such
vehicle is the same or as safe as originally equipped. The Village Finance
Department may, at its discretion, prescribe that antique vehicle plates be
issued for an indefinite term, such to correspond to the term of Wheel Tax
licenses issued generally as provided in this title. (Ord. 10-2573, 2-22-2010)
7-2-10: FAILURE TO PURCHASE; DELINQUENCY PENALTY:
   A.   Delinquency Penalties Established: Vehicle license fees not paid on or
before April 30 of each year for vehicles acquired on or before April 15 of
each year shall be deemed delinquent. Said fees shall be increased by a fifty
dollar ($50.00) penalty on May 1 and for the first thirty one (31) calendar day
period of delinquency thereafter, and the penalty shall be increased an
additional fifty dollars ($50.00) on June 1 and for the thirty (30) calendar
day period of delinquency thereafter, and on July 1 and for the period of
delinquency thereafter the penalty shall be increased an additional fifty
dollars ($50.00). The total delinquent penalties assessed during any single
license year extending from May 1 to April 30 shall not exceed one hundred
fifty dollars ($150.00), exclusive of the annual license fee. If the annual
license fee and the delinquent penalties are owed, the Village may collect
license fee(s) and delinquent penalties through any administrative or legal
process or may also issue a code citation and seek collection of the general
code penalty under section
1-4-1 for failure to comply with this Chapter.
   B.   Time Limit For Purchasing License: Fifteen (15) days shall be allowed
in which to purchase a license for a vehicle acquired after April 15 before the
delinquency penalty is applied. A current year vehicle license shall not be
sold for a vehicle which should have been properly licensed during the prior
year, except upon the purchase of the prior year's license and payment of all
delinquent fees due therefor.
   C.   Application To New Residents: New residents displaying a current, valid
sticker license emblem from another municipality shall not be required to
purchase a current Village license for the balance of the fiscal year or until
the expiration of the existing license, whichever is sooner.
   D.   Debt Owed To Village: No Village license or permit shall be issued
under this Code to a person who owes any fee, fine, payment, penalty or debt to
the Village, and no such person shall be allowed to register himself or herself
or any family members to participate in any Village programs and activities
(for example, recreation department programs), unless and until the outstanding
fee, fine, payment, penalty or debt is: (a) paid; or (b) being actively
contested in accordance with applicable Village policies or procedures; or (c)
discharged by action and authority of the corporate authorities or the Village
Manager in accordance with applicable Village policies or procedures. (Ord. 15-
2818, 11-23-2015; amd. Ord. 19-2982, 11-25-2019)
7-2-11: SENIOR CITIZEN DISCOUNT:
Beginning on January 1, 1999, any resident of the Village who is sixty five
(65) years of age or older, shall be entitled to a five dollar ($5.00) discount
off the annual license fee specified in this chapter each year. The resident
must apply for the discount to the Village's Finance Department by producing a
valid Illinois State driver's license proving age. (Ord. 98-2035, 4-27-1998)
7-2-12: PENALTY:
In addition to the delinquency penalties provided above in this Chapter, any
person found guilty of violating any of the provisions of this Chapter shall be
fined not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than seven hundred
fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. Each day in which a violation occurs
or continues shall constitute a separate offense. A person charged with
violating a provision of this Chapter may be issued a violation notice in lieu
of the Village filing a complaint in court against that person. The violation
notice shall be administratively adjudicated pursuant to Chapter 6 of this
title and the fines and penalties established therein. (Ord. 19-2982, 11-25-
2019)
CHAPTER 3
PARKING REGULATIONS
SECTION:
7-3-1: No-Parking Places
7-3-2: General Parking Restrictions And Prohibitions
7-3-3: Parking At Curb
7-3-4: Handicapped And Disabled Parking Restrictions
7-3-5: Dead Storage Of Passenger And Commercial Vehicles
7-3-6: Signs Posted
7-3-7: Prima Facie Proof, Violations
7-3-1: NO-PARKING PLACES:
   A.   Prohibited Places: It shall be unlawful to permit any vehicle to stop,
stand or park at any time in any of the following places, except when necessary
to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a
police officer or traffic-control device: (1978 Code §
9-5-1; amd. 1997 Code)
      1.   Within an intersection.
      2.   On a crosswalk.
      3.   Upon any bridge or viaduct, or in any subway or tunnel or the
approach thereto.
      4.   Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or within thirty feet
(30') of a point of the curb immediately opposite the end of a safety zone.
      5.   Within thirty feet (30') of a traffic signal, beacon or sign on the
approaching side.
      6.   Within twenty feet (20') of a crosswalk at an intersection.
      7.   At any place where the standing of a vehicle will reduce the usable
width of the roadway for moving traffic to less than eighteen feet (18').
      8.   Within fifteen feet (15') of a fire hydrant.
      9.   At any place where the vehicle would block the use of a driveway.
      10.   Within fifty feet (50') of the nearest rail of a railroad grade
crossing. (1978 Code §
9-5-1)
      11.   Within twenty feet (20') of the driveway entrance to any department
of fire and inspectional services station and on the side of the street
opposite the entrance to any such station within seventy five feet (75') of
such entrance when properly signposted. (1978 Code §
9-5-1; amd. 1997 Code)
      12.   On any sidewalk or parkway.
      13.   At any place where official signs prohibit parking.
      14.   On the roadway side of any vehicle stopped or parked at the edge or
curb of a street.
      15.   Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when
stopping, standing or parking would obstruct traffic.
      16.   On any railroad tracks.
   B.   Moving Of Vehicle: No person other than a police officer shall move a
vehicle not lawfully under his control into any such prohibited area or away
from a curb such distance as is unlawful. (1978 Code §
9-5-1)
7-3-2: GENERAL PARKING RESTRICTIONS AND PROHIBITIONS:
   A.   Street Cleaning; Snow Removal:
      1.   Street Cleaning: It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle on any
street or roadway, or portion thereof, in the village at any time when such
street or roadway is being cleaned. Whenever any police officer finds an
unattended motor vehicle violating the terms of this subsection A1, the officer
may provide for the removal of such vehicle to the nearest garage or place of
safety by having the vehicle towed, at the owner's expense, in accordance with
the provisions of chapter 9 of this title. Temporary signs indicating the date
and time when such cleaning shall be performed and that violators shall be
subject to towing at their expense shall be posted on the streets and roadways
at least twenty four (24) hours before such cleaning work is performed.
      2.   Snow Removal: It shall be unlawful to park any motor vehicle on any
street or roadway, or portion thereof, in the village for twelve (12) hours
after a snowfall of two (2) or more inches, as determined by the official
weather reading at Midway airport, has occurred, or until the snow has been
removed, provided that the snowfall has stopped. Whenever any police officer
finds an unattended vehicle violating the terms of this subsection A2, the
officer may provide for the removal of such vehicle to the nearest garage or
other place of safety by having the vehicle towed, at the owner's expense, in
accordance with the provisions of chapter 9 of this title. The following signs
shall be erected throughout the village at reasonable intervals to notify the
public of the provisions of this subsection A2:
NO PARKING ON ANY STREET OR ROADWAY FOR 12 HOURS AFTER A 2 INCH SNOWFALL, OR
UNTIL THE SNOW HAS BEEN REMOVED PROVIDED SNOWFALL HAS STOPPED.
MOTOR VEHICLES IN VIOLATION WILL BE TOWED AWAY AT THE OWNER'S EXPENSE.
      3.   Penalties: Any person convicted of violating any of the provisions
of this section shall be assessed a fine not to exceed seven hundred fifty
dollars ($750.00) and may be assessed such other fines, fees or costs, as are
authorized by chapter 9 of this title or state law. Each day such violation is
committed or permitted to continue shall constitute a separate violation and
shall be punishable as such hereunder. The registered owner of a vehicle towed
for a violation of this section may secure the release of the vehicle by
furnishing evidence of his or her identity and ownership or possessory right to
the vehicle, by signing a receipt for the vehicle and by paying or causing to
be paid to the village and/or the towing and impoundment service operator the
assessed fines and towing and impoundment fees.
   B.   Time Limit Parking: It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle for a
period of time in excess of the amount of time designated by ordinance and so
posted. (1978 Code § 9-5-3)
   C.   Vehicles For Sale; Peddling Merchandise From Vehicle: It shall be
unlawful to park any vehicle upon any street for the purpose of displaying it
for sale, or to park any vehicle upon any street from which vehicle merchandise
is peddled or sold. (1978 Code § 9-5-6)
   D.   Loading Zone: It shall be unlawful for the driver of a vehicle to stand
a passenger vehicle for a period of time longer than is necessary for the
loading or unloading of passengers in any place designated by the village board
as a loading zone and marked as such, or in any of the following designated
places:
Directly in front of the entrance to any theater at any time that the theater
is open. (1978 Code § 9-5-7)
   E.   All Night Parking: No person shall park any vehicle on any streets in
the village between the hours of three o'clock (3:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:
00) A.M. of any day, except physicians on emergency calls, or persons granted
permission by the department of law enforcement services. (1978 Code § 9-5-8;
amd. 1997 Code)
   F.   Alleys:
      1.   No person shall park a vehicle within an alley except for the
purpose of loading and unloading merchandise and then only under such
conditions as to leave available not less than ten feet (10') of the width of
the roadway for the free movement of vehicular traffic.
      2.   No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle within an alley in
such a position as to block the driveway entrance to any abutting property.
(1978 Code § 9-5-9)
   G.   Cab And Bus Stands: No vehicle other than a licensed taxicab shall be
parked in any area designated by ordinance as a cab stand, and no vehicle other
than a bus shall be parked in a place so designated as a bus loading zone.
(1978 Code § 9-5-10)
   H.   Parking Motor Vehicles On Private Property:
      1.   It shall be unlawful to park any motor vehicle on any private
property without the consent of the owner of the property.
      2.   No truck having a gross weight of eight thousand one (8,001) pounds
or more shall be parked on any driveway or open area of any lot in an R-1, R-2,
R-3 or A residential district except for a period no longer than is necessary
for the expeditious loading or unloading of such vehicle. (1978 Code § 9-5-11)
      3.   No truck having a gross weight of eight thousand one (8,001) pounds
or more shall be parked on any street or public way in an R-1, R-2, R-3 or A
residential district for more than four (4) consecutive hours, except in
connection with its use for current work being done on adjoining premises and
provided a permit therefor has been obtained for such extended parking in
advance from the department of law enforcement services. (1978 Code § 9-5-11;
amd. 1997 Code; Ord. 00-2157, 12-18-2000; Ord. 20-2994, 1-27-2020)
7-3-3: PARKING AT CURB:
   A.   Parallel And Angle Parking: No vehicle shall be parked with the left
side of such vehicle next to the curb, except on one- way streets, and it shall
be unlawful to stand or park any vehicle in a street other than parallel with
the curb and with the two (2) right wheels of the vehicle within twelve inches
(12") of the regularly established curb line; except that upon those streets
that have been marked for angle parking, vehicles shall be parked at the angle
to the curb indicated by such marks. (1978 Code § 9-5-5)
   B.   Occupying More Than One Parking Space 1 : Notwithstanding the
foregoing, no person shall park a vehicle in any space designated by markings
on the pavement in such a manner that any part of such vehicle occupies more
than one space or protrudes beyond the markings designating such space; except
that a vehicle which is of a size too large to be parked within a single
designated space may occupy two (2) or more adjoining spaces. (Ord. 90-1797, 5-
21-1990)
 
Notes
1 1. See also subsection 7-3A-3B of this chapter.
7-3-4: HANDICAPPED AND DISABLED PARKING RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   Parking Restricted: It shall be unlawful for any person to park a
vehicle in any area which is restricted to handicapped or disabled parking
unless such vehicle is occupied, when arriving in such area, or is intended to
be occupied when leaving such area, by at least one person who is physically
disabled within the definition of paragraph 5/1-159.1 of the vehicle code of
Illinois 1  or is physically handicapped so as to qualify for a handicapped
parking identification card issued by any township government within Cook
County. If the amount of fine for violating this section shall subsequently be
changed, the village shall change its handicapped parking signs to indicate the
current amount of the fine. (Ord. 06-2382, 2-27-2006)
   B.   Display Of Special Registration License Plate Or Handicapped
Identification Card:
      1.   If any vehicle parked in an area restricted to disabled and
handicapped parking displays special registration license plates issued for the
benefit of disabled veterans or physically handicapped persons by the state, or
any other state or territory of the United States, or displays upon the
driver's visor so as to be visible when the visor is in the down position, a
handicapped parking identification card issued by any township government
within Cook County, it may be presumed by any police officer that the vehicle
is lawfully parked in such restricted area.
      2.   However, such presumption may be overcome by a showing that such
vehicle was neither used to transport a disabled or handicapped person to such
restricted area nor intended to be used to transport such person from such
restricted area, in which case the person parking such vehicle shall be guilty
of a violation of subsection A of this section.
   C.   Improper Use Of Special Registration License Plates Or Handicapped
Parking Identification Card:
      1.   It shall be unlawful for any person to lend to another any special
registration license plate or handicapped parking identification card issued to
him or her if the person desiring to borrow the same would not be entitled to
use thereof, nor shall any person knowingly permit the use of any of the same
by one not entitled thereto, nor shall any person display upon any vehicle any
special registration license plate or handicapped parking identification card
not issued for such vehicle or not otherwise lawfully used thereon under this
section.
      2.   No person shall duplicate, alter or attempt to reproduce in any
manner a handicapped parking identification card issued by any township
government within Cook County and use the same or such card which has been so
duplicated, altered or reproduced by another, within the village.
      3.   Violation of this subsection C shall constitute a separate and
distinct violation from a violation of subsection A of this section. (Ord. 80-
1589, 11-17-1980)
   D.   Penalty: Any person who violates the provisions of subsection A of this
section or the provisions of subsection C of this section shall be subject to
penalty as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code for each violation. (Ord. 80-1589, 11-17-1980; amd. 1997
Code)
 
Notes
1 1. 625 ILCS.
7-3-5: DEAD STORAGE OF PASSENGER AND COMMERCIAL VEHICLES:
The outside dead storage of any inoperable, wrecked or abandoned motor vehicle,
or any motor vehicle not currently licensed by the state or other state or
country, and not either enclosed in a building or structure, or located on the
sales lot of a licensed automobile dealer, is prohibited in the village. This
section shall not apply to motor vehicles located on the premises of a licensed
garage or service station for repairs, and in the process of being repaired.
(Ord. 88-1762, 11-28-1988)
7-3-6: SIGNS POSTED:
Appropriate signs shall be posted in all areas where parking is limited or
prohibited indicating such limitations or prohibitions. (1978 Code § 9-5-12)
7-3-7: PRIMA FACIE PROOF, VIOLATIONS:
The fact that an automobile which is illegally operated or parked is registered
in the name of a person shall be considered prima facie proof that such person
was in control of the automobile at the time of such violation. (1978 Code § 9-
5-13)
ARTICLE A. PARKING METER ZONES
SECTION:
7-3A-1: Parking Meter Or Meter Box Zones
7-3A-2: Placement Of Meters Or Meter Box
7-3A-3: Parking Meter Or Meter Box Spaces
7-3A-4: Deposit Of Coins Or Currency, Fee And Time Limits
7-3A-5: Prohibited Acts
7-3A-6: Proceeds From Parking Meters And Meter Boxes
7-3A-1: PARKING METER OR METER BOX ZONES:
The parking meter zones shall be: (Ord. 00-2118, 3-20-2000)
   A.   Burlington Avenue from the intersection of Central Avenue to the west
end of the parking area, approximately located at the centerline extended of
Prospect Avenue; and (Ord. 00-2123, 4-24-2000, eff. 7-1-2000)
   B.   The south side of Hillgrove Avenue from a point three hundred sixty
feet (360') east of Prospect Avenue to Grand Avenue. (Ord. 00-2118, 3-20-2000)
7-3A-2: PLACEMENT OF METERS OR METER BOX:
Individual parking meters or a centralized meter box shall be installed in the
parking meter zones as established and provided for in this code. Individual
parking meters shall be placed adjacent to the individual parking places
hereinafter described. Each parking meter shall be placed or set in such manner
as to show or display by a signal whether or not the parking space adjacent to
such meter is legally in use. A centralized meter box may not necessarily be
located immediately adjacent to the parking space or spaces regulated, however,
regardless of its location, the meter box will be set in such manner as to show
or display by a signal whether or not the parking spaces regulated are legally
in use. (Ord. 00-2118, 3-20-2000)
7-3A-3: PARKING METER OR METER BOX SPACES:
   A.   Designation Of Spaces: The municipal services department will designate
the parking spaces for which a parking meter or meter box is to be used by
appropriate markings upon the curb and/or the pavement of the streets. Parking
meter spaces so designated shall be of appropriate length and width so as to be
accessible from the traffic lanes of such street.
   B.   Parking In Designated Spaces 1 : No person shall park a vehicle in any
such designated parking meter or meter box space during the restricted or
regulated time applicable to the parking meter zone in which such meter is
located so that any part of such vehicle occupies more than one such space or
protrudes beyond the markings designating such space; except, that a vehicle
which is of a size too large to be parked within a single designated parking
meter or meter box space shall be permitted to occupy two (2) adjoining parking
meter or meter box spaces as long as payment has been deposited in the parking
meter or meter box for each space so occupied.
   C.   Backing Toward Meter Prohibited: Each vehicle shall be parked facing
the meter for the designated parking space. No vehicle shall be backed into any
parking meter space. (Ord. 00-2118, 3-20-2000)
 
Notes
1 1. See also subsection
  7-3-3B of this chapter.
7-3A-4: DEPOSIT OF COINS OR CURRENCY, FEE AND TIME LIMITS:
   A.   Deposit Of Coins Or Currency, Or Other Accepted Payment Method
Required: No person shall park a vehicle in any parking meter or meter box
space during the restricted and regulated time applicable thereto unless a
payment is made in the coin, coins or currency of the United States Of America
or by any other accepted method of payment (e.g., credit card or debit card) in
the appropriate denomination as designated from time to time by the village
board and as posted by sign, into the meter or meter box.
   B.   Parking In Space With Expired Time Prohibited: No person shall permit
their vehicle to be parked in any such parking meter or meter box space during
the restricted and regulated time applicable to the parking meter zone in which
such meter or meter box is located while the parking meter or meter box for
such space indicates by signal that the lawful parking time in such space has
expired. This provision shall not apply to the act of parking or the necessary
time which is required to deposit immediately thereafter a coin, coins, or
currency in such meter or meter box.
   C.   Fee: Beginning October 1, 2019, the fee for each parking meter space
during the restricted and regulated time applicable thereto shall be four
dollars ($4.00).
   D.   Scope Of Provisions: The provisions of this section shall not relieve
any person from the duty to observe other and more restrictive provisions of
this code and the state vehicle code prohibiting or limiting the stopping,
standing or parking of vehicles in specified places or at specified times.
(Ord. 15-2813, 8-25-2015; amd. Ord. 19-2962, 8-19-2019)
7-3A-5: PROHIBITED ACTS:
   A.   Use Of Slugs: No person shall deposit or attempt to deposit in any
parking meter any slug, button or any other device or substance as substitutes
for coins or currency of the United States Of America.
   B.   Tampering With Meter Or Meter Box: No person shall deface, injure,
tamper with, open or wilfully break, destroy or impair the usefulness of any
parking meter or meter box. (Ord. 00-2118, 3-20-2000)
7-3A-6: PROCEEDS FROM PARKING METERS AND METER BOXES:
   A.   Application Of Proceeds: The coins and currency required to be
deposited in parking meters as provided in this code are levied and assessed as
fees to cover the regulation and control of parking upon public streets; the
cost of parking meters and meter boxes, the installation, inspection,
supervision, operation, repair and maintenance, control and use of parking
spaces; regulating the parking of vehicles in parking meter zones; and the
costs of acquiring, establishing, improving, maintaining and operating public
off street parking facilities.
   B.   Commuter Parking Or Burlington Northern Fund: The coins and currency
deposited in parking meters and meter boxes shall be collected by the director
of law enforcement services or his designees and shall be deposited by the
village treasurer in the fund known as the commuter parking or Burlington
Northern fund (hereinafter the "fund").
   C.   Disposition Of Funds: The village manager or his designees shall pay
from the fund the cost of any parking meters or meter boxes or other related
appurtenances purchased by the village; expenses incurred for their
installation, inspection, service, supervision, repair and maintenance;
expenses incurred for making collections from such parking meters or meter
boxes; and for the enforcement of the provisions of this code applicable to
parking meter and meter box zones. The net proceeds of the operation of parking
meters and meter boxes in the fund, after the payment of such costs and
expenses, shall be used for parking studies and for the acquisition,
establishment, improvement, maintenance and operation of public off street
parking facilities, or any other legal obligations of the fund, as the village
board shall from time to time direct. (Ord. 00-2118, 3-20-2000)
ARTICLE B. PERMIT PARKING
SECTION:
7-3B-1: Application Of Provisions
7-3B-2: Parking Permit Locations Designated
7-3B-3: Issuance And Sale Of Permits
7-3B-4: Marking Permit Parking Spaces
7-3B-5: Violations
7-3B-1: APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS:
This article shall apply to all Village designated permit parking locations for
which charges for parking are imposed and collected by means of the issuance
and sale of window sticker or mirror tag permits by the Village. (Ord. 00-2118,
3-20-2000)
7-3B-2: PARKING PERMIT LOCATIONS DESIGNATED:
The following locations are designated as permit parking locations and may be
so designated by the Village Manager or his designees by posting adequate
notice in such locations of said designation:
   A.   That portion of the following nonmetered parking zones:
Burlington Avenue, north side
From Grand Avenue to Central Avenue.
From a point sixty four feet (64') east of Wolf Road to a point one hundred
feet (100') east of Howard Avenue.
Hillgrove Avenue, south side
From Grand Avenue to a point three hundred sixty feet (360') east of Prospect
Avenue.
From Howard Avenue to a point two hundred thirty six feet (236') east.
Waldo Erickson Drive, north side
From the entrance to lower level Springrock Park to a point four hundred eighty
eight feet (488') east.
The Village Manager or his designee may, from time to time, so designate
additional portions of such nonmetered parking zones as permit parking
locations or, alternatively, may designate any portion of permit parking
locations as parking meter or meter box zones by causing parking meters or a
meter box to be placed in service thereon and by posting adequate notice in
such portion of such designation. (Ord. 00-2118, 3-20-2000; amd. Ord. 00-2123,
4-24-2000, eff. 7-1-2000; Ord. 02-2210, 12-2-2002, eff. 1-1-2003)
   B.   Municipally owned and operated nonmetered parking lots as may be, from
time to time, designated by the Village Board, and for which a permit and/or
fee may be required:
Western Springs Grand Avenue Community Center parking lot.
Wolf Road commuter parking lot. (Ord. 00-2118, 3-20-2000)
7-3B-3: ISSUANCE AND SALE OF PERMITS:
   A.   Number Of Permits Authorized: The Village Manager or his designee shall
cause suitable window sticker or mirror tag permits to be prepared and made
available for issuance and sale. The aggregate number of such permits prepared
and available at any one time shall not exceed one hundred thirty five percent
(135%) of the number of parking spaces designated and available for permit
parking. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the number of permit window stickers or
mirror tags sold shall not exceed the number of permit spaces designated and
available for such use unless the Village Manager determines on the basis of
surveys of parking space vacancy rates and other relevant criteria that the
sale of an additional amount of parking window stickers or mirror tags is
justified. The Village Manager shall notify the Village Board of Trustees not
less than thirty (30) days before the effective date of his decision to sell
more than one hundred percent (100%) of the spaces available for permit
parking. Permit window stickers or mirror tags shall be issued and sold for six
(6) month periods commencing January 1, and July 1 in each year. Permit window
stickers or mirror tags for different six (6) month periods shall be designated
by different colors or in some other manner as approved by the Village Manager
or his designee.
   B.   Restrictions: Permit window stickers or mirror tags shall be offered
for sale by the Village Manager or his designee during regular business hours
at the Village offices not less than fourteen (14) days prior to each such six
(6) month period and shall be sold subject to the following: (Ord. 02-2210, 12-
2-2002, eff. 1-1-2003)
      1.   Permit Renewals: At the discretion of the Village Manager or his
designee, permit renewal notices may be mailed to existing permit holders and
renewal permits may be issued and sold by the Village Manager or his designee
to such permit holders in advance of the time when such permits are made
available for sale at the Village offices.
      2.   Reserved Permits: At the discretion of the Village Manager or his
designee, permit window stickers or mirror tags offered for sale may be
reserved for sale only to persons residing within the corporate limits of the
Village, except the foregoing shall not apply to permit parking spaces
constructed with monies received pursuant to agreements with the commuter rail
division of the regional transportation authority, or the Illinois Department
of Transportation. (Ord. 00-2118, 3-20-2000)
   C.   Permit Fees: Beginning May 1, 2019, the fee for each window sticker or
mirror tag for each six (6) month period shall be one hundred eighty dollars
($180.00) for residents and two hundred twenty dollars ($220.00) for
nonresidents, except in the Wolf Road commuter parking lot. The fee for each
window sticker or mirror tag for each six (6) month period in the Wolf Road
commuter parking lot shall be two hundred eighty dollars ($280.00) for
residents and three hundred forty dollars ($340.00) for nonresidents. Such fees
for the sale of a new window sticker or mirror tag permit, or the fee for a
replacement window sticker or mirror tag permit, shall be reduced by one-sixth
(1/6) for each full calendar month in each six (6) month period that has
expired prior to the date of sale of such window sticker or mirror tag permit.
No reduction shall be made for periods of less than one month. (Ord. 19-2952,
4-22-2019)
   D.   Refunds: Refunds for permit window stickers or mirror tags will be made
only in the first three (3) months of the permit period. Refunds will be based
on whole months remaining on the permit. (Ord. 02-2210, 12-2-2002, eff. 1-1-
2003)
   E.   Transfer Of Permit: Permit window stickers or mirror tags shall not be
transferable.
   F.   Waiting List: Names of persons unable to obtain permit window stickers
or mirror tags due to unavailability of permit space shall be maintained on
waiting lists for Village residents and nonresidents. Said Village residents or
nonresidents shall be contacted as permit window stickers or mirror tags become
available. (Ord. 00-2118, 3-20-2000)
7-3B-4: MARKING PERMIT PARKING SPACES:
Suitable markings approved by the Village Manager or his designee shall be
painted or placed upon the pavement, curb, street or other location for the
purpose of designating permit parking spaces. Each vehicle parked in a
designated permit parking area shall be parked wholly within such markings.
(Ord. 00-2118, 3-20-2000)
7-3B-5: VIOLATIONS:
It shall be unlawful for any person:
   A.   To park or let stand any vehicle in any designated permit parking area
at any time between the hours of five o'clock (5:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:
00) P.M. on any day except Saturdays, Sundays and public holidays, unless such
vehicle shall have attached to the inside surface of the passenger side corner
of the rear window thereof a currently valid window sticker permit issued by
the Village or have attached to the rearview mirror a mirror tag permit issued
by the Village.
   B.   To park or let stand any vehicle across or upon any marking designating
a parking space in a permit area. (Ord. 00-2118, 3-20-2000)
ARTICLE C. BUSINESS DISTRICT PARKING PERMITS
SECTION:
7-3C-1: Application Of Provisions
7-3C-2: Parking Locations Designated
7-3C-3: Issuance And Sale Of Permits
7-3C-4: Violations
7-3C-5: Citation, Payment And Impoundment
7-3C-1: APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS:
This Article shall apply to all Village designated downtown business district
permit parking locations for which charges for seven (7) hour parking permits
are imposed and collected by means of the issuance and sale of an annual window
sticker or mirror tag permits by the Department of Law Enforcement Services.
(Ord. 98-2041, 6-22-1998)
7-3C-2: PARKING LOCATIONS DESIGNATED:
The following locations are designated as business district permit parking
locations and shall be designated by posting the appropriate signs in such
locations of said designation:
   A.   HILLGROVE AVENUE - SOUTH SIDE
From Lawn Avenue to Wolf Road (800 block of Hillgrove Avenue)
   B.   WALNUT STREET - SOUTH SIDE
From Grand Avenue to Lawn Avenue (900 block of Walnut Street)
The Department of Public Works, subject to the prior approval of the President
and Board of Trustees, is hereby authorized to erect the appropriate signs
designating the business district permit parking locations. (Ord. 98-2041, 6-
22-1998)
7-3C-3: ISSUANCE AND SALE OF PERMITS:
   A.   Number Of Permits Authorized: The Director of the Department of Law
Enforcement Services shall cause suitable annual business district window
sticker or mirror tag permits to be prepared and made available for issuance
and sale to the owners of businesses located within the downtown business
district area of the Village. The downtown business district area of the
Village is approximately bounded by 42nd Street and Chestnut Street to the
north, Howard Avenue to the east, Elm Street and 45th Street to the south and
Central Avenue to the west. The window sticker or mirror tag permits shall be
issued and sold on an annual basis and shall pertain to the period of time
starting January 1 and ending December 31 of each year.
   B.   Restrictions: Annual window sticker or mirror tag permits shall be
offered for sale by the Director of the Department of Law Enforcement Services
or his designated representative during regular business hours at the Village
offices not less than fourteen (14) days prior to January 1 each year and shall
be sold subject to the following:
      1.   Application: On an annual basis each owner of a business located and
operating in the downtown business district area of the Village may apply for
business district parking permits for use by the employees of the owner's
business on a form provided by the Department of Law Enforcement Services.
      2.   Permit Criteria: Issuance and sale of a business district parking
permit by the Director of Law Enforcement Services is subject to the following:
         a.   Proof that the applicant is the current business owner of a
business located in the downtown business district area;
         b.   The business owner has a current Village business license;
         c.   The business owner is not indebted to the Village; and
         d.   Payment of the required permit fee.
      3.   Seven Hour Parking: Those persons who park a motor vehicle
displaying a current, valid business district parking permit in the designated
downtown business district permit parking areas may remain parked at such
location for a seven (7) consecutive hour period (9:00 A.M. to 4:00 P.M.)
without violating the posted hourly parking restrictions.
   C.   Permit Fees: The fee for each annual business district window sticker
or mirror tag permit shall be one dollar ($1.00).
   D.   Refunds: No refunds shall be made for business district window sticker
or mirror tag permits.
   E.   Transfer Of Permit: Business district window sticker or mirror tag
permits shall not be transferable. (Ord. 98-2041, 6-22-1998)
7-3C-4: VIOLATIONS:
It shall be unlawful for any person:
   A.   To park or let stand any vehicle in any designated downtown business
district permit parking area in violation of the posted hourly parking
restrictions, unless such vehicle shall have attached to the inside surface of
the passenger side corner of the rear window thereof a current, valid business
district window sticker permit issued by the Department of Law Enforcement
Services or have attached to the rear view mirror a current, valid business
district mirror tag permit issued by the Department of Law Enforcement Services
or unless otherwise permitted by law. (Ord. 98-2041, 6-22-1998)
7-3C-5: CITATION, PAYMENT AND IMPOUNDMENT:
   A.   Citation: Any person charged with a violation of any of the provisions
of this Article may settle such charge by paying to the Village, within seven
(7) days after the date of the Department of Law Enforcement Services citation
alleging such violation, the sum of twenty five dollars ($25.00) for each
offense so charged.
   B.   Penalty: Any person found guilty of a violation of any provision of
this Article shall be subject to a fine of not less than twenty five dollars
($25.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each such
violation.
   C.   Impoundment: Any vehicle parked in violation of the provisions of this
Article may be towed away by or at the order of the Department of Law
Enforcement Services and impounded until payment in full of all reasonable
costs and expenses incurred in connection with such towing and storage of such
vehicle, as well as any fines authorized by this Article. (Ord. 98-2041, 6-22-
1998)
ARTICLE D. ELECTRIC VEHICLE CHARGING STATIONS
SECTION:
7-3D-1: Application Of Provisions
7-3D-2: Definitions
7-3D-3: Use Of Electric Vehicle Parking Spaces In Public Right-Of-Way; Charging
7-3D-4: Permit Approval; Permitted Locations
7-3D-5: Signage
7-3D-6: Penalties
7-3D-1: APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS:
The general purposes of this chapter are: (1) to facilitate and encourage the
use of electric vehicle charging stations by those who own and operate electric
vehicles; and (2) to establish regulations concerning Village-owned electric
vehicle charging stations on public property. (Ord. 20-3004, 5-18-2020)
7-3D-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of interpretation and enforcement of this article, the
following terms shall have the meanings stated in this section. Any term not
defined in this article shall have the meaning ascribed to it in other sections
of this code or ordinances of the Village, and, if not defined therein, such
term shall have the meaning ascribed to it in the Illinois Vehicle Code, 625
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-100 et seq. or other applicable Illinois law.
ELECTRIC VEHICLE: Any vehicle that is licensed and registered on public and
private highways, roads, and streets that contains original, stock equipment
from the vehicle manufacturer to accept charging from an electric vehicle
charging station and that operates, either partially or exclusively, on
electrical energy from the grid, or an off-board source, that is stored on-
board via a battery for motive purpose. "Electric vehicle" includes: (1) a
battery powered electric vehicle operated solely by electricity; and (2) a
plug-in hybrid electric vehicle that operates on electricity and gasoline and
has a battery that can be recharged from an external source.
ELECTRIC VEHICLE CHARGING STATION: An electrical component assembly or cluster
of component assemblies designed specifically to charge batteries located
within electric vehicles. The charging station may also contain appurtenances
for the purposes of customer payment.
ELECTRIC VEHICLE PARKING SPACE: Any marked parking space that identifies the
use to be exclusively for the parking of an electric vehicle.
NON-ELECTRIC VEHICLE: Any motor vehicle that does not meet the definition of
electric vehicle. (Ord. 20-3004, 5-18-2020)
7-3D-3: USE OF ELECTRIC VEHICLE PARKING SPACES IN PUBLIC RIGHT-OF-WAY;
CHARGING:
Electric vehicle charging stations and electric vehicle parking spaces are
reserved for charging electric vehicles only.
   A.   Village-Owned Electric Vehicle Charging Stations: The use of a Village-
owned electric vehicle charging station and adjacent electric vehicle parking
space(s) shall be limited to electric vehicles for no more than three (3) hours
of continuous charging per day. For purposes of this subsection, "charging"
means that an electric vehicle is connected to an electric vehicle charging
station.
   B.   Usage Fee: There shall be no fee or charge for the first three (3)
hours of charging per day after connecting to a Village-owned electric vehicle
charging station. After the three (3) hour period, the usage fee for electric
vehicle charging shall be twenty dollars ($20.00) per sixty (60) minute
interval.
   C.   Unlawful Parking: No person shall park any non-electric vehicle in an
electric vehicle parking space. A non-electric vehicle parked in an electric
vehicle parking space is subject to a fine and tow, per chapter 9 (Abandoned,
Inoperable, Hazardous and Unlawful Vehicles) of this title.
   D.   Electric Vehicle Parking Generally: Electric vehicles may park in any
space designated for public parking, subject to the same restrictions that
apply to non-electric vehicles.
   E.   Disclaimer: The Village of Western Springs is not liable or responsible
for the failure to operate or for any damage caused by an electrical vehicle
charging station. (Ord. 20-3004, 5-18-2020)
7-3D-4: PERMIT APPROVAL; PERMITTED LOCATIONS:
   A.   Public Right-Of-Way Or Other Public Property: The location of electric
vehicle charging stations and electric vehicle parking spaces within any public
right-of-way or on any public property are subject to approval by the corporate
authorities after submittal of a permit application (on Village form),
including site design plan, electrical plan, signage plan, and electric vehicle
charging station equipment and specifications plan, to and review and approval
by the Director of Community Development and/or the Director of Municipal
Services. For non-Village-owned electric vehicle charging stations to service
electric vehicle parking spaces within any public right-of-way, such use shall
require approval of a license agreement (on the Village form) by the corporate
authorities, in their sole discretion. The following locations of electric
vehicle charging stations and electric vehicle parking spaces are authorized:
      1.   One (1) electric vehicle charging station and two (2) electric
vehicle parking spaces located at: north side of Burlington Avenue immediately
west of Grand Avenue.
   B.   Private Property For Commercial Use Or General Public Use: The location
of electric vehicle charging stations and electric vehicle parking spaces on
any private property for commercial use or made available for use by the
general public are subject to approval by the corporate authorities after
submittal of a permit application (on Village form), including site design
plan, electrical plan, signage plan, and electric vehicle charging station
equipment and specifications plan, to and review and approval by the Director
of Community Development and/or the Village Engineer. Electric vehicle charging
stations and electric vehicle parking spaces permitted under this subsection
are allowed in all zoning districts, except in the A - Single-Family Residence
District, the R1 - Single-Family Residence District, the R2 - Single-Family
Residence District, the R2 - Single-Family Residence-PUD District, the RB -
Residential buffer district and the SFA - Single-Family Attached Residence
District such electric vehicle charging stations and electric vehicle parking
spaces shall be used only by (a) property owners and occupants of single-family
residences, (b) property owners, occupants and tenants of any multi-family
buildings and (c) patrons of any group assembly buildings (e.g., community
pool, theatre and places of worship).
      1.   The following locations of electric vehicle charging stations and
electric vehicle parking spaces are authorized: None.
   C.   Private Property For Private Use: The location of an electric vehicle
charging station and electric vehicle parking spaces on any private property
used for private, non-commercial purposes or not made available to the general
public are subject to approval by the Director of Community Development after
submittal of a permit application (on Village form), including site design
plan, electrical plan, signage plan, and electric vehicle charging station
equipment and specifications plan, to and review and approval by the Director
of Community Development.
   D.   Compliance With Other Regulations: Approval of such electric charging
stations and electric vehicle parking spaces shall be subject to all applicable
National and State regulations as well as any local amendments adopted by the
corporate authorities.
   E.   Removal: The corporate authorities may authorize by ordinance the
removal of any designated electric vehicle parking space from Village-owned
property if, in their sole discretion, the designated electric vehicle parking
space creates any parking issues within the Village. The Director of Community
Development, or his or her designee, may require the removal of any designated
electric vehicle parking space from privately-owned property under subsection B
above if, in his or her sole discretion, said designated electric vehicle
parking spaces create any parking issues within the Village. (Ord. 20-3004, 5-
18-2020)
7-3D-5: SIGNAGE:
Electric vehicle parking spaces shall be posted with signage indicating the
space is to be used exclusively for electric vehicle charging purposes and that
violators are subject to a fine and tow of the offending vehicle.
   A.   Electric vehicle parking spaces shall be posted with signage indicating
the maintenance number for the equipment.
   B.   Electric vehicle parking spaces shall be posted with the following
information: (a) voltage and amperage levels; (b) time limitation; (c) usage
fee; (d) user instructions related to the electrical vehicle charging station;
(e) disclaimer that the City of Western Springs is not liable or responsible
for the failure to operate or for any damage caused by an electrical vehicle
charging station. (Ord. 20-3004, 5-18-2020)
7-3D-6: PENALTIES:
Any person convicted of violating any of the provisions of this article shall
be assessed a fine of not less than thirty five dollars ($35.00) and not to
exceed seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) and may be assessed such other
fines, fees or costs, as are authorized by chapter 9 (Abandoned, Inoperable,
Hazardous and Unlawful Vehicles) of this title or state law. Each day such
violation is committed or permitted to continue shall constitute a separate
violation and shall be punishable as such hereunder. The registered owner of a
vehicle towed for a violation of this section may secure the release of the
vehicle by furnishing evidence of his or her identity and ownership or
possessory right to the vehicle, by signing a receipt for the vehicle and by
paying or causing to be paid to the Village and/or the towing and impoundment
service operator the assessed fines and towing and impoundment fees. (Ord. 20-
3004, 5-18-2020)

period of time longer than indicated, except Sundays and holidays, unless
prohibition or restriction signs specifically include Sundays and holidays.

7-4-8: SPEED RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   Reasonable Speed: No vehicle may be driven upon any street or alley in
the Village at a speed which is greater than is reasonable and proper with
regard to traffic conditions and the use of said street or alley or endangers
the safety of any person or property. The fact that the speed of a vehicle does
not exceed the applicable maximum speed limit does not relieve the driver from
the duty to decrease speed when approaching and crossing an intersection, when
approaching and going around a curve, when approaching a hillcrest, when
traveling upon any narrow or winding roadway or when special hazard exists with
respect to pedestrians or other traffic or by reason of weather or road
conditions. Speed must be decreased as may be necessary to avoid colliding with
any person or vehicle on or entering the street or alley in compliance with
legal requirements and the duty of all persons to use due care.
   B.   Speed Limits Established:
      1.   Roadways Under Jurisdiction Of State Or County: It shall be unlawful
to drive any vehicle on any street or highway within the Village under the
jurisdiction of the Illinois Department of Transportation or the County at a
speed exceeding that lawfully set.
      2.   Roadways Not Under Jurisdiction Of State Or County; General Speed
Restrictions: Unless some other speed restriction is established under this
section, it shall be unlawful to drive any motor vehicle on any street not
under the jurisdiction of the Illinois Department of Transportation or the
County at a speed in excess of twenty five (25) miles per hour or in an alley
at a speed in excess of fifteen (15) miles per hour.
      3.   Vehicles With Solid Tires: It shall be unlawful to operate any
vehicle equipped with two (2) or more solid tires on any street or alley within
the Village and under its jurisdiction at a speed in excess of ten (10) miles
per hour.
      4.   Schools: No person shall drive a motor vehicle at a speed in excess
of twenty (20) miles per hour while passing a school zone or while traveling
upon any public thoroughfare on or across which children pass along, to and
from school, during school days when schoolchildren are present. Appropriate
signs shall be posted to indicate this restriction. (1997 Code)
      5.   Speed Limits On Specific Roadways: It shall be unlawful to drive any
motor vehicle on the following roadways in the Village in excess of the
following speed limits:
   20 Miles Per Hour
BURLINGTON AVENUE from Johnson Avenue to Grand Avenue.
GILBERT AVENUE/WILLOW SPRINGS ROAD from the south right- of-way line of 47th
Street to a point four hundred eighty nine feet (489') south of said line.
Signage shall state that the speed regulation applies:
      On school days when children are present
HILLGROVE AVENUE from Howard Avenue to Central Avenue.
LAWN AVENUE between Burlington Avenue and Elm Avenue.
WALKER STREET between Hampton and the recreation center.
   30 Miles Per Hour
GILBERT AVENUE from Ogden Avenue to 47th Street.
   35 Miles Per Hour
GILBERT AVENUE/WILLOW SPRINGS ROAD from a point seventy six feet (76') south of
the south right-of-way line of 47th Street to the southerly Village limits.
(Ord. 07-2450, 6-25-2007)
