subsequent finding of liability within the 12 month period. With regard to a
firm or corporation, a fourth or subsequent finding of liability shall mean a
fourth or subsequent finding attributable to any one employee-driver.

violation of the provisions of sections 15-102, 15-103 or 15-107 of the
Illinois vehicle code 5 , shall be fined for the first or second violation not
less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00)
for each offense, and for the third and subsequent violations by the same
person, firm or corporation within a period of one year after the date of the
first offense, not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) nor more than one
thousand dollars ($1,000.00).
   G.   If a second division vehicle and load are operated within the village
and the required registration fees and taxes for the gross weight of the
vehicle and load have not been paid or the vehicle and load exceed the

two thousand one (2,001) pounds or more, the operator or owner shall be fined
as stated in subsection E of this section. For any unregistered vehicle or

as established in subsection H of this section.

7-7-7: PERMITS FOR OVERWEIGHT AND/OR OVERDIMENSION VEHICLES:
   A.   A permit shall be required for the movement of any vehicle or
combination of vehicles with a nondivisible load on roadways and bridges within
the jurisdiction of the village which exceeds the dimensions and weights
permitted for the particular roadways to be traversed whether they be
nondesignated or designated roadways.
   B.   The village, with respect to any street or highway under its
jurisdiction, may, upon application to the village police department on forms
provided by the police department and good cause being shown therefor, issue a
special permit authorizing the applicant to operate or move a vehicle or
combination of vehicles of a size or weight of vehicle or load exceeding the
maximum specified in section
7-7-6 of this chapter. The applicant shall furnish the following information in
the special permit application:
      1.   The name and address of the owner or lessee of the vehicle.
      2.   Applicant's name.
      3.   Type of permit request, whether it be for a single trip or round
trip.
      4.   The description and registration (or the Illinois department of
transportation's (IDT) registration number or classification) of the power
unit.
      5.   Description of the object or vehicle to be moved.
      6.   The number of axles of the vehicle or combination of vehicles.
      7.   The maximum axle weights of all single, tandem or series axles.
      8.   Maximum gross weight of the vehicle.
      9.   The maximum width, length and height of the vehicle and load.
      10.   Requested routing over village streets to and from a specific
location.
   C.   For purposes of this section, the following definitions apply:
ONE-WAY OR SINGLE TRIP MOVEMENT: One move from the point of origin to the point
of destination. Any additional stops between the point of origin and the point
of destination are expressly prohibited. Single trip permits are effective for
seven (7) consecutive days from the date of issuance unless otherwise directed
by the police department.
ROUND TRIP MOVEMENT: Two (2) trips over the same route in opposite directions.
Round trip permits are effective for fourteen (14) consecutive days from the
date of issuance.
   D.   The owner or his or her agent shall submit an application fee based on
the below charts for a single routing which will be valid for seven (7)
calendar days or round trip routing valid for fourteen (14) calendar days.
Permits are valid only for the date periods specified on the permit and for the
specific vehicle, load and routing as established by the chief of police or
designee. No substitution of vehicle, load or routing is permitted without the
express written permission of the chief of police or his or her designee. The
permit must be carried in the vehicle to which the permit applies.
   FEE SCHEDULE1

1.   If a vehicle requires a permit due to multiple weight and/or dimension
issues, the total fee will be based on the largest individual weight or
dimension factor only.
2.   Plus necessary and appropriate administrative, engineering and road damage
fees.
   E.   The chief of police or his or her designee is authorized to approve the
application for approved routes. Upon approval and payment of all required
fees, the police department shall issue a permit allowing passage of the
oversize and/or overweight vehicles over village streets. The permit shall be
specific and contain:
      1.   Permit number.
      2.   The dates the permit is valid.
      3.   Whether the permit is for single or round trip routing.
      4.   The description of object or vehicle to be moved.
      5.   Authorized gross weight, axle weights, width, length and height.
      6.   The authorized routing over village streets including the origin and
termination point within the village.
      7.   The fee paid.
      8.   The date and signature of the chief of police or his or her
designee.
      9.   In addition, the permit will specify general conditions that the
permittee must comply with that are consistent and reasonable for the
protection of the general public and village streets. A copy of all permits
issued will be provided to the village manager for informational purposes.
   F.   It is the duty of the permittee to read and familiarize himself or
herself with the permit provisions upon receipt. Undertaking of the permit move
is deemed prima facie evidence of acceptance of the permit and that:
      1.   The permittee is in compliance with all operation requirements;
      2.   All dimension and weight limitations specified in the permit will
not be exceeded;
      3.   All operation, registration and license requirements have been
complied with;
      4.   All financial responsibilities, obligations and other legal
requirements have been met;
      5.   The permittee assumes all liability for any and all damages or for
injury or damage to persons or to public property, including streets, bridges,
sidewalks, curbs, light poles, infrastructure in public rights of way, village
owned appurtenances, or to private property, including his or her own, or to
the object being transported, caused directly or indirectly by the
transportation or movement of vehicles and objects authorized under the permit.
The measure of liability shall be the actual cost for all repairs or
replacement of property damaged by permittee; and
      6.   Permittee agrees to and shall indemnify and hold harmless the
village and its appointed and elected officials, officers, president and board
of trustees, engineers, attorneys, volunteers, agents, or employees, from any
and all suits, claims, damages, costs, judgments, settlements, or proceedings
of any kind, arising from physical injuries, including loss of life, or damage
to or loss of property related to acts or omissions by permittee, its officers,
agents, or employees, pursuant to the permit or arising from the movement
authorized by the permit.
   G.   The permit shall be carried in the vehicle to which the permit applies
at all times while operating on streets within the village and shall be
exhibited upon demand to any law enforcement officer, police officer or
authorized official of the village.
   H.   Whenever any vehicle is operated in violation of the provisions of a
village permit, whether it be by size, weight or general provisions, either or
both the owner or driver of such vehicle shall be deemed liable for such
violation and either or both the owner or the driver of such vehicle may be
prosecuted for such violation.
   I.   The permits issued under this section constitute the grant of a
privilege by the village and may be denied, suspended or revoked for such
reasons as the village may deem rationally related to its governmental
interests, including, but not limited to:
      1.   A permittee knowingly providing incorrect information on an
application for a permit;
      2.   A permittee, its agents or employees acting on a permit which has
been altered;
      3.   Noncompliance by permittee, its agents or employees with federal,
state or local laws pertaining to the transport of goods or operation of a
vehicle engaged in the transportation of goods;
      4.   Overdue fines or fees due to the village; and
      5.   Moving on village streets without a valid permit as is required by
this section.
Suspension or revocation of a current permit shall be for the time determined
appropriate by the chief of police or his or her designee. Reinstatement may be
made upon conditions determined by the village and payment of all outstanding
settlements or judgments. The charges for reinstatement are:
Denial: No charge.
Suspended: Fifty dollars ($50.00).
Revoked: Seventy five dollars ($75.00).
   J.   Police escorts shall be required for certain vehicles and loads as
determined by the chief of police or his or her designee. The total number of
officers necessary to provide for a safe move shall be determined by the chief
of police or his or her designee. Fees for escorts shall be in addition to any
permit fees and shall be sixty five dollars ($65.00) per hour per officer
assigned with a minimum fee of one hundred thirty dollars ($130.00),
irrespective of the time or number of officers actually used. (Ord. 07-2453, 7-
23-2007)
7-7-8: VEHICLES PROHIBITED ON CERTAIN STREETS:
   A.   As provided under the authority of sections 15-111 and 15-316 of the
Illinois vehicle code 1 , it shall be unlawful to operate any vehicle upon any
street where the operation of that vehicle is prohibited by ordinance and where
signs of such prohibition are posted. Vehicles operating under the authority of
section 15-111 or 15-316 while utilizing village streets under "reasonable
access" rules will be considered in violation of this section if they are not
utilizing the most direct route to points of loading and unloading.
   B.   It shall be unlawful to operate any "construction vehicle", as defined
herein, on any street in the village when signs are posted on that street
prohibiting "construction vehicles". Where the chief of police, with the
approval of the village board, establishes an established truck route,
construction vehicles will utilize only those established routes to service
those areas of the village under construction.
   C.   It shall be unlawful to park a commercial motor vehicle on a
residential street while said truck is running between the hours of ten o'clock
(10:00) P.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. the following day. (Ord. 07-2453, 7-
23-2007)
 
Notes
1 1. 625 ILCS 5/15-111, 5/15-316.
7-7-9: OVERSIZE/OVERWEIGHT VEHICLES PERMITTED ON CERTAIN STREETS:
   A.   As provided under the authority of subsection 15-111(f) of the Illinois
vehicle code 1 , the village reserves the right to designate streets and/or
highways under the village's jurisdiction as class II designated streets.
Vehicles utilizing those as such can be of a weight, length and width
consistent with sections 15-102 (width), 15-107 (length) and 15-111 (weight).
The following streets and/or highways are hereby designated as class II
designated streets: None.
   B.   The superintendent of public works is authorized and directed to post
or cause to be posted, streets designated as class II truck routes as governed
by subsection A of this section. (Ord. 07-2453, 7-23-2007)
 
Notes
1 1. 625 ILCS 5/15-111(f).
7-7-10: PENALTY:
In addition to any penalties provided for elsewhere in this chapter, any
person, firm or corporation who or which violates, disobeys, neglects, fails to
comply with or resists enforcement of the provisions of this chapter will be
fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty
dollars ($750.00) for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed
committed on each calendar day a violation occurs. Local ordinance violations
under this chapter may be prosecuted in the Cook County circuit court or
through the village's administrative adjudication program as directed by the
village manager. (Ord. 07-2453, 7-23-2007; amd. Ord. 08-2486, 2-25-2008)
In addition to seeking a fine, as hereinabove provided, the village attorney
may institute any proper action in the name of the village of Western Springs
to enjoin the violation of any provision of this chapter. (Ord. 07-2453, 7-23-
2007)
CHAPTER 8
SKATES, SKATEBOARDS AND OTHER TOY VEHICLES
SECTION:
7-8-1: Riding Rules; Roadway
7-8-2: Riding Rules; Business Districts
7-8-3: Ramps And Jumps
7-8-4: Railroad Platforms
7-8-5: Parental Responsibility
7-8-6: Violations
7-8-7: Penalty
7-8-1: RIDING RULES; ROADWAY:
Any person upon skates, skateboard or similar device (herein a skater) shall
when operating upon a roadway be subject to regulations as provided in 625
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-1007 "Pedestrians Walking on Highways":
   A.   Where a sidewalk is provided and its use is practicable, it shall be
unlawful for any skater to skate along and upon an adjacent roadway.
   B.   Where a sidewalk is not available, any skater who is skating along and
upon a highway shall skate only on a shoulder, as far as practicable from the
edge of the roadway.
   C.   Where neither a sidewalk nor a shoulder is available, any skater who is
skating along and upon a highway shall walk as near as practicable to an
outside edge of a roadway, and if on a two- way roadway, shall skate only on
the left side of the roadway.
   D.   Except as otherwise provided in this Chapter, any skater upon a roadway
shall yield the right of way to all vehicles upon the roadway. (Ord. 97-1995,
2-24-1997)
7-8-2: RIDING RULES; BUSINESS DISTRICTS:
Any person upon skates, skateboard or similar device when operating such device
on the sidewalks in any business district shall exercise due caution regarding
pedestrians on the sidewalk. (Ord. 97-1995, 2-24-1997)
7-8-3: RAMPS AND JUMPS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to use, operate, ride upon or propel a
skateboard, skates or, similar device on or over any jumping device, or ramp or
similar structure, upon any public sidewalk, street or roadway, or public right
of way, not designated for such use by Village officials. (Ord. 97-1995, 2-24-
1997)
7-8-4: RAILROAD PLATFORMS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to use, operate, ride upon, or propel a
skateboard, skates or similar device on any railroad platform or other railroad
property or where posted signs prohibit such activity. (Ord. 97-1995, 2-24-
1997)
7-8-5: PARENTAL RESPONSIBILITY:
The parent of any child and the guardian of any ward shall not authorize or
knowingly permit any child or ward to violate any provisions of this Chapter.
Any parent or guardian knowingly authorizing or permitting a violation shall
upon conviction thereof be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished in
accordance with the provisions provided in Section
7-8-7 of this Chapter. (Ord. 97-1995, 2-24-1997)
7-8-6: VIOLATIONS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to resist or obstruct any police officer in
the enforcement of this Chapter. (Ord. 97-1995, 2-24-1997)
7-8-7: PENALTY:
The penalty for the violation of any section of this Chapter shall not be less
than fifteen dollars ($15.00), nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00),
for each offense. (Ord. 97-1995, 2-24-1997)
CHAPTER 9
ABANDONED, INOPERABLE, HAZARDOUS AND UNLAWFUL VEHICLES
SECTION:
7-9-1: Definitions
7-9-2: Unlawful Use Or Abandonment; Nuisance Declared; Removal Authorized
7-9-3: Authorization For Vehicle Towing, Impoundment And Disposal
7-9-4: Temporary Custody By Nonowner; Removal By Towing Service
7-9-5: Towing Hazardous Or Unlawful Vehicles
7-9-6: Towing Abandoned Or Inoperable Vehicles
7-9-7: Post-Tow Notice
7-9-8: Post-Tow Appeal
7-9-9: Procedures For Release Of Towed Vehicles
7-9-10: Disposition Of Towed Or Impounded Vehicles
7-9-11: Obtaining Ownership Information
7-9-12: Exemption From Civil Liability
7-9-13: Penalties
7-9-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of interpretation and enforcement of this chapter, the
following terms shall have the meanings stated in this section. Any term not
defined in this section shall have the meaning ascribed to it in other sections
of this code or ordinances of the village, and, if not defined therein, such
term shall have the meaning ascribed to it in the Illinois vehicle code, 625
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-100 et seq.
ABANDONED VEHICLE: A vehicle (other than a hazardous or unlawful vehicle)
which:
   A.   Is in a state of disrepair rendering the vehicle incapable of being
driven in its condition; or
   B.   Does not have a current, annual state vehicle license purchased for it
and attached thereto (except vehicles for sale by new and used motor vehicle
dealers and vehicle repair shops); and
   C.   Has not been moved or used for seven (7) consecutive days or more and
is apparently deserted.
   D.   Notwithstanding the above, no vehicle housed on a continuing basis in
an enclosed building (except when actual work is being done on the vehicle)
shall be considered an abandoned vehicle.
DIRECTOR OF LAW ENFORCEMENT SERVICES: Police chief of the Western Springs
police department.
HAZARDOUS VEHICLE:
   A.   A vehicle which has been involved in an accident and is disabled or
cannot be immediately moved by the owner or operator of the vehicle.
   B.   A vehicle which presents an immediate danger to the health or welfare
of the public.
   C.   A vehicle abandoned or disabled on a public street, way, or alley which
impedes the orderly flow of traffic or poses potential danger to pedestrians or
other operators of vehicles.
   D.   A vehicle which must be moved to allow for proper municipal snow
removal from a public street, way or alley.
HIGHWAY, ROADWAY OR STREET: The entire width between the boundary lines of
every right of way publicly maintained when any part thereof is open to the use
of the public for purposes of vehicular travel.
INOPERABLE MOTOR VEHICLE: Any motor vehicle from which, for a period of at
least seven (7) days, the engine, wheels or other parts have been removed, or
on which the engine, wheels or other parts have been altered, damaged or
otherwise so treated that the vehicle is incapable of being driven under its
own motor power. "Inoperable Motor Vehicle" shall not include a motor vehicle
which has been rendered temporarily incapable of being driven under its own
motor power in order to perform ordinary service or repair operations.
PERSON: Any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company, or
organization of any kind.
PROPERTY: Any real property within the village or any village- owned real or
personal property within or outside the corporate limits which is not a
highway, roadway or street.
REGISTERED OWNER: The person or entity recorded with the Illinois secretary of
state as the vehicle owner or listed in the registry of motor vehicles of
another state, or, if after diligent search no such person or entity can be
located, then the owner of the property on which the vehicle is located, if on
private property.
UNLAWFUL VEHICLE:
   A.   A vehicle which has been reported stolen or is the subject of a search
and seized by the police department or other law enforcement agency.
   B.   A vehicle which was operated by a person placed under lawful arrest for
violation of any statute or local ordinance and who by reason of the arrest is
unable to operate the vehicle.
   C.   A vehicle parked in violation of state statutes or village ordinances
which prohibit parking at the location in question or for the period of time
for which the vehicle has been parked, and where either the statute or the
ordinance authorizes the vehicle to be towed and the signs posted at or near
the general location in question note that fact.
VEHICLE: A machine propelled by power other than human power designed to travel
along the ground by use of wheels, treads, runners or slides and transport
persons or property or pull machinery and shall include, without limitation,
automobile, truck trailer, motorcycle, tractor, buggy and wagon. "Vehicle"
includes trailers designed to be pulled by a propelled device. (Ord. 00-2156,
12-18-2000)
7-9-2: UNLAWFUL USE OR ABANDONMENT; NUISANCE DECLARED; REMOVAL AUTHORIZED:
   A.   Maintenance And Use Illegal: It shall be unlawful for any person to
allow or maintain an abandoned, inoperable, hazardous, or unlawful vehicle
within the village or to use or allow use of a vehicle in such a manner that
renders such vehicle an inoperable, hazardous or unlawful vehicle.
   B.   Declaration Of Public Nuisance: The village declares that abandoned,
inoperable, hazardous and unlawful vehicles are public nuisances subject to
abatement pursuant to the provisions of this chapter. The outside dead storage
of any vehicle listed in section
7-3-5 of this title are public nuisances subject to abatement pursuant to the
provisions of this chapter.
   C.   Abandonment: The abandonment of a motor vehicle or other vehicle or any
part thereof on any highway in the village is unlawful and subject to penalties
as set forth herein. The abandonment of a motor vehicle or other vehicle, or
any part thereof, on private or public property, other than a highway, in view
of the general public, anywhere in the village is unlawful. A motor vehicle or
other vehicle, or any part thereof, so abandoned may be cited for violation of
this chapter or authorized for removal by or upon the order of the police chief
as provided in this chapter.
      1.   Private Property: An abandoned or inoperable vehicle on the private
property of the owner or other person legally entitled to have possession of
the vehicle (except repair shops and vehicle dealers) is declared to be a
nuisance unless continuously housed in an enclosed building except when actual
repair work is being performed, and is subject to citation for violation of
this chapter and/or removal to abate the nuisance, by the procedures described
in this chapter. Unless the vehicle constitutes a health or safety hazard, the
village shall not authorize towing of any vehicle of an owner known to be out
of town continuously during the notice procedure outlined above. The provisions
of this chapter shall not apply to any motor vehicle that is kept within a
building when not in use, to any operable historic vehicles over twenty five
(25) years of age, or to a motor vehicle on the premises of a place or business
engaged in the wrecking or junking of motor vehicles.
      2.   Other Relief: The village may use any other available remedies,
ordinances or statutory procedures against the registered owner to abate the
nuisance. A complaint may be filed in the circuit court for violating the
provisions of this chapter, in lieu of or in addition to the provisions of this
chapter for citation or abating the nuisance by towing.
   D.   Prohibition Of Wrecked, Discarded Or Abandoned Vehicles: No person in
charge or control of any property other than village property within the
village, whether as owner, tenant, occupant, lessee, or otherwise, shall allow
any dismantled, nonoperating, wrecked, junked, discarded or abandoned vehicle
to remain on such property longer than seven (7) days or on village property
within or outside the corporate limits for a longer time than forty eight (48)
hours; except that this section shall not apply with regard to a vehicle in an
enclosed building; a vehicle on the premises of a business enterprise operated
in a lawful place and manner, when necessary to the lawful operation of such
business enterprise; or a vehicle in an appropriate storage place or depository
maintained in a lawful place and manner by the village. (Ord. 00-2156, 12-18-
2000)
7-9-3: AUTHORIZATION FOR VEHICLE TOWING, IMPOUNDMENT AND DISPOSAL:
The police department, and any other duly authorized agents or forces of the
village, are hereby authorized to tow, impound, and dispose of abandoned,
inoperable, hazardous and unlawful vehicles pursuant to the procedures set
forth in this chapter. A vehicle that is towed pursuant to this chapter shall
be impounded only at a facility approved by the police chief and shall be
impounded only until lawfully released or disposed of pursuant to the
provisions of this chapter and applicable state statutes. (Ord. 00-2156, 12-18-
2000)
7-9-4: TEMPORARY CUSTODY BY NONOWNER; REMOVAL BY TOWING SERVICE:
When an abandoned, lost, stolen or unclaimed motor vehicle or other vehicle
comes into the temporary possession or custody of a person in this state, not
the owner of the vehicle, such person shall immediately notify the police
department when the vehicle is within the corporate limits of the village. Upon
receipt of such notification, the police chief shall authorize a towing and
impoundment service operator to remove and take possession of the abandoned,
lost, stolen or unclaimed motor vehicle or other vehicle. The towing service
operator will safely keep the towed vehicle and its contents, maintain a record
of the tow until the vehicle is claimed by the owner or any other person
legally entitled to possession thereof, or until it is disposed of pursuant to
the provisions of this chapter and applicable state statutes. (Ord. 00-2156,
12-18-2000)
7-9-5: TOWING HAZARDOUS OR UNLAWFUL VEHICLES:
   A.   Notice; Procedures: Any hazardous or unlawful vehicle may be towed
without notice to its registered owner; however, notice and an opportunity for
a hearing on the appropriateness of the tow must be provided to the registered
owner of the vehicle within twenty four (24) hours of the tow in accordance
with section
7-9-7 of this chapter. (Ord. 00-2156, 12-18-2000)
7-9-6: TOWING ABANDONED OR INOPERABLE VEHICLES:
   A.   Pre-Tow Notice; Procedures: At least twenty one (21) days before the
village tows an abandoned or inoperable vehicle, the police chief, or his
designee, shall cause a written "Pre-Tow Notice" to be personally delivered to
the registered owner of the vehicle or shall mail the pre-tow notice by
certified or registered mail, return receipt requested, to the address of the
registered owner of the vehicle recorded with the Illinois secretary of state
or, if the vehicle bears a registration number of a state other than Illinois,
then to the address of the registered owner in that state's registry of motor
vehicles. The pre-tow notice shall provide the following information:
      1.   Requirement To Move And/Or Repair: A statement that, no later than
twenty one (21) days from the date of the pre-tow notice, the vehicle in
question must be moved from its improper location to a proper and lawful
location and/or repaired to a lawful condition.
      2.   Fine: A statement that if the vehicle is not moved and/or repaired
within the twenty one (21) day period, then the registered owner or other
responsible party shall be fined pursuant to section
7-9-13 of this chapter.
      3.   Tow: A statement that if the vehicle is not moved and/or repaired
within the twenty one (21) day period, then the vehicle may be towed and
impounded pursuant to this chapter without further notice.
      4.   Description Of Vehicle: A description of the make, model, year, and
color of the vehicle.
      5.   Registration And Plate Numbers: The vehicle's registration number,
and the number and state of the license plates displayed on the vehicle.
      6.   Location And Condition: The location and condition of the vehicle
that caused the village to determine that the vehicle is abandoned and/or
inoperable.
      7.   Owner Name And Address: The name and address of the registered owner
of the vehicle.
      8.   Summary Of Procedures: A summary of the procedures set forth in this
chapter relating to the towing and impoundment of abandoned and inoperable
vehicles, and the right of the registered owner to appeal.
   B.   Pre-Tow Sticker: On or before the day on which the police chief, or his
designee, personally delivers or mails the pre-tow notice pursuant to
subsection A of this section, the village shall affix a "Pre-Tow Sticker" in a
conspicuous place on the vehicle in question. The pre-tow sticker shall
prominently state the earliest date on which the village would be authorized to
tow the vehicle pursuant to this chapter and the address and telephone number
of the police department.
   C.   Pre-Tow Appeal: The registered owner of an abandoned or inoperable
vehicle may challenge the validity of a pre-tow notice by prosecuting a pre-tow
appeal pursuant to this subsection.
      1.   Initiation Of Appeal: To initiate a pre-tow appeal, the registered
owner of the vehicle in question shall deliver a written request for a pre-tow
appeal to the police chief prior to the expiration of the twenty one (21) day
period set forth in the pre-tow notice. The request for a pre-tow appeal shall
state whether a pre-tow hearing is requested and shall state the general nature
of the registered owner's defense.
      2.   Scheduling Of Hearing; Waiver: The police chief will schedule, in
consultation with the registered owner of the vehicle in question, a pre-towing
hearing within five (5) days, excluding weekends and holidays, of the police
chief receiving the request for a pre-tow appeal, or on such later day as is
mutually agreed by the parties. The registered owner shall be deemed to have
waived the right to a pre-tow appeal if the registered owner fails to appear
for the pre-tow hearing without prior notice of absence and good cause shown
therefor.
      3.   Status Of Vehicle Pending Hearing: Pending final disposition of a
pre-tow appeal, the vehicle in question shall not be towed, except pursuant to
the procedures of this chapter applicable to hazardous and unlawful vehicles.
      4.   Conduct Of Hearing; Burden: The police chief, in his discretion, may
conduct the pre-tow hearing or may appoint a hearing officer to conduct the
hearing. The enforcement officer responsible for the decision to tow the
vehicle in question shall not serve as hearing officer. The registered owner of
the vehicle must appear in person at the hearing. To invalidate the pre-tow
notice, the registered owner must submit evidence that conclusively
demonstrates that the vehicle is not an abandoned or inoperable vehicle and is
not otherwise subject to being towed pursuant to this chapter. The police chief
or hearing officer shall have the authority to require the presence of the
enforcement officer responsible for the proposed tow and any other village
personnel and to request the presence of other witnesses at the hearing.
      5.   Decision: Based on the hearing record, the police chief or hearing
officer shall issue a written decision: a) affirming the validity of the pre-
tow notice and confirming that the vehicle in question is an abandoned or
inoperable vehicle subject to towing pursuant to this chapter, or b) revoking
the pre-tow notice. The police chief or hearing officer shall deliver a copy of
the decision to the registered owner within forty eight (48) hours after the
conclusion of the pre-tow hearing. The decision of the police chief or hearing
officer on a pre-tow appeal shall be final.
      6.   Action If Affirmation: If the police chief or hearing officer
affirms the validity of a pre-tow notice and confirms that the vehicle in
question is inoperable or abandoned, then the police chief shall direct that
the vehicle be towed; provided, however, that the vehicle shall not be towed
if, within forty eight (48) hours after the police chief's or hearing officer's
decision, the registered owner or other responsible party causes the vehicle to
be moved from the improper location to a proper and lawful location and/or
causes the vehicle to be repaired to a lawful condition. If the vehicle is not
moved and/or repaired within said forty eight (48) hour period, then the
registered owner shall be fined pursuant to this section and the vehicle may be
towed immediately and without further notice. If the vehicle is towed pursuant
to this subsection, then the registered owner shall be liable for the towing
and impoundment fees.
      7.   Action If Revocation: If the police chief or hearing officer revokes
the pre-towing notice, then the police chief shall direct that the pre-tow
sticker be removed and that the vehicle not be towed. The registered owner may
display a copy of the police chief's or hearing officer's decision in the
vehicle. No vehicle about which such a decision has been rendered shall be
towed by the village unless the vehicle is otherwise subject to towing pursuant
to this chapter.
      8.   No Determination Of Violation: A pre-tow appeal and hearing shall
not be determinative of, and shall not be used or construed to adjudicate, any
other citation or violation of any village ordinance relative to the vehicle in
question.
      9.   No Appeal: If the registered owner of an abandoned or inoperable
vehicle does not initiate a pre-tow appeal pursuant to this section, then the
vehicle may be towed after the twenty one (21) day period expires without
further notice, the right to a pre-tow appeal shall be deemed to have been
waived, and the registered owner shall be subject to fine pursuant to section
7-9-13 of this chapter.
      10.   Right To Post-Tow Appeal: If a pre-tow appeal is not initiated
pursuant to this section, the registered owner of the towed vehicle shall
nevertheless have the right to a post-tow appeal pursuant to section
7-9-8 of this chapter.
   D.   Failure To Move Or Repair: Unless a pre-tow appeal is initiated
pursuant to this chapter, a vehicle subject to a pre- tow notice may be towed
by the village if it is not moved from its improper location to a proper and
lawful location or is not repaired to a lawful condition twenty one (21) days
after the police chief, or his designee, delivers or mails the pre-tow notice
in accordance with this chapter. The registered owner of a vehicle subject to a
pre-tow notice shall be fined a mandatory amount of two hundred dollars
($200.00) for each violation of this chapter, if the registered owner fails to
move the vehicle from its improper location to a proper and lawful location or
to repair the vehicle to a lawful condition within the twenty one (21) day
notice period set forth in the pre-tow notice, or, if a pre-tow appeal is
initiated, within forty eight (48) hours after the police chief or hearing
officer renders a decision affirming the validity of the pre-tow notice.
   E.   Records To Be Kept: When a vehicle is authorized to be towed under this
chapter, the police department shall keep and maintain a record of the vehicle
towed, listing the color, year of manufacture, manufacturer's trade name,
manufacturer's series name, body style, vehicle identification number, license
plate year and number, and registration sticker year and number displayed on
the vehicle. The record shall also include the date and hour of tow, location
towed from, location towed to, reason for towing, and the name of the officer
authorizing the tow. (Ord. 00-2156, 12-18-2000)
7-9-7: POST-TOW NOTICE:
   A.   Post-Tow Notice: Except in cases where the identity of the registered
owner cannot be ascertained, within twenty four (24) hours after towing any
hazardous or unlawful vehicle pursuant to this chapter, or within seven (7)
days after towing any abandoned or inoperable vehicle pursuant to this chapter,
the police chief shall cause personal delivery to the registered owner of the
vehicle in question of a post-tow notice or shall mail the post- tow notice by
certified or registered mail, return receipt requested, to the address of the
registered owner of the vehicle recorded with the Illinois secretary of state
or, if the vehicle bears a registration number of a state other than Illinois,
then to the address of the registered owner in that state's registry of motor
vehicles. The post-tow notice shall provide the following information:
      1.   Statement Of Towing: A statement that the vehicle has been towed
pursuant to this chapter.
      2.   Description Of Vehicle: A description of the make, model, year, and
color of the vehicle.
      3.   Registration And Plate Numbers: The vehicle's registration number,
and the number and state of the license plates displayed on the vehicle.
      4.   Location And Condition: The location and condition of the vehicle
that provided the village with authorization to tow the vehicle as an
abandoned, inoperable, hazardous, or unlawful vehicle pursuant to this chapter.
      5.   Owner Name And Address: The name and address of the registered owner
of the vehicle.
      6.   Summary Of Procedures: A summary of the procedures set forth in this
chapter relating to the towing and impoundment of vehicles, and the right of
the owner to appeal.
      7.   Release Of Vehicle: A statement that the registered owner must
secure release of the vehicle prior to appealing the tow.
   B.   Towing And Impoundment Facility Notice: Each towing and impoundment
service operator utilized by the village for purposes of towing and impounding
vehicles pursuant to this chapter shall display, in a prominent location, a
sign indicating the opportunity and procedures for appealing the validity of
the towing of any vehicle and related fines and fees. Such sign shall be placed
in a location readily visible to the public transacting business at such towing
or impoundment facility. (Ord. 00-2156, 12-18-2000)
7-9-8: POST-TOW APPEAL:
The registered owner of a towed vehicle may challenge the validity of any tow
and related fines and fees by prosecuting an appeal pursuant to this section.
   A.   Initiation Of Appeal: To initiate a post-tow appeal, the registered
owner of the towed vehicle shall deliver a written request for a "Post-Tow
Appeal" to the police chief no later than fifteen (15) days after: 1) the towed
vehicle has been released pursuant to section
7-9-9 of this chapter, or 2) the registered owner receives a post-tow notice
pursuant to section
7-9-7 of this chapter, whichever is earlier. The request for a post-tow appeal
shall state whether a post-tow hearing is requested and shall state the general
nature of the registered owner's defense.
   B.   Waiver: The registered owner of a towed vehicle shall be deemed to have
waived the right to a post-tow appeal if the registered owner fails to timely
initiate a post-tow appeal in accordance with the provisions of subsection A of
this section.
   C.   Post-Tow Hearing:
      1.   Scheduling Of Hearing; Waiver: The police chief shall schedule, in
consultation with the registered owner of the towed vehicle, a post-tow hearing
within five (5) days, excluding weekends and holidays, after the police chief
receives the request for a post-tow appeal pursuant to this section, or on such
later day as is mutually agreed by the parties. The registered owner shall be
deemed to have waived the right to a post-tow appeal if the registered owner
fails to appear for the post-tow hearing without prior notice of absence and
good cause shown therefor.
      2.   Conduct Of Hearing; Burden: The police chief may conduct the post-
tow hearing or may appoint a hearing officer to conduct the hearing. The
enforcement officer responsible for the decision to tow the vehicle shall not
serve as hearing officer. The hearing officer may be the same hearing officer
as presided over the pre- tow hearing regarding the same vehicle. The
registered owner of the vehicle must appear in person at the hearing. To
invalidate the tow, the registered owner must submit evidence that conclusively
demonstrates that the towing of the vehicle was not authorized pursuant to this
chapter or was otherwise invalid. The police chief or hearing officer shall
have the authority to require the presence of the enforcement officer who was
responsible for the tow and any other village personnel and to request the
presence of other witnesses at the hearing.
      3.   No Determination Of Violations: A post-tow appeal and hearing shall
not be determinative of, and shall not be used or construed to adjudicate, any
other citation or violation of any village ordinance relating to the vehicle in
question.
   D.   Decision On Post-Tow Appeal:
      1.   Decision: Based on the hearing record, the police chief or hearing
officer shall issue a written decision: a) affirming, in whole or in part, the
validity of the tow or any related fines and fees, or b) invalidating, in whole
or in part, the tow or any related fines and fees. The police chief shall
deliver or mail a copy of the police chief's or hearing officer's decision to
the registered owner of the vehicle in question within three (3) days after the
conclusion of the post-tow hearing. The decision of the police chief or hearing
officer on a post-tow appeal shall be final.
      2.   Action If Affirmation: If the police chief or hearing officer
affirms the validity of a tow of a vehicle that has been released pursuant to
section
7-9-9 of this chapter, then the village shall retain the amounts paid pursuant
to section
7-9-13 of this chapter. If the police chief or hearing officer affirms the
validity of the tow of a vehicle that has not been released pursuant to section
7-9-9 of this chapter, then the police chief shall include in the decision: a)
an explanation that the registered owner may secure the release of the towed
vehicle pursuant to section
7-9-9 of this chapter, and b) the total amount of fines and fees, accrued to
that date that must be paid prior to release of the vehicle in question.
      3.   Action If Invalidation: If the police chief or hearing officer
invalidates, in whole or in part the subject tow, then the village shall, in
the case of a previously released vehicle, return to the registered owner all
amounts received pursuant to section
7-9-9 of this chapter, or if the vehicle has not been released, authorize the
immediate release of the vehicle without towing and impoundment fees being
assessed against the registered owner. (Ord. 00-2156, 12-18-2000)
7-9-9: PROCEDURES FOR RELEASE OF TOWED VEHICLES:
   A.   Payment Of Expenses Of Towing And Impounding: The registered owner of
or person abandoning, parking or otherwise keeping a vehicle in violation of
the provisions of this chapter, which is towed and impounded under the
provisions of this chapter shall be responsible for those fees and expenses of
towing and impounding of the vehicle, which must be paid before the release of
the vehicle. The village hereby reserves the right to bring an action at law
against said violator, to collect fees or other charges assessed under this
chapter which are owed to the village. This fee shall be in addition to a fine
provided for herein for any violation of this chapter.
   B.   Requirements For Release: The registered owner of a vehicle towed
pursuant to this chapter may secure the release of the vehicle by furnishing
evidence of his or her identity and ownership or possessory right to the
vehicle, by signing a receipt for the vehicle, and by paying or causing to be
paid to the village and/or the towing and impoundment service operator the
following fine and fees:
      1.   Fine: The fine imposed pursuant to section
7-9-13 of this chapter.
      2.   Towing And Impoundment Fees: The towing and impoundment fees charged
by the towing and impoundment service operator.
   C.   Release Of Invalidation Of Tow: Notwithstanding any other provision of
this chapter to the contrary, the registered owner of a towed vehicle may
remove the vehicle without paying any fine or fee otherwise required to be paid
pursuant to this chapter if the police chief determines, on appeal or
otherwise, that the tow of the vehicle was not authorized pursuant to this
chapter or was otherwise invalid.
   D.   Taking Possession: The registered owner shall take possession of the
towed vehicle no later than twenty four (24) hours after satisfaction of the
requirements for release set forth above.
   E.   Hearing Request: After release of a towed vehicle pursuant to this
section, the registered owner of the vehicle in question may subsequently
appeal the tow and request a hearing pursuant to section
7-9-8 of this chapter. (Ord. 00-2156, 12-18-2000)
7-9-10: DISPOSITION OF TOWED OR IMPOUNDED VEHICLES:
   A.   Claiming Of Vehicles: Vehicles may be claimed any time before a vehicle
is sold at public sale or disposed of as provided in this section and
applicable state law. The registered owner, lienholder, or other person legally
entitled to its possession may reclaim the vehicle by presenting to the police
department proof of ownership or proof of the right to possession of the
vehicle and paying of any and all fees, charges and penalties assessed.
   B.   Disposition Of Unclaimed Vehicles:
      1.   Sale: When an abandoned, inoperable, lost, stolen, or unclaimed
vehicle seven (7) years of age or newer remains unclaimed by the registered
owner, lienholder, or other person legally entitled to its possession for a
period of thirty (30) days after notice has been given as provided in this
section, the vehicle shall be sold at public auction to a person licensed as a
used parts dealer, rebuilder, or scrap processor under 625 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/5-100 et seq.
      2.   Notice: A notice of the time and place of the sale shall be posted
in a conspicuous place for at least ten (10) days prior to the sale on the
premises where the vehicle has been impounded. At least ten (10) days prior to
the sale, notice of the time and place of the sale shall be provided by
certified mail, return receipt requested, to the registered owner, lienholder
or other person legally entitled to the possession of the vehicle. The notice
shall contain a complete description of the vehicle to be sold and what steps
must be taken by any legally entitled person to reclaim the vehicle. If the
vehicle has dealer plates, notice shall also be sent to the dealer.
      3.   Returned Mail: In those instances where the certified notification
of towing specified in this section has been returned by the postal authorities
to the sender, due to the addressee having moved or being unknown at the
address obtained from the registration records of this state, the sending of a
second certified notice will not be required.
   C.   Disposal Of Unclaimed Vehicles Without Notice:
      1.   When the identity of the registered owner, lienholder, or other
person legally entitled to the possession of an abandoned, lost, or unclaimed
vehicle of seven (7) years of age or newer cannot be determined by any means
provided for in this section, the vehicle may be sold as provided herein
without notice to any interested person whose identity cannot be determined.
      2.   When a vehicle of more than seven (7) years of age is impounded as
specified by this section, it will be kept in custody for a minimum of ten (10)
days for the purpose of determining the identity of the registered owner,
lienholder or other legally entitled persons and contacting such person by the
U.S. mail, public service, or in person for a determination of disposition, and
for the purpose of an examination of the state police stolen vehicle files for
theft and wanted information. At the expiration of the ten (10) day period
without the benefit of disposition information being received from the
registered owner or the lienholder, the police department may authorize the
disposal of the vehicle as junk or salvage.
      3.   A vehicle classified as an antique vehicle may, however, be sold to
a person desiring to restore it.
   D.   Report Of Transaction To Be Kept: When a vehicle taken into custody as
provided herein is reclaimed by the registered owner, lienholder, or other
legally entitled person, or when the vehicle is sold at public sale or
otherwise disposed of as provided in this section, the police department will
cause a report of the transaction to be maintained for a period of one year
from the date of the sale or disposal.
   E.   Proceeds To Be Deposited In Treasury: When a vehicle located within the
corporate limits of this village is towed away and disposed of as set forth in
this section, the proceeds of the public sale or disposition, after the
deduction of towing, storage, and processing charges, shall be deposited in the
treasury of the village. (Ord. 00-2156, 12-18-2000)
7-9-11: OBTAINING OWNERSHIP INFORMATION:
   A.   When the police department cannot learn the identity of the registered
owner, lienholder, or other person legally entitled to possession of a vehicle
from village records, they will cause the vehicle registration records of the
state of Illinois to be searched by the secretary of state for the purpose of
obtaining the required ownership information.
   B.   The police department will cause the stolen motor vehicle files of the
state police to be searched by a directed communication to the state police for
stolen or wanted information on the vehicle. When the state police files are
searched with negative results, the information contained in the national crime
information center files will be searched by the state police. The information
determined from these record searches will be returned to the police department
for that agency's use in sending a notification by certified mail to the
registered owner, lienholder, and other legally entitled person advising where
the vehicle is held, requesting a disposition be made and setting forth all
required information.
   C.   Notification to the registered owner, lienholder, or other person
legally entitled to ownership of the impounded vehicle shall be sent no later
than ten (10) days after the date the police department impounds or authorizes
the impoundment of a vehicle. However, if the police department is unable to
determine the identity of the registered owner, lienholder, or other person
legally entitled to ownership of the impounded vehicle within a ten (10) day
period after impoundment, the notification shall be sent no later than two (2)
days after the date the identity of the registered owner, lienholder, or other
person legally entitled to ownership of the impounded vehicle is determined.
   D.   When the registered owner, lienholder, or other person legally entitled
to the possession of a vehicle cannot be identified from the registration files
of this state or from the registration files of a foreign state, if applicable,
the police department shall notify the state police for the purpose of
identifying the vehicle owner or other person legally entitled to the
possession of the vehicle. The information obtained by the state police will be
immediately forwarded to the police department for notification purposes. (Ord.
00-2156, 12-18-2000)
7-9-12: EXEMPTION FROM CIVIL LIABILITY:
No police officer, towing service owner, operator or employee shall be held to
answer or be liable for damages in any action brought by the registered owner,
former registered owner, or his legal representative, or any other person
legally entitled to the possession of a motor vehicle or other vehicle when the
vehicle was processed and sold or disposed of pursuant to the provisions of
this chapter and applicable state statutes. (Ord. 00-2156, 12-18-2000)
7-9-13: PENALTIES:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed
guilty of a petty offense and upon conviction thereof shall be assessed a
mandatory fine of two hundred dollars ($200.00) and may be assessed such other
fines, fees or costs, as are authorized by this chapter, this code or state
law. Each day such violation is committed or permitted to continue shall
constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such hereunder. (Ord.
00-2156, 12-18-2000)
CHAPTER 10
SEIZURE AND IMPOUNDMENT OF MOTOR VEHICLES
SECTION:
7-10-1: Definitions
7-10-2: Public Nuisance Declared
7-10-3: Seizure And Impoundment
7-10-4: Posting A Bond
7-10-5: Preliminary Probable Cause Hearing
7-10-6: Plea Hearing/Evidentiary Hearing
7-10-7: Disposition Of Impounded Motor Vehicles
7-10-8: Applicability Of Other Laws
7-10-9: Use Of Fees Collected
7-10-10: Administrative Review
7-10-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, and the interpretation and enforcement
thereof, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have
the meanings given herein, unless the context in which they are used shall
indicate otherwise. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the
present tense include the future, words in the singular number include the
plural number, and words in the plural number include the singular number. The
words "shall" and "will" are mandatory and "may" is permissive. Words not
defined shall be given their common and ordinary meanings.
HEARING OFFICER: An attorney licensed in the State of Illinois for a minimum of
three (3) years, who is not an officer or employee of the Village, designated
by the Village Manager.
OWNER OF RECORD: The record titleholder to a motor vehicle as registered with
the Secretary of State of the State of Illinois, or any other applicable
governmental agency. (Ord. 16-2853, 11-28-2016)
7-10-2: PUBLIC NUISANCE DECLARED:
A motor vehicle, operated with the permission, express or implied, of the owner
of record, shall be declared a public nuisance and shall be subject to seizure
and impoundment under this chapter where such motor vehicle is used in the
commission of any of the violations set forth in this section or when the
commission of any of the violations set forth in this section makes impoundment
of the motor vehicle reasonably necessary as a community caretaking function so
that the motor vehicle does not jeopardize public safety and the efficient
movement of vehicular traffic. It shall not be necessary for criminal charges
to be filed, prosecuted, and/or proven in order to demonstrate that a vehicle
was subject to seizure and impoundment based on an officer having had probable
cause to believe one or more of the following violations was committed:
   A.   A violation of any of the below sections of the Illinois Vehicle Code,
as amended:
      1.   625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/6-101 (drivers must have licenses
or permits), except where the violation is for a license which has been expired
for twelve (12) months or less or for a license which is invalid because of
curfew (as in the case of a graduated license);
      2.   625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/6-303 (driving while driver's
license, permit or privilege to operate a motor vehicle is suspended or
revoked), except where said driver's license, permit or privilege to operate a
motor vehicle is suspended only for a violation of the emissions inspection
laws as set forth in 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/13C-1 et seq., or for an
unpaid citation (parking or moving);
      3.   625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-204(c) (fleeing or attempting to
elude a peace officer), provided it is the third or subsequent offense;
      4.   625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-401 (motor vehicle accidents
involving death or personal injuries);
      5.   625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-501 (driving under the influence
of alcohol, other drug or drugs, intoxicating compound or compounds or any
combination thereof);
      6.   625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-503(b-1) (reckless driving that
causes injury to child or crossing guard) and 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/
11-503(c-d) (aggravated reckless driving); or
      7.   625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-506(d)(1-2) (street racing),
provided it is a second or subsequent violation, or 625 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/11-506(d)(3) (aggravated street racing);
   B.   The stopping of a person against whom a warrant has been issued by a
Circuit Court for failing to appear to answer charges that the person was:
      1.   Operating a motor vehicle while that person's license was suspended
or revoked in violation of 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/6-303;
      2.   Operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol,
other drug or drugs, intoxicating compound or compounds or any combination
thereof in violation of 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-501; or
      3.   Operating a motor vehicle without having a valid driver's license or
permit in violation of 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/6-101;
   C.   Operation or use of a motor vehicle to commit, or in the attempt to
commit a violation of any of the below sections of the Criminal Code of 1961,
as amended:
      1.   720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-6 (indecent solicitation of a
child);
      2.   720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-14 (prostitution);
      3.   720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-14.1 (solicitation of a sexual
act);
      4.   720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-14.3 (promoting prostitution);
      5.   720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-14.4 (promoting juvenile
prostitution);
      6.   720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-18 (patronizing a prostitute);
      7.   720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-18.1 (patronizing a juvenile
prostitute);
      8.   720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/12-2 (aggravated assault);
      9.   720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/12-3.05 (aggravated battery);
      10.   720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/16-1 (theft);
      11.   720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/16-2 (theft of lost or mislaid
property);
      12.   720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/16-3 (theft of labor or services
or use of property);
      13.   720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/16-5 (theft from coin operated
machine);
      14.   720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/16-18 (tampering with
communication services; theft of communication services);
      15.   720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/16-25 (retail theft);
      16.   720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/18-1 (robbery);
      17.   720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/18-2 (armed robbery);
      18.   720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/19-1 (burglary);
      19.   720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/19-3 (residential burglary);
      20.   720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/20-1 (arson);
      21.   720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/20-1.1 (aggravated arson);
      22.   720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/20-2 (possession of explosives or
explosive or incendiary devices);
      23.   720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/21-1 (criminal damage to
property);
      24.   720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/24-1 (unlawful use of weapons);
      25.   720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/24-1.1 (unlawful use or possession
of weapons by felons);
      26.   720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/24-1.2 (aggravated discharge of a
firearm);
      27.   720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/24-1.2-5 (aggravated discharge of
a machine gun or firearm equipped with a device designed or used for silencing
the report of a firearm);
      28.   720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/24-1.5 (reckless discharge of a
firearm);
      29.   720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/24-1.6 (aggravated unlawful use of
a weapon);
      30.   720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/24-2.1 (unlawful use of firearm
projectiles);
      31.   720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/24-2.2 (manufacture, sale, or
transfer of bullets or shells represented to be armor piercing bullets,
dragon's breath shotgun shells, bolo shells, or flechette shells);
      32.   720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/24-3 (unlawful sale of firearms);
      33.   720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/24-3.1 (unlawful possession of
firearms and firearm ammunition);
      34.   720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/24-3.2 (unlawful discharge of
firearm projectiles);
      35.   720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/24-3.3 (unlawful sale or delivery
of firearms on the premises of any school);
      36.   720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/24-3.4 (unlawful sale or delivery
of firearms by liquor licensee);
      37.   720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/24-3.5 (unlawful purchase of a
firearm);
      38.   720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/24-3.6 (unlawful use of a firearm
in the shape of a wireless telephone);
      39.   720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/24-3A (gunrunning);
      40.   720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/24-3A-2 (armed violence);
      41.   720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/25-1 (mob action); or
      42.   The motor vehicle is otherwise subject to seizure and impoundment
pursuant to 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/36-1 (seizure);
   D.   Operation or use of a motor vehicle to:
      1.   Commit, or attempt to commit a violation of the Cannabis Control
Act, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 550/1 et seq.;
      2.   Commit, or attempt to commit a violation of the Illinois Controlled
Substances Act, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 570/100 et seq.; or
      3.   Solicit, possess, or attempt to solicit or possess cannabis or a
controlled substance, as defined by the Cannabis Control Act, 720 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 550/1 et seq.; or the Illinois Controlled Substances Act, 720
Illinois Compiled Statutes 570/100 et seq. (Ord. 16-2853, 11-28-2016)
7-10-3: SEIZURE AND IMPOUNDMENT:
   A.   Probable Cause; Removal: Whenever a police officer has probable cause
to believe that a motor vehicle is subject to seizure and impoundment pursuant
to this chapter, the police officer shall cause the motor vehicle to be removed
or towed to a facility authorized by the Village. When the motor vehicle is
removed or towed, the police officer shall notify, or make a reasonable attempt
to notify, any person identifying himself or herself as the owner of record or
lessee of the motor vehicle or any person who is found to be in control of the
motor vehicle at the time of the alleged violation(s), if there is such a
person, of the fact of the seizure, the motor vehicle owner of record or
lessee's right to request a preliminary hearing, and the right to a plea and
evidentiary hearing as provided in this chapter. The Village shall also provide
notice that the motor vehicle shall be impounded pending the completion of the
hearings provided for in this chapter, unless the owner of record or lessee of
the motor vehicle, or a lien holder of record of the motor vehicle, posts with
the Village a cash bond and pays all towing and storage fees, as set forth in
section
7-10-4 of this chapter.
   B.   Removal By Third Party: A police officer who has probable cause to
believe that a motor vehicle is subject to seizure and impoundment pursuant to
this chapter shall first ascertain whether the seizure and impoundment is
necessary and reasonable under the circumstances. If in the judgment of the
police officer then present, a person authorized by the owner of record, lessee
or the operator of the motor vehicle is present and capable to provide for the
lawful immediate removal of the motor vehicle, and said motor vehicle is not
required to be held as evidence in regard to the violation, the police officer
shall allow that individual to promptly remove the motor vehicle without it
being subject to seizure and impoundment if seizure and impoundment of the
motor vehicle is contemplated pursuant to section
7-10-2 of this chapter. (Ord. 16-2853, 11-28-2016)
7-10-4: POSTING A BOND:
If a bond in the amount of five hundred dollars ($500.00) is posted with the
Village, the impounded motor vehicle shall be released to the owner of record,
lessee or any lien holder, upon the payment by the owner of record, lessee or
any lien holder of the towing and storage costs to the applicable towing
company. If an administrative fee is imposed pursuant to section
7-10-6 of this chapter, the bond shall be applied to said fee; provided, in the
event that a violation of this chapter is not proven, the bond shall be
returned to the person posting the bond. All bond money posted pursuant to this
section shall be held by the Village until a Hearing Officer issues a decision,
or, if there is judicial review pursuant to section
7-10-10 of this chapter, until a reviewing court issues a final decision. (Ord.
16-2853, 11-28-2016)
7-10-5: PRELIMINARY PROBABLE CAUSE HEARING:
Where the owner of record or lessee of a motor vehicle seized under the
provisions of this chapter makes a request, in writing and filed with the
Director of Law Enforcement Services or the Director's designee, for a
preliminary probable cause hearing within twenty four (24) hours after the
seizure of the motor vehicle, the Director of Law Enforcement Services or the
Director's designee must conduct a preliminary probable cause hearing within
forty eight (48) hours after the request for a preliminary probable cause
hearing is received by the Village; provided that if the date for the
preliminary probable cause hearing falls on a Saturday, Sunday or legal
holiday, the preliminary probable cause hearing will be held on the next
business day following the Saturday, Sunday or legal holiday. For purposes of
this section, the following shall apply:
   A.   All interested persons shall be given a reasonable opportunity to be
heard at the preliminary probable cause hearing.
   B.   The formal rules of evidence shall not apply at the preliminary
probable cause hearing, and hearsay testimony shall be allowed, and shall be
admissible.
   C.   If, after the conclusion of the preliminary probable cause hearing, the
Director of Law Enforcement Services or the Director's designee determines that
there is probable cause to believe that the motor vehicle was used as provided
in section
7-10-2 of this chapter, the Director of Law Enforcement Services or the
Director's designee shall order the continued impoundment of the motor vehicle,
unless the owner of record or lessee of the motor vehicle posts a cash bond
with the Village in the amount of five hundred dollars ($500.00), and pays the
towing and storage costs to the applicable tow company, as set forth in section
7-10-4 of this chapter.
   D.   If the Director of Law Enforcement Services or the Director's designee
determines that there is not probable cause to believe that the motor vehicle
was used as provided in section
7-10-2 of this chapter, the motor vehicle shall be returned to the owner of
record or lessee of the motor vehicle without any fees or other costs, but the
owner of record or lessee shall be responsible to pay any towing or storage
charges to the applicable tow company. (Ord. 16-2853, 11-28-2016)
7-10-6: PLEA HEARING/EVIDENTIARY HEARING:
   A.   Notice Of Hearing: Within ten (10) days after a motor vehicle is
impounded pursuant to this chapter, the Village shall notify the owner of
record or lessee and any lien holder of the date, time and location of a plea
hearing that shall be conducted, pursuant to this section. Such notice shall be
by certified mail, return receipt requested, or first class mail, to the owner
of record, or lessee and any lien holders, as shown on the records of the
Illinois Secretary of State. Notice by mail need not be given when the owner of
record or lessee and any lien holder of the motor vehicle has been personally
served with notice, in written form, of the time, date and location of the plea
hearing.
   B.   Hearing; General: The plea hearing shall be conducted by a Hearing
Officer, designated by the Village Manager. The owner of record or lessee shall
appear at a plea hearing and enter a plea of guilty or not guilty. If a plea of
guilty is entered, or if the owner of record or lessee fails to appear, the
cause shall be disposed of at that time, with an order/default order in favor
of the Village, which order/default order shall require the payment to the
Village of a five hundred dollar ($500.00) administrative fee and towing and
storage costs to the applicable tow company, and the continued impoundment of
the motor vehicle until the five hundred dollar ($500.00) administrative fee
and towing and storage costs are paid to the Village and applicable towing
company, respectively. If the owner of record or lessee pleads not guilty, an
evidentiary hearing shall be scheduled and held no later than forty five (45)
days after the date of mailing of notice of the hearing, unless continued by
the Hearing Officer. All interested persons shall be given a reasonable
opportunity to be heard at the evidentiary hearing. At any time prior to the
evidentiary hearing date, the Hearing Officer may, at the request of either the
Village, the owner of record or lessee, direct witnesses to appear and give
testimony at the evidentiary hearing. The formal rules of evidence shall not
apply at the evidentiary hearing, and hearsay evidence shall be admissible.
   C.   Hearing; Entry Of Order; Posthearing: If, after the evidentiary
hearing, the Hearing Officer determines, by a preponderance of the evidence,
that the motor vehicle was used in connection with a violation set forth in
section
7-10-2 of this chapter, the Hearing Officer shall enter an order finding the
owner of record or lessee of the motor vehicle civilly liable to the Village
for an administrative fee in the amount of five hundred dollars ($500.00), and
require the motor vehicle to continue to be impounded until the administrative
fee is paid to the Village, plus applicable towing and storage costs to the
applicable tow company. The five hundred dollar ($500.00) administrative fee
shall be a debt due to the Village. If a cash bond has been posted pursuant to
section
7-10-4 or subsection
7-10-5C of this chapter, the bond shall be applied to the administrative fee.
If the owner of record or lessee fails to appear at the evidentiary hearing,
the Hearing Officer shall enter a default order in favor of the Village, which
order shall require the payment to the Village of the five hundred dollar
($500.00) administrative fee and towing and storage costs to the applicable tow
company, and the continued impoundment of the motor vehicle until the five
hundred dollar ($500.00) administrative fee and towing and storage costs are
paid to the Village and the applicable towing company, respectively. If the
Hearing Officer finds no such violation occurred, the Hearing Officer shall
order the immediate return of the owner of record or lessee's motor vehicle
without any fee or other costs, or, if a cash bond had previously been posted,
the cash bond shall be returned, but the owner of record or lessee shall be
responsible for any towing or storage charges to the applicable tow company.
All orders issued by the Hearing Officer under this chapter shall be in
writing.
   D.   Hearing; Burden Of Proof: At the evidentiary hearing, the violation
citation shall be prima facie evidence that the violation was committed as
provided in the citation, and the burden of proof shall be upon the owner of
record to prove that the violation was not committed.
   E.   Village Responsibility: If the Hearing Officer finds that the Village
exceeded its authority under this chapter in the seizure and impoundment of a
motor vehicle, the Village shall be liable to the registered owner or lessee of
the vehicle for the cost of storage fees and reasonable attorney's fees. (Ord.
16-2853, 11-28-2016)
7-10-7: DISPOSITION OF IMPOUNDED MOTOR VEHICLES:
   A.   If the administrative fee and other applicable fees are not paid within
thirty five (35) days after an administrative fee is imposed against an owner
of record who defaults by failing to appear at the hearings provided in section
7-10-6 of this chapter, or who admits guilt at the plea hearing, the motor
vehicle shall be deemed unclaimed and shall be disposed of in the manner
provided by law for the disposition of unclaimed motor vehicles pursuant to 625
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-100 et seq., as amended. In all other cases, if
the administrative fee and applicable towing and storage costs to the
applicable tow company are not paid within thirty five (35) days after a
written decision was issued, the motor vehicle shall be deemed unclaimed and
shall be disposed of in the manner provided by law for the disposition of
unclaimed motor vehicles pursuant to 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-100 et
seq., as amended.
   B.   Except as otherwise specifically provided by law, no owner of record,
lessee, lien holder or other person shall be legally entitled to take
possession of a motor vehicle impounded under this chapter until the
administrative fee and towing and storage costs to the applicable tow company
imposed pursuant to this chapter have been paid. However, whenever a person
with a lien of record against an impounded motor vehicle has commenced
foreclosure proceedings, possession of the motor vehicle shall be given to that
person if he or she agrees in writing to refund to the Village the amount of
the net proceeds of any foreclosure sale, less any amounts required to pay all
lien holders of record, not to exceed the administrative fee, plus the
applicable towing and storage costs.
   C.   Costs for towing and storage of a motor vehicle pursuant to this
chapter shall be those approved by the Village Manager to ensure uniformity of
charges and costs among all tow companies authorized to tow for the Department
of Law Enforcement Services. (Ord. 16-2853, 11-28-2016)
7-10-8: APPLICABILITY OF OTHER LAWS:
This chapter is in addition to and shall not replace or otherwise abrogate any
existing State or Federal laws or any ordinance that relates to the seizure or
impoundment of motor vehicles, and any fee provided for in this chapter shall
be in addition to any and all penalties that may be assessed or imposed by a
court for any criminal charges. This chapter shall not apply: a) if the motor
vehicle used in the violation was stolen at the time of the violation and
verifiable proof of the theft is provided to the Village; b) if the motor
vehicle is operated as a common carrier as defined by applicable law and the
violation occurs without the knowledge of the person in control of the motor
vehicle; or c) if the motor vehicle is subject to successful forfeiture
proceedings under 725 Illinois Compiled Statutes 150/1 et seq., as amended
("Drug Asset Forfeiture Procedure Act"); 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/36-
1 et seq., as amended ("seizure and forfeiture of vessels, vehicles and
aircraft"); or other State or Federal forfeiture laws. (Ord. 16-2853, 11-28-
2016)
7-10-9: USE OF FEES COLLECTED:
All fees collected by the Village pursuant to this chapter shall only be
deposited and used for Village traffic safety and enforcement expenditures and
for the expenses of the Village's Administrative Adjudication Program. (Ord.
16-2853, 11-28-2016)
7-10-10: ADMINISTRATIVE REVIEW:
Any owner of record, lessee, lien holder or other person with a legal interest
in the motor vehicle, shall have the right to appeal the decision of the
Hearing Officer to the Circuit Court for the Fifth Judicial Circuit, Cook
County, Illinois, pursuant to the Administrative Review Act, 735 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/3-101 et seq., as amended. Unless stayed by a court of
competent jurisdiction, any fine, penalty, or administrative fee imposed under
this chapter which remains unpaid in whole or in part after the expiration of
the deadline for seeking judicial review under the Administrative Review Act,
may be enforced in the same manner as a judgment entered by a court of
competent jurisdiction. (Ord. 16-2853, 11-28-2016)
TITLE 8
PUBLIC WAYS AND PROPERTY
CHAPTER 1
STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND PUBLIC WAYS
SECTION:
8-1-1: Supervision By Department Of Public Works
8-1-2: Village Datum
8-1-3: Grades Of Streets And Sidewalks
8-1-4: Names Of Streets
8-1-5: Numbering Buildings
8-1-6: Buildings Or Structures Located On Public Property
8-1-7: Buildings And Structures Encroaching On Public Ways
8-1-8: Street Obstructions
8-1-9: Excavations
8-1-10: Restricted And Prohibited Acts And Conditions
8-1-11: Block Parties
8-1-1: SUPERVISION BY DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC WORKS:
The Department of Public Works shall have charge and supervision of all
streets, alleys, highways, Village grounds, walks, crosswalks, parks and
buildings within and belonging to the Village and of the construction, care,
repair and maintenance thereof. (1997 Code)
8-1-2: VILLAGE DATUM:
The base or datum for the street and other levels of the Village is the level
of Lake Michigan as approximately determined by the Village surveys in 1886 and
is hereby established as the horizontal plane 95.35 feet below a rectangular
bench mark in the concrete at the base of the iron flagpole on the Village
green at Hillgrove Avenue near Lawn Avenue. Said bench mark is also 673.329
feet above mean sea level as determined by the United States Coast and Geodetic
Survey in July, 1947 (said elevation being the preliminary field determination,
subject to minor correction when adjusted or fitted to the national level net).
(1997 Code)
8-1-3: GRADES OF STREETS AND SIDEWALKS:
The grades of streets and sidewalks as shown upon the official maps of the
Village are hereby established as the grades of such streets and sidewalks.
(1997 Code)
8-1-4: NAMES OF STREETS:
The several streets and avenues in the Village shall be known and designated by
the names adopted by the several ordinances now in force and now respectively
assigned thereto on the House Number Map approved by the President and Board of
Trustees on July 11, 1927, and all amendments and revisions thereof, said Map
being on file in the Village Hall and being incorporated herein by reference.
(1997 Code)
8-1-5: NUMBERING BUILDINGS:
   A.   Building Numbering Required: All buildings situated or hereafter
erected or located on any lots fronting on any street or avenue within the
Village, except garages and other accessory buildings, shall be numbered in the
manner described herein and as may hereafter be provided by ordinance.
   B.   Method Of Numbering:
      1.   All buildings fronting on north and south streets or streets running
in a northerly or southerly direction shall be numbered consecutively from a
line running parallel with and located approximately six hundred feet (600')
north of the north section line of Section Six, Township Thirty-Eight North,
Range Twelve, East of the Third P.M. as a base line, beginning with the number
3800 at said line and increasing toward the south.
      2.   All lots or buildings located on east and west streets or streets
running in an easterly or westerly direction shall be numbered consecutively
from the west line of Gilbert Avenue (and its continuation as Willow Springs
Road) as a base line, beginning with the number 1 and increasing toward the
west.
      3.   The house numbers from their starting point shall commence with the
number 1 and run consecutively, the odd numbers being on the east and south and
the even numbers on the west and north sides of the respective streets or
avenues, as shown by the Map described in Section
8-1-4 of this Chapter.
   C.   Assignment Of Numbers: The Department of Code Enforcement shall assign
or cause to be assigned the proper house numbers to each lot or building and
shall at any time upon request inform the owner, agent or person in possession
of such premises what such number is.
   D.   Location And Size: Each of the figures of every house or building
number shall be not less than three inches (3") in height and so marked as to
be easily read. The numbers shall be placed in a conspicuous place on the side
or above the front door of the building to which the same are attached.
   E.   Adjustments To Numbers: The Department of Code Enforcement shall have
authority to adjust and reassign house numbers in order to avoid conflict or
correct mistakes.
   F.   Alteration Of Numbers Prohibited: Whenever any house or building shall
have been numbered or renumbered as provided in this Chapter, such number shall
not be altered without the consent of the Department of Code Enforcement.
   G.   Compliance With Numbering System: Any person being the owner, agent or
person in possession of any building now or hereafter erected in the Village
who shall, for thirty (30) days after demand by the Department of Code
Enforcement, neglect or refuse to number any such building owned or occupied by
