CHAPTER 8
PROPERTY MAINTENANCE CODE
SECTION:
9-8-1: Adoption Of Property Maintenance Code
9-8-2: Amendments To Code
9-8-1: ADOPTION OF PROPERTY MAINTENANCE CODE:
The village has adopted by ordinance and incorporated by reference into this
chapter as the property maintenance code of the village of Western Springs,
Cook County, Illinois, the code entitled the international property maintenance
code, 2006 edition, as published by the International Code Council (ICC),
except as amended in this chapter or by the publisher. Three (3) copies of the
international property maintenance code, 2006 edition, and all of its
regulations are on file in the office of the village clerk and are kept
available for public use, inspection and examination in accordance with 65
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-3-2. (Ord. 14-2767, 10-27-2014)
9-8-2: AMENDMENTS TO CODE:
The following sections of the international property maintenance code, 2006
edition, are amended as follows:
Section 101.1 (page 1, second line): Insert in parentheses (village of Western
Springs).
Section 106.4 Penalties: Any person who violates any of the provisions of this
chapter shall be subject to a fine of not more than seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00) for each violation for each day that the violation continues, and
each day that the violation continues shall be deemed a separate offense
subject to a separate penalty. Such a fine shall be in addition to any other
fee or charge authorized pursuant to the terms of this chapter.
Section 111 Right To Appeal is deleted.
Section 507 Storm Drainage, subsection 507.1 shall read as follows:
Drainage of roofs and paved areas, yards and courts, and other open areas on
the premises, shall not be discharged in a manner that creates a public
nuisance. Roof drains and sump pumps must be discharged to a grassy surface in
a manner that does not create a public nuisance. Roof drains and sump pump
discharges shall be located within five feet (5') of the building wall and may
not discharge directly onto adjoining properties.
Section 603.2 Heat Supply: Insert October 1st [date] to June 1st [date].
(Ord. 14-2767, 10-27-2014)
CHAPTER 9
UNSAFE BUILDINGS
SECTION:
9-9-1: Powers Of The Chief Building And Code Official
9-9-2: Notice Of Unsafe Structure
9-9-3: Repair Or Demolition
9-9-4: Improper Construction
9-9-5: Demolition By Department Of Fire And Inspectional Services
9-9-6: Destruction By Fire
9-9-7: Nuisance Declared
9-9-8: Stopping Improper Construction Or Wrecking
9-9-1: POWERS OF THE CHIEF BUILDING AND CODE OFFICIAL:
The Chief Building and Code Official shall have the responsibility to
administrate, regulate and offer opinions relating to the provisions of this
Chapter, subject to the conditions, modifications and limitations contained
herein. (Ord. 98-2064, 12-21-1998)
9-9-2: NOTICE OF UNSAFE STRUCTURE:
   A.   Notice To Owner: If the Department of Code Enforcement shall find in
the Village any building or structure or part thereof in such an unsafe
condition as to endanger life, health or property, but such that, by the
immediate application of precautionary measures, the danger may be averted, he
shall forthwith notify in writing the owner, agent, contractor or person in
possession, charge or control of such building or structure or part thereof to
adopt and put into effect such precautionary measures as may be necessary or
advisable in order to put such building or structure or part thereof in a safe
condition. Such notice shall state briefly the nature of the work required to
be done, and shall designate a time within which such work shall be completed,
this time to be fixed by the Department of Code Enforcement upon taking into
consideration the condition of such building or structure or part thereof and
the danger to life or property due to its unsafe condition. Such notice may be
served personally or by registered mail.
   B.   Posting Notice: If the Department of Code Enforcement shall be unable
to find the owner of such building, structure or part thereof, or any agent,
contractor or person in possession, charge or control thereof, upon whom such
notice may be served, he shall post the said notice upon such building, at or
near its principal entrance. (1978 Code § 5-7-2; amd. 1997 Code; Ord. 98-2064,
12-21-1998)
9-9-3: REPAIR OR DEMOLITION:
   A.   Repair Of Structure: If the owner, agent, contractor or person in
possession, charge or control of such building or structure or part thereof,
when notified as hereinabove provided, shall fail, neglect or refuse to put
such building, structure or part thereof, in a safe condition, and to adopt
such precautionary measures as shall have been specified by the Department of
Code Enforcement within the time specified in such notice, then, at the
expiration of such time, the Chief Building and Code Official may proceed
forthwith to do, or cause to be done, all work necessary to place such
building, structure or part thereof in a safe condition.
   B.   Demolition Of Structure: If the work of putting any building, structure
or part thereof in safe condition must be accomplished by the Chief Building
and Code Official and it shall appear that such building, structure or part
thereof is in such condition as not to warrant the expenditure thereon of a
sufficient sum of money to make such repairs or to do such work as is necessary
to put it in a safe condition, the Chief Building and Code Official shall have
authority to tear down or demolish such building or structure or part thereof,
and the expense thereof and the expense of making any repairs or doing any work
thereon shall be charged to the person owning or in possession, charge or
control of such building or structure or part thereof, and the Chief Building
and Code Official shall recover or cause to be recovered from such owner or
person in possession, charge or control, the cost to the Village of doing such
work. (1978 Code § 5-7-3; amd. 1997 Code; Ord. 98-2064, 12-21-1998)
9-9-4: IMPROPER CONSTRUCTION:
   A.   Notice To Owner: If it shall be found that any building or structure or
part thereof is being constructed or built in violation of any of the
provisions of this Code or of the building code, the Department of Code
Enforcement shall forthwith, in writing, notify the owner, agent, contractor,
superintendent or architect engaged in erecting such building, structure or
part thereof, of such fact, and shall specify briefly in such notice in what
manner such provisions have been violated, and shall require the person so
notified to forthwith make such building, structure or part thereof conform to
and comply with the provisions of this Code and of the building code,
specifying in such notice the time within which such work shall be done.
   B.   Demolition Of Structure: If, at the expiration of the time set forth in
such notice, the person so notified shall have refused, neglected or failed to
comply with the request made in such notice and to have such building or
structure, or part thereof, concerning which notice was sent, changed so as to
conform to and comply with the provisions of this Code and of the building
code, the Department of Code Enforcement shall proceed forthwith to tear down
or cause to be torn down such building or structure, or such part thereof as
has been erected and constructed in violation of any of said provisions, and
the cost of such work shall be charged to and recovered from the owner of such
building or structure or from the person for whom such building or structure is
being erected. (1978 Code § 5-7-4; amd. 1997 Code; Ord. 98-2064, 12-21-1998)
9-9-5: DEMOLITION BY DEPARTMENT OF FIRE AND INSPECTIONAL SERVICES:
The Department of Code Enforcement shall also have authority to direct the
Director of Fire and Inspectional Services, after written notice has been
served upon the owner, lessee, occupant, agent, contractor or person in
possession, charge or control thereof, to tear down any defective or dangerous
wall or any building or part thereof which may be constructed in violation of
the terms of this Code or of the building code. (1978 Code § 5-7-5; amd. 1997
Code; Ord. 98-2064, 12-21-1998)
9-9-6: DESTRUCTION BY FIRE:
In case of the destruction, or partial destruction, of any building by fire or
by the action of the elements, when any department of the Village government,
pursuant to the provisions of this Code, shall have incurred any expense on
behalf of the Village in an effort to preserve or to prevent the destruction of
any such building, or for the preservation of the life or health of its
occupants, the Department of Code Enforcement shall ascertain the amount of
such expenditure and present a claim therefor to the owner of such building or
his agent and shall collect the same from such owner or agent. No permit for
the reconstruction, alteration or repair of such buildings shall be issued
until such claim has been paid. (1978 Code § 5-7-6; amd. 1997 Code; Ord. 98-
2064, 12-21-1998)
9-9-7: NUISANCE DECLARED:
Any unsafe, dilapidated or abandoned building or other structure situated
within the limits of the Village is hereby declared to be a nuisance and
punishable as such, and each day that such building or other structure shall be
permitted to remain in such unsafe, dilapidated or abandoned condition shall
constitute a separate offense. (1978 Code § 5-7-7)
9-9-8: STOPPING IMPROPER CONSTRUCTION OR WRECKING:
The Chief Building and Code Official or his designee shall have full authority
and power to stop summarily the construction or the wrecking or tearing down of
any building, when the same is being done in a reckless or careless manner or
in violation of any provision of this Code, or in such manner as to endanger
life or property, and to order any and all persons engaged in said work to stop
and desist therefrom. (1978 Code § 5-7-8; amd. 1997 Code; Ord. 98-2064, 12-21-
1998)
CHAPTER 10
SIGNS
SECTION:
9-10-1: Purpose
9-10-2: Definitions
9-10-3: Applicability; Exceptions
9-10-4: General Construction; Maintenance
9-10-5: Standards For Illuminated Signs
9-10-6: Location
9-10-7: General Restrictions
9-10-8: Signs Prohibited In All Districts
9-10-9: Signs Permitted In Residential Districts
9-10-10: Signs Permitted In Commercial Districts
9-10-11: Attention Getting Devices And Banners In Commercial Districts
9-10-12: Standards For Wall Signs
9-10-13: Standards For Freestanding Signs
9-10-14: Standards For Window Signs
9-10-15: Standards For Suspended Signs
9-10-16: Standards For Canopy And Awning Signs
9-10-17: Uniform Sign Plans For Shopping Centers And Other Multi-Occupant Land
Uses
9-10-18: Administration And Enforcement Responsibilities
9-10-19: Permit Requirement And Procedure; Schedule Of Required Sign Permit
Fees
9-10-20: Nonconforming Signs
9-10-21: Variations
9-10-1: PURPOSE:
This chapter is adopted for the following purposes:
   A.   To preserve and protect the public health, safety and welfare by
regulating outdoor advertising and signs of all types.
   B.   To maintain the inherent right of business to communicate reasonably
and identify their products and services by promoting the reasonable, orderly
and effective display of signs and outdoor advertising.
   C.   To enhance the physical appearance of the village, making it a more
enjoyable and pleasing community. (Ord. 93-1856, 1-25-1993)
9-10-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and terms shall have the
meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section:
BUILDING FRONTAGE: The width of a building as measured along the outside wall
most parallel to the street which fronts the building. Where an establishment
occupies only part of the building, then the building frontage of that
establishment is the width of that portion of the building which is occupied by
the establishment.
COMMERCIAL DISTRICTS: The C1 village center commercial district, C2 community
shopping district, O limited office district, ORI office research and limited
industrial district and DT downtown transitional district as set out in the
development control ordinance.
ERECT: To build, construct, attach, hang, place, suspend or affix and shall
also include the painting of all signs.
MULTI-OCCUPANT LAND USE: Any combination of multi-family dwellings and/or
nonresidential establishment in one or more buildings under single ownership or
management with common parking facilities. This shall include, but not be
limited to, a shopping center, multi-tenant office building, apartment complex
or townhome development.
PERMITTEE: Any person to whom a permit has been issued pursuant to the
provisions of this chapter.
PERSON: Means and includes any individual, firm, partnership, association,
corporation, company or organization of any kind.
RESIDENTIAL DISTRICTS: The A single-family residence district, R1 single-family
residence district, R2 single-family residence district, R3 two-family
residence district, R4 multi-family residence district, RB residential buffer
district, SFA single-family attached residence district and R5 continuing care
retirement community residence district set out in the development control
ordinance.
SHOPPING CENTER: Any concentration of retail stores and service establishments
in one or more buildings under single ownership or management with common
parking facilities.
SIGN: Any object, device, display or structure or part thereof which is used
primarily to advertise, identify, display, direct or attract attention to an
object, person, institution, organization, business, project, service event or
location by any means including words, letters, figures, designs, symbols,
fixtures, colors, motion, illumination or projected images. The term "sign"
includes, but is not limited to, every projecting sign, wall sign, roof sign,
billboard, posterboard, freestanding sign, ground sign, window sign, vehicle
sign, awning, canopy, marquee, changeable copy sign, illuminated sign, flashing
sign, animated sign, temporary sign, portable sign or any other attention
getting device, or other display whether affixed to a building or separate from
any building.
Animated Sign: Any sign or part of a sign which changes physical position by
any movement or rotation, or any sign which presents the illusion of movement.
Attention Getting Device: Any pennant, flag, valance, banner, propeller,
spinner, streamer, searchlight, balloon and similar device or ornamentation
designed for purposes of promotion or advertising or attracting attention.
Awning, Marquee, Canopy Sign: Includes any fixed sign, as well as retractable
or removable marquee, canopy and awning, respectively, projected over,
suspended above or erected upon any public thoroughfare.
Awning Sign: A sign which appears on a rooflike shelter, either permanent,
retractable or removable, which is made of canvas or other material that is
affixed to a building or structure in order to provide protection from sun,
rain, snow and other elements.
Banner: A piece of fabric or flexible plastic which is suspended from or
attached to a building, pole or similar fixture and is designed or used for the
purpose of promoting, advertising or attracting attention.
Billboard Or Posterboard: A single or double faced sign permanently erected on
the premises, including changeable copy signs, used for the display of
information not associated with the establishment located on the same premises
as such sign.
Business Sign: A sign that directs attention to or advertises a business or
profession conducted upon or to a commodity, service or entertainment sold or
offered upon the zoning lot upon which such sign is erected.
Canopy Sign: A sign which appears on a rooflike shelter, either permanent,
retractable or removable, which is self-supporting and provides protection from
sun, rain, snow and other elements.
Changeable Copy Sign: A sign wherein provision is made for the manual change of
letters or characters in the field in or upon the surface area of the sign.
Construction Sign: A sign which is erected in association with construction or
remodeling work being conducted on the property and announces the name of and/
or other information about the architect, contractor or subcontractor who is
performing the work or about the project itself.
Directional Or Informational Sign: A sign which directs or guides persons to an
establishment or to facilities intended to serve the public, including
entrances, exits, parking areas, towing zones and full service and self-service
gasoline pumps.
Externally Illuminated Sign: A sign illuminated by a source of light which is
cast upon, or falls upon, the surface or face of the sign to illuminate by
reflection only.
Festoon Lighting: A group of two (2) or more incandescent light bulbs hung or
strung overhead, not on a building or structure, which are exposed to persons
on a public right of way, or which are not shaded or hooded to prevent the
direct rays of light from being visible from the property line.
Flashing Signs: Any directly or indirectly illuminated sign, either stationary
or animated, which exhibits changing natural or artificial light or color
effects by any means whatsoever.
Freestanding Sign Or Ground Sign: A sign which is completely or principally
self-supported by one or more posts or other supports which are not attached to
the principal building on the property and anchored in or upon the ground. This
shall include, but not be limited to, signs attached to poles or supports for
lights, canopies and other items or structures.
Garage Sale Sign: A sign which announces a garage sale or rummage sale
conducted by the owner or occupant of the property.
Identification Sign: Any sign which states the name of the business or
establishment, including either the national company or local proprietor and/or
the nature of the goods, services or other activities available at or conducted
in the business or establishment.
Internally Illuminated Sign: A sign, all or any part of the letters or design
of which is made of incandescent, neon or other types of lamps; a sign which
painted, flush or raised letters lighted by an electric lamp or lamps are
attached thereto; a sign having a border of incandescent or fluorescent lamps
thereto attached and reflecting light thereon; or a translucent sign, whether
lighted by electricity or other illuminant.
Nameplate: A sign which displays only the name and/or address of the occupant.
Nonconforming Sign: A sign, lawful at the time of the enactment of this
chapter, or at the time of the enactment of any amendment hereto which renders
the sign nonconforming, but which does not comply with all of the regulations
of this chapter or any amendment hereto.
Obsolete Sign: A sign which advertises a business which is not being presently
conducted upon the premises on which the sign is located.
Off Premises Sign: A sign which directs attention to or advertises a use,
business, commodity, service or activity not conducted, sold or offered upon
the premises where the sign is located. (This term also includes those signs
commonly known as business signs, billboards and poster panels.)
Personal Celebration Sign: A sign which announces or commemorates a special
event pertaining to a particular person or identifiable group of persons, such
as a birthday, graduation, anniversary or welcome home.
Political Sign: Any sign announcing candidates seeking political office and/or
any sign concerning political issues or other issues affecting government or
public policy.
Portable Sign: (This term also includes those signs commonly known as sandwich
signs.) Any sign that is not permanently affixed to a building structure or the
ground; a sign designed to be moved from place to place. These signs primarily
include, but are not limited to, signs attached to wood or metal frames
designed to be self-supporting and movable; paper, cardboard or canvas signs
wrapped around supporting poles. Also included are those signs, commonly
trailer mounted, which are designed to be moved from place to place.
Projecting Sign: A sign supported by a wall which projects more than twelve
inches (12") over any street, sidewalk, alley or public way or public easement
or which projects more than twelve inches (12") from the face of any building,
structure or supporting wall. Any sign suspended under a marquee and in a place
approximately perpendicular to the wall of the adjoining building shall not be
deemed to be a "projecting sign".
Real Estate Sign: A sign located for purposes of advertising a parcel of land
or a building as available for sale, rental or lease.
Roof Sign: A sign erected, constructed or maintained in whole or in part upon
or over the roof of a building or structure. Roof signs shall not include those
signs maintained upon the lower slope of a mansard roof which do not extend
above the uppermost point of the lower slope. Such signs shall be classified as
wall signs.
Sign Face: That part of the sign which is or can be used to identify,
advertise, to communicate information or for visual representation which
attracts the attention of the public for any purpose. This shall include any
background material, panel, trim, color and direct or self-illumination that
differentiates the sign from the building structure, backdrop surface or object
upon or against which it is placed. This shall not include any portion of the
support structure for the sign; provided, that no message, symbol or any of the
aforementioned sign face criteria is placed on or designed as part of the
support structure.
Sign Surface Area: The exposed surface of the sign enclosed by the perimeter of
the sign face. With respect to signs which are composed of a group of
individual symbols, letters, figures, illustrations, messages, forms or panels,
the sign surface area shall be the smallest contiguous rectangle which encloses
the whole group.
Suspended Sign: A sign which is suspended over a pedestrian walkway from the
marquee, overhang, soffit or similar feature of a building.
Temporary Sign: Any sign, banner, pennant, valance or other display constructed
of cloth, canvas, light fabric, cardboard, wallboard or other materials, with
or without a frame, and intended or designed for use for a limited period of
time.
Time And/Or Temperature Signs:
   A.   Time Signs: Devices which periodically display the time of day.
   B.   Temperature Signs: Devices which periodically display the current
temperature.
Traffic Sign: Any official traffic signs authorized by the Illinois Compiled
Statutes or the Illinois vehicle code.
Wall Sign: A sign which is mounted on, attached to, carved or integrated into,
or applied to the exterior wall of a building or structure, or to the lower
slope of a mansard roof.
Window Promotional Sign: Any sign painted on, affixed to or placed against any
window, or which is placed in a display case for view from the outdoors through
a window, for the specific purpose of attracting the attention of passersby to
a sale, special promotional item or other products or services, or for the
purpose of announcing a change in the status of the business, such as a grand
opening, change in management or going out of business. This shall include, but
not be limited to, signs stating the prices of merchandise or services, but
shall not include the display of merchandise in the window.
Window Sign: A sign which is painted on, affixed to or placed against any
window, or which is placed in a display case for view from the outdoors through
a window.
VILLAGE CENTER - C1: Those commercial districts adjacent to Hillgrove Avenue
between Central Avenue and Howard Avenue, and adjacent to Burlington Avenue
between Central Avenue and Johnson Avenue. (Ord. 93-1856, 1-25-1993; amd. 1997
Code; Ord. 12-2705, 12-17-2012)
9-10-3: APPLICABILITY; EXCEPTIONS:
The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to the following listed signs,
except that there are certain specific provisions contained in this chapter
that regulate certain signs listed below:
   A.   Signs not visible beyond the boundaries of the lot or parcel upon which
they are situated or from any public thoroughfare or right of way.
   B.   Official signs of any public or governmental agency.
   C.   Any sign of any official court or public office notices thereof, or any
flag, emblem or insignia of a government, school or religious group.
   D.   Any sign which is located completely within an enclosed building, and
which sign is not visible from outside of the building.
   E.   Tablets, grave markers, headstones, statuary/memorial plaques or
remembrances of persons or events that are noncommercial in nature and which
project no more than four inches (4") above the ground.
   F.   Any official traffic signs authorized by the Illinois Compiled Statutes
or the Illinois vehicle code.
   G.   Temporary signs celebrating the occasion of traditionally accepted
patriotic or religious holidays as well as national and state holidays.
   H.   Signs of a noncommercial nature and in the public interest erected by,
or on the order of, a public officer, including any temporary sign regarding
demolition, excavation or construction activities required by subsection
9-13-9B of this title.
   I.   Signs on a truck, bus, trailer or other vehicle used in the normal
course of a business which is not primarily the display of such signs.
   J.   Changing of the copy of a sign, bulletin board, display encasement,
marquee or maintenance where no structural changes are made, or changing of
interchangeable letters on signs designed for use of interchangeable letters.
   K.   Private (noncommercial) nameplate identification signs or street
address identification signs when such signs do not exceed two (2) square feet
in area.
   L.   Tablets, such as memorials, cornerstones, name of a building, date of
erection, when built into the walls of the building or affixed thereto.
   M.   Temporary signs, not including political signs, for events of a
general, villagewide, civic or public benefit nature as may be authorized by
the village board of trustees, which signs shall be removed within forty eight
(48) hours after the expiration of such event.
   N.   No trespassing signs, warning signs (e.g., "Beware Of Dog") and other
such signs regulating the use of property when such signs do not exceed two (2)
square feet in area.
   O.   Real estate signs advertising or directing persons to a "realtor open
house". Such signs may be placed on private property or within a public right
of way on the ground, subject to the following restrictions:
      1.   The realtor open house sign shall not exceed four (4) square feet in
area.
      2.   The realtor open house sign shall be a freestanding ground sign, not
attached to any utility pole or structure nor to any traffic control sign or
related pole, and shall be placed at least three feet (3') from the curb or
edge of the pavement.
      3.   Only one realtor open house sign shall be permitted within one
hundred fifty feet (150') of another sign which relates to the same address,
and only one realtor open house sign relating to the same address shall be
permitted in front of a single lot.
      4.   The realtor open house sign shall not interfere with traffic,
visibility or public safety, as determined by any village officer or employee
authorized to enforce any of the provisions of this code, and shall only be
displayed on Friday, Saturday and Sunday of the weekend that the realtor open
house will take place, and only between the hours of ten o'clock (10:00) A.M.
and five o'clock (5:00) P.M.
      5.   No attention or attracting devices shall be attached to any realtor
open house sign.
      6.   Each realtor open house sign must have attached to it an adhesive
label or other means to identify the name, address and telephone number of the
person responsible for the placement and removal of such sign.
      7.   If the sign does not comply with the above restrictions, a fine in
the amount of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) and not more than seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) shall be charged to the person whose name is on
the sign pursuant to the penalty provisions set forth in section
1-4-1 of this code. If no names are found on the sign, the owner(s) of the
property identified on the sign shall be assessed the fine.
   P.   Political signs which are placed on private personal property,
commercial property, or real property with the consent of the owner, do not
exceed a surface area of six (6) square feet per face and do not violate the
location restrictions of section
9-10-6 of this chapter.
(Ord. 07-2457, 8-27-2007; amd. Ord. 12-2705, 12-17-2012; Ord. 25-3253, 3-24-
2025)
9-10-4: GENERAL CONSTRUCTION; MAINTENANCE:
All signs shall be constructed and maintained as hereinafter described:
   A.   Building Code: All signs shall be constructed of approved materials and
shall comply with the requirements of the Western Springs building code and any
amendments thereto.
   B.   Electrical Code: All signs in which any electrical wiring and/or
connections are to be used shall comply with the village of Western Springs
electrical code and any amendments thereto. (Ord. 93-1856, 1-25-1993)
   C.   Development Control Ordinance: All signs shall comply with all
applicable requirements set forth in the village development control ordinance
and any amendments thereto. (Ord. 93-1856, 1-25-1993; amd. 1997 Code)
   D.   Metal Signs: A metal sign shall have its face or background constructed
of metal not thinner than no. 28 B and S gauge, which may cover a wood frame
and may be provided with letters, figures, characters, borders or moldings of
wood. The border, if of wood, shall not exceed three inches (3") in width.
   E.   Maintenance: The permittee for each sign shall paint and maintain all
parts and supports thereof as necessary to prevent rusting, rotting,
illegibility or other deterioration. All broken or missing parts shall be
promptly replaced. All seams between panels or other components of the sign
shall be maintained in a sealed condition.
   F.   Wind Pressure And Dead Load Requirements: All signs shall be designed
and constructed to withstand a wind pressure of thirty (30) pounds per square
foot and shall be constructed to receive dead loads as required in the village
building code and other applicable village ordinances and any amendments
thereto which the village may adopt from time to time.
   G.   Glass Limitations: Any glass forming a part of any sign shall be safety
glass.
   H.   Posting Of Permit Information For Electrical Signs: For any sign with
electrical components, the village may require the person erecting the sign to
post on the sign a certificate, permit or other label identifying the voltage
of any electrical apparatus used therein, the date the sign was erected and
other information relating to the issuance of a permit for the sign or village
inspection of the sign.
   I.   Legibility: All letters, characters, logos and symbols on each sign
shall be legible, with the edges of the letters and characters cleanly defined
and unfaded. (Ord. 93-1856, 1-25-1993)
9-10-5: STANDARDS FOR ILLUMINATED SIGNS:
All internally or externally illuminated signs shall meet the following
requirements:
   A.   Limits On Internal Illumination: No sign shall be internally
illuminated except for a sign having an opaque background and illuminating only
letters, trademarks or logos.
   B.   Limits On Degree Of Illumination: Signs shall be illuminated only by
steady, stationary, shielded light sources directed solely at the sign, or
internal to it, without creating a traffic hazard for motorists or pedestrians.
Illuminated signs shall not produce more than thirty (30) foot-candles of
illumination four feet (4') from the sign.
   C.   External Illumination: Whenever external illumination is used for a
sign, the source of light shall be located, shielded and directed in such a
manner that the light source is not visible from a public street or private
residence.
   D.   No Placement Inside Windows: Illuminated signs shall not hang or be
placed inside any window. (Ord. 93-1856, 1-25-1993)
9-10-6: LOCATION:
   Signs within the village shall be subject to the following requirements:
   A.   Locations Prohibited Generally: No sign shall be erected in a location
prohibited by this chapter. No sign shall be erected so as to prevent free
ingress to or egress from any door or window, or any other way required by the
building code of the village and amendments thereto or by the department of
community development regulations.
   B.   Utility Poles, Trees, Fire Escapes: No sign shall be attached to a
utility pole, a tree, a standpipe, gutter drain or fire escape, nor shall any
sign be erected so as to impair access to a roof.
   C.   Rights-Of-Way And Parkways: No sign, with the exception of political
signs on election day, shall be located, erected or maintained upon any right-
of-way or parkway for any purpose, except for traffic signs, informational or
temporary signs and official signs authorized by the Village or other public or
government agencies as provided for in subsections
9-10-9H,
9-10-3B, F, G, H, and M of this chapter, and realtor open house signs as
provided for in subsection
9-10-3O of this chapter. On election days, political signs are allowed on any
polling place property while the polls are open, and only beyond the one
hundred foot (100') radius of the polling room, whether publicly or privately
owned.
   D.   Interfering With Traffic Signs Or Signals: Any sign which from the
street is in direct line of vision of any traffic sign or signal is prohibited.
   E.   Creating Traffic Hazards: All signs which are declared to be a traffic
hazard by the Department of Law Enforcement Services shall be relocated or
rearranged in accordance with safety standards.
   F.   Violating State Law: No sign permitted under this chapter shall be
allowed or maintained if the sign shall in any way violate the Illinois Highway
Advertising Control Act of 1971, as amended.
   G.   Above Roofs: No sign shall be located so as to project above the top
edge of the roof or the top of the parapet, whichever forms the top line of the
building silhouette.
(Ord. 93-1856, 1-25-1993; amd. Ord. 98-2064, 12-21-1998; Ord. 13-2728, 9-9-
2013; Ord. 25-3253, 3-24-2025)
9-10-7: GENERAL RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   Allowed Information In Signs: No sign (excluding signs located wholly
within a building or signs erected in conformance with subsection B of this
section or subsection
9-10-9G of this chapter) shall be erected or maintained on any premises, except
to identify the building or to state the name or the person or entity occupying
the premises and the product or service offered. (Ord. 93-1856, 1-25-1993)
   B.   Political Signs: These signs shall not exceed a surface area of six (6)
square feet per sign face. These signs shall be placed only on private personal
property or within the boundaries of private real property. On election days,
political signs are allowed on any polling place property while the polls are
open, and only beyond the one hundred foot (100') radius of the polling room,
whether publicly or privately owned.
(Ord. 12-2705, 12-17-2012; amd. Ord. 25-3253, 3-24-2025)
9-10-8: SIGNS PROHIBITED IN ALL DISTRICTS:
Animated signs.
Attention getting devices (except as otherwise provided in section
9-10-11 of this chapter).
Billboards or posterboards.
Festoon lighting (except where installed by the Village of Western Springs or
approved by the Village Board as part of a temporary use permit as an outdoor
dining and/or outdoor liquor cafe).
Flashing signs.
Obsolete signs.
Off premises signs.
Portable signs.
Projecting signs.
Roof signs.
Signs in conflict with traffic signals.
Signs painted on the walls of buildings.
Signs which move or have moving parts, which movement is caused by the wind or
mechanically.
Time and temperature signs. (Ord. 17-2872, 2-27-2017)
9-10-9: SIGNS PERMITTED IN RESIDENTIAL DISTRICTS:
In all residential districts, only the following classes of signs are permitted
in accordance with the regulations set forth herein:
   A.   Exceptions: Signs listed as exceptions to this chapter in section
9-10-3 of this chapter shall be permitted in residential districts.
   B.   Nameplates And Identification Signs For Multiple-Family Dwellings:
These shall be permitted in R4 Residential Districts, subject to the following:
      1.   Area And Number: There shall not be more than one nameplate for each
dwelling unit indicating the name and address of each occupant. Furthermore,
one additional identification sign not exceeding six (6) square feet displaying
the name and address and/or management of the development shall be permitted
for each building complex or development.
      2.   Height: No sign shall project higher than seven feet (7') above
ground level at the base of the sign.
      3.   Location: No identification sign shall be located less than fifteen
feet (15') from the property line.
   C.   Real Estate Signs: These shall be permitted in residential districts,
subject to the following:
      1.   Area And Number: There shall be not more than one such sign for each
lot, parcel or tract. No sign shall exceed six (6) square feet in area. In
computing the area of a real estate sign, the structural supports adjacent to
and coterminous with the sign face, if any, shall be considered part of the
display and thus of the "sign surface area" as defined in section
9-10-2 of this chapter.
      2.   Height: No sign shall project higher than forty two inches (42")
above the ground level at the base of the sign.
      3.   Location: No sign shall be located closer than fifteen feet (15') to
any other lot, parcel or tract.
      4.   Removal: Signs shall not be allowed to be maintained for more than
fourteen (14) days after the sale or rental of the property.
   D.   Directional Or Informational Signs: These signs shall be permitted in
residential districts, subject to the following:
      1.   Area And Number: Signs designating parking area entrances or exits
are limited to one sign for each such exit or entrance and to a maximum size of
two (2) square feet each. In addition, one sign designating the existence per
parking area and limited to a maximum size of two (2) square feet shall be
permitted.
      2.   Height: No sign shall project higher than seven feet (7') above the
ground level at the base of the sign.
   E.   Institutional Identification Signs For Institutional And Other
Nonresidential Uses: These signs shall be permitted in residential districts,
subject to the following:
      1.   Area And Number: There shall be no more than one sign per lot,
parcel or tract. No sign shall exceed thirty (30) square feet in area per sign
face.
      2.   Height: No sign shall project higher than seven feet (7') above the
ground level at the base of the sign.
      3.   Location: No sign shall be located closer than fifteen feet (15') to
any other lot, parcel or tract.
   F.   Institutional Changeable Copy Signs: These signs shall be permitted in
residential districts, subject to the following:
      1.   Area And Number: There shall be no more than one sign per lot,
parcel or tract. No sign shall exceed thirty (30) square feet in area per sign
face.
      2.   Height: No sign shall project higher than seven feet (7') above the
ground level at the base of the sign.
      3.   Location: No sign shall be located closer than fifteen feet (15') to
any other lot, parcel or tract.
   G.   Temporary Signs: Only the following classes of temporary signs shall be
permitted in residential districts, subject to the regulations contained
herein:
      1.   No such sign, other than a personal celebration sign, shall exceed a
surface area of six (6) square feet per sign face and twelve (12) square feet
total;
      2.   No more than two (2) temporary signs shall be placed on the property
at any one time, and no more than one temporary sign of a particular type shall
be placed on the property at any one time;
      3.   No such sign shall be illuminated;
      4.   No such sign, other than a personal celebration sign, shall project
higher than forty two inches (42") above the ground level at the base of the
sign;
      5.   No such sign shall be located within five feet (5') of any other
lot, parcel or tract;
      6.   No such sign shall be located, erected or maintained upon any public
right of way;
      7.   (Rep. by Ord. 12-2705, 12-17-2012)
      8.   A temporary real estate sign shall be removed no later than fourteen
(14) days after a lease for the property has been signed by the new tenant or
after title to the property has been transferred to the new owner;
      9.   A temporary sign shall, for a garage sale or art/craft sale, in no
case be erected for a period longer than three (3) days, nor shall such signs
be erected on the same property for a total of more than three (3) days in any
thirty (30) day period; and
      10.   A temporary personal celebration sign shall in no case be erected
for a period longer than three (3) days, nor shall such signs be erected on the
same property for a total of more than three (3) days in any thirty (30) day
period.
      11.   In connection with the construction or remodeling of a building,
there shall be permitted one sign not exceeding six (6) square feet in area,
per sign face, including supports. Said sign shall be removed within one week
after completion of the structure indicated. Such signs shall not be
illuminated.
      12.   A political sign shall not exceed a surface area of six (6) square
feet per sign face. Political signs on residential property are not prohibited
during any period of time; however, political signs that fall into disrepair or
become a nuisance due to their condition must be removed, but may be replaced
with a sign in good condition.
   H.   Subdivision Identification Signage: These signs shall be permitted in
residential districts, subject to the following:
      1.   No such sign shall exceed thirty six (36) square feet of surface
area per sign face. Surface area shall include any supporting structures. Each
sign shall be restricted to two (2) faces.
      2.   Subdivision identification signs shall indicate only the name of the
subdivision and not include any other information.
      3.   No such sign shall be located in the public right of way, except
upon approval of an ordinance authorizing the location of the sign by majority
vote of the corporate authorities. The criteria that the corporate authorities
shall rely on in considering the approval of such sign shall consist of the
recommendation of the village engineer and submittal of evidence from the
applicant that allows the corporate authorities to make a finding that the
criteria set forth in subsection H4 of this section have been met.
      4.   Existing nonconforming subdivision identification signage may be
replaced even if located in a public right of way, provided that the following
criteria are met: it complies with all other sections of this chapter
concerning new signage; the location of the sign does not obstruct any driver
or pedestrian sightlines or create other view obstructions; the placement of
the sign, in whole or in part, within the public right of way is necessary
because it is not feasible to locate the sign, in whole or in part, on private
property; receives the recommendation of the village engineer; is limited to
one sign per subdivision entranceway and is approved by ordinance by a majority
vote of the corporate authorities.
      5.   The height of subdivision identification signs, including attachment
structures, shall not exceed five feet (5') above the curb level adjacent to
the sign.
      6.   Only one subdivision identification sign shall be located per
subdivision entranceway.
      7.   Subdivision identification signs shall be externally illuminated
only; provided, that such illumination corresponds to the regulations of this
chapter.
      8.   Subdivision identification signs shall be kept in a state of good
repair and appearance so as not to reflect negatively upon adjacent properties.
The village reserves the right to remove unsightly or unkempt signs wholly or
in part located in village rights of way.
      9.   Proposed plans for subdivision identification signs shall be
reviewed by the plan commission in conjunction with other aspects of proposed
subdivision construction for conformance with this chapter.
(Ord. 93-1856, 1-25-1993; amd. Ord. 13-2728, 9-9-2013; Ord. 25-3253, 3-24-2025)
9-10-10: SIGNS PERMITTED IN COMMERCIAL DISTRICTS:
In addition to those signs identified in section
9-10-3 of this chapter, only the following signs shall be allowed in commercial
districts, in accordance with the regulations set forth in this section and
elsewhere in this chapter:
   A.   Identification Signs: Identification signs.
   B.   Directional Or Informational Signs: Directional or informational signs;
provided, that:
      1.   No such sign shall have a surface area larger than two (2) square
feet per sign face.
   C.   Temporary Signs:
      1.   No political sign shall exceed a surface area of six (6) square feet
per sign face and twelve (12) square feet total;
      2.   No temporary real estate sign shall exceed a surface area of twelve
(12) square feet per sign face and twenty four (24) square feet total;
      3.   No more than two (2) temporary signs, not including political signs,
shall be placed on the property at any one time, and no more than one temporary
sign of a particular type shall be placed on the property at any one time;
      4.   No such sign shall be illuminated;
      5.   No such sign shall project higher than forty two inches (42") above
the ground level at the base of the sign;
      6.   No such sign shall be located closer than fifteen feet (15') to any
other lot, parcel or tract;
      7.   No such sign shall be located, erected or maintained upon any public
right of way;
      8.   A political sign on property used for commercial purposes shall be
erected no earlier than thirty (30) days before, and shall be removed no later
than three (3) days after, the election or other event to which it pertains.
The foregoing restriction does not apply to residential property; and
      9.   A temporary real estate sign shall be removed no later than fourteen
(14) days after a lease for the property has been signed by the new tenant or
after title to the property has been transferred to the new owner.
      10.   In connection with the construction or remodeling of a building,
there shall be permitted one sign not exceeding six (6) square feet in area per
sign face. Said sign shall be removed within one week after completion of the
structure indicated. Such signs shall not be illuminated.
   D.   Limits On Surface Areas Of Signs: The surface area of the signs on a
property in the C1 and C2 commercial districts shall not exceed the following:
      1.   The total aggregate area for all freestanding, wall, marquee and
window identification signs on any single parcel of property shall not exceed
two (2) times the linear building frontage of the principal display side of the
property, and no single wall or window sign shall exceed in any event an area
of one hundred (100) square feet.
      2.   A freestanding sign may not exceed a surface area of forty (40)
square feet per sign face or eighty (80) square feet total.
   E.   Limit On The Number Of Identification Signs For First Story
Establishments: For establishments which are located on the first story of a
building, or which are the sole occupants of a building, there shall be no more
than one identification sign for each street which the building, or that
portion of the building which is occupied by the establishment, faces. No more
than one such sign shall be erected on any one side of the building. In
addition, the establishment may have one awning sign or suspended sign on the
front of the establishment. Furthermore, where an establishment has a rear
entrance, an additional identification sign which also directs persons to the
rear entrance may be posted above or to the side of the rear entrance;
provided, that such sign does not exceed one square foot in surface area.
   F.   Limit On The Number Of Identification Signs For Upper Story
Establishments: Where the upper stories of a building are occupied by
establishments different than those on the first story, the following limits
apply (see diagram attached to ordinance 93-1856 on file in the office of the
village clerk):
      1.   If the upper story is occupied by only one establishment, then the
establishment may erect one identification sign for each street on which the
part of the building occupied by the establishment faces. Any such sign shall
be mounted on the exterior wall of the building, above the first story. No more
than one such sign shall be erected on any one side of the building. The
establishment may erect one additional identification sign on the first story;
provided, that such sign is located within four feet (4') of the first story
entrance to the establishment and does not exceed a total surface area of four
(4) square feet.
      2.   If the upper stories are occupied by more than one establishment,
then the owner or management of the building may erect one sign, identifying
the building but not the individual establishments therein, for each street on
which the building faces. Any such sign shall be mounted on the exterior wall
of the building, above the first story. No more than one such sign shall be
erected on any one side of the building. The owner or management of the
building may erect one additional sign on the first story, identifying any or
all of the occupants of the upper stories; provided, that such sign is located
within four feet (4') of the first-story entrance to those establishments and
does not exceed a total surface area of six (6) square feet.
   G.   Signs At Shopping Centers: In addition to the signs permitted under
this chapter for individual establishments within a shopping center, the
shopping center may erect one identification sign for the shopping center,
identifying the name of the shopping center but not any of the individual
establishments therein. A shopping center which occupies ten (10) acres or more
of land and which fronts on two (2) primary roads shall be allowed to have two
(2) such signs; provided, that each sign is located on and faces a different
road.
   H.   Signs At Automobile Service Stations: In addition to other signs
permitted under this chapter, automobile service stations may erect changeable
copy signs advertising the prices of different grades of gasoline or other
fuels; provided, that:
      1.   Such signs are permanently mounted either to the fuel pumps or to
the supports of a canopy covering the fuel pumps.
      2.   Such signs shall not be erected higher than twelve feet (12') above
the ground.
      3.   There shall be no more than four (4) sign faces per pump island.
      4.   The combined surface area of all such signs at each pump island does
not exceed twenty four (24) square feet.
      5.   Such signs shall not be internally illuminated except that gasoline
price signs that are a part of an existing freestanding sign may use internal
illumination to display prices. Such signs shall include only price
information. Messages or other displays are prohibited.
      6.   Two (2) directional signs indicating full- or self-service not
exceeding two (2) square feet in size are permitted per pump island.
(Ord. 93-1856, 1-25-1993; amd. 1997 Code; Ord. 12-2705, 12-17-2012; Ord. 13-
2728, 9-9-2013; Ord. 25-3253, 3-24-2025)
9-10-11: ATTENTION GETTING DEVICES AND BANNERS IN COMMERCIAL DISTRICTS:
   A.   Approval Required: Attention getting devices, banners and signs may be
erected on a temporary basis in commercial districts, in connection with a
grand opening or similar such business event or in connection with a community
or charitable event, but only upon approval by the department of code
enforcement.
   B.   Application For Approval: Applications for approval of such a permit
shall be submitted to the department of code enforcement and processed as a
sign permit.
   C.   Restrictions On Approval: The department of code enforcement shall
approve the proposed attention getting devices or banners only upon finding
that: (Ord. 93-1856, 1-25-1993; amd. 1997 Code)
      1.   The attention getting device or banner does not create such glare or
distraction that it endangers traffic safety and does not obstruct the view of
traffic signs and traffic signals;
      2.   The applicant will take adequate steps to minimize the visibility of
the attention getting device or banner from residential districts; and
      3.   The attention getting device or banner does not involve a
searchlight.
   D.   Display Time And Number Limited: In no case shall such attention
getting devices or banners be permitted to remain in place for longer than
seven (7) days nor more than on two (2) occasions per season per occupancy.
(Ord. 93-1856, 1-25-1993)
9-10-12: STANDARDS FOR WALL SIGNS:
All wall signs shall comply with the following limitations and requirements:
   A.   The sign shall extend no further than twelve inches (12") from the wall
to which it is attached.
   B.   The sign shall be attached to the wall so that the face of the sign is
substantially parallel to the wall.
   C.   The maximum vertical dimension of the sign shall be no greater than
four feet (4').
   D.   No message shall appear on that portion of the sign which extends the
sign from the wall, except for the electrical permit information that may be
required under subsection
9-10-4H of this chapter.
   E.   In commercial districts, the sign shall be no higher than the height of
the building or fifteen feet (15') above curb level, whichever is lower, and
the sign shall be no lower than five feet (5') above the curb level or, if the
sign projects further than three inches (3") from the wall, no lower than seven
feet six inches (7'6") above the curb level.
   F.   If mounted on the lower slope of a mansard roof, the sign shall project
no higher than the uppermost portion of the lower slope. (Ord. 93-1856, 1-25-
1993)
9-10-13: STANDARDS FOR FREESTANDING SIGNS:
All freestanding signs, except for temporary signs and nameplates for single-
family dwellings, shall comply with the following limitations and requirements:
   A.   A freestanding sign shall have no more than two (2) sign faces, with no
more than one sign face per side (or limited to a single sign).
   B.   There shall be no more than one such sign on the property; except, that
a shopping center which occupies ten (10) acres or more of land and which
fronts on two (2) primary roads shall be allowed to have one additional
freestanding identification sign.
   C.   The sign shall be located in the front yard.
   D.   The sign shall not be erected or project within five feet (5') of the
public right of way.
   E.   In commercial districts, the sign consisting of no more than two (2)
sign faces shall be principally supported by one or more posts or other
supports that extend seven feet (7') from grade to the base of the sign face.
   F.   In commercial districts, the sign including supports shall be no higher
than twelve feet (12') above the curb level. (Ord. 93-1856, 1-25-1993)
9-10-14: STANDARDS FOR WINDOW SIGNS:
The total area of all window signs on display at any one time, including window
promotional signs, shall not exceed forty percent (40%) of the total area of
the window in which they are located. A series of windows which are separated
by frames and supporting material less than six inches (6") in width shall be
considered as a single window for the purposes of this computation. (Ord. 93-
1856, 1-25-1993)
9-10-15: STANDARDS FOR SUSPENDED SIGNS:
All suspended signs shall comply with the following limitations and
requirements:
   A.   Suspended signs shall be permitted at shopping centers only;
   B.   The sign shall hang no less than eight feet six inches (8'6") above the
sidewalk;
   C.   The sign shall be located in front of the establishment it serves;
   D.   The sign shall not exceed a total surface area of six (6) square feet;
   E.   There shall be no more than one such sign per establishment fronting on
the marquee, overhang or other building feature from which the sign is
suspended; and
   F.   No information shall appear on the sign other than the name of the
establishment or the type of business conducted therein. (Ord. 93-1856, 1-25-
1993)
9-10-16: STANDARDS FOR CANOPY AND AWNING SIGNS:
All canopy and awning signs shall comply with the following limitations and
requirements:
   A.   The letters or characters of the sign shall appear only on the apron of
the canopy or awning; and
   B.   The letters or characters shall be no more than eight inches (8") from
top to bottom. (Ord. 93-1856, 1-25-1993)
9-10-17: UNIFORM SIGN PLANS FOR SHOPPING CENTERS AND OTHER MULTI-OCCUPANT LAND
USES:
   A.   Permit Required: No sign for a shopping center or other multi-occupant
land use shall be erected until and unless the village has reviewed and
approved a permit for a uniform sign plan for the entire development.
   B.   Application For Permit: Applications for approval of such a permit
shall be submitted to the department of code enforcement and processed in the
same manner as a sign permit, in accordance with section
9-10-19 of this chapter.
   C.   Restrictions On Issuance: The plan commission shall approve the uniform
sign plan only upon finding that: (Ord. 93-1856, 1-25-1993; amd. 1997 Code)
      1.   The sizes of signs and the materials used in the signs shall be
consistent throughout the property, or shall establish a hierarchy of different
types of signs, with the size and materials of the signs in each category being
consistent for all signs in that category;
      2.   The design of and materials used for the structural elements of the
signs shall be consistent with the design of and materials used for the
building or buildings which the signs serve;
      3.   The surface area of an individual wall sign shall not exceed two (2)
square feet for each one linear foot of building frontage occupied by the
establishment, or one hundred (100) square feet, whichever is less, and where
the establishment erects more than one wall sign, the cumulative surface area
of the wall signs shall not exceed two (2) square feet for each one linear foot
of building frontage occupied by the establishment, or one hundred (100) square
feet, whichever is less; and
      4.   The signs shall conform to all other requirements of this chapter.
(Ord. 93-1856, 1-25-1993)
9-10-18: ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT RESPONSIBILITIES:
It shall be the duty of the department of code enforcement to administer and
enforce the provisions of this chapter, in conjunction with the village
building code, village electrical code and the village development control
ordinance. In case of conflict in a particular instance between any provision
of this chapter and a provision of the building code or development control
ordinance, the more restrictive provision shall govern. (Ord. 93-1856, 1-25-
1993; amd. 1997 Code; Ord. 98-2064, 12-21-1998)
9-10-19: PERMIT REQUIREMENT AND PROCEDURE; SCHEDULE OF REQUIRED SIGN PERMIT
FEES:
   A.   Permit Required; Exceptions: No sign shall be erected, converted,
enlarged, reconstructed, structurally altered or rearranged unless the person
proposing such work has received a sign permit. No permit shall be required for
the following; provided, however, that the sign meets all requirements of this
chapter:
      1.   Signs listed in section
9-10-3 of this chapter as allowed in all districts; (Ord. 93-1856, 1-25-1993)
      2.   Political signs and temporary real estate, temporary personal
celebration and temporary garage sale signs allowed under sections
9-10-9 and
9-10-10 of this chapter; (Ord. 12-2705, 12-17-2012)
      3.   Window promotional signs; or
      4.   Maintaining a sign or changing the copy of a sign where no
structural changes are made. (Ord. 93-1856, 1-25-1993)
   B.   Permits For Temporary Signs: For temporary signage requiring a permit,
each permit will be approved and issued by the department of code enforcement;
provided, that such signage meets all requirements of this chapter. (Ord. 93-
1856, 1-25-1993; amd. Ord. 98-2064, 12-21-1998)
   C.   Preliminary Conference: (Rep. by Ord. 98-2064, 12-21-1998)
   D.   Application For Permit: The application for a sign permit shall be made
in writing, on a form furnished by the department of code enforcement, and
shall include the following information: (Ord. 93-1856, 1-25-1993; amd. Ord.
98-2064, 12-21-1998)
      1.   The name and address of the applicant and the sign contractor who
will be performing the proposed work.
      2.   The location, by street address, of the building or structure to
which the sign is to be attached or the lot on which the sign is to be erected.
      3.   One set of plans and specifications showing the method of
construction, location, support, attachment to the building or ground, method
of illumination and lighting intensity.
      4.   If not included in the plans required above, one sketch showing the
sign faces, exposed surfaces and proposed message, all accurately represented
in scale as to size, proportion and color, and showing, if the sign is to be
attached to a building, the sign on the facade of the building.
      5.   Written consent of the owners of the building or structure to which
the sign is to be attached and/or the land on which the sign is to be erected,
where the owners are not the applicants for the sign permit.
      6.   Any other pertinent data as may be required by the village building
code or permit application to provide for the enforcement of this chapter.
(Ord. 93-1856, 1-25-1993)
   E.   Term Of Permit; Fees: Permits shall be for the life of the sign, or any
shorter period as stated on the approved permit by the department of code
enforcement. However, any permit may be revoked at any time by the department
of code enforcement upon finding that the sign violates any provision of this
chapter or that the permittee made false representations in securing the sign
permit. No fee which the permittee paid for the permit shall be refunded when a
permit is revoked. (Ord. 93-1856, 1-25-1993; amd. 1997 Code)
